business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 1 December.

talk.start.para: —Order! The committee is considering opposition amendment No. 4 on sheet 2026, moved by Senator Forshaw. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

—At the time of the adjournment on Friday, we had just commenced considering opposition amendment No. 4. This amendment deals with the establishment of GM-free zones. It relates to the right of a state to accept or reject certain GMO dealings licensed by the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator on a marketing and/or an environmental basis. This is an issue that has been of some moment for a long time, particularly in relation to Tasmania. Tasmania, being an island state, has argued quite vigorously that it should have the right to declare some, if not the whole, of the state as a GM-free zone, particularly in relation to its reputation for providing world-class clean, green products. That is not to say that world-class clean, green products are not produced in other parts of Australia—they certainly are—but, given that Senator Calvert is sitting directly opposite me, I probably have to give a plug to Tasmania in this regard.

speech.para: As we are all aware, in recent times there have been some issues of significance with regard to the agriculture and fisheries industries in Tasmania. Those issues relate to the protection of their disease-free industries. That is another debate, one that we no doubt will have in due course when the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs References Committee undertakes its inquiry into the import risk assessment of New Zealand apples and pears. It is a different issue in that it is related to quarantine issues, but it is nevertheless integral to the state government ensuring that genetically modified organisms do not become a major problem for their industries in the future. The Tasmanian government and various industry groups have argued that Tasmania should be a GM-free zone.

This amendment is the result of a lot of hard work by the Labor Party to try to bring about a position whereby the rights of Tasmania and other states to declare GM-zones within their state's boundaries are recognised in this legislation. This was not something that the government wanted to accept at the outset but, through the good work of the Labor Party, we have managed to reach a position whereby this amendment recognises areas designated under state law as GM-free zones for marketing purposes.

We will come to amendment No. 16 in due course, but I will make mention of it now. Amendment No. 16 will allow a state, where it believes the regulator has not taken account of a state-specific environmental concern, to appeal such a decision to the Federal Court. We are therefore looking at promoting the rights of states to have GM-free zones in a marketing context—which is dealt with by the amendment currently before the chair—and also with respect to environmental issues, which we will come to when we get to amendment No. 16. With those remarks, I urge the Senate to support this amendment.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government is pleased to accept this amendment, which reflects the approach agreed by all states and territories and ensures that the ministerial council may issue policy principles recognising GM-free zones established under state legislation for marketing purposes. It is also important to note that the government has no problem with providing for GM-free zones under this legislation, where these are necessary to protect markets or for economic concerns. I note that the explanatory material issued in connection with the legislation some 12 months ago flagged that the legislation would deal with this, and it does. The ALP has moved an amendment which makes this explicit. The concentration on GM-free zones and the suggestion that there is some sort of problem is misleading in the extreme.

—I would like some explanation. We have just had the Labor Party turn down the right of local government to declare itself a GM-free zone. Labor blocked that, with the government. Now we have a Labor amendment which says:

quote.para: The Ministerial Council—

speech.para: That is the collective of states and the Commonwealth—

quote.para: may issue policy principles in relation to recognising areas, if any, designated under State law for the purpose of preserving the identity of one or both of the following:
(i) GM crops;
(ii) non-GM crops;
for marketing purposes.

speech.para: What about for health purposes? What about for environmental purposes? And what is this `may'? One might read into this that there is a veto by the ministerial council over any state. Senator Forshaw has indicated that that is not the case. Then why have it?

talk.start.para: —I said you might read that into it.
—Senator, you will get your opportunity to tell me whether I am right or wrong on this.
—We have been going seven minutes and you are verballing me again.

—Yes, exactly. The senator says that I am verballing him again. He is very bright this afternoon. What I am doing is asking the senator to explain why Labor has come up with such wish-wash on this matter. The amendment says that `the ministerial council may issue policy principles in relation to recognising areas, if any, designated under the state law.' Then we get to the interesting thing where we find that it is not just to meet the community concern about GM crops but also to meet the concerns, no doubt, of the Monsantos of the world that there can be areas designated under state law for their crops to be put in.

speech.para: The debate is about keeping areas GM free, but we have the Labor Party saying, `Maybe the debate should be about areas being specifically designated for GM crops.' That is a new one. Then there is a limitation at the end, where it says that the council can look at designating areas under state law for being GM or GM free for marketing purposes. The question I would like clarified is: why only for marketing purposes? And where is the corresponding Labor amendment to look at the other important concerns which people in the community have expressed and which are giving rise to such a big public debate?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —We are considering the Labor Party amendment, which the government is pleased to accept. With regard to the issues raised by Senator Brown, it is a matter of acknowledging that where a GM-free zone is required is very often because of market or economic concerns and issues. Senator Brown raised a couple of issues with regard to the matter of state responsibility, and I think I covered that the other day when we were pursuing the issue relating to local government. We said that these are certainly matters for involvement of the state government but certainly not for veto by local government.

speech.para: The issue of whether it is a health or an environmental concern would be first addressed by the regulator, who would not allow the release in the first instance. So the GM-free zones do become very much a matter of the market and economy, because of the level and the basis on which these things are considered. Health and environment are already covered by the regulator. If an environmental issue arises, the regulator will not approve it. This is certainly about marketability.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats, possibly like other members of the crossbenches, probably have little choice but to support this amendment. That is not to say that I do not endorse, on behalf of my party, the concerns outlined by Senator Brown. I acknowledge the point made by the parliamentary secretary that the regulator would have already made a judgment or an assessment in relation to health and environmental considerations. Whether or not the criteria by which those judgments are made are strong enough is another part of this debate. But certainly we believe that these zones, states, territories and—as we heard in the debate on Friday—local councils should have the right to take the regulator's judgment and then decide whether or not they are satisfied with the regulator's assessment of the health and environmental aspects. There may be areas that have determined that, regardless of the regulator's assessment, they do not want GM crops in their area, and that is the right we sought to give not only states and territories but also local government when we debated the relevant Greens amendment on Friday.

speech.para: Once again I remind the chamber of Senator Tambling's glowing defence, in fact promotion, of local government. I am paraphrasing Senator Ian Macdonald's view, Senator Tambling—through you, Madam Temporary Chair—that you recognised that local government was the closest form of government to the people and therefore the most democratic form of government. So I am sorry to hear your comments again today in terms of excluding local government from having a say.

In relation to marketability, the Democrats are on record as recognising that places—particularly those with a unique geographical advantage, such as the island of Tasmania—should be given the right to opt out. Yes, it does give them a niche in a market sense, not to mention the health and environmental advantages. We are on record in our committee report as acknowledging that an opt-out provision is the `most appropriate mechanism to ensure domestic and export market diversity while effectively containing the impact of gene technologies on the environment'. So at all times we were arguing for consumer choice, for market differentiation—for a niche, if you like—in the market. We know from surveys conducted that something like 70 per cent of Japanese customers polled, for example, said that they would happily import and buy GE or GM-free goods from a country like Australia. So there is no denying that there is a market advantage there. But we certainly couched our arguments in favour of an opt-out provision in the context of environmental and health safety. I have to agree with you, Senator Brown: it is extraordinary that the amendment that finally will get up is one that relates to marketing purposes specifically. I put on record our disappointment on behalf of the Democrats that this is not a stronger amendment, but I advise that we will be supporting it as at least an option in relation to this issue.

talk.start.para: — I would like to respond to a couple of points. Firstly, once again we have this issue of local government raised and, once again, it is said by various senators from both the Greens and the Democrats that we are about excluding local government. That is simply not true. As I said the other day, a proposition to have local government declare GM-free zones raises substantial constitutional issues, because it is the states that regulate local government. The fact of the matter is that if, you attempt to do that, (1) it is most likely beyond power and, (2) it will cause the states to walk away from the agreement for complementary legislation to regulate gene technology on the basis of having a national scheme. It is simply not possible to do it under the current arrangements. Local government will clearly have a say by working with their state governments to focus upon those areas where they would wish to have a GM-free zone within their local government area or covering their local government area. That is not outlawed by this legislation. Our amendment recognises that a state can declare a region or an area a GM-free zone, and that could include a local government area. But the fact of the matter is that this parliament cannot do what you want it to do with respect to local government having an automatic right on their own to do it. As I said, this is an agreement between the states and the Commonwealth, and it is the states that have the power to regulate local government.

speech.para: It is also the states that have the power to regulate agriculture, for instance. Anybody who understands anything about the way in which agriculture works in this country would know that you have areas of a state—for instance, in my home state of New South Wales—which are not necessarily relevant to a single local government area. For instance, they could be under pasture protection control boards which operate across a range of local government areas. But we cannot give a pasture protection control board—which is probably a more relevant benchmark to look at than even local government—authority to declare an area a GM-free zone under their jurisdiction within the state power because it particularly focuses on agriculture; it is ultimately regulated through the states, through the various departments of agriculture or parks and wildlife. With respect to the second issue about environmental considerations, I said at the outset that we would be moving a further amendment, No. 16, which will provide a mechanism for bringing about GM-free zones on the basis of environmental considerations.

talk.start.para: —I spent some time in the period between when we were last discussing this issue and this morning to try to find the link between the government's acceptance of Labor's amendment and the amendments that the government and the opposition voted down last Friday. I believe it pertains to two areas: one is the area in the bill in which Labor's proposed amendment will actually sit. It will sit in a section of the bill that gives the ministerial council the ability to issue policy principles. The Labor amendment states:

quote.para: recognising areas, if any, designated under State law for the purpose of preserving the identity of one or both of the following:
(i) GM crops;
(ii) non-GM crops

speech.para: By being situated in this section of the bill it will require the ministerial council to actually effect it. So if they do not go ahead and effect it, there is no problem with putting Labor's amendment in there. Conversely, the One Nation amendment proposed last week would sit within section 72 of the bill, which requires the regulator to notify specific people in relation to the issue—the proposed suspension, cancellation or variation of a dealing; in other words, a licence. That covers the different approaches that were being made by the two amendments. Labor's amendment will require the ministerial council to effect it; whereas, in actuality, One Nation's amendment would require the Gene Technology Regulator to notify not only the local councils but also the state.

There is another concern I have with this amendment, and I put this forward for the benefit of other senators in this chamber. I believe that this amendment, because of the way it is drafted, could actually work in the reverse—that is, it could be used as an advantage in protecting a GM area to the detriment of anyone in the surrounding areas. I believe there is a need for some scrutiny before we vote on this particular amendment. The amendment says that it recognises areas, if any, of a GM crop. If this amendment is passed—and it would appear that it is going to be because the government has indicated support for it—it will work to protect a GM area. I believe that that could be to the detriment of properties surrounding a property on which a genetically modified crop is grown. Where are the rights of those property owners who adjoin or are adjacent to a property on which a dealing is being carried out? Where are their rights if they wish to remain genetically modified free, particularly if they have similar crops? We have only to go back to the StarLink incident and the problems it has raised in the United States to be aware of the ramifications of a person claiming they have a GM-free product that can be contaminated by the cross flow of pollination of a genetically modified crop within that same area. That is the issue that really concerns me in relation to Labor's amendment. If this amendment is passed, it will, as much as anything, guarantee that a GM crop can go ahead irrespective of the objections of anyone in the immediate area—let alone any health or environmental issues—and that GM crop could take precedence over the rights of anyone in that area objecting to it. I have enormous concerns about the way the amendment is framed. I take nothing from the opposition's position of allowing for areas to remain non-GM free. I support that 100 per cent. But I most certainly have some concerns as to the wording of the amendment.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —Senator Harris has actually raised a related point—that is, that I am curious about the workability of this amendment. I put on record that I support the amendment, but I am curious about ensuring the protection of non-GM crops. I am wondering if we can gain some assurances from the government in the situation where you have both a GM site and a non-GM site and you have open trucks with GM crops and product coming past. As I say, I am all in favour of opt-out provisions and GE-free zones, but I just want to make sure that people who are into non-GM crops, food and trade will be given assurances that their non-GM foodstuffs or crops are going to be protected, especially where they may be next to a GM field and you have, for example, open trucks and possible contamination. I thank Senator Harris for putting StarLink on the record. Even though we got chastised last week for speaking about it, I think it is particularly relevant—certainly the Americans thought it was anyway.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate some of the issues raised by Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Harris, but I would ask them to come back to the fundamentals of the legislation and the fundamental role of the regulator. If Senator Harris still has any confusion about the actual functions and role of the regulator, I would be happy to make staff available to him to take him through the many other aspects of the legislation where he will find that the issues that he raised will quite rightly and properly be the functions and role of the regulator. The use of policy principles to achieve an opt-out is the preferred option for all states and territories. This is a very important issue when we are looking at this particular amendment as proposed by the Labor Party. With regard to the issues raised by Senator Stott Despoja, I advise that the states are not seeking the rights that she initially referenced. The states have confidence in the provisions of this bill and will also support the additional capacity to deal with marketability which will be provided through this amendment. In relation to Tasmania, which was mentioned earlier, the Tasmanian government supports the bill and this amendment as meeting that state's needs. So, in the interests of timing on this bill, on which I am keen to make progress today, I would ask that we give good consideration to the Labor Party amendment.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —First of all, I am aware of the things that Senator Tambling just mentioned in response to me. I am aware of the position of the states. I am aware of the position of Tasmania. I am aware of what has been negotiated in recent months. That is why I am not moving the amendments that we originally talked about as Democrats—that is, to ensure an opt-out provision—although, of course, the crossbenches have actually moved amendments along those lines which I support. So I understand all of that. I did not ask the parliamentary secretary for the patronising response he gave to Senator Harris's question; I asked about the workability of the amendment. I know what the regulator does. I have read the legislation. I understand the opt-out provisions and what has been negotiated. I want to know about the workability of the amendment that is before the chair and that was moved by the Labor Party and agreed to by the government.

—While the government representative gets time to answer Senator Stott Despoja's telling point there, I ask the mover of the amendment why it is limited to marketing and what the Labor Party has in mind for GM zones marketing. There is a specific provision here that GM zones should be marketed. So I ask what the Labor Party has in mind there. I remind the Labor Party that it turned down the amendments put forward earlier by the Greens and One Nation which would have given local government the facility to make its own mind up or at least not be excluded from that facility. The Labor Party did not support that. While Senator Tambling is being informed by his advisers, I draw his attention again to a document I brought before the Senate last week headed `Why GM foods are a key to successful organic farming and sustainable agriculture'. This attack on organic farming coming out of the University of Queensland's Botany Department was apparently endorsed by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority and the Office of Gene Technology. I asked the government to find out whether or not those two government authorities had, in effect, endorsed this amazing document from the University of Queensland. I will be pressing that as the day goes on, and I would be happy to have an answer from the government now that it has had the weekend to find out.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —In relation to the issue of workability raised by Senator Stott Despoja, while the states, the territories and the Commonwealth are confident of the sense of this amendment, all jurisdictions recognise there is work to do in implementing it. I am very confident that the collaborative approach that has resulted in this legislation and that seeks across the board support for the amendment will result in a very workable system. I appreciate there is still detail to be worked out, and I would be happy to keep the Australian Democrats across the issue and informed as this particular process develops.

speech.para: Senator Brown has previously referred to the issue that he also just raised with regard to a document that includes an article on GM and organic farming. On Friday afternoon he asked me to clarify that particular matter. The document also contains the ANZFA logo and ANZFA information sheets on the back page. I can confirm that, with regard to the article and the document generally, the Australia New Zealand Food Authority has absolutely no affiliation or connection now or in the past with the articles on GM food printed in that document. The information and opinions with respect to organic farming contained in the document are those of the authors. No contact with ANZFA has ever been made by the author or the institution involved with regard to the document or the article. While it is true that the ANZFA logo appears on the document, no permission was ever given by ANZFA to use the logo. ANZFA is currently taking steps to rectify the situation. Approaches are being made to demand an explanation from those responsible for the publication of the document as to why there has been unauthorised use of the ANZFA logo. ANZFA will be insisting on immediate cessation of this practice and the immediate removal of the logo or any unauthorised reference to ANZFA in relation to this publication.

talk.start.para: —Does that apply to the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee, whose logo appears to be placed right next to that of ANZFA? Does the action that the government is contemplating include legal action?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I will certainly refer that to GMAC. I would presume under the circumstances in which the ANZFA advice has been given to me—I have not checked specifically with respect to GMAC—that the same comments would apply.

—I asked the Labor Party what sort of advantage it saw in this clause allowing for genetically modified crops or areas where genetically modified crops are being planted to be marketed. What is the marketing edge that the Labor Party sees and that it wants to push through with this amendment?

—As I said in my opening remarks in support of the amendment, it was the Tasmanian government in particular which raised the issue of the need to protect its clean green image. The amendment we have moved was what ultimately was negotiated and agreed to by the states.

—No, it is not. I will not go on with this because I do not think Senator Forshaw can answer it. We are talking about his Labor colleagues in Tasmania, who probably do not understand what this clause means anyway. This clause is about recognising areas designated under state law for GM crops for marketing purposes.
—It covers both GM crops and non-GM crops.

—Yes, I can understand and everybody in here can understand why you would want to advertise yourself as GE free. I am asking what tortured logic and thinking is behind a Labor amendment which says that, on the other hand, people might want to advertise themselves as being `GE contaminated'—as being in places where GE crops are being grown. Can the Labor Party talk about anywhere in the world that has seen this as a marketing advantage?

—I wish to comment briefly on Senator Tambling's response to me and place on record that I do appreciate the briefings from his department—they have been helpful—but what is important is not the briefings that the minister can provide me with after the bill is passed but the actual structure of the bill. No matter how many briefings I receive from Senator Tambling's office after the bill is passed, it is not going to have any effect on the bill. This opposition amendment is going to have an effect on the bill. It will have an effect on the bill in a way that is quite curious, because the amendment proposes to protect the rights of two totally opposite positions. This is the point that I am trying to make in the chamber. How can the amendment preserve the right—and I put it in the positive tense—of somebody who wants to market himself as a producer of GM crops and, at the same time, protect the rights of someone in the same area who wants to stay GM free? I do not believe that this amendment can be workable.

speech.para: I ask a question of Senator Tambling relating to the workability of the bill in GM-free areas. In certain areas around Emerald where large cotton crops are grown, one has only to drive through the region to know when the cotton crop is being taken off. It is evident because both cotton by-product and cotton seed are strewn along the side of the road. I will be very interested in Senator Tambling's answer as to how the government is going to ensure that, if an area is established as GM free, the integrity of that GM-free status will not be voided by somebody transporting GM crops through it and spilling them on the side of the roadway. These are the issues where, as I believe Senator Tambling himself has said, there are lots of things to work out. I think we had better start working a few things out. As I said earlier regarding the advice and the offer of advice from his department, that will not help the people in a GM-free area who find a GM crop transported through it and have spillage of that crop in the area. Rather than pushing the bill through in such haste, we should be having a very detailed discussion on not only the bill but also the regulations. We should be looking at how the government intends, eventually, to be able to protect, as this amendment states, the rights of the area that wishes to market itself as producing GM crops as against the rights of the people who wish to stay non-GM, which is contained in the same amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Greens amendments (23), (24) and (25):

quote.para: (23) Clause 21, page 16 (lines 25 to 29), omit subclause (1) (but not the notes), substitute:
(1) The Ministerial Council may issue policy principles in relation to any issue concerning the development, use or release of GMOs or GM products.
(24) Clause 22, page 17 (line 26), at the end of subclause (1), add:
; (h) any other person that the Ministerial Council considers appropriate.
(25) Clause 22, page 17 (after line 29), at the end of the clause, add:
(3) Before issuing a policy principle, the Ministerial Council must publish a notice:
(a) in the Gazette; and
(b) in a newspaper circulating generally in each State; and
(c) on the Regulator's Internet website;

speech.para: containing details of the proposed policy principle and inviting submissions from the public.

quote.para: (4) A notice published under subsection (3) must include an address where submissions may be lodged and specify the closing date for submissions, which must not be earlier than 30 days after the date on which the notice was published.
(5) In finalising a policy principle, the Ministerial Council must consider all submissions received on or before the date contained in a notice under subsection (3).

speech.para: Clause 21 states that the ministerial council may issue policy principles. This is the council made up of state and territory ministers, along with the federal minister. The clause states:

quote.para: The Ministerial Council may issue policy principles in relation to the following:
(a) ethical issues relating to dealings with GMOs;
(b) matters relating to dealings with GMOs prescribed by the regulations ...

speech.para: Why limit it to that? The Greens amendment would swap that wording for:

quote.para: The Ministerial Council may issue policy principles in relation to any issue concerning the development, use or release of GMOs or GM products.

speech.para: Clause 22 would allow for policy principles to be developed in consultation with anyone, and there is a list of people to whom the council may go to get assistance and advice. It seems sensible—and I think the government might see the sense in this—that it should include any other person that the ministerial council considers appropriate. It may be an expert in the field who is not on the ethics committee or is not the regulator, et cetera, that the ministerial council wants to use for advice. That is a sensible and practical amendment.

Finally, the Greens are saying that, before issuing these policy principles that it has deliberated on, the ministerial council has to let the public in on this by both advertising what the policy principles proposed are and giving time for public feedback. That is very important. It means that the Australian public can be involved in the development of policy by this council as it goes along. It is a simple democratic move and I am sure the government and the Labor Party will support these amendments.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —These are fairly straightforward and sensible amendments in relation to the policy principles. As I have said a number of times, the Democrats believe that the only way that we will instil public faith in this new technology is to ensure that there is a level of public awareness and, more importantly, community education and empowerment. That is what these amendments seek to do—not only going through usual means but including the Internet web site as a means by which people can have input into the policy principle formulation process. I think the idea of feedback and community input in the form of submissions is highly commendable. The Democrats will be supporting the amendments.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government will not be agreeing to these amendments. These amendments propose to set out in even more detail the processes that the ministerial council must undertake before issuing a policy principle. The bill already provides that extensive consultation must be undertaken before a policy principle is issued by the ministerial council. It is entirely unnecessary for more detailed provisions to be included about how such consultation should be undertaken. This is, apparently, a matter for ministerial council to determine. However, Senator Brown can be assured that, consistent with the extensive consultation reflected throughout the bill, the ministers will advertise widely and call for comment from the public upon policy principles.

—I rise in support of the Greens amendments and relay to the chamber that the difficulty that I have with the bill as it stands printed is that it allows the ministerial council total consideration over all of the people involved, particularly in regard to the industry and the environment. The other group that is totally missing in section 22 of the bill is the consumers. The bill itself says that the policy principles will be developed in consultation with the Gene Technology Technical Advisory Committee, the regulator, the consultative group, the ethics committee, such Commonwealth and state agencies and such regulatory services as the ministerial council considers appropriate, such industry groups as the ministerial council considers appropriate, and such environmental consumer and other groups as the ministerial council considers appropriate. So if the ministerial council does not consider it appropriate to consult with you on policy principles, then you have no way of addressing the issues that you would like addressed.

speech.para: I believe that Senator Brown's amendment goes part of the way to ensuring that people are aware of the policy principle that is being developed, but it still concerns me that it is at the total discretion of the ministerial council as to whether any of the environmental, consumer or other groups are consulted.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not be supporting the amendments. I have heard the comments of the parliamentary secretary, and we agree with them. But we make a further point—which is that the policy principles have to ultimately relate back to the objects of the act. They relate to the regulation of GMOs under this act. Therefore, the proposals put forward by Senator Brown go well beyond the ambit of the legislation in that regard in going to other areas regulated elsewhere. We believe there is scope for very extensive consultation through the regulatory scheme that is included in the legislation.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Greens amendments (26), (27) and (28):

quote.para: (26) Clause 24, page 18 (line 23), at the end of subclause (2), add:
; (g) any other person that the Ministerial Council considers appropriate.
(27) Clause 24, page 18 (line 23), at the end of subclause (2), add:
; and in accordance with subsections (2A) and (2C).
(28) Clause 24, page 18 (after line 23), after subclause (2), insert:
(2A) Before finalising a code of practice for submission to the Ministerial Council, the Regulator must publish a notice:
(a) in the Gazette; and
(b) in a newspaper circulating generally in each State; and
(c) on the Regulator's Internet website;

speech.para: containing details of the proposed code of practice and inviting submissions from the public.

quote.para: (2B) A noticed published under subsection (2A) must include an address where submissions may be lodged and specify the closing date for submissions, which must not be earlier than 30 days after the date on which the notice was published.

(2C) In finalising a code of practice for submission to the Ministerial Council, the Regulator must consider all submissions received on or before the date contained in a notice under subsection (2B).

speech.para: These amendments apply the same improved rules of public consultation and transparency to the codes of practice as the previous amendments would have to the policy principles. I commend them to the house.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Again, the government will be opposing the Greens amendments on this occasion. These amendments are entirely unnecessary. They simply describe in more detail how the ministerial council must undertake consultation on codes of practice. This level of prescription and detail in the bill is unnecessary. The legislation already requires that the ministerial council undertake consultation with all of the committees under the legislation, Commonwealth and state agencies, industry groups and environmental, consumer and other groups. Furthermore, the codes of practice are then subject to parliamentary scrutiny as disallowable instruments. So once again, these amendments are unnecessary and the government opposes them.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —Again, the Democrats will be supporting these amendments for the same reasons I outlined earlier in relation to the policy principles. I take on board the minister's claim that they are unnecessarily prescriptive. I do not agree with that, certainly in regard to the first two amendments. Senator Harris mentioned in regard to the last set of amendments the phrase `any other person that the ministerial council considers appropriate'. I do not think that is particularly binding or prescriptive. Amendment (28) essentially allows for, again, the publication of a notice and the opportunity for the public to have input through a submission process basically containing details of the proposed code of practice and inviting submissions from the public. I still do not understand why this is unnecessarily prescriptive or why this is going to interfere with the process that has been agreed to with the states or the territories or the Commonwealth or what have you. In response to the last set of amendments, Senator Forshaw was talking about how the policy principles would have to be formulated in accordance with the objects of the act. I put on record again the fact that—
—We haven't debated them.

—Yes, we have still not debated the objects of the act. I understand that there were good reasons on Thursday and Friday. I am just wondering whether perhaps at some stage procedurally we will want to get back to those issues, because, as I mentioned a number of times in the debate on Friday, I think any discussion about amendments or the rest of the clauses in the bill should be within the context of what the objects of the bill are. That aside, I do not see that claiming that there is a prescription there that is too harsh is really an argument. I think it is a bit of a furphy and once again an attempt to ensure that there is minimal public involvement—not simply consultation but public involvement. I do not see the harm in it; it might actually see quite a few more Australians having some faith in the regulatory system, the regulator and the rules that we come up with.

—I rise to speak in support of the Greens amendments and I would just like to comment on Senator Tambling's comment about unnecessary detail. I believe any detail we can put in this legislation that will clarify the process definitely cannot be just brushed aside as unnecessary detail. I believe this bill, as well as setting out the duties of the Gene Technology Regulator, also has another very important function—that is, to facilitate making the public aware of what is happening in relation to genetically modified food. The amendments that the Greens have put forward would actually bring that process very, very clearly into the legislation.

speech.para: We have an obligation when drafting legislation to see that it has the clarity and also the detail that give everybody an understanding—not only the regulator and the industry, but also the general public—as to how they can have an input into the process. I believe the public having that input into it will also lift the level of public knowledge of the issues, because the more this process is discussed at the local area level, the more we lift the awareness of the public and the right of the public to actually have an input into and a say on what they are consuming. So, for clarity, I believe the details are necessary.

Senator Tambling also said that the ministerial council has to be in touch with and confer with all of the committees. But we find, as I mentioned earlier in relation to the policy principles, that the bill is drafted with the prhase `as the ministerial council considers appropriate', so there is no guarantee that these people will be consulted. Senator Tambling also raised the issue of disallowable instruments. The difficulty this place has is that there is no opportunity to have any input into regulations: you have the option of accepting them or moving a disallowance motion. In actuality the desirable situation would be to have the clarity in the bill, have the debate on the issues and put all the issues on the table so that, when the regulations came through, there would be far fewer regulations that would have disallowance motions moved against them. So, rather than the detail being unnecessary, I believe the detail is critical in relation to the bill. I support the amendments.
Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move amendments (11) and (12) on sheet 2030:

quote.para: (11) Clause 23, page 18 (after line 6), at the end of the clause, add:
(2) Before issuing a policy guideline, the Ministerial Council must be satisfied that the policy guideline was developed in accordance with section 23A.
(12) Page 18 (after line 6), after clause 23), insert:
(1) The guidelines are to be developed in consultation with the following:
(a) the Gene Technology Advisory Committee;
(b) the Regulator;
(c) the Consultative Group;
(d) the Ethics Committee.
(2) Consultation under subsection (1) must be in accordance with guidelines (if any) issued by the Ministerial Council for the purposes of this section.

speech.para: The purpose of amendment (11) is to place into the bill on page 18 a linkage for a new section 23A. This is in relation to the ministerial council issuing policy guidelines. The clause that One Nation is putting forward in amendment (12) is in relation to consultation on policy guidelines:

quote.para: (1) The guidelines are to be developed in consultation with the following:
(a) the Gene Technology Advisory Committee;
(b) the Regulator—

speech.para: Madam Temporary Chair, I seek guidance from you. This amendment refers to `the Consultative Group' and a previous amendment that has been passed and accepted has changed that to `Committee'. Do I need to seek leave to amend that amendment?

talk.start.para: (Senator Knowles)—Yes, you do, Senator Harris.
—I seek leave to amend amendment (12) to delete the reference to `Group' under (1)(c) and replace it with `Committee'.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —This goes to the issue that I have been raising all the way through—particularly in regard to Senator Brown's amendments, which have just been voted down—which is that we must have clarity and that the guidelines must be developed through consultation. These amendments remove the ability of the ministerial council to not consult. Subsection (2) in amendment 12 reads:

quote.para: Consultation under subsection (1) must be in accordance with guidelines (if any) issued by the Ministerial Council for the purposes of this section.

speech.para: This is to clarify the situation to the effect that the ministerial council is required to develop policy guidelines in consultation. It does not say that the ministerial council is bound by any suggestions of those committees. It leaves the ability of the ministerial council to determine what the outcomes will be, but it most certainly and very clearly binds the ministerial council to consult with those groups.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting these amendments, which seek to emulate the same consultation processes that exist for the policy principles. If, for some reason, the government will not be supporting these amendments, I would be happy to hear it elaborate on why.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government does not support the amendments moved by Pauline Hanson's One Nation. The point of the guidelines is for the ministerial council to discuss various things and, like the AHMC or other ministerial councils, to issue guidance to the Gene Technology Regulator. The guidelines could therefore be as brief as a couple of lines. The ministerial council could issue guidelines either following the six-monthly meetings or out of session. In the initial stages of the establishment of the regulatory system, we expect a reasonably high number of guidelines to be issued. These would be publicly available but, because of their nature, would not be the subject of consultation. The guidelines would be in the nature of communiques that come out of the health ministerial council. The government believes that consultation with committees and interested parties on policy guidelines is important. It would not, however, be practical to have a mandatory and detailed consultation process written into the bill. This is because ministers must be able to react quickly and provide guidelines to the regulator. ALP senators and other senators can be assured that all policy guidelines issued by the ministerial council will be publicly released. Given this, the government believes it is inappropriate to require consultation before the ministerial council issues guidelines—as opposed to policy principles, which will be subject to extensive consultation as already provided for under the bill. The government opposes these amendments.
—Generally speaking, for the reasons that the government opposes the amendments, I support them.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Australian Greens amendments (1) to (5), (7) and (8):

quote.para: (1) Clause 31, page 22 (line 12), omit paragraph (c).
(2) Clause 32, page 23 (lines 12 to 14), omit paragraph (d).
(3) Clause 32, page 23 (line 25) to page 24 (line 2), omit subsections (3) and (4).
(4) Clause 33, page 24 (line 10), omit paragraph (d).
(5) Clause 33, page 24 (lines 21 and 22), omit subclause (4).
(7) Clause 142, page 88 (line 27), omit "or 141".
(8) Clause 143, page 89 (lines 28 to 32), omit subclause (3).

speech.para: I indicate that clause 141 will be opposed in the following terms:

quote.para: (6) Clause 141, page 88 (lines 16 to 23), TO BE OPPOSED.

speech.para: I ask the government: what is an exempt dealing?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that an exempt dealing is something that is exempt from the provisions of the act.

—He has been reading Alice in Wonderland again! I am not going to accept that. In answer to an important question like this—because exempt dealings are at the heart of public concern in this matter—I expect a definition and some examples from the government. It appears that an exempt dealing is any matter relating to genetically modified organisms that the regulator wants to call exempt—in other words, that are exempt from the provisions of the legislation. That is pretty important stuff, and I expect the minister to give a pretty detailed account of exactly what is meant by the government—which drew up the legislation—by `exempt dealing'. If you look at the definitions at the front of the bill, there is no definition of `exempt dealing'—let us have one.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the issue raised by Senator Brown has been comprehensively addressed since last August. The draft regulations have been widely distributed and available. In fact, the government made it very much a part of the consultation process that those regulations were distributed well in advance of any debate on this legislation. Those issues have been addressed fully in the regulations. I refer to pages 22 and 23 of the draft document `Gene Technology Regulations 2000', issued in August 2000. I do not think Senator Brown would want me to read it, but there is a description of dealings and there are five major subsections that deal with that area.
—I would like the minister to explain what he means by `exempt dealings' and why there is no definition in the bill.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Let me give Senator Brown a concise definition that has been available to him since August of last year under the explanatory guide to the regulations. At page 39 of that document it reads:

quote.para: The exemptions described in Part 1 of Schedule 1 have been based on the current exemptions described in the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee guidelines for small-scale genetic manipulation work. The GMAC exemptions have been developed over the past 25 years based on the experience of assessing applications in Australia. The exemptions apply to a very limited number of dealings with GMOs that have been assessed over time as presenting no significant biosafety risks to public health and safety, including occupational health and safety or the environment, and are undertaken within contained facilities, that is, they do not involve intentional release of a GMO into the environment.

speech.para: And, as I said, at pages 22 and 23 of the draft regulations the full descriptions are set out in over a page and a half.

talk.start.para: —What page were you reading from, Senator?

—The draft Gene Technology Regulations of August 2000 is the document that has been distributed since August of last year, and the explanatory guide to the draft Gene Technology Regulations was issued at the same time. It is in those two documents.
—I ask Senator Tambling whether he could give us an example of a GMO exempt dealing.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised to inform the senator of item 3 specifically from the regulations, which reads `any dealing involving the introduction of genetically modified somatic cells into an animal, unless the cells are capable of giving rise to infectious agents'.
—Could the minister give an example of where that sort of dealing is occurring in Australia which would be exempt?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised it is low-risk laboratory work done in contained situations.

—Let us get out of the circle of non-specificity here. Could I please have an example put to the committee of an exempt dealing that is occurring in Australia or has occurred? A specific piece of experimentation will do—any one of these pieces of experimentation that is occurring in a laboratory that is safe and is not intended to be released. I think this is pretty important and I think Senator Tambling ought to be able to give a very clear example of what an exempt dealing is. Apparently there are exempt dealings occurring in Australia and they are going to continue to occur, so if he could just give us the details of one of them—where it is occurring, who is doing it and what the experimentation is aimed to achieve—that would help the committee.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —As Senator Brown would know, all this documentation was made comprehensively available to the Senate committee that undertook the work in this area. Furthermore, we have actively invited people to tell us which activities should be removed from the current exempt list, and we will continue to consult on the exempt list over the coming months. If there are scientific reasons for taking something off the exempt list, that will be accommodated.

—He cannot. I am not going to delay the committee, but we have got this extraordinary situation where the government cannot give an example of what is going on. If you want to explain a very important part of legislation, you give an example of how that legislation would be used. What the government representative has said is that there are exempt dealings that have been listed already, but he cannot give an example of one; he can only use general terms. He cannot say whether it is happening at the University of Tasmania, at the TAFE college in Darwin or in somebody's laboratory somewhere. I would have expected that he could do that so that we could get a clear bead on what the government sees or what the authorities have previously seen as an exempt dealing. I think it is wholly unsatisfactory that the government cannot come up with a list of these and give some specific examples here and now. We should not be dealing with generalities. Genetic manipulation and scientific experimentation are major features of the day. They are occurring all around the world. We do not have to be dealing with concepts here; we are dealing with reality. We should be able to get an example or two of what is occurring now behind closed doors in laboratories in Australia, and waving the regulations about, proposed or otherwise, is not good enough.

speech.para: I ask the parliamentary secretary if he could please enlighten the committee. If he cannot, then he should say so, and we can move into a further debate about the Greens amendments, which will remove this provision for exempt dealings. There should be a very clear understanding, I believe, that this legislation should make all dealings subject to a decision rather than an exemption and should put conditions on those dealings. We are concerned that influence will be brought to bear on the regulator down the line by corporate interests, for example, to exempt a matter that they want to experiment with or to have trial plantings of. We need to know exactly what the government has in mind if there is not going to be a great deal of legitimate concern that this exemption clause will be used to get around the provisions of the bill which meet the concerns of the Australian public about genetic experimentation in the wider sense of the term.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I have asked the attendants to pass to Senator Brown some very detailed and scientific language from the draft documentation issued last August which has been available to the senator since that time. I refer him to what was listed on pages 23 and 24 relating to bacteria, fungi, slime moulds and tissue culture. I could read all of these particular issues out, but they are in themselves very scientific and specific. We have invited information from the wider community on these issues. If any of these issues need to be removed, the consultation process would be available to accommodate that. That has been the purpose of having this documentation distributed and widely available since last August. I hope that Senator Brown finds pages 23 and 24 of some help.

—Senator Tambling made the comment that exempt dealings would be carried out in a confined environment. Could Senator Tambling clarify what level of containment would be used in those laboratories, whether schedule 1, 2 or 3, or could we see an exempt dealing being carried out in a schedule 4 laboratory? That would assist the committee in understanding the type of work that could be carried out as an exempt dealing.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I refer to the specific and very special questions which have been asked by Senator Harris. I would have hoped he would have taken the opportunity to ask previously if he had this complex detailed requirement. In respect to schedule 1, this is always in a secure working environment, whereas schedule 2 is in a physical containment 2 laboratory—it is a matter of definition.

—I thank Senator Tambling and seek clarification that exempt dealings would be carried out not in an open environment but only within a confined area. I specifically refer to the situation in Mount Gambier which was brought to the committee's notice where, under that licence, there was a requirement to have confined environments but it was proven by photographs of that trial that those confined environments had been breached by being torn in some cases and totally blown away in others. Could Senator Tambling assure the committee that there would be no exempt dealings that would be carried out in the open environment and that exempt dealings would be carried out within a confined area only?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I can give Senator Harris the assurance he is seeking.

—I want to take this first opportunity to explain a certain matter which arose on Friday. As we are talking about exemptions, I thought this might be an appropriate place to do this. Senator Brown has raised the issue of the problems in certain laboratories. We do not know what is happening. I also made mention of that on Friday and commented in relation to an experiment referring to:

quote.para: ... cloning which took place in Dr Trounson's unit in Melbourne whereby they transferred the nucleus of a human somatic cell into a denucleated pig's ovum.

speech.para: That experiment took place but not in Dr Trounson's laboratories. It is a matter which was included in a patent submitted by the Melbourne company Stem Cell Sciences Pty Ltd of which Dr Peter Scott Mountford is a director. I had the wrong doctor, obviously. I regret it if Dr Trounson has been offended by that, although I do not know whether or not he has. It was not my intention to mislead. The mistake was made because I connected comments made in the media at the time of the pig ovum story with comments that Dr Trounson made earlier in the inquiry into human cloning being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in which Dr Trounson commented on 2 March this year:

quote.para: There are only two groups in the world that are working on human embryonic stem cells that we know of ... that is Wisconsin and ourselves.

speech.para: He said that if the work was being done in Australia on somatic cell transfer from a human to an animal ova:

quote.para: ... it would be most likely done in our laboratories—

speech.para: that is, `our' meaning Dr Trounson's laboratories. You see, I jumped to a conclusion which, in the end, was not correct. However, the experiment was done and we did not know about it. The point I am making about this is that, when the story broke that a Melbourne company had done the procedure and was seeking patents on the process, the mistake was made of presuming that the laboratory was one of those belonging to Dr Trounson. I do apologise, but you can see the problem that I had. However, it has been done. There had been a patent sought for the process, and we would not have known about this experiment had it not been for the fact that the patent had been applied for. That is one of the reasons—not the major reason—for my amendments to the Gene Technology Bill 2000: to ensure that that type of experiment is not allowed to continue to be done should any other scientist wish to undertake that type of experiment.

On the question of exclusion, I will be making some comments about that whole area when the committee deals with the amendments, but I wanted to use this occasion to express my regret to Dr Trounson and to indicate that it was a case of mistaken identity; albeit, I appeal to him, with some justification given his own words before the committee in March. Perhaps some mitigation of guilt is there!

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I would just comment briefly on the issues raised by Senator Harradine in that area. I am pleased to note that he has acknowledged the points that he has just made with regard to this issue. Certainly, it is more appropriate that we deal with the substantive matters with regard to both Senator Harradine's amendment that we will hopefully deal with later in the day and any other proposed amendments that might arise in this area. I was also given a copy of Professor Trounson's letter to the President of the Senate dated 4 December, in which Professor Trounson says, referring to the Senate Hansard of Friday, 1 December:

quote.para: A brief note to follow up our conversation on Friday 1st December, 2000.
Senator Harradine referred to "the cloning which took place in Dr. Trounson's unit in Melbourne whereby they transferred the nucleus of a human somatic cell into a denucleated pig's ovum".
This is not true and no such work was ever done in any of my laboratories.

Senator Harradine refers to a matter that is included in a patent submitted by the company, Stem Cell Sciences Pty Ltd. None of this work was ever done in my laboratory. There has never been any proposal to our Animal or Human Ethics Committees for any such research at the Institute of Reproduction and Development.

speech.para: It is signed by Professor Trounson, Professor, Obstetrics and Gynaecology/Paediatrics. I hoped Senator Harradine would have taken the opportunities in the last 12 months whilst this issue has been under major consideration, both by Senator Crowley's committee and in the other consultation processes, going on, as I said, over 12 months in the development of this particular legislation. I accept the point that Senator Harradine makes that it is more appropriate to return to this debate on both his amendment and those that may be made at a later hour in the debate on this particular issue.

talk.start.para: —I think that was quite ungenerous of the parliamentary secretary to suggest that I should have been at this committee or that committee. I think I am on, at the present moment, around 15 committees of this parliament.
—What do you do with your spare time?

—That includes participating membership. Senator Bolkus will know; we have seen each other in various areas, including on the refugee issues that came before L&C. Am I to understand from the parliamentary secretary that one cannot move an amendment to a piece of legislation in this chamber, and give notice of it as I have done in this regard, unless one has been to this committee or that committee? That is why the committees make reports, and that is why we can examine those reports and see whether it is appropriate or inappropriate to move amendments. My concern on this occasion is to make sure that this legislation does in fact prevent cloning of human embryos. I do not want to go into that, but the fact of the matter is that this bill has an elaborate structure to deal with genetically modified organisms of a plant and animal variety but not of a human variety. Anything goes in that particular area, unless you are receiving public funding.

—I would like to ask the government to consider, in the time coming up, what restriction is put on the regulation saying the dealing does not involve an intentional release into the environment. What are the safeguards there?
(Senator Sherry)—The question is that clause 141 stand as printed. Those of that opinion, say aye—

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —Mr Temporary Chairman, my understanding is that we are going to defer some of the matters in this debate to a later time and that we are not ready to vote on the amendment before the chair. It might be better to resolve this when we return.
—Thank you for clarifying your intent.

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate

talk.start.para: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Vanstone, Minister for Justice and Customs, Minister representing the Attorney-General and Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be absent from question time today. Senator Vanstone is opening the Pacific Region Transnational Crime Seminar in Brisbane. During Senator Vanstone's absence, Senator Ellison will take questions relating to the Justice and Customs portfolio, the Attorney-General's portfolio and the Immigration and Multicultural Affairs portfolio.

—My question is to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Defence. Does the minister agree that the report by Mr Tony Blunn into the death of Mr Merv Jenkins damns the techniques used by Defence Security and department of foreign affairs officers in their heavy-handed efforts to interview and intimidate Mr Jenkins? Can the minister also confirm that the report exonerates Mr Jenkins from the allegation that he improperly passed information to unauthorised persons?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The government have always tried to balance the concern we would all have for the Jenkins family and their wishes with the needs of national security. That is why we agreed to allow the release of an unclassified version of the report of the Inspector-General of Intelligence Security. Defence has also accepted the report's criticisms and will follow up the recommendations. A number of changes have already been made. This government have established the Defence Intelligence Board and appointed a new director to DIO.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that this exoneration of Mr Jenkins has been too long in coming, what urgent action will the Howard government now take to ensure that all of the recommendations of the report are implemented and to ensure full access to compensation for Mr Jenkins's family as a clear gesture that the Commonwealth government accepts some degree of responsibility for these tragic circumstances?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —As Senator Hogg would realise, there may be legal action stemming from the case. In that context, the minister is not prepared to comment on that. If there is anything that the minister can add to the answer I have given, I am sure he will do his best to help.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Given the weekend's public display of support for reconciliation, will the minister outline how the government is supporting reconciliation through practical initiatives in health, housing, education and employment and by strengthening indigenous families? Will the minister also inform the Senate of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Chapman for the question and for his continued interest in reconciliation. He has been a strong advocate of that process. I would like to congratulate all those people who walked the talk yesterday in Melbourne and Perth. It was good to see Senator Ray there. Many people participated in both walks, and similar crowds have turned out for previous walks in other states. This is a demonstration of the enormous goodwill between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. Most people want better life outcomes for indigenous people, who remain the most disadvantaged group in our society. That is why the Howard government has committed to practical reconciliation, with initiatives to overcome disadvantage particularly in the areas of health, housing, education, employment and economic empowerment.

answer.para: Lasting reconciliation is something that cannot be achieved overnight. It is something that takes time and must come from the hearts and minds of individuals. Reconciliation will continue as a people's movement, and I congratulate the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation for the great contribution it has made over the past decade. The government's practical approach begins with the record $2.3 billion we are spending on initiatives this year. We are targeting this to achieve realistic and practical outcomes.

I have spoken at length in the Senate of the government's outstanding $40 million indigenous community infrastructure Army initiative and the dramatic improvements being made in indigenous communities most in need. In indigenous health, for instance, the government has increased spending by 50 per cent since 1996. The Public Health Association of Australia last week applauded the government's Primary Health Care Access program as `a landmark public health achievement'. This program has many benefits, including improved access to health services in remote areas. Indigenous-specific housing programs now account for 20 per cent of the Commonwealth's total spending on public and community housing. In education, we have increased funding by $100 million, and our policies are starting to achieve rapid improvements—for example, a record number of 8,000 indigenous students undertook tertiary study last year.

On the employment front, the government's $115 million indigenous employment policy placed 1,500 people in jobs in its first year. Another 2,500 were assisted through structured training and employment projects. The number of indigenous Australians commencing traineeships and apprenticeships has increased almost sixfold—from around 800 in 1994 to about 4,600 last year. We are also building stronger families by tackling welfare dependency and addressing social issues which lead to indigenous family violence. I thank Senator Newman for her initiative in that regard.

When Labor were in government for 13 years they failed indigenous Australians. Everyone knows that. Indigenous leaders know it. Noel Pearson last week endorsed our approach, saying, `In many ways, the coalition are more understanding of our predicament.' He said, `The Labor Party had largely left welfare reform to be articulated by the coalition.' The comments followed a stinging attack on the Labor Party by indigenous leader Tracker Tilmouth and the decision by Maurie Ryan Japarte to establish his own Aboriginal party. Both are present members of the ALP. It is clear that Labor have not learned anything in opposition. We all know their disgraceful description of the portfolio.

There is an overwhelming desire by the community to redress the wrongs of the past and to pursue equality in the future. The Howard government's practical reconciliation is something of which all Australians can be proud because we are making a real impact on overcoming disadvantage and improving the lives of indigenous Australians. I am quite confident that all those who marched in the various states and capital cities have an overwhelming desire to put those things of the past behind us, to overcome the disadvantage that is still there and to achieve equality in the future for all indigenous Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In relation to the report by Mr Tony Blunn into the death of Mr Merv Jenkins, the DIO liaison officer in Washington, what action is the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade taking to investigate Mr Blunn's finding that key evidence was missing, including letters, tapes and electronic copies of correspondence, from the Defence Intelligence Organisation?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I would take that question on notice.
—Oh, that's good.
—It is a very serious issue and should be treated seriously, Senator. I will take it on notice and, if there is any information I can provide at the end of question time, I will do so.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am surprised that, considering this was in the media last Friday, the minister has not got an answer for at least some of this. I also ask: what action is the department taking or planning to take in response to the finding of the Blunn inquiry that the conduct of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in the investigation into Mr Jenkins's handling of intelligence material was counterproductive and contributed to Mr Jenkins's suicide?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —As I said, on such a sensitive matter I would prefer to take it on notice and see what I can provide.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Given that local government representatives from councils across Australia are meeting in Canberra this week, will the minister outline the government's initiatives to assist local councils to deliver their services, particularly to Australians living in regional and remote areas?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McGauran for the question. Senator McGauran has experience in local government, as do many of my colleagues here, including Senator Calvert and Senator Heffernan. A lot of people here have an interest in local government. I am also delighted with the question, because this week local government from right across Australia are meeting in Canberra for their annual conference. I might say that when the Prime Minister opened the conference this morning he was very warmly received, as one would well expect with the good news that the Prime Minister was able to announce this time last week about the additional $1.6 billion investment into roads, including the $1.2 billion investment in local roads being delivered through local councils—people who understand and know what it is all about.

answer.para: Senator McGauran has asked me what programs we have worked on with local governments. Time will not allow me to go through them all, because there are so many: the $45 million local government fund under the Networking the Nation program; the money that has been spent on regional health services; the money spent for the fly in, fly out GP services in rural and regional Australia for women; the $1.5 billion Natural Heritage Trust—most of which went to rural and regional Australia, and in which councils were very closely involved with local government—and $70 million for the Rural Transaction Centre Program. Most of those programs have an element in which the local authorities join with the federal government in looking at them. Local governments are also very much involved with the Regional Flood Mitigation Program. Other Networking the Nation programs are programs that local governments have done a marvellous job with.

talk.start.para: —You couldn't answer questions about that at estimates. You told them to go and ask Richard about it.

—I hear Senator Mackay screaming at me from over there. It is a pity she wouldn't ask a question at question time and show some interest in local government, as my colleague Senator McGauran and others on this side do.

answer.para: I am brought to the situation where one might say that what the Howard government has done is fairly well recognised: money going out in many ways—the $1.2 billion package announced last Monday and additional money for local governments over and above what we have given them elsewhere. I am minded to ask: are there alternative proposals? What have the Labor Party done? We have had a lot of promises about things going to happen, but we never seem to actually get down to the nitty-gritty of what the Labor Party might do. We have had Mr Beazley criticising the $1.2 billion local roads package. He calls it `boondoogling'—or boondoggling or whatever the word is. He says there is a smell of pork about it. But down there at the local government conference this morning, I can tell you that every single one of the councils that spoke to me came up to me specifically to say, `Thank you for that.' It is across the whole of Australia; it is not in any one area or another. It is delivered by the state local grants commission, absolutely independently and fairly, and local government are very pleased—not for themselves but for the people they represent, their constituents. They understand what this massive investment will be. We are still waiting for the Labor Party's proposal. All we have from them is criticism, nitpicking, carping and allegations of boondoggling. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Liquefied Petroleum Gas

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. What action does the Howard government propose to take to curb skyrocketing LPG prices? Isn't it a fact that before the introduction of the GST no taxes applied to LPG but now LPG attracts the full 10 per cent GST, thus making LPG more expensive than it would otherwise have been? Isn't it also the case that, due to the GST impact on LPG prices, it is no longer economically viable to convert from petrol to LPG?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —LPG prices in Australia have risen as a result of rising world LPG prices. That is a very important point. As Senator Conroy pointed out, no excise is paid on LPG in Australia. The fact of the matter is that there has been a very sharp rise in LPG prices on world markets and, as a consequence, LPG prices in this country have also risen. That causes us concern, as it should cause you concern, Senator Conroy. I think it is very important that we recognise the reason for this rise in prices, which is that we have experienced rising LPG prices on world markets. I also make the point that the Labor Party, of course, has no policy to deal with this. The issue of the GST was raised by Senator Conroy, which is interesting.
