As he would know, business users can claim an input tax credit. It is interesting because the GST is in fact Labor Party policy. Senator Conroy, I have to say that, if you are being critical of this government and if you are saying that Labor Party policy is to remove the GST from LPG and from petrol, that is a very big statement of policy. But if you are not proposing to do that, your policy is precisely the same as this government's policy. You should not try to fool taxpayers that your policy is different. What you should do is be honest with people and recognise that, in relation to fuels, this country has faced rising fuel prices because of trends on world markets.
—And the GST.

—Senator Conroy talks about the GST, but the GST is Labor Party policy. If Senator Conroy is going to stand up and ask me a supplementary question—and I always hope that he does ask me a supplementary question—perhaps he could clarify for people who may be listening whether Labor Party policy is not to have a GST on fuel. We will wait with great interest to see whether he can address that issue or whether, as on so many other issues, there is really no Labor Party policy. In fact, the Labor Party's policy in relation to the GST is the same as the government's policy. If there is a roll-back proposed in this area, you had better tell us, because it is going to cost a lot of money.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that the Saudi marker contract price for LPG was 33.42c per litre in Australian dollar terms on 1 November 2000? Can he explain why LPG now sells for around 60c per litre? Does the minister believe that LPG producers are exploiting Australian motorists? If so, isn't the Howard government party to this exploitation, given that the GST applies to the price inflated end retail price?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I indicate to Senator Conroy that the ACCC, in its report on the movement of fuel prices in the September quarter 2000, estimated that LPG prices could have been expected to rise by some 6.7c per litre during the quarter, with 2.5c per litre due to the introduction of the GST and 4.2c per litre due to the increase in the Saudi Arabian contract price in Australian dollar terms.
—So there's no exploitation?

—I am quoting the report from the ACCC, the independent prices monitor. You asked me a question as to what has happened, and I am now quoting to you the report of the ACCC. The ACCC report found that the `average LPG price increase in the five major metropolitan cities over the September quarter was less than 6c per litre'. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Does the minister still stand by the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, which he chaired? In particular, does he stand by recommendation No. 22, which states:

quote.para: Before the appointment of a person to the board, the proposed nominee should be required to appear before a joint parliamentary committee to enable the Parliament to scrutinise the person's credentials.

question.para: If so, when will the government's new board appointee, Mr Maurice Newman, be appearing before a joint parliamentary committee?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I know we have spent a lot of time looking at the most effective way of putting in place proper governance arrangements. But, as I am sure Senator Bourne is well aware, whenever we have tried to make constructive suggestions about how one might alter the ABC Act or indeed the charter provisions, we have been constantly told that the Democrats in particular, and no doubt the Labor Party on principle, are opposed to change, which means that we are essentially stuck with the current arrangements. As you know, the requirements for prospective appointees to the board are expressed, as is the charter itself, in very broad terms. They contemplate a range of possible experiences in media, communications and business, to some extent at least. But, in broad terms, I do not think they do impose onerous requirements. That is the system that has operated for many years. It is the first time I have ever heard that Senator Bourne was proposing a change to the ABC Act in that regard. If she is interested in having a discussion about changes to the act and the charter, I am sure we would be happy to have a talk to her.

answer.para: As you will recall, there were specific recommendations from the Mansfield report that priority be given to news and current affairs, children's television and regional coverage—both radio and television. On every occasion we were told, `No thanks very much; we do not want to go down that path.' Indeed, I can recall Mr Johns, the former managing director, saying that there was nothing wrong with the charter because it enabled the ABC to do whatever it wanted to do—which I actually thought was the problem not the solution. Nonetheless, that is where things are at the present time. Therefore, I do not envisage Mr Newman appearing before any parliamentary committee. I think his credentials are impeccable. As I am sure Senator Bourne would acknowledge, he has been a respected leader in the business community for many years. I am sure he is an ABC enthusiast, as many of us are. I have no doubt that he will bring a very useful perspective to its deliberation.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer, but it is obvious that my private member's bill, which would put into legislation his recommendation on board appointees going before joint parliamentary committees, has completely passed him by, despite the fact that it has actually been considered by this Senate. That is quite amazing. I ask the minister to have a look at my private member's bill again. I am sure he will enjoy it. It puts into legislation his recommendations from that parliamentary committee. I also ask the minister to please have a look at the recommendations of that report, which of course he chaired, particularly recommendations 15, 16, 17 and 21. I am sure he will be amazed to see that, since he got into the ministry, he appears to have gone against—directly opposite—his own recommendations. So I ask the minister to have a look at those recommendations, have a look at my private member's bill and have a look at the Hansard report of what happened with my private member's bill. (Time expired)

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think we are going back a fair way in history, are we not? What year was that—about 1994 or 1995?

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It was 1995, was it? I suspect the world has changed fundamentally since then—not least of all, of course, with new media technologies and the Internet transforming the business case as far as the ABC is concerned. You would probably find that an offensive term, but I would have thought that the ABC would have to focus on priority areas just like anyone else. Indeed, they do espouse the new digital technology with great enthusiasm.

answer.para: I have to make a confession to Senator Bourne: I will not be able to look `again' at her bill, because I do not think it has actually crossed my desk until now. My humblest apologies. I will have a good look at it. I do not actually recall recommendations 16, 17, 18 and 21. But, once again, I will see whether they have any enduring relevance. To the extent that they do, we will have a good think about it. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Bottled Gas

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp as Assistant Treasurer. Minister, what advice can you offer aged pensioners Roy and Doris Barker of Upper Beaconsfield in Victoria who rely on bottled gas to heat their home and who now, due to skyrocketing gas prices, have to go to bed earlier to conserve energy? What answer does the government have when Mr Barker says, as he did on AM last week:

quote.para: We've never wasted it. We just can't possibly afford it on pensioners' money—we can't afford that sort of money.

question.para: Aren't Roy and Doris Barker just more victims of the Howard government's tax rip-off on gas, given that no tax applied before the introduction of the GST?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The first bit of advice I would give to Roy and Doris Barker would be: `Don't vote Labor.' I would say to Roy and Doris Barker that Senator Jacinta Collins is standing up here and pretending that her tax policy in relation to the GST is different from ours. I would urge Roy and Doris Barker to write to Senator Collins and to say in their letter: `Dear Jacinta, could you make it clear just what your tax policy on the GST and LPG is? Is it correct, as Senator Kemp says, that the Labor Party has endorsed the GST? Or is it correct that you are in some way going to roll back the GST and that this may affect the price of LPG gas?' That is the letter they should write to you. I would ask them to send me a copy of your response because then we would see whether there has been a significant policy decision from the Labor Party or whether this is just the usual bogus nonsense that the Labor Party goes on with.

answer.para: I think we can shortcut this because, after question time, we are going to have a motion to take note of the answer, and Senator Collins will stand up and we will listen very carefully to see whether she is trying to mislead those two pensioners or whether in fact she has a real policy prescription for them. The truth of the matter is that LPG prices have risen as a result of trends on world markets. That is the honest answer.

talk.start.para: —Oh, come on!

—It is interesting that Senator Sherry is getting terribly excited—as he does from time to time, feeling that Senator Collins may rather fluff this in the taking note of the answer debate. When you stand up, Senator Sherry, we will see what the Labor Party's tax policy is. If you are proposing to change the GST as it relates to fuel and LPG, you are making a significant policy decision. The reason why people are turning off the Labor Party in droves is that Labor have no policies. They stand for absolutely nothing. Senator Collins, you are trying to mislead pensioners with that question.

—You can correct me, Senator, when we have the motion to take note or even in your supplementary question by making it clear just what your policy is. In relation to tax reform, this government has done many important things to assist aged pensioners, not the least is the guaranteed real rise in pensions and benefits.

—Senator Newman has outlined on many occasions the many advantages that aged pensioners and self-funded retirees obtain from the tax reform package. Senator Collins, the challenge is in your hands. Stand up now—you have asked the question—and clarify the Labor Party policy. I bet that, as on every other occasion, Senator Collins will duck the issue.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. This is the government's question time and I hope the minister will provide an answer on the government's policy. Is the minister aware that the Prime Minister confirmed on 24 November on the Neil Mitchell program on 3AW that the price of LPG has risen as a direct result of the GST? Is the minister aware that his coalition colleagues in the Western Australian government have today expressed concern about the drastic effects of the rising cost of bottled LPG on many older people in rural areas in the state? In view of the Prime Minister's admission, just how does the Howard government—which is in government—intend to alleviate the GST induced cost rises being experienced by low income older people like Roy and Doris Barker of Upper Beaconsfield?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The point I make to Senator Collins is that raising your voice does not mean you have made it clear what the Labor Party position is. If you had listened to my response to Senator Conroy in which I said that, according to the ACCC, 2.5c per litre is due to the introduction of the GST, you would realise that I have actually answered that part of your question. The substantial rise that you are talking about is not due to the GST; it is due to the rise in world prices. We will have this debate after question time. This may be the big day when the Labor Party announces roll-back. This may be the day that Australia has been waiting for. Of course, if this is not part of roll-back, Senator, you are guilty of seriously misleading Roy and Doris Barker. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. I ask: would the minister inform the Senate of recent examples of leading edge computer research and e-commerce business development that are being supported by the government? I ask: is the minister aware of any alternative approaches to the support of Australia's information industries?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The government has certainly been very active on this front. There are a number of leading edge projects that we think deserve specific government support. Only a few days ago, Senator Minchin, Dr Kemp and I presented a $9 million cheque to the Special Research Centre for Quantum Computing at the University of New South Wales to enable them to progress—

—I am sorry you could not make it. It was a great effort and you would have enjoyed it thoroughly. What we were concerned to do was to enable that project to continue in Australia when Australia does have a leading edge and when we do have a real opportunity to develop a prototype quantum computer that would enable miniaturisation to the extent of speeding up computing power to the tune of about one billion times. That is pretty serious business in anyone's language.
—Are you going to sell it as part of the IT outsourcing?

—So instead of wandering around bagging IT outsourcing out of one side of your mouth and then conceding out of the other that it is still Labor Party policy, what you should do is get out there and support some of these projects and demonstrate that the Labor Party is serious. Similarly, on behalf of Senator Minchin, I was in Sydney the other night launching the Asia-Pacific IBM innovation e-business centre. Again, with government support, that centre was able to establish itself in Sydney rather than—
—Senator Alston, ignore interjections.

—Yes, I think the old Senator Lundy is getting a bit lost in translation. I am having a problem. That was again a very good example of where the government can make a difference with a modest amount of money, but it made all the difference in the world in terms of whether that e-business innovation centre was located in Australia or in Singapore. I think it is a very big win to Australia. I am sorry Senator Lundy was not around to put out a press release to congratulate the government on its support.

answer.para: Unfortunately, of course, the Labor Party are very much behind the game. I was intrigued to see recently an article headed—I thought quite engagingly—`Bring on the clowns, oh, they're on'. It talked about how, in the mid-nineties, industry were generally telling the Labor Party that the Internet was the way of the future but, unfortunately, Labor Party IT guru, Michael Lee, ignored the tech upstarts and preferred CD-ROMs as his multimedia of choice. Nothing much has changed in the Labor Party—I think we are all aware of that—but they still pretend that somehow this `knowledge nation' is going somewhere. I have read reports saying that there is quite a deal of unhappiness among the frontbench of the ALP because they see poor old Mr Beazley as a sitting duck. He got out there and talked about it more than 12 months ago, but has done nothing ever since. And, of course, it must have been particularly galling to people like Senator Lundy, who are on that task force which was established in Hobart in lieu of any serious policy decision, that once again they outsourced the idea and set up a task force. We read in the Weekend Australian on 14 October: `Vacuum at the heart of Labor's agenda'. So here we are some four months down the track and that committee had not yet met. Senator Lundy, has it met since—in the last six or seven weeks?

talk.start.para: —Senator Alston, you should be directing your remarks to the chair and not asking questions across the chamber.

—Indeed, Madam President. Perhaps I could make the point another way. Senator Lundy spent the first two minutes interjecting constantly—listening to every word I said! The minute I ask whether in fact that committee has met now, nearly six months later, Senator Lundy is too busy talking to Senator Mackay—which I think really answers the question. What it tells you is that the task force still has not met. It is just an empty charade. We know that nothing is going to happen on this front and that there is only one crowd taking the issue seriously. That is very unfortunate for those who have desperate aspirations to become shadow minister for IT, but fortunately we still do not have one on the other side the chamber. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the government is drafting regulations for the Aged Care Act setting out the criteria by which the minister will exempt nursing homes from the 1 January 2001 accreditation deadline? Will the government commit to tabling those regulations before parliament rises? Given that the deadline is now less than a month away, why hasn't the government finalised those regulations earlier? Does the minister think it appropriate that the rules be changed so close to the deadline?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Evans for the question. I do not have a brief in relation to that question. I will take it on notice and get back to him when I get a response from the minister.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I would appreciate his response as soon as possible. Can he also provide information as to how many nursing homes are likely to be affected by the exemption process?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Again, I will take that on notice.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Minister, is it the case that Australia used undue pressure on the World Heritage Committee members to keep Kakadu off the endangered list at Cairns last week? How many bureaucrats were in Cairns; how many travelled overseas before the meeting; what sorts of deals and threats did they make; and what was the cost?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The World Heritage Committee meeting in Cairns was a great success. I would like to congratulate the Australian delegation. This was a meeting chaired by Australia, being held in Australia, of the body that is principally responsible for the governance of world heritage, certainly between the major UNESCO meetings from time to time. Its agenda included issues such as new listings and reports on listings about which there was some question. As the honourable senator might know, there is a regular reporting process in relation to existing listings. There are some listings that are categorised as `in danger' and there is a report on those listings and such matters.

answer.para: As I said, the meeting was very successful and we are very pleased to have hosted it. It gave delegates from the 30 countries an opportunity to see Australia's management of two very important world heritage areas—the Great Barrier Reef and the wet tropics—and, in particular, to look at the way in which we are managing the multiple use issues in highly complex environments and how work and living activities can take place that are compatible with protecting world heritage values. I might say that, in conjunction with the meeting, as a first, we held a youth forum on world heritage for delegates from the South Pacific. I addressed that. It was a very successful forum. We also held our first indigenous forum in conjunction with this meeting. That was also important because a number of our listings—I think four—are listed for cultural values. The issue of managing cultural values is a highly complex one, one that is evolving, particularly now that part of the contemporary debate is about how you protect living cultures as opposed to sites.

The issue of Kakadu was on the agenda because we had to report back. I am pleased that that report was received positively. The independent scientific report was further evidence that no damage had been done by the 20-odd years of mining in the nearby uranium mines in Kakadu. We further advanced, although I must admit only to a small degree, the issue of cultural values in relation to the Jabiluka matter. I was pleased in that regard.

I was particularly pleased that at this meeting we were able to have listed the Greater Blue Mountains region in New South Wales. It is important for this wonderful area to be listed for its demonstration of ecological development, particularly in relation to the eucalypt. It has not been an easy task to obtain that listing because of some differences between the scientists. Nevertheless, in the end the World Heritage Committee accepted the advice of the Australian government and I am pleased about that.

Whilst on that subject, I acknowledge the support from the New South Wales state government and many conservationists and scientists who supported us in that application. I also mention Kerry Bartlett, the local member for the region. He played a leadership role in relation to that successful application. It will further enhance the tourism appeal of Sydney, as well as demonstrate to the world that we have yet another icon that we recognise as being of world heritage value and that the international community accepts that value as well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is rare for the minister for the environment not to attempt at all to answer any aspect of a question put to him, so I will again ask him: what sort of deals and threats were made in order to get the committee to not place Kakadu on the endangered list? What was the cost? How many bureaucrats travelled overseas? Where did they go, what did they do, and who did they meet with? Minister, why did Australia not vacate the chair when Kakadu was being discussed? Isn't your government concerned that this huge effort to justify a uranium mine so close to a world heritage site is undermining the work of the World Heritage Committee?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The good news that came out of that meeting was that the independent scientific panel, chosen from around the world, confirmed that Kakadu is safe. That is good news. I would have thought that was something that would have pleased the honourable senator.
—They didn't say that at all. They were very specific and you are lying.

—What it demonstrated was that international scientists support the views of the Supervising Scientist, under Australian legislation, that nearby uranium mining is conducted in a way that is totally safe in relation to the world heritage values. That was the big news that came out of Cairns. I would have thought that that should be applauded by all Australians. By the way, there were no threats and no deals.
—Senator Bolkus, I ask you to withdraw the unparliamentary words that you used during the time you were disorderly.
—I withdraw, Madam President.

—My question is directed to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I ask: is the minister aware of a report on dental decay and gum disease prepared for last week's Australian Health Ministers Council meeting which warns that `meeting even minimum acceptable standards of access to general dental care for concession card holders is beyond the capacity of states and territories'? Doesn't this report highlight the shameful consequences of the Howard government's scrapping of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in 1996, including that delays in dental care are resulting in pensioners being `more than twice as likely to have had all of their teeth extracted'? When will the Howard government get health priorities right—fixing pensioners' teeth instead of pulling them out?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The best thing that Senator McLucas could do would be to convince the Labor Mayor of Brisbane to introduce fluoridation of the Brisbane water, because the lack of fluoridation of Brisbane water has produced dental decay in half the population of Queensland. Councillor Soorley has prevented the fluoridation of water in Brisbane. Every other capital city, as I understand it, has got it. That is the first point I would make. I would suggest that Senator McLucas, as a senator for Queensland, work on the Labor Party to introduce fluoride into the water supplies of Queensland. That would produce a greater improvement in dental health care in the state of Queensland than anything else.

answer.para: The states have been traditionally responsible for the provision of public dental health services in their jurisdiction—every state. In the dying days of the 1993 election campaign, then Prime Minister Paul Keating announced booster funding for the Dental Health Program for a finite period of four years. He set a limit of four years on it. A target was set of treating 1½ million people over that four years. As usual, Labor did this without any thought, without consultation with the states—there was no consultation with the states; we are well aware of that—and without any planning.
Senator Crowley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Crowley is shouting out because she should have done something about it and did not. The Commonwealth introduced the Commonwealth Dental Health Program between 1994 and 1997 to assist the states in reducing waiting lists and to implement better management practices for the future. It was never intended to be an ongoing program. The states were always expected to resume responsibility for public dental care once the program had finished. The Labor Party never intended it to be extended. The program at best was a stopgap measure which did very little to address the underlying structural issues affecting the provision of public dental health care.

answer.para: It is fascinating to note that the opposition has not made any commitment to the Dental Health Program. As Senator Kemp said of the Labor Party, Senator McLucas can get up in her supplementary and announce what the Labor Party's policy is in relation to dental health care. They did not have it in their election program for 1996 or for the election and they have not yet announced it as a continuing program. So I would ask Senator McLucas to tell us what they are going to do on that side in relation to the Dental Health Program. Even while their program of booster funding was in operation, there were significant criticisms of the basic range of services, the lack of preventative service and the fee schedule under the program. I remember the Australian Dental Association commenting on it because they had not been consulted. The very providers of the service were not asked—that is how much planning went into it. On the other hand, it is always disappointing to hear about people who have had to wait for treatment for health problems, and dental health problems are no different. However, it is pleasing to see that some states are acknowledging their responsibilities by providing additional funding to their public dental services and by entering into arrangements such as those currently announced in South Australia and the initiatives in Queensland.

I would again ask Senator McLucas, as a Labor Party member and as a promoter of dental health care—which is the implication of the question—that she get on to Councillor Soorley and ask him to take the biggest step that could be taken in regard to the prevention of dental decay in the state of Queensland: introducing fluoride into the public water supplies of Brisbane.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Doesn't the report graphically describe the effect of the Howard government's scrapping of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program on Australia's 4.7 million adult concession card holders? Can the minister confirm that, as a direct result of this callous action, some 140,000 low income people in New South Wales face a wait of 4½ years; 78,000 South Australians wait for more than 3½ years and 140,000 Victorians wait nearly two years for dental care? Given that these delays are increasingly leading to removal of the teeth rather than enduring the pain, just how much did the scrapping of the Commonwealth dental scheme save the Howard government?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Even Senator McLucas would be aware that the provision of public care is the responsibility of the states. Under the Medicare agreements, funding was increased to the states. If the states are not accepting their responsibility, I would suggest to Senator McLucas that she write to the premiers of the states—predominantly Labor—and ask them to do something about it.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the minister inform the Senate of details of the policies that have delivered both real growth in wages and falling unemployment under the Howard government? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies? What effect would these policies have on the Australian economy?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you for that important question, Senator. It was a question that I rather would have expected to get from Senator George Campbell, to be quite frank. Senator George Campbell—rightly—was very critical of falling real wages under the former government, under the Keating and Hawke governments. There are many issues in regard to which I differ from Senator George Campbell, but I think that he did a very important community service in nailing the performance of the former Labor government on this issue. I congratulate Senator George Campbell for doing that.

answer.para: Australian families have benefited enormously from the responsive management of the economy by the Howard government. In reforming the budget, in keeping the budget in surplus and in reducing Labor's debt, we have created a climate of lower interest rates, falling unemployment and rising real wages.

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, who was one of the senior ministers responsible for running up the massive debt under the former government, will be pleased to know that we have managed to cut Labor's debt which they left this country of $96 billion. We have now brought it down to a projected $44 billion by the end of 2000-01. I think that is very good news and that, frankly, the performance of the government across a wide range of areas has delivered real benefits to Australians. Between 1996 and the year 2000—and this is the figure which I think Senator George Campbell will be particularly interested in, as he was successful in nailing the former government on this—real wages for the low paid grew by some nine per cent. Between 1983 and 1996—that is, the term of the former Hawke and Keating governments—real wages for the low paid actually fell by 5.2 per cent. In 13 years a Labor government managed to cut the real wages of low paid workers. The Howard government, in its term of office, has managed to raise real wages by some nine per cent.

answer.para: Another thing that we in this government are particularly proud of is that we have been able to create real jobs. Mr Keating boasted of the recession we had to have and I think most Australians were pretty appalled by that statement. Many people found themselves without jobs and of course many people in business went broke. But we now have a forecast of a further three per cent growth in employment this financial year and of course these benefits—rising real wages, falling unemployment—come on top of the fact that we have been able to cut taxes. We have been able to deliver arguably the largest income tax cut in Australian history.

talk.start.para: —Why are you the biggest taxing government for 10 years?

—Senator Conroy butts in, but I wonder whether Senator Conroy can stand up after question time—it is going to be very busy after question time today—and guarantee the very substantial income tax cuts that this government has given. This question has been asked on many occasions of the Labor Party—to guarantee the income tax cuts which have been delivered by the Howard government—and each Labor spokesman has ducked that issue. We know what the Labor performance was like on real wages. We know what the Labor performance was like on unemployment. Unemployment at one stage was over 11 per cent. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware that Dr David Vaux of the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute and co-winner of this year's Glaxo Wellcome Science Medal has described the government's attitude to medical research as `pathetic'? Isn't it a fact that the government has exaggerated every promise and announced them two and three times over to cover up the fact that Australia is not putting medical research and biotechnology at the top of the agenda in the same way as many overseas countries?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of Dr Vaux's statement, but I would expect that any medical researcher would want more money for medical research. The Medical Research Society of Australia are always promoting the desire of their members for more funding in medical research. That is their right to do so and I would expect them to do so. There is never enough money for medical research, whichever government is in power. It is a matter of allocation of resources, and that is a matter of fact. They did that when the Labor Party were in power: the Medical Medical Research Society of Australia were constantly wanting more funding, and got an adequate response consistent with the funding that was available for medical research. We are doing the same: we have increased the funding for medical research.

answer.para: I refute the allegation that Senator Crowley has made, that we are constantly announcing the same funding allocations. Of course we would like to give more money for medical research. But the reality is that it is enormously expensive and there are many more applications put in by researchers than there is funding available. We are doing our best. We appreciate the difficulties that medical researchers have in getting funding, particularly for an ongoing program—they themselves have to constantly attempt to raise funds to keep programs going—but with the allocation of funding through the budget process it is inevitable that there will be a shortfall between demand and supply.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise to ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that it is the government that has exaggerated every promise; it is not a matter of the constant complaints of the medical profession. My supplementary question is: can the minister confirm that the 400 medical research projects which the government has announced it will fund in 2001 is significantly down on the 428 projects funded this year? Can the minister also confirm that the government has shelved its promise to double spending in six years?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —There is a difference between quality and quantity. Senator Crowley seems to imply that, because it has gone down from 440 to 428, somehow that is a dereliction of duty on behalf of the government. It is the quality of research that counts, not the numbers. I would assume, because of that, that, if there is a disparity, then the end product of the research should be the important and significant item that should be taken into consideration rather than a mere matter of numbers. I think, as a generalisation, there are something like four times the requests made to the National Health and Medical Research Council than grants that are given out by the NHMRC.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. Will the minister inform the Senate how the Howard government is supporting local government, particularly in rural and regional Australia, to restore and protect the natural environment?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Local government is a very important partner in the management of a better environment, something that I have to say was underrated by our predecessor, the Labor Party. On coming to government, we quickly recognised the importance of building a partnership with local governments in delivering better on-ground outcomes. I might mention a few subject matters in which that partnership is already bringing rewards. The first I would like to mention is the area of Cities for Climate Change. We recognise that, when it comes to delivering better outcomes on the ground in relation to greenhouse gases, local governments have a particular role that they can play. That is because, firstly, within their own operations they are responsible for significant greenhouse gas emissions and, by their own conduct, they can produce a better outcome.

answer.para: Secondly, and more importantly, they have the capacity to influence a broad range of the wider community. So we established a partnership with them under the banner of Cities for Climate Change. That is an international program which I think originated in Canada some years ago in which we set benchmarks for local governments that wish to sign on. They seek to achieve those benchmarks on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and we give them credit for doing so. Since we established that partnership in Australia, Cities for Climate Change in Australia is the most successful of all such projects throughout the world. More Australian local governments have signed up to that program, more Australian local governments are committed to it and are achieving better outcomes, than anywhere else in the world, and I pay credit to local government in that regard.

The second area I want to mention—because it is obviously important—is in relation to waste management. Local governments have a critically important role to play in relation to better waste management across the Australian community. We as a government—again, in contrast to our predecessor, the Labor Party—are interested in reducing waste to landfill. But we can only do that successfully if we establish partnerships with those who collect the waste, those who process the waste and those who translate that waste into an asset with value that can therefore help create markets. Local governments are critical players through the kerbside recycling system in the delivery of better waste outcomes in Australia, and I give them great credit for that. It is not always easy, because sometimes they are the so-called meat in the sandwich: they get pressed by the householder on the one side and they get pressed by the corporations that wish to process the waste on the other. It is expensive from time to time for local governments, but it is a great service that they provide to the community in collecting that waste and, in particular, in facilitating the whole movement of recycling, in which Australia, again, has been a world leader.

The third area I want to mention—because it is not so well appreciated—is the contribution that local governments can make in relation to biodiversity and conservation. This was neglected in the past by the Labor Party—it is the same old story; they were not interested in local government. When we came to government, we began a partnership with local governments to establish how they could assist us in achieving better biodiversity outcomes, particularly in urban areas. Studies were made; we have done an audit of all local governments in Australia, and many are already committed to projects that can deliver better outcomes in this regard. Rate rebate schemes are being put in place. It is a great success story, and I compliment local government again. (Time expired)
Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Crowley asked me a question today in question time and I have some supplementary information in relation to her question. Senator Crowley asked me about the funding for medical research. A total package of $230.3 million in health and medical research grants was announced, which represents a $32.3 million increase over the year 2000. Included in the funding package is $95.3 million for new grants commencing in 2001. The successful project grants were chosen from 1,834 applications—a four per cent increase over last year. That is a success rate of around 25 per cent, which I mentioned in my answer and which demonstrates that only the very best research grant proposals are funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council.

debateinfo.title: JOINT HOUSE DEPARTMENT: GREENHOUSE CHALLENGE AWARD

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to advise honourable senators that on Friday, 1 December 2000 at the Australian Engineering Excellence Awards 2000 the Joint House Department won the inaugural Greenhouse Challenge Award—sponsored by the Australian Greenhouse Office—in the medium to small category, for organisations generating less than 100,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions per annum. The Joint House Department won this award in recognition of the percentage reduction achieved over a sustained period of 12 years, with energy consumption in Parliament House being reduced by 52 per cent and greenhouse gas emissions by 47 per cent. The award demonstrates the commitment to greenhouse gas emission reductions in Parliament House and reflects Joint House Department's focus on having Parliament House lead by example.

speech.para: This award complements and builds on the inaugural award for Best Performance of an Agency Leading by Example, made jointly by the Australian Greenhouse Office and the Department of Industry, Science and Resources to the Joint House Department on 15 March this year. That award recognised the efforts of the department in promoting its considerable efforts in maintaining the Australian Parliament House as a showcase for energy and environmental efficiency to the national and international media, and it served as a showcase for a department that is leading by example. The Joint House Department has demonstrated and articulated the substantial environmental, greenhouse and financial rewards available through a comprehensive energy and greenhouse gas abatement program and is proud to have been integrally involved in helping Australian industry in greenhouse abatement programs through technological developments. The award is a credit to Mr Adrian Guilfoyle and to all staff of the department who have contributed to this wonderful achievement, and it demonstrates the value of a long-term strategic approach to achieving lasting results for the environment.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Liquefied Petroleum Gas

talker.name: Cook, Sen Peter
Senator COOK
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked by Senators Conroy and Collins today, relating to the goods and services tax and liquefied petroleum gas.

speech.para: I refer to the answers given by Senator Kemp today in question time on questions concerning LPG.
Honourable senator interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I note the interjection: Senator Kemp has left the chamber, despite the fact that he claims to have placed on the record a series of questions that we should answer. Senator Kemp in question time is an interesting study for all budding politicians. Should a question be asked that seeks information genuinely that might have a slight taint of embarrassment for the government, Senator Kemp turns and patronises the questioner, tries to bluster his way through or answers the question with yet another question—does anything but come to grips with the real problem.

speech.para: Today we asked, as we normally do, a number of questions about real problems for real people in real Australia. In the case of all of these questions, what did we get? Bluster, answering of questions with questions and patronising responses from the minister. It is not surprising, because on LPG there is a real case to answer here for the government. Prior to the introduction of the GST, there was no excise tax on LPG in Australia. There was no tax of any sort, but now there is; there is a GST on LPG.

In the Australian Labor Party's petrol price inquiry, as we have moved around Australia and taken evidence, particularly in regional and remote Australia, about what people's concerns are about escalating petrol prices, one of the issues that has come through quite clearly in a heartfelt way from real Australians about their own personal concerns is their wanting an explanation for the skyrocketing price of LPG. We understand to some extent that petrol has gone up, but how can you explain how LPG has shot through the roof? What do you say to an ordinary Australian who says, `I converted my car, at the cost of $2,000, to consume LPG instead of petrol, but I cannot now make the saving. It was a bum investment by me. Petrol prices are high, LPG prices are high, and the cost of conversion is a cost I bear because I still cannot make the saving. The two prices have come together'?

We asked a question today on behalf of Roy and Doris Barker of Upper Beaconsfield in country Victoria. They are pensioners who rely on LPG for home energy and home fuel. They bought LPG and put the house on it when they thought that would make a saving in a thrifty way in their country household with a meagre income based on the pension. They now cannot make ends meet because of government taxation on their fuel source. What do you say to people like that? Those ordinary Australians, those real Australians, deserve a better answer than being patronised, being rubbished and being asked what the ALP is doing, when this is the government in office and this is the government that takes responsibility for what should be done.

We asked today—this is a realistic and reasonable question—whether the minister can confirm that the Saudi market contract price for LPG was, in Australian dollars, 33.42c per litre on 1 November this year. We asked the minister to explain why LPG now sells at around 60c per litre. You are buying it off the Saudis at only 33.42c, the world parity price: how come you are paying in most metropolitan areas 60c a litre and, if you want to go to some of the country areas of Australia, you are paying a damn sight more? Who is taking the rake-off? If you have got the ACCC out there as a consumer watchdog, why isn't it sooled onto LPG distributors to ensure that fair pricing applies?

At the end of the day, what about the government tax, what about the GST? LPG was not taxed before. It is taxed now, and who does it hurt? People at the lower levels of the income scale. What does the government care? Judging by what the minister said today, not at all does it worry about this. It makes pretty speeches which sound nice in this parliament but are nothing more than political debate that does not address the real questions of ordinary Australia, reasonably raised in the regions, where people are in distress because of the inability to make ends meet in their household budgets. We know about the government rip-off on petrol prices—what about the rip-off on LPG?

talk.start.para: —I find it strange that Senator Cook, the man that left us with a $10.4 billion deficit when he said that in fact the budget was balanced, should be taking note of questions with respect to the taxation component of fuel prices, a question that was asked by Senator Collins. If Senator Kemp, who answered the question—and I thought he did an excellent job in answering the question—should intimidate Senator Cook, I think Senator Kemp is doing a good job. If Senator Cook wants to ask questions, of course he should be allowed to do so, but he should not be intimidated by Senator Kemp. On the other hand, if Senator Collins wanted to take note of the answer to a question that she asked, why isn't she in the chamber? It is a strange way that you people on the other side have of dealing with politics. Just like in Queensland, I do not follow what you do. It is a strange thing.

speech.para: Above all this humbug and drivel and Labor Party speak, there is actually some sense in what the government is doing. If the Labor Party are saying they are going to drop prices and they are going to remove some taxation component, what are they going to put the cost of that on? We know that they are going to evidently fix petroleum product prices, they are going to roll back the GST and they are going to give 6.5 per cent of the allocation to the states of GST revenue to local government. This is what the senator has said on the other side: they will give 6.5 per cent to local government—

talk.start.para: —Which senator?

—Senator Mackay said it: 6.5 per cent of the GST money raised by the states goes to local government. They are some of the policies that the Labor Party have announced. But spending on health is going to be increased and spending on education, at both the secondary and tertiary levels, is going to be increased. Today we found out they are going to reintroduce some sort of dental program—more money. What is going to happen? I will tell you what is going to happen. The fact that we have made income tax cheaper for 80 per cent of Australians means that is possibly going to go up. The fact that we have raised the tax free threshold means that will be lowered. The fact that we have dropped capital gains tax by 50 per cent means that is going to go back up again. The fact that we dropped company tax this fiscal year from 36 to 34 per cent means that is going to go up again. Next year company tax goes from 34 per cent down to 30 per cent, and that is going to go up. They are going to fix petroleum prices.

speech.para: Let me tell you what is happening in Western Australia, Madam Deputy President. I know you are always interested in things Western Australian. The government over there has introduced a scheme that in fact gives a great incentive. Senator Cook has not heard of this, but the Western Australian government gives a great incentive to convert to LPG. You know what has happened? Hundreds of people are converting to LPG. Senator Cook said that this was a disincentive.

talk.start.para: —No, they are not; they are getting out of LPG.

—Here is a bloke from southern Tasmania—Senator Sherry—telling me what is going on in Western Australia. Let me tell you what is going on: the state government in Western Australia has given a $500 incentive per vehicle to change to LPG. In some instances, it would cost up to $2,500 to convert to LPG, but it is an incentive. Madam Deputy President, I want to give you some figures that will tell you what has happened in recent times. In recent times, between 26 October and 30 November—less than a week ago—320 subsidies were paid out by the state government. Since the scheme was announced, there has been a steady increase in the applications—it does not sound like it is a disincentive, Senator Cook—culminating in 150 conversions in the past two weeks alone. To put that in perspective, there were 103 LPG conversions registered for the entire month of November last year.
—Wow!

—It is a significant number of conversions: 150 conversions in the past two weeks alone, Senator Cook—more than double in the same period last year. That is wow! What is your policy on it, Senator Cook?
—We will tell you.

—If you—God forbid—ever get back into power, are you going to leave us with a black hole again? Are you going to leave us with $10 billion that you said was a balanced budget? Are you going to roll back the GST? How is it going to be paid for? It is going to be paid for by a rise in personal income tax and company tax? We know that that is what is going to happen. (Time expired)

—The example that Senator Lightfoot has outlined to the chamber of the Court Liberal government in WA having to introduce a $500 subsidy to encourage conversions from diesel and petrol to gas highlights the very problem that this federal Liberal government has caused by introducing a GST on gas. Up until 1 July, gas had no tax on it at all—no excise and no other tax. The problem is that the Liberal-National Party, on top of rising world prices, put a GST on gas. That is the very problem that Senator Lightfoot has highlighted. It would not be necessary for the Western Australian Liberal government to introduce a subsidy for gas conversion if a GST had not been put on gas in the first place. I do not believe that it will have a successful long-term impact because, during the course of the Labor Party's fuel inquiry, we heard from a number of excellent witnesses about the problems being experienced in the gas industry.

speech.para: When we were down in Trafalgar, we heard from the Gippsland Taxi Association. It is well known that most taxis in this country are fuelled by gas because, traditionally, it has been a cheaper fuel for running a vehicle, despite the problems of the extra costs of conversion—which is an average of $2,000—and despite the cost of the additional mechanical wear. For vehicles that travel long distances, it is more economic to use gas. That was certainly the case up until 1 July. The Gippsland Taxi Association told us that most taxi fleets—not just in Victoria but right around Australia—are reviewing whether or not to keep their gas cylinders in their motor vehicles because it is now more expensive to run a vehicle on gas rather than on diesel or petrol. We heard from Alexandra in the Murrundindi shire. They are a council that has 12 gas powered vehicles. Likewise, they are now questioning whether or not it is worth while keeping gas powered vehicles because they are more expensive to operate. In fact, they have made a decision to rip the gas cylinders out of their motor vehicles.

There is an example today of a minister and a government out of touch. The questions put to the Assistant Treasurer and the response reflect that not just the minister is out of touch; most of the Liberal-National Party sneered, jeered and laughed when the question was put to Senator Kemp about pensioners Roy and Doris Barker. These two pensioners—who, by the way, did not get the $1,000 pensioner bonus that the Prime Minister promised to every pensioner in this country—use bottled gas for heating. It is not just pensioners who use bottled gas; the importance of this issue, as I have mentioned, is also in respect of motor vehicles. Some trucks use gas as well, and it is also uneconomic in that area. It is particularly important in rural and regional Australia. Unfortunately, most people who live in rural and regional Australia are not connected to gas mains. Therefore they have to use bottled gas. The cost is higher because you are using a bottled product. We were given the example—which was laughed at and sneered at by members of the Liberal-National Party—of pensioners whose gas bill has gone from 44c a litre a year ago to 77c a litre in the last quarter plus GST, bringing it to 84c a litre. Their gas bill has gone up to $264.90 a quarter—it has almost doubled in one year—of which $18.20 is GST. These are pensioners in rural and regional areas, and you would at least expect the National Party to be making some sympathetic sounds and introducing some policy initiatives to help these people. But no, we got laughs and sneers about the suffering of pensioners in these circumstances.

There is a new tax on gas—which has never been taxed before—and that is the GST. The GST is a percentage tax of 10 per cent, and when it comes off a higher base, with higher world prices, it means more revenue for the government and greater costs and suffering for truck drivers, for taxi owners and for pensioners in this country.

talk.start.para: —What an incredible debate! It is typical of the Labor Party on the other side that they consistently pick one little thing, take it out of context and try to run an argument around it. First of all, let me deal in my contribution with the comments that have been made with regard to the Court government. The Court government are doing what is right and proper in their area of responsibility because they are the recipients of the GST, as are all the other states. Are we going to see the other Labor states follow suit? Not likely. It will be a very similar outcome; the same result as happened with the dairy package. There was one state government—Western Australia—that came in and supported the federal package; none of the other states did. We see this inconsistency in policy positions put before this place time and time again by the Labor Party.

speech.para: What is really getting under the Labor Party's skin now is that they have ceased to be able to look at the big picture, and that is incredibly important. We see that the ALP are disappointed by the positive reception to the GST. What has occurred during recent times? Unemployment has reached a 10-year low of 6.3 per cent. Just recently the October trade figures showed a surplus of $324 million. Did the Labor government once in 13 years produce one month of surplus? Of course they did not; they never even got remotely close to it. Economic growth is expected to exceed four per cent in 2000-01. Employment growth is now projected at three per cent for the year. Productivity growth is 2.3 per cent compared to an average of 1.4 per cent in the 1980s—in the years of Labor. You can go on quoting these figures ad infinitum on the changes we have made through our total policy projection against what the Labor Party did.

We should go back for a moment or two to the situation with LPG and the figures. The ALP are blaming everything on the GST. We saw Senator Kemp here today, in answer to that question, quite precisely and quite correctly highlight the fact from the ACCC report that 2.5c per litre was due to the introduction of the GST. What he did not dwell on today, in terms of the cost within that particular industry and the transport involved, was the removal of the fuel excise of 24c per litre for the trucks that carry it around. He did not highlight the fact that we got the wholesale sales tax completely out of the system. Those opposite just harp on one particular aspect, with the inability—which is consistent over there—to look at the whole restructuring of the taxation system, which is starting to drive an enormous amount of industry in regional and remote Australia today—

talk.start.para: —Into the ground.

—because their costs have come down in real terms. Senator Schacht is interjecting. It is particularly disappointing because he knows that personally. If you are having a chat, as we were in Poland and Hungary a couple of weeks ago, he would acknowledge that in private, but he will not in this particular place. He knows darn well that he would do that. If we look at the Saudi Arabian LPG contract price international benchmark, it rose from $US133 per tonne in February 1999 to $US325 per tonne in October 2000. That is why the price of LGP has gone up. It is no different whatsoever from the principle of the price of crude oil increasing. Unless there is further production coming on line or the demand weakens for these particular products, the prices are going to stay up there.

speech.para: The government, in their policy position, have addressed the full spectrum of matters before us. We have addressed, as Senator Lightfoot said, this huge deficit which we inherited when we came to government of significantly more than $10 billion. In fact, it was a deficit that we were told time and time again was not there. When the books were opened up, it was sitting there all right. It was this government, the Howard coalition government, that addressed that particular aspect and put this country on the road to recovery so that we could pay our own way, pay our own bills, get unemployment down and do all of the things that are necessary to have a fair and equitable society. If you look further at the details for that pensioner who was quoted here today, you will find, when you add up all the sums, that that pensioner and the rest of the pensioners are, in relative terms, better off than they were under the Labor Party. I do not have time in my contribution today to go into all of that, but I hope one day very shortly that I will have time, because the figures demonstrate the case exactly.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion by Senator Cook to take note of the practically non-answers given by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, on the issue of LPG prices in Australia. Senator Kemp could not answer the fundamental point being made in our questions that, since the GST came in, the ratio of LPG prices to petroleum prices went from roughly two to one to two-thirds of the price, which is a complete disincentive for those in Australia who previously, for economic and environmental reasons, wanted to convert their petrol powered cars to LPG. When LPG was below 40c a litre, the petrol price in Australia was between 70c and 80c in metropolitan areas. It might have been in the very high 60s, but it was generally in the 70c to 80c range. That was at two to one. Now LPG is over 60c in the city. City petrol prices are in the 90c range. So instead of being half it is now about two-thirds of the price.

speech.para: The ACCC has said that part of that price increase is the 2.5c GST that has been imposed on LPG. It still does not take account of the fact that there has been a substantial increase in the price to the consumer in Australia, and the government has done nothing to get the ACCC, as the consumer watchdog in Australia, to investigate why these prices have shot up. As Senator Cook pointed out, the world parity price in the gulf area, where most of the LPG is produced, is 33½c per litre. Yet it comes into Australia at 60c a litre, with about 2½c to 3c for the GST. Someone in the distribution chain is making a good whack of profit at the expense of the consumer. What they have done, seeing that the petrol price has gone up, also as a result in part of the increase created by the GST—a tax on a tax; a tax on the excise—is to add to the outcome. Some people in the LPG industry have said, `Well, if petrol has moved up, we can crib ours up and take an extra profit.'

As Senator Cook and Senator Sherry have pointed out, in the petroleum inquiry conducted by the Labor Party—and I went to a number of the hearings—people have pointed out that it is no longer economical to make the judgment that, because LPG is half the price of petrol and it costs up to $2,000 to convert a normal car from petrol consumption to LPG, over a period of probably up to a year you will get your money back and after that you will save money. That was a good environmental outcome as well as an economic outcome. Now, from the evidence we receive, those people are saying, `When you do your sums, it is no longer economical. It is no longer clear cut to change.'

That is a tragedy. Australia is extremely self-sufficient in LPG. We export a lot of it. It is a fuel that is much more benign to the environment than petrol or other fossil fuels. We should be doing everything to encourage more conversion in Australia to a source of fuel that we have abundant supplies of, but under the policies of this government—under its ideologically driven obsession with the GST—it has decided to penalise consumers. The evidence we received in our inquiry was that, overwhelmingly, it was small businesses—the taxidriver, the small truck operator and a whole range of charity organisations—that had converted or were thinking of converting to LPG. They now are not making the same advantage for their organisations.

This has been a distressing outcome for the Australian consumer. It has been an outcome driven by the stupidity of this government. It has adopted a Pontius Pilate attitude—there is nothing to worry about; let the consumer pay. The government has done nothing to protect the consumer from what is clearly a rip-off in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer from Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, to the question asked today by Senator Bourne in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporations.

speech.para: Madam Deputy President, I think you might agree with me that the issue of the ABC and its structure, format and programming is one which many Australians feel particularly passionate about, and I declare my hand as a card carrying member of the Friends of the ABC. For that reason, the make-up and ethos of the board are very important in determining the way in which the ABC is run and the kind of programming that we do or do not see. That is why many Australians were particularly alarmed that the management informed ABC staff in the science unit only last Thursday that the television science unit was to be disbanded and the staff made redundant.

This means that, from this point on, there will be no ABC in-house produced science programming for television. Science is an area that is particularly vulnerable to product endorsement. As we debate some very crucial pieces of legislation in the chamber this week—for instance, genetic technology—we need to keep in mind the importance of information about science being made available to the citizens of this country, particularly if we are to be the clever country to which so many politicians would have us aspire.

In 1995, a Senate select committee heard evidence from ABC whistleblowers that product placements and endorsements had become part of the lifestyle programs on the ABC. Science programs are equally as vulnerable. Drug companies, for example, supporting programs that talk about the virtues of some of the latest drug developments, offer this information as if it were independent or impartial—both of these being critical aspects of the role of the ABC in Australia. These are easy programs to make. They sell well and they sell products well. Vulnerable people seek hope in the promises of drug and pharmaceutical companies. Imagine programs made by industrial companies or biotech companies like Monsanto or Aventis talking up the benefits of GM foods. There is a great deal of concern across the world about mad cow disease, yet increasingly such issues are being made public because of the actions of concerned citizens and not because of independently produced programs about such issues by public broadcasters like the ABC.

Government funding, together with some extremely alarming management decisions, have resulted in the downgrading and defunding of important programming. Much harder programs to make—although it should be noted, not necessarily more expensive programs—are those which have always been made by the ABC science unit. These programs question and test the assertions made by these companies. They seek to investigate and to test hypotheses in accordance with the principles of scientific investigation and investigative journalism. Thanks to the disbanding of the science unit, this marks the end of the ABC's independence in science programming. It marks the beginning of the end for all ABC programs and services which are made in the same way.

Staff within the ABC are extremely concerned about what is taking place within the organisation, and we Democrats share that concern. Like many other Australians, we want a fully-funded truly independent national public broadcaster. We do not want our ABC to be the subject of questions and uncertainty about its editorial integrity or independence. Board appointments have been made that feel tainted by political allegiances. These should be referred to a joint parliamentary committee in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate select committee report, Our ABC, and the provisions of the Democrats' private member's bill. Stopping the ABC science unit from asking difficult questions may suit the government or their business friends, but will it suit them in opposition? Quantum, the award winning ABC science program, wins awards and is so cherished and valued precisely because it is independent. The ABC loses its editorial control of programs as soon as they are purchased from outside the organisation. This is a sad day for the life of the ABC and a very sad day for ABC audiences. Minister Alston should go back to the recommendations of that report and focus strongly on the legislative need for the Democrats' private member's bill on this issue, as introduced by Senator Bourne.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

para.inline: Defence Portfolio Regulations Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Regulations 2000 (No. 1), Statutory Rules 2000 No.263

quote.para: 5 October 2000
The Hon John Moore MP
Minister for Defence
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Defence Portfolio Regulations Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Regulations 2000 (No.1),Statutory Rules 2000 No. 263, that enables the call out of the Australian Defence Force in situations other than pursuant to Part IIIAAA (Utilisation of Defence Force to protect Commonwealth interests, and States and self-governing Territories, against domestic violence) of the Defence Act 1903.

As a general comment, the Committee noted that the Explanatory Statement to this instrument is brief and does not provide an item-by-item explanation of the new proposals. This is disappointing given the importance of the issues addressed in the Regulations.

New regulation 11A states that Part 3 of the Regulations ("Aid to Civilian Authorities") applies if the Defence Force is called out under "any lawful authority other than Part IIIAAA" of the Defence Act 1903. The Explanatory Statement adds only that Part 3 will apply where powers under Part IIIAAA are "not appropriate". On the basis of the instrument and the Explanatory Statement, therefore, it is difficult to determine under what situations the new regulations might apply. More specifically, under what other "lawful authority" can the Defence Force be called out?

New subregulation 11B(1) applies when the Defence Force is called out to protect "Commonwealth interests". The regulation goes on to state that the Defence Force must be utilised in a way that is "reasonable and necessary to protect the Commonwealth interest". This regulation appears to be modelled on section 51D of the Defence Act 1903. Two comments may be made about the new subregulation (which apply equally to subregulation 11B(2)).

First, like subregulation 11B(1), section 51D uses the expression "reasonable and necessary" to define the level at which the Defence Force is to be utilised. Notwithstanding this similarity, the Committee seeks your advice on whether this expression is sufficiently precise and certain.

Secondly, unlike section 51D, subregulation 11D(1) does not specify that "the Commonwealth interest" which it is reasonable and necessary to protect must be the same as the "Commonwealth interests" which have caused the Defence Force to be called out in the first place. That is, as the provision is currently worded, there is no necessary relationship between "Commonwealth interests" and "the Commonwealth interest". The Committee also seeks clarification of this point.

New subparagraph 11D(1)(b) provides that "a member of the police force" of a State or Territory may give a written request to the Chief of the Defence Force requesting that the Defence Force, which is being utilised in accordance with regulation 11B, be utilised for a particular task. This reflects a similar provision in paragraph 51F(1)(b) of the Act. The Committee seeks confirmation that it is intended that any member of the police force might make such a written request.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice as soon as possible but before 9 November 2000 when disallowance action may be initiated.
Yours sincerely
Helen Coonan
Chair
15 November 2000
Senator Helen, Coonan
Chair
Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600

Thank you for your letter of 5 October 2000 concerning the Defence Portfolio Regulations Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Regulations 2000 (No. 1) (Statutory Rule No. 263). These Regulations enable the call out of the Australian Defence Force in circumstances other than pursuant to Part IIIAAA of the Defence Act 1903.

The first matter that you raise is the inadequacy of the Explanatory Statement in relation to the Regulations. As you are aware the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Act 2000 and the associated Regulations were the culmination of a lengthy consultation process which required considerable effort both from my department and the Attorney General's Department. Given the time constraints in finalising the legislation, it was considered that an Explanatory Statement that was concise and informative was appropriate. It was not considered necessary in the circumstances to adopt an item by item approach. I trust that the following explanation in relation to certain aspects of the Regulations you have drawn to my attention will allay your concerns.
Regulation 11A states that Part 3 of the Regulations applies if the Defence Force is called out under any lawful authority other than under Part IIIAAA of the Defence Act 1903.

Part IIIAAA is not a code in relation to the calling out of the Defence Force to assist law enforcement agencies. Rather, Part IIIAAA enables assault powers or broad area security powers, or both, to be conferred on the Defence Force when called out under that Part. The new regulations are aimed at those rare situations which might arise where it might be appropriate to call out the Defence Force to assist in law enforcement, but where it would not be appropriate to confer on the Defence Force the significant powers set out under Part IIIAAA.

In relation to your query regarding the use of the expression "reasonable and necessary", this term appears routinely in Commonwealth legislation and it confines the exercise of powers. In exercising powers under the Regulations (and under Part IIIAAA) it is understood that members of the Defence Force may only use such force as is reasonable and necessary in the circumstances. That is, a degree of force that is not excessive, but is fair, proper and reasonably necessary in the circumstances. In the event that excessive force is used, a member of the Defence Force may be prosecuted under the ordinary criminal law for assault, unlawful damage or any more serious offence that might be committed.

References to "Commonwealth interest" and "Commonwealth interests" are the same. It was thought inappropriate, however, to include a definition of "Commonwealth interest" in either the Regulations or the Act as it potentially covers a broad range of matters. In developing the legislation, it was considered too limiting to define this expression. It would nevertheless include financial or proprietary interests rather than Commonwealth parliamentary power.

In relation to your final query relating to the reference to "a member of the police force" in paragraph 11D(1)(b) of the Regulations and paragraph 51F(1)(b) of the Act, it was never intended to confine the operation of these provisions to a particular rank of police officer. Of course, the individual police officer would always be under the command of his or her Police Commissioner and be given the appropriate authority in the circumstances.
I trust this information will clarify the queries that you have raised and that any proposed disallowance action of these Regulations will be avoided.
Yours sincerely
JOHN MOORE

Dear Senator Coonan
Thank you for your letter of 5 October 2000 concerning the Radiocommunications (Third Part Users Apparatus Licence) Amendment Determination 2000 (No. 2).

By way of background, the Radiocommunications (Limitation of Authorisation of Third Party Users) Determination 1995 (the substantive determination) was made on 13 December 1995 and notified in the Gazette on 20 December 1995. The substantive determination has been amended by the Radiocommunications (Third Party Users Apparatus Licence) Amendment Determination 2000 (the first amending determination) and by the Radiocommunications (Third Party Users - Apparatus Licence) Determination 2000 (No. 2) (the second amending determination).

Regarding your point about the third error referred to in the explanatory memorandum for the second amending determination, this error concerned the fact that, instead of changing the name of the substantive determination to "Radiocommunications (Third Party Users - Apparatus Licence) Determination 2000" section 1 of Schedule 1 of the first amending determination (made on 17 July 2000 and notified in the Gazette on 26 July 2000) changed the name of the substantive determination to "Radiocommunications (Third Party Users - Apparatus Licence). Amendment Determination 2000" that is, to the same name as the first amending determination itself.

This error meant that there were two determinations called "Radiocommunications (Third Party Users - Apparatus Licence) Amendment Determination 2000" one being the substantive determination and the other being the first amending determination.
