quote.para: 12 October 2000
The Hon Warren Truss MP
Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to Temporary Order No. 4 of 2000 made under subsection 43(8) of the Fisheries Management Act (1991), that amends the Southern Bluefin Tuna Management Plan 1995 by defining Southern Bluefin Tuna only in terms of species Thunnus maccoyii.

The Explanatory Statement refers to the similarities between the Southern and Northern Bluefin Tuna species, and notes the difficulty which fishers and compliance officers have had in differentiating between them. The Committee understands that because of this difficulty, the Management Plan had previously included both species within the definition of Southern Bluefin Tuna. The Committee notes that the Explanatory Statement advises that with the development of genetic testing it is now possible to positively distinguish the two types of tuna, and therefore it is no longer necessary to include both species in the Management Plan. However, it is not clear how distinctions based on genetic testing can assist fishers and compliance officers in differentiating the two species. The Committee would appreciate clarification of how this distinction will work in practice.

Helen Coonan
Chair
21 November 2000
Senator the Hon Helen Coonan
Chair
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Coonan

Thank you for your letter of 12 October 2000 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances seeking clarification on genetic testing in relation to Temporary Order No. 4 of 2000 made under subsection 43(8) of the Fisheries Management Act 1991.

Genetic testing provides. fishers with a practical means of differentiating northern bluefin tuna (NBT) and southern bluefin tuna (SBT). The Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) has implemented arrangements whereby fishers, at a relatively low cost (in relation to the value of the fish), can provide a sample of the particular fish (the tail section) to a specified and approved genetic testing facility (CSIRO) for genetic identification. Fishers use processing facilities for the preparation of tuna for export. It is at this point that, a sample is taken from the fish for genetic testing purposes. The sample is frozen and sent to the CSIRO laboratory with relevant details of the fish and its owner. Confirmation of the species identification determines whether or not the fisher will use quota. The need for quota will only apply to fish identified as SBT. Genetic identification clarifies any compliance issues in relation to the need to hold SBT quota and also allows AFMA to report on catches of NBT to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.
To date there has been no reported complications with the testing arrangements put in place by AFMA
I trust that this satisfactorily answers your question.
Yours sincerely
WARREN TRUSS

subdebateinfo.title: Parliamentary Delegation to Ireland and China

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Ireland and China, which took place from 6 to 21 July 2000. I seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement in Hansard.

quote.para: I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation which visited Ireland and China in July this year. I led the delegation in China, and the Speaker led the delegation in Ireland.

The delegation's visit provided a valuable opportunity to gauge the developments currently shaping one of Australia's most important regional neighbours. It also enabled us to consider and report on the opportunities that exist to broaden and strengthen Australia's relations with China.

The delegation was fortunate to meet with senior Chinese representatives, including the Chairman of the National People's Congress, Mr Li Peng. We were able to find out about the issues of current interest in China, particularly the attention that China is devoting to the development of its western regions and its focus on environmental issues.

One of the highlights of the visit was the opportunity that we had to travel to regional areas and discuss with regional representatives the challenges that they are facing in today's China. As part of our regional visit, we were also able to see how Australian aid was bringing fresh water to a village and how it was helping to improve the life of children in an orphanage in southern China.

On behalf of the delegation, I wish to thank the National People's Congress and all who contributed to the success of our visit. The delegation is sure that those who have primary responsibility for managing Australia's relations with China will find the observations in the report useful in strengthening those relations for the mutual benefit of both countries.
I commend the report to the Senate.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Crane, I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry (High Quality Beef Export to the European Union) Order 2000, together with the Hansard record of the committee's proceedings and documents presented to the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —I understood that Senator Crane was going to speak to this report as chair of the committee. This issue that was considered by the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee is a rather complex one. It involved the consideration of a decision made by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on 23 December last year in which he announced that there would be a substantial change to the allocation system for European Union high quality beef exports from Australia. The shorthand reference for that is EUHQB. I note that the other day, in answer to a question from me during question time, Senator Alston was mistaken. I think he may have thought that EUHQB stood for European Union headquarters in Brussels. It does not; as I said, it refers to the fact that Australia has an entitlement to export 7,000 tonnes of high quality beef into the European market each year. While this is only a small proportion of our overall meat exports, it is nevertheless a prime market, and a significant premium is paid for that high quality beef.

speech.para: The background to this is set out in great detail in the Senate committee's report. I would like to compliment the staff of the committee for this excellent report. Normally, as I think all senators are aware, the reports of legislation committees on particular bills before the Senate are often fairly brief because they are generally quite confined in the issues that are examined. But, for this report, it was necessary to go into some detail about the history of the way in which the allocation system had worked in previous years in order to understand the implications and impact of the minister's decision last December when he changed the arrangements. The issue came to the attention of the committee because a number of companies involved in the export of high quality beef to the European Union market believed they had been unfairly disadvantaged because of the minister's decision.

I will very quickly summarise what happened. In February 1999 the then minister, Mr Vaile, requested the Red Meat Advisory Council to conduct a review of the administrative arrangements for the allocation of the quota. At that time, the quota was allocated under what was called an 80/20 allocation system. It would take me some time to explain that in detail but, effectively, the quota was allocated based upon performance of exporting beef into the European Union market in the previous year, as well as taking into account a proportion, 20 per cent, of export into other markets.

There was a system in operation whereby companies that could not for one reason or another fulfil the entire quota they had been allocated would in turn sell that proportion of the quota on what was called a `lend' basis to other companies. So if companies could not meet their full quota during one year they would lend it to another company, and they would get it back again at the end of the year. The Red Meat Advisory Council was asked to review this system because there had been lobbying and complaints about the way in which the system worked. What happened is that, in June 1999, the minister sought advice on how the allocation might be made for the first half of the 1999-2000 year. The Red Meat Advisory Council recommended to the minister that the existing arrangements be retained for the current year, 1999-2000, until it had completed its full review. The minister did not accept the advice of the Red Meat Advisory Council and went ahead and issued directions as to how the quota would be allocated for a portion of the year.

A lot of things happened after June and many meetings were held with the industry. But the primary point is that it got to a stage in late 1999 where the Red Meat Advisory Council's views had not been accepted by the minister and they had to look at a range of proposals. It appears, and an allegation has been made, that some participants in the industry had inside knowledge about what was going to occur. On 23 December the minister made his announcement about the new system. He decided to go to a system which is known as the shipper of record rather than the old performance based system. But the problem was that, even though he announced that decision on 23 December 1999, the basis for calculation for the next year was on the full year going back to May 1999. In other words, it had a retrospective effect. There were companies that had sold quota between May and December 1999 that suddenly found that they had lost for all time any entitlement to that quota. This, of course, they believed placed them at somewhat of a disadvantage vis-a-vis others who had purchased that quota. It was also the case that there had been a long history that any changes to the allocation system should be made with 12 months notice so that the industry could adjust. That was not followed in this case. As a result a major problem was raised with the committee.

I think I will leave my remarks at that. I know that Senator Crane and Senator O'Brien wish to speak on this issue. It appears now that the industry as a whole is in favour of the new system. It is on that basis that I withdraw my disallowance motion. People are prepared to accept the new system for the future, but are still concerned about the fact that they have been disadvantaged in this forthcoming year. I will leave it to Senator Crane and Senator O'Brien to take up where I have left off.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak on the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee inquiry report into the Australian meat and livestock industry, I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a number of points. The first point I would make, is that this inquiry was rather complex and, in some areas, rather difficult to understand. It was not until the committee really got to the intricacies of some of the workings in the meat industry and how the EU entitlement had worked over the years, that I—and will not speak for the rest of the committee—came to grips with the changes and the reasons for the supposed changes. As Senator Forshaw said in his closing remarks, there was industry unanimity in terms of where they wanted to get. The dispute was about how they got there.

speech.para: There are two issues for the committee and me that I particularly want to highlight. One is the issue of retrospectivity and the impact on some of those people who have been in the trade. One witness to the inquiry, Mr Hines, said that he had been in the industry for 28 years. The other question was the issue of prior knowledge and whether or not anybody had been able to take commercial advantage of that. I will come back to that particular question, but I have to say that I do not think we will ever be able to prove it one way or the other. But when you analysed everything in front of you in terms of some of the buying habits that occurred I guess you had to be, at the very least, suspicious that there had been some prior knowledge and that what would be termed in the corporate world as insider trading could have occurred, even if it did not occur. That was the basis behind some of our recommendations, which I will come to.

With respect to the issue of retrospectivity, technically the advice from the Auditor-General's office probably is correct in terms of what the quotas are and who owns them. But, in a commercial sense, with a practice that had gone on for 20-odd years, there is no doubt that some people did suffer commercial retrospectivity in the changeover. This happened for the simple reason that they sold some of their quotas as an outright sale and they sold some of their quotas as what is known as a lend sale, which returns at the end of the year, with every expectation that they would come back to them at the end of the year. I have no doubt at all that there was commercial retrospectivity and it was unfair to some of the people involved in the process.

The other issue was the question of prior knowledge. I particularly want to draw the attention of the Senate to clauses 328 and 329, which spell this out very clearly. Two things occurred. Firstly, an AFFA report was released and was not marked confidential. One has to question whether or not that document went beyond the recipients of it, although when some of them received it and passed it on to their own members they did mark it confidential. Secondly, a series of conversations—we are not sure how many, but at least two or three, if not more—occurred between Mr Read, who was the principal officer from AFFA, and other people in the meat industry, which did give them knowledge. Just how people used that knowledge is open to speculation. It is worth noting, as you will see in clause 329—which was corrected or updated evidence that was put by the committee—that, having been told that there had been no trading by a particular company, we saw quite clearly after a particular conversation that there was trading by that particular company. As I said earlier in my comments, we will never be able to prove that. I do not even know whether or not it was just a commercial decision or whether it was `good guessing power'—which is a quote from Mr Roseby—or whether it just happened. But the fact is that the question is there, and we have decided on a safety first proposition which we are putting to the minister in this report to deal with this particular issue.

Senator Forshaw has just announced his withdrawal of the disallowance motion, that the status quo will remain for this year. But we are recommending that there be a variation in the way it is done in the future.

That has a number of benefits. The first benefit is that it will totally get rid of the retrospectivity—it will not exist. It will totally get rid of the prior knowledge question, because it will all be done after the events that have taken place. On top of that, those people known as `traders' in the industry who used to buy and sell quota will not be rewarded for quota they are not trading in beef sales to the EU. It is spelled out very clearly in recommendation 3:

quote.para: The Committee recommends that where exporters choose not to re-enter the EU HQB market in 2001/2002 through a decision of their own not to meet EU accreditation standards, their uncommitted quota allocation should be available to EU accredited packer exporters and non-packer exporters currently in the market. Allocation of uncommitted quota should be on the basis of applications to the Secretary of AFFA.

speech.para: One of the principal reasons—not the only one—why this issue was before my committee was purely and simply the concern that some people were making a profit who were not really involved in the meat industry and were trading in just quotas.

My criticism of this process really goes to the man in charge of the process—Mr Read. In July there was a package of unanimous recommendations from RMAC. If that had been presented, in my view, in the proper way and its total concept to the minister, we could well have had a different result and we may not have been here today—in fact, we would not be standing here today—with this particular report.

With regard to the handling of this at a higher level within the department, they need to look at better and more precise processes into the future so that we avoid the type of things that we have seen and we avoid an inconclusive recommendation going to the minister. It became clear out of this issue that `packer exporters' and `non-packer exporters' were terms which most people in the context did not understand. There are two forms of people who trade with the EU and the EU beef entitlement: those who actually do the slaughter, arrange the market and sell the product, and the others. Sangers were a classic example of this—working with Bindaree Beef. They did the actual marketing and the selling in the EU, whereas the abattoir was a separate operation and was done under contract, and that was the split between the two.

At the end of the day, our inquiry is recommending—and this is going to be adopted now because of the withdrawal of the disallowance motion—that the current arrangements stay for this year. We return for the establishment next year to a performance based operation. That then goes to the shipper of record to operate into the future. If you are going to be in the EU special beef allocation, then you have to actually be in there, you have got to trade, you have to be part of the process—you cannot profit on both sides. If that was adopted, it would become a good arrangement and it would be a fair arrangement. I think it would overcome those concerns the committee had—the two things we found very difficult to live with. One was the question of commercial retrospectivity and the other—as the evidence put before us indicated—was the potential for the use of prior knowledge. I will make no judgment as to whether or not that was utilised, but one has to be suspicious when you see the buying habits which occurred following that information and all the data that we had put on the table.

talk.start.para: —Can I say, in relation to this report, that I am not sure whether the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee does more work than any of the other committees of the Senate or whether it just seems that way—others will make that judgment, I am sure, and everyone will have their own view. But it really is the case that this committee does have a larger workload, and the reason is that there has been a failure by successive ministers in this government to properly administer this portfolio.

speech.para: This report that has just been tabled is yet another example of what is now a very long list of very poor ministerial decisions in the agriculture portfolio. Not only have these decisions being built on poor public policy, but they have also cost affected industries money—a lot of money in this case, I suspect. In some cases, we in this place—and I include government senators—have been able to sort out the messes and save successive ministers from themselves; but in others we have not, and the agriculture industries and farmers have been forced to put their hands in their pockets as a result.

I can give you some examples: the import protocols for cooked chicken meat. The draft protocols were flawed, required cooking temperatures were too low and the cooking time too short. The then minister, Mr Anderson, was only saved from signing off on these flawed protocols by a call from a journalist from the Australian Financial Review, who pointed out to the minister's office the disaster, both political and quarantine, that would follow. In the end, the right protocols were put in place and, as a result of work done by this committee, of course that happened—no thanks to the minister, I must say.

When the Australian pork industry was under assault from a flood of imported produce and sought relief in terms strictly in accordance with WTO obligations, the industry was told to forget it. In the end, the government, however, under pressure in this chamber particularly, and from the pork industry, did provide the industry with some assistance, but it was quite late coming and quite disjointed. We have seen, as we will hear later this week in the case of AWRAP, that successive ministers took decisions that led to the Cape Wools fiasco, and we have not heard the end of that matter.

Turning to my state and the drought in the Tasmanian Central Highlands, despite the plight of farmers in this region of Tasmania, the government argued for, I think, two years about detail. Rather than facilitate the assessment process for assistance to these farmers, the government worked to frustrate that process. In the end, the minister conceded that their claim was legitimate. Regarding OJD, again it was this committee that forced the minister's hand. Mr Anderson held out until the bitter end against taking a national approach to what is clearly a national problem. It was an inquiry undertaken by this committee that forced Mr Anderson's hand on the matter. I note in passing that we had a hearing on the matter this morning. The government has again taken its eye off the ball in relation to the OJD problem. Hundreds of farmers are suffering both economic and social hardship as a result. The committee is again looking at this important matter and it appears that we will have to sort out this problem as well.

Turning to the question of EU beef quotas—I stress, for the benefit of Senator Alston, that this is European Union high-quality beef—we now have another mess, a mess which, in this case, is very much of the government's own making. Again, this committee has had to look at the matter and has had to come up with what is an equitable solution. It should be stressed that the committee's findings are unanimous, except for the additional comment which the Labor Party makes in its addendum to the report. For the sake of the Hansard I will read it:

quote.para: The Labor Party notes with concern that the failure of the former Minister, Mr Vaile, and the current Minister, Mr Truss, to properly manage the change in quota arrangements has significantly disadvantaged a number of industry participants.

The Labor Party notes Mr Vaile was presented with a set of unanimous recommendations from his key industry advisory body, RMAC, on 2 July 1999. But the then Minister failed to act on that advice and the matter remained unresolved until two days before Christmas, some eight months into the trading year.

It is the view of the Labor Party that a timely response by Mr Vaile and Mr Truss to the July recommendations from the RMAC could have resulted in a more timely and equitable outcome for all EU HQB participants.

speech.para: Listening to what Senator Crane has just said, the issue of retrospectivity arose because of the delay. RMAC was a body that was appointed by the government to advise the minister. Then it was Mr Vaile and there was a change in ministers. It was a body of the government's own making. It drew together the various groups within the industry. They were charged with the responsibility of coming up with a recommendation, and they did. They came up with a unanimous recommendation. Had it been acted upon when it was received, we would not have had the inquiry that we had because there would not have been the hue and cry that occurred in the industry when the minister announced the decision months later, particularly when the decision retrospectively affected the entitlements—what I consider would almost have been a property entitlement—of quota holders.

Whatever the motivation of the minister, if the minister had a view that there was something wrong in the history of trading with quotas in the industry, the minister should have been very forthcoming and charged RMAC with dealing with that in the context of the report they made to the minister on 2 July. But it only became clear later that the minister had decided that there was another way that the matter ought to proceed. Because it took until 23 December to announce that and effectively it was going to recognise the temporary arrangements that quota holders had put in place because they had traded their quota entitlements on what the industry terms `a lends basis'—in other words, they sell with a right to receive back quota entitlements—the minister put in place arrangements whereby those people who had purchased quota effectively for one year's use got that use on an ongoing basis. Those people who made the sale with the understanding that they would get it back, as they had every year previously, found that their rights were to disappear. Who could be surprised that the industry would react in the way that it did? There are suggestions that there will be litigation. There have been suggestions that there was prior knowledge and that some people purchased quota on the basis that they knew what the decision was and, therefore, they were effectively doing something akin to insider trading to their advantage and to the disadvantage of quota holders.

In the two minutes available to me I will attempt to deal with what Senator Crane has said. The committee has effectively said, `We are not going to support a disallowance because, if the regulation was disallowed, the minister would then be in a position to put in place whatever he wanted anyway.' Secondly, the industry was saying, `We can live with this arrangement for a couple of years, but we have to have a means of returning to an equitable redistribution of the quotas.' What the committee has recommended is that, at the end of that two-year period, there be another look at the allocation of quotas with regard to a greater history period of actual traders in quota so that, whilst the minister may have some real concerns about people who simply trade in quota but never actually trade in beef, there can be an equitable addressing of the problem so people who may temporarily have traded in quota because of particular circumstances but who have a long history of trading can get back into the game and can have their position properly considered—so that quotas can be allocated, including in Senator Crane's state of Western Australia. Currently they are excluded. There are no quotas held in the hands of any of the abattoirs in Western Australia.

There are accreditation issues involved here as well. It is a complex area and I will not be able to deal with it in the time available to me. But I would hope that the minister accepts that this unanimous recommendation from all of the parties in the committee, the government senators included, is worth while having a good hard look at. I hope the minister does not just take the opportunity of saying, `I will do what I like and damn the committee,' because it will then be a matter that this committee has to visit again. It will add to the workload of the committee and we will end up with other recommendations put to the government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Murray)—by leave—agreed to:

motion.para: That general business notice of motion No. 717 standing in the name of Senator Lees for today, relating to the introduction of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 2000, be postponed till 27 February 2001.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I acknowledge the tabling today of the annual report from the Family Law Council for 1999-2000. In doing so, I would ask senators, if they have the opportunity, to take a look at some of the rich statistics that it provides, particularly in relation to the incidence of both marriage and divorce and how that reflects on the way the trend in both those areas has been moving since 1976. For example, on page 20 of the report the council notes that the most recent statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that the marriage and divorce rates increased slightly in 1999. The marriage rate per 1,000 in the population increased from 5.9 in 1998 to six in 1999, after a slight decrease in 1996 and 1997. The divorce rate increased from 2.7 per 1,000 in 1998 to 2.8 in 1999. It is interesting to note that that is a tiny and marginal increase in the divorce rate.

The more interesting statistic, however, is when you compare that to the divorce trend over recent years. The council notes that there were some 52,600 divorces in 1999, representing a small increase, of just 2.4 per cent, on the number of divorces in 1998. But in the overall picture it represents a 27 per cent increase on 1989 compared with an increase of just seven per cent between 1989 and 1999.

One of the issues that might concern us is the way we can look at that in addition to the matrix provided by the council in relation to the statistics it has on where it waivers court fees. From 1 December 1996 a filing fee of $500 has been payable under regulation 11 of the Family Law Regulations Act of 1984. Since the introduction of that fee, roughly 30 per cent of people, or a third, seeking application for divorce had the fee waived. Yet just a few years later, in the year 2000, that is nudging 52 per cent, or just over 50 per cent. I think the area of concern there for legislators is the possible link—and I stress possible—between economic difficulties, or financial circumstances, and the pressure or need to divorce. We note, for example, that the level of marriages in 1976 was 109,973 couples and yet in 1999 it was 114,300—only an apparent marginal increase, given that that was accompanied by a significant increase in population within the nation over that time.

When it comes to children, the current statistics show that over the period 1989 to 1999 the percentage of divorces granted where children under 18 years of age were involved fell from 55 per cent to 54 per cent, only a marginal drop. Yet in terms of raw numbers what that meant for recent years—particularly in regard to the average number of children of divorcing couples in 1999—was that 53,444 children, an immense number of children, were involved in divorce cases. In some ways the statistics that have been shown here today through this annual report validate the decision the Senate took recently to support the legislation presented by the Attorney-General for the introduction of prenuptial agreements for married partners. We have them already for de facto partners but not for married partners. Of course, appropriate safeguards were placed within that legislation to ensure that one partner in a particular relationship could not be subject to some form of abuse in terms of the imbalance of power within that relationship which may occur.

We learn, too—particularly in relation to children in terms of an overall picture of Australia—from a report by Michelle Gunn and Barclay Crawford, parts of which were published in the Australian newspaper on 17 November this year, that the early thirties are now officially the most popular age for women to have children. In 1999, women aged 30 to 34 had more babies than those aged 25 to 29. This is the first time that peak fertility has become a `thirty-something' phenomenon. If the trend continues, by 2002 the majority of babies will be born to women aged 30 and over and by 2008 it will be 58 per cent. There were 248,900 births in Australia last year. The total fertility rate is at a historical low of just 1.75 babies per woman. It was 1.76 in 1998.

We have also seen, in terms of the overall picture of Australia, that one in three women is now waiting until her thirties to have her first child. One in seven babies is born to a single mother and 28 per cent to unmarried mothers. About 65 per cent of single mothers are over the age of 30 and fewer than three per cent are teenagers. Twenty-eight per cent of women will remain childless. Almost half of the women seeking IVF are aged over 35 and the average 24-year-old woman will fall pregnant within a year of trying, while a 39-year-old can take an average of three years. There are further statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, as reported by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. Given the general trend, it is imperative that governments acknowledge the changing nature and structure of relationships—particularly the levels of marriage and divorce and also of those choosing to have children or not—and ensure that there are appropriate legislative frameworks within which to do that.

I note also from page 49 of the report from the council—where they are discussing recommendations in letters of advice from the council to the Attorney-General still under consideration—that there still appear to be some outstanding issues which we in the Senate should continue to monitor. For example, in relation to parenting plans, in a joint letter of advice produced with the National Alternative Dispute Resolution Advisory Council, the council advocated to the Attorney that division 4 of part VII of the Family Law Act 1975 should be amended specifically to do two things: firstly, to encourage the use of parenting plans and the use of consent orders where a party requires that elements of the plan be enforceable and, secondly, to repeal the registration provisions.

In response to that, the Attorney has noted, in a letter of return to the council, that that would be a matter for detailed consideration—or at least it was in the Attorney's brief to the council in June this year. I am not sure of the extent to which division 4 of part VI may or may not have been dealt with recently by the Senate in changes to the Family Law Act, but I suspect that part of that may have been dealt with in contact orders, on which the Senate had some debate, and in a decision over the structure in which the courts may apply some form of reprimand, ultimately leading to jail, to those recalcitrant parents denying the other partner access to children.

I think I am perhaps confusing two different issues there. However, it is worth noting that, since that act as been amended, we now have the three-tiered structure where there are remedial programs for recalcitrant parents, and the courts have the final option of eventually jailing a recalcitrant parent for not providing the appropriate contact orders to what under those circumstances would be an estranged partner. In a general sense, family law is a very complex and very difficult area, particularly because it is so emotive in terms of finances and children. I compliment the Chair, Des Semple, and his colleagues for dealing with what is a very difficult area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the 37th report entitled Six treaties tabled on 10 October 2000, together with the Hansard record of the committee's proceedings, minutes of proceedings and submissions received by the committee. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: I seek leave to have my tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

quote.para: Madam President, the report I have just presented contains the results of the review by the Treaties Committee of 6 proposed treaty actions tabled in Parliament on 10 October 2000, those being:

speech.para: · a Protocol concerning International Registration of Marks;
· an Agreement with Egypt regarding Cooperation in the Protection of Children;
· a Double Taxation Agreement with the Russian Federation;
· various Acts of the Universal Postal Union; and
· Amendments to the Schedule of the International Whaling Convention.

quote.para: In our report we express support for each of these treaty actions.
There were two additional proposed treaty actions presented to Parliament on 10 October which we have not yet reported on:

speech.para: · a proposed Agreement on Privileges and Immunities for the Tribunal on the Law of the Sea; and
· the 1998 Statute of the International Criminal Court.

quote.para: I hope we will be able to resolve our position in relation to the Agreement on Privileges and Immunities for the Tribunal on the Law of the Sea by the end of the week, but as Parliament is rising for the summer adjournment on Thursday we will not be able to present our findings until the New Year.
There is, however, much more to be done in relation to our review of the Statute for the International Criminal Court.
We have held one hearing on the Statute so far and are presently receiving written submissions from individuals and non-government organisations, all of which warrant careful consideration.

We are also keen to review the legislation that the Government has developed to give domestic effect to the Statute. Our view is that if we are to report on whether ratifying the Statute is in the national interest, we need also to consider the impact of ratification on our domestic law.

Accordingly, we have written to the Attorney-General asking that the Bill be referred for our consideration at the same as we are examining the National Interest Analysis for the Statute. We have not yet received a response from the Attorney.
I think it unlikely that we will be able to report on this matter until late in the Autumn sittings.
Turning back to Report 37, I would like to focus on two of six treaty actions we have reviewed: the Protocol on Registration of Marks and the Agreement with Egypt on the Protection of Children.
The Protocol on the Registration of Marks will in our view have a very beneficial effect on the handling of trademark registration.

Under the existing regime, in order to protect trade marks in overseas markets an Australian trade mark owner must register and maintain trademark protection in the trade mark office of each particular country where protection is required. This may involve filing multiple applications in languages other than English and the payment of government and legal fees on each occasion—a time consuming, expensive and not fully effective procedure.

Under the proposed Protocol the process will be streamlined allowing Australian trademark owners the ability to file single applications in Australia, in English, and pay fees to one office to obtain trademark protection in all, or any of the other countries that are Parties to the Protocol.

The effective implementation of the Protocol will require IP Australia (the relevant Commonwealth agency) to maintain a continuing program of business education about the advantages of international trademark protection and about how to obtain the protection afforded by the Protocol. This type of support is particularly important for small export focussed business that may be without in-house expertise this area.
We also support the aims of the Agreement with Egypt concerning the Protection of Children.

This bilateral agreement establishes a mechanism to assist nationals of either country whose children have been abducted to the other country, or where difficulties with contact between a parent and child have arisen. At present, parents seeking to re-establish contact with a child who has been `illicitly transferred and not returned' from one country to another have access only to consular assistance.

The Agreement is in Australia's interests because Egypt is not a party to the Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, so the mechanisms and protocols available under the Convention cannot be used in cases involving Egypt. Egypt is one of several countries with child custody laws based on religious law and is unlikely to become a party to the Child Abduction Convention.

Under the Agreement, a joint consultative commission will be established, enabling parents to seek assistance from officials in both countries with direct knowledge of and expertise in, the administrative and judicial structures in each country.

The Commission will assist in locating children who have been abducted, as well as encouraging dialogue and the amicable resolution of issues between parents. In addition, it will facilitate the issue of travel documents to parents and children seeking to be reunited.
Madam President, as we are nearing the end of the parliamentary year, I would like to make a few comments about the work of the Treaties Committee in the last twelve months.
I think we can reasonably lay claim to being the most productive committee in the Parliament. In the life of this Parliament, we have produced 20 reports - 10 since this time last year.
Although we have tabled a report today, we still have 6 inquiries on foot. We are reviewing:

speech.para: · the Kyoto Protocol on Greenhouse Gas emissions;
· Australia's relationship with the World Trade Organisation;
· Australia's extradition law, policy and practice;
· the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety; and the two proposed treaties I referred to earlier
· the Statute of the International Criminal Court; and
· the privileges and immunities of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea.

quote.para: This is a substantial workload by any standards.

I would like to thank my colleagues on the Committee for having contributed so effectively over the last twelve months to the process of encouraging wider community understanding of and debate about the impact of treaties on the lives of Australians.
I commend this latest report, Report 37, to the Senate.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Parliamentary Delegation to the 104th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference and a Bilateral Visit to Vietnam

talk.start.para: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 104th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held at Jakarta from 15 to 21 October 2000 and a bilateral visit to Vietnam from 22 to 27 October 2000. I seek leave to move a motion in respect of the report.

speech.para: I want to highlight a few matters regarding both the conference and the bilateral visit. The conference was held in Jakarta and 108 countries participated in it. The Australian parliament can be proud of the manner in which we as a delegation as a whole conducted ourselves. We were very ably led by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Hon. Neil Andrew. I will not go to each and every one of the matters in which the delegation participated other than to take advantage of the fact that I am speaking in this place by highlighting that I participated in the study committee that looked at the prevention of military and other coups against democratically elected governments. I actually spoke to the conference on that matter and participated, as I said, in the study committee that drafted a resolution which was unanimously carried by the conference at its final session on the Thursday. During my speech, I made a point about the fact that Fiji had been suspended from participation in the conference because of the recent coup that had occurred in that place. As I indicated, all members of the delegation played a role in the various subject matters that were discussed and debated at the conference. The resolutions of the conference are very adequately detailed in the body of the report.

On the matter of the committee to promote respect for international humanitarian law, I just want to highlight that the handbook that has previously been adopted by the committee has been presented to the Australian Parliamentary Library. It was originally produced in English. It has now been translated into French, Spanish, Arabic, Russian, Japanese, Serbian and Indonesian, and a ceremony was held to hand over the Indonesian translation of the book. Plans are in place to translate it into Hindi, Portuguese, German and Hebrew, and those will be available shortly. There are plans—and I participated in meetings of officers of the second committee of the IPU on preparing these—to begin work, together with the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, on the preparation of a handbook on international refugee protection, a handbook which we intend to present to the council in 2001, the year of the 50th anniversary of the corresponding convention.

All in all, as I said in my opening remarks, Australia can be very proud of the work of the delegation so ably led by the Speaker. We participated in all facets of the conference but also played constructive roles in the various geopolitical groups that were represented in the Asia-Pacific group and the Twelve-Plus group, which is mainly representative of the European nations. We gained some respect in all of those committees, and respect has been gained not only in the conference I attended but in the many conferences preceding it. The next conference will be held in Havana, Cuba in April 2001.

I want to make some remarks about the delegation's visit to Vietnam. When honourable senators get copies of the report, they can refer to page 37, which shows two pictures of the very magnificent My Thuan Bridge in Vinh Long Province, Vietnam. It is a very significant aid package that Australia has given to that nation. Australia regards Vietnam as a very important neighbour in the Asia-Pacific region, which we are part of. We were one of the first countries to restore a bilateral aid program to Vietnam following the withdrawal of the Vietnamese presence from Cambodia and the signing of the Paris peace accords. Currently we have a commitment of $260 million in aid over four years to assist that nation to develop. The total assistance of some $70 million per year makes Vietnam Australia's third largest partner in development cooperation. The My Thuan Bridge over one arm of the Mekong River is a magnificent facility and a magnificent piece of infrastructure. Australia contributed two-thirds of the $90 million cost of the bridge; the rest was contributed by Vietnam. With the completion of the bridge, Australia's assistance in this sector will increasingly support small-scale infrastructure, agriculture and capacity building for rural development in the region. Whilst we were on our way to visit the bridge, we witnessed at first hand some of the flooding that that nation has been afflicted with in recent times, flooding that Australia is now experiencing in New South Wales. The aid that we are giving to that country is being very well received.

Vietnam continues to be a very important trading partner to Australia. It was our 32nd largest export market in 1999-2000. Two-way trade totalled $2.11 billion, up from $1.32 billion in 1998-99. Australia's exports to Vietnam reached $384 million, up from $349 million in 1998-99—an increase of 10 per cent. Major Australian exports to Vietnam include cereals, flour, dairy products, aluminium, copper, electrical machinery and equipment, medical and pharmaceutical products, refined petroleum and motor vehicle parts. Another area of importance to Australia is education. In Ho Chi Minh City, Australia's RMIT University has recently been licensed to operate Vietnam's first fully foreign owned university, which will commence in 2003. Many Australia-Vietnam education and training collaborations are under negotiation. Education and training was Australia's single largest export to Vietnam in 1999 and, excluding in-country activities, is estimated to be worth in excess of $70 million. While we were in Hanoi, we took the opportunity to visit the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. ACIAR promotes research into sustainable agricultural production and natural resource management in developing countries. ACIAR's activities are funded from Australian official development assistance. Current financial commitment by ACIAR in Vietnam is just over $3 million spread over 32 active projects.

Three million dollars is not an insignificant amount of money but they certainly do make the money stretch a long way, as we found out when we visited Danang on the second day of the visit. We proceeded by car to Tam Ky and Tra My and looked at some of the infrastructure projects that Australia has assisted in funding. The Tra My project is worthy of mention because its aim is to reduce poverty in isolated ethnic minority communes by providing access to transport, education, health care, markets and agricultural extensions. The hospital that we visited had basic medical services and was servicing a population of some 53,000 people. Australia has provided $566,900 through the NGO Vietnam-Australia Program, which is under the supervision of the Adventist Development Relief Agency Vietnam.

We also had a look at two bridges, one at Tra Doc and one at Tra Bui, which were constructed using AusAID funding. The suspension bridges cost around $120,000 each to construct, and they provide a lifeline between villages on either side of very fast flowing rivers that cut deep gorges through the mountainside. They provide the people with the ability to take produce to market, they enable children to attend the local primary school and health centre and they enable people to attend to other basic needs. While in Danang, we witnessed the signing of a memorandum of understanding on a renewable energy project between Danang and the International Centre for Application of Solar Energy, CASE, which is a Perth based operation. Again, one can be very proud of what Australia is contributing.

The highlight of the visit to Vietnam was of course the visit to the My Thuan Bridge, which I spoke about earlier. It was constructed by Baulderstone Hornibrook Engineering Pty Ltd, with Maunsell McIntyre Pty Ltd as the supervising engineers. The bridge was completed ahead of schedule in March this year. It was within budget and it was constructed with an exemplary safety record. The bridge project provided continuous training for Vietnamese construction workers, resulting in significant transfers of skills.

Finally, I want to give some thanks particularly to the Ambassador to the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, His Excellency Michael Mann, to his wife, Monique, to the Consul-General in Ho Chi Minh City, Lisa Filipetto, and to the very professional staff both in Ho Chi Minh City and in Hanoi. They provided us with magnificent briefings and explanations on what was happening around us. I have mentioned the leadership of the delegation leader, the Speaker, Neil Andrew. I cannot but mention the work of the secretary of the committee, Mr Peter Keele. Nothing was too hard for Peter to keep the delegation fully informed of what was happening to us, and our every need was met by Peter. In the early part of our report we also acknowledge the assistance given by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Parliamentary Library and the various sections of the parliament who made this delegation a success. Of course, success will be judged in years to come rather than now, but I am pleased to have been part of a delegation that has contributed to the benefit of Australia in the region, both at the conference and in Vietnam.
