cognateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN RESEARCH COUNCIL (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 30 November.
AUSTRALIAN RESEARCH COUNCIL BILL 2000
The bill.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrats amendment No. 1:

quote.para: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (after line 19), at the end of paragraph (a), add:
(iv) that may, on its own initiative, conduct inquiries into matters related to research and research education and publish the results; and

speech.para: In its 1999 white paper `Knowledge and innovation: a policy statement on research and research training', the federal government proposed a series of reforms designed to create a strong and vibrant research base. Setting aside some of the concerns held by the Democrats about other reforms proposed in the white paper, we of course support the notion of a strong, vibrant and independent research council able to, in the words of the white paper, `play a more strategic role in providing advice on the allocation of funding'. As I set out in my speech in the second reading debate last Thursday when it was hastily brought on in the midst of the Gene Technology Bill chaos, the Democrats do not believe that this legislation will create a stronger and more independent research council but believe that a number of the provisions in the legislation actually undermine the aim which the government purports to have.

The first Democrat amendment seeks to address one of the fundamental problems in this reform model set out in the bill by restoring the power of the ARC to initiate its own inquiries on matters relating to research and research education. We fail to see how without this power the ARC would be able to meet the expectations accorded it in the white paper, including the strategic role in developing strategic planning for research funding and education. The bill currently provides that the ARC may carry out such inquiries under ministerial discretion—or direction, I am sorry. That is a bit of a Freudian slip but probably appropriate in relation to this bill. This raises additional concerns about the ability of the ARC to be a sufficiently independent entity to provide impartial advice on the matters it is investigating. In removing the power to initiate inquiries originally provided by the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988, the federal government have departed from the model of the National Health and Medical Research Council. I am wondering whether the minister could indicate what flaws there are in the operation of the power by the NHMRC. What flaws have they identified that have actually led them to remove the power from the ARC? I am just wondering whether there is a particular rationale for the removal of that ability.

The importance of research and development to Australia's future innovative and economic performance is becoming increasingly apparent, and of course we are hearing rhetoric in relation to that aim all the time not only from the government but also from the opposition. Whether or not that commitment is going to be matched with adequate funding and resources and a strong, independent research centre and research body in the form of the ARC is questionable.

It is important that we get the reform of the Australian Research Council right to enable it to play the central role which the government has accorded it in directing Australia's research efforts. This amendment restores a key tool for the ARC in performing that function. The words that I seek to include in the objects part of the bill are:

quote.para: ... that may, on its own initiative, conduct inquiries into matters related to research and research education and publish the results ...

speech.para: That is the crux of that amendment. It is not a new notion. We seek to have that reinstated into this bill because we think it is important to achieving the very objectives which the government has outlined in its own white paper. I hope that the opposition will support that amendment. I ask the minister: what is the rationale or the justification for removing that opportunity or power of the ARC?

talk.start.para: —The opposition support this Democrat amendment. In general, our approach in dealing with this bill should be summarised at this point. Given that the issues are obviously significant, I would hate to think that, because we do not give a detailed response to every proposition put, there could be any implication drawn that we do not regard these issues as serious. At this time in the parliamentary schedule, there is some pressure on the legislative program. Our intention is not to go to these matters in great detail. I trust, Senator Stott Despoja, that we will be able to conclude these matters by 6.30 p.m. tonight.
—That depends on whether you are bringing on the ESOS legislation.
—No, we are in fact bringing on the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Bill 2000.
—In which case we can move through this at lightning speed.
—It is important that we pay particular attention, given the time of year, so that these matters are dealt with thoroughly and appropriately, but not necessarily at great length.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —In answer to the Democrats' question in relation to the carryover of the ability to initiate an inquiry of its own motion, the NHMRC is another research council which deals with medical aspects and not education as such. That is really not such a precedent to be relied upon. The role of the ARC in the new research and research training framework has been clearly defined in the `Knowledge and innovation' paper. It is intended that its role in the national innovation system will be broadened, and this should be delivered through the development and implementation of a strategic planning process. The areas in which the minister may seek ARC advice have been broadened to research matters. This allows for a wider range of areas that may be considered by the ARC than was the case under the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988. We have a broadening of the areas into which the ARC can make inquiry but we have decided not to carry over the power to conduct inquiries on its own motion. The ARC will also be providing advice on matters developed and formed through its planning process, as I mentioned. There is nothing in the bill that prevents the ARC from asking the minister to refer a matter to it for consideration and advice. This will ensure that there is consultation on research matters between the minister and the ARC.

speech.para: The amendments to this bill do not carry over the provision within the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988 to prevent the ARC from carrying out inquiries on its own motion if it would prejudice the performance of its other functions. The environment proposed by both the opposition and the Democrats could see an ARC that is too busy conducting inquiries on its own motion to provide timely advice to government on matters concerning national research priorities or emerging fields of research such as nanotechnology and photonics, to name a couple. I think that answers both the question put by the Democrats and the reason for the government's opposition to this amendment.

talk.start.para: —On this matter, we have indicated that we are supporting the Democrats' position. During the second reading debate, I indicated our concerns about this matter and we indicated similar concerns at the Senate inquiry. I find it odd that you are taking this particular view. I understand that within government it is only recently that you were prepared to accept an amendment along these lines. Therefore, we can see no reason why the ARC ought not to have the measure of independence proposed in this amendment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I will probably withdraw amendment (2) standing in my name. I understand the opposition shares a concern that we had at the time of drafting—that is, that the states when referred to are already deemed to include territories, but I might ask for advice from the clerks. This amendment was included on the clerks' advice. I am happy to withdraw it if the minister and others in the chamber believe that the definition of the `states' includes the Northern Territory and the ACT. I am not quite sure why it has been included in the drafting process, but knowing that the clerks usually know better than I and probably the majority of us in this chamber at any given time, if the advice from the Senate is to proceed with the amendment, then I will happily move the amendment. Otherwise I will proceed with the amendment, having not moved the amendment standing in my name on behalf of the Democrats. If the minister and his capable advisers would like to shed some light on whether or not `states' is deemed to include territories, then I will be satisfied with the explanation.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The Acts Interpretation Act 1901, section 17, Constitutional and Official Definitions, says:

quote.para: (o) `State' shall mean a State of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: Therefore, that would not include a territory.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrats amendment No. 2:

quote.para: (2) Clause 4, page 3 (after line 7), at the end of the clause, add:
States includes the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory.

speech.para: I move the above amendment for the obvious reason of making sure that the territories are not left out in the definition section of the legislation.

talk.start.para: —We will support that position.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrats amendment No. 3:

quote.para: (3) Clause 6, page 4 (line 18), at the end of paragraph (1)(b), add ", including by determining the distribution of funds for a particular year between 2 or more categories of research programs".

speech.para: This amendment seeks to strengthen the independence of the ARC and enhance its strategic decision making capacity. While it is appropriate that there be consultation between the minister and the ARC regarding the levels of caps among different research programs, the Democrats believe it is more appropriate that the ARC be responsible for making the final determination. This will not remove ministerial influence as he or she will have the power to approve strategic plans. I urge the opposition and the government to support the amendment. Otherwise I am happy, as Senator Carr has indicated, to move this debate along.

talk.start.para: (Senator Knowles)—Senator Stott Despoja, may I seek guidance from you? On the running sheet your amendments (3) and (4) are to be moved by leave together. You only mentioned amendment (3).

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I think I will separate the amendments if the chamber will allow me to.

—The opposition does not support Democrat amendment (3). In our judgment this is a matter that ought correctly to be the responsibility of the government of the day, which should make the decisions about the broad parameters of expenditure after receiving advice from the ARC and, of course, other bodies within government.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The paper that we have referred to, `Knowledge and innovation', announced that the minister would divide funding between research programs in order to maintain the balance between the current level of funding being used to support both basic and applied research. The government has made a commitment that this balance would remain the same for the time being. It is the role of the government to ultimately determine the allocation of funding across these various programs, and the comments made by Senator Carr are not at variance with that. The government will oppose the amendment.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrats amendment No. 4:

quote.para: (4) Clause 6, page 4 (after line 20), after paragraph (1)(c), insert:
(ca) the function of conducting, on its own initiative, inquiries into matters related to research and research education, and publishing the results; and
(cb) the function of making recommendations to the Minister and to the States about matters related to research and research education; and

speech.para: Briefly, this amendment relates again to enabling the ARC to conduct its own inquiries into matters relating to research and research education. I note the submission of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee in particular on this matter, which remarks that the current power is used only rarely and that it is a useful power for the ARC to have—that is, to undertake inquiries into areas which may become concerns if not investigated at an early stage. I say to the opposition, through you, Chair, that I understand there are some concerns regarding this amendment. You were considering supporting it if I made some changes. I am happy to accommodate those changes if you will outline them for the benefit of the chamber. I understand you have a problem with reference to `and to the States'. I would rather have the ALP amend my amendment to remove those words `and to the States' in the second line of (cb) in order to give this amendment a chance of getting up. It is an important issue. Perhaps Senator Carr will advise the chamber.

talk.start.para: —Senator Stott Despoja has correctly indicated the opposition's position on this matter. We would be prepared to support this amendment if the words `and the States' were removed. I move:

quote.para: Paragraph (cb), omit "and to the States".

speech.para: The simple concern that we have here is that these particular words do not add anything to the proposition that is before the chamber and it would strengthen the proposition if it were `of making recommendations to the Minister about research ...' That would be the appropriate formulation. If that proposition is accepted by the Democrats and is carried by the chamber, then we would withdraw our amendment (1) and support the Democrat amendment in its place.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The ARC is a Commonwealth advisory body and it is not appropriate for it to be making recommendations to the states. Although Senator Carr's proposed amendment would remedy that situation, the government is still opposed to this amendment because it really is part of the regime put forward to the Democrats in relation to the initiation of inquiries by the ARC. I have already covered that aspect in previous debate.
—The question is that the opposition amendment moved by Senator Carr to the Democrats amendment be agreed to.
—The question now is that the Democrats amendment, as amended, be agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —Democrat amendment (5) is similar, I understand, to the opposition amendment in relation to accountability of ministerial requests. I am inclined to withdraw my amendment in favour of the Labor Party amendment on this particular matter. I think they are comparable, but I am happy to support the one standing in the name of Senator Carr on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, unless he has a particular problem with that.
—I move:

quote.para: (2) Clause 6, page 4 (after line 29), at the end of the clause, add:

(5) The Minister must cause a copy of any request made under subsection (2) to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which the request was made.

speech.para: The bill requires a request by the minister for advice from the ARC to be included in the ARC's annual report. Reports are published only after the end of each financial year and with considerable delay. The parliament needs a more efficient way of being kept up to date with the activities of the ARC. This amendment provides for this by requiring requests from the minister for advice to be tabled in the parliament within 15 sitting days.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government is opposed to this. Any such request for advice by the minister is included in the annual report. At present there is no requirement for tabling of a request at the time that it is made. I believe it is sufficient for it to be contained within the report. I also note that the Democrats have referred to the National Health and Medical Research Council as a precedent. There is no requirement of the NHMRC to table requests that are made from time to time.
—I think I was referring to a different matter.

—You were going to rely on that as a precedent. That is why I arranged it—on the basis that you were. Anyway, you are not. It is the practice in any event for the minister to issue a press release, which we believe is sufficient.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

quote.para: (6) Clause 7, page 5 (line 3), after "give", insert "general".
(7) Clause 7, page 5 (after line 8), after subclause (2), insert:

(2A) The Minister is not entitled to direct the ARC (or the Board) about the ARC's handling of particular scientific, technical or ethical issues or about the distribution of funds for a particular year between 2 or more categories of research programs.
(8) Clause 7, page 5 (lines 9 to 11), omit subclause (3), substitute:
(3) Particulars of any directions given by the Minister under this section in a financial year must be:
(a) tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the direction is given; and
(b) included in the annual report for the ARC for the financial year.
(9) Clause 10, page 6 (line 19), after "give", insert "general".
(10) Clause 10, page 6 (lines 22 to 24), omit subclause (2), substitute:
(2) Particulars of any directions given by the Minister under this section in a financial year must be:
(a) tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the direction is given; and
(b) included in the annual report for the ARC for the financial year.
(11) Clause 11, page 7 (lines 10 to 12), omit subclause (2), substitute:
(2) Particulars of any notifications given by the Minister under this section in a financial year must be:
(a) tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the notification is given; and
(b) included in the annual report for the ARC for the financial year.

speech.para: These amendments relate to directions and accountability. You can see that my concern relating to ministerial influence is reflected in the first amendment—that is, inserting the word `general' before the word `directions' on page 5 of the bill. Essentially that is to enable the minister to give general direction to the board about the ARC's functions as opposed to `give directions', which sounds more prescriptive.

The rest of the amendments ensure that the minister is not entitled to direct the ARC, or the board, about the ARC's handling of particular scientific, technical or ethical issues or about the distribution of funds for a particular year between two or more categories of research programs. Anyone who was a part of the Senate inquiry into this legislation will know that this was a concern primarily for organisations like FASTS, but it was also reflected in the submissions of the NTU, CAPA and other organisations that were concerned about the level of ministerial discretion and ministerial influence in relation to this legislation. The Democrats' concerns in relation to that issue are clearly on record in the Senate committee's report on that bill. Our amendments seek to ensure that the minister cannot have specific direction or influence in relation to those particular matters that I outlined. The accountability of ministerial directions is still relevant to this debate:

quote.para: Particulars of any directions given by the Minister under this section in a financial year must be:
(a) tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the direction is given; and
(b) included in the annual report for the ARC for the financial year.

speech.para: Again, that amendment relates to accountability measures. The Democrats are particularly committed to that. Based on the last amendment, I am sure that the opposition would be keen to support that. Indeed, that is reflected in amendment No. 10. Amendment No. 9 after `give' adds the word `general', which relates to the nature of the advice that the minister is able to give. Amendment No. 11, standing in my name, again reflects the accountability issue in relation to the accountability of ministerial notification. These amendments are designed to ensure transparency and accountability but also to curtail that ministerial discretion and influence that we are concerned about. Certainly those concerns were reflected in the Senate inquiry on this piece of legislation.

talk.start.para: —We are dealing with Democrat amendments Nos 6 to 11. The opposition has a different position on many of these, so we will need to vote on them separately. I flag that at this point. The opposition will be opposing amendment No. 6 on the basis that, while on most occasions the minister's advice to the board should be in general terms, there may be occasions when it would be appropriate for it to be in more specific terms. Labor will support Democrat amendments for such directions to be tabled in parliament, as well as their appearing in the annual report, so there is ample scope for public scrutiny and accountability. What we are trying to get across is the need to balance out the requirement for specific directions, and to ensure that matters where there is a shortfall in the advice tendered, with the more general concern to ensure independence within the ARC and, on the same basis, to ensure that there is appropriate accountability and transparency in the arrangements entered into on these matters.

speech.para: The opposition will not be supporting Democrat amendment No. 7. This essentially concerns the ministerial directions power. We feel that the minister's capacity to direct the ARC to recommend particular proposals as deserving or not deserving assistance is sufficient to cover this matter. The second part goes to the power of the minister to set broad parameters for research funding. Again, I think similar issues apply.

We will be supporting Democrats amendment No. 8, which is a requirement that directions given by the minister about the ARC's function being tabled in parliament in addition to being in the annual report. I think that speaks for itself. We will not be supporting Democrat amendment No. 9, which requires that the directions to the board about the performance of the board's functions be general directions. We feel this would limit the capacity of the board. We will be supporting amendment No. 10, which requires directions by the minister on the board's functions to be tabled in parliament. Again this is an issue of public accountability. We will be supporting Democrat amendment No. 11, which requires notification of the general Commonwealth policies regarding research to be tabled in parliament, in addition to being contained in the annual report.

talk.start.para: (Senator Sherry)—For the chair's benefit, could I recap. You have indicated opposition to Democrat amendments Nos 6, 7 and 9 and support for Nos 8, 10 and 11.
—That is correct.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government believes that these amendments should be opposed, for a number of reasons. As with all advisory bodies to the government, the ARC will, from time to time, be requested to provide advice to the minister on short-term matters and priorities. Similarly, the minister may direct the ARC to concentrate on particular priorities of the government; for example, strengthening Australia's information and communications technology and biotechnology bases. The amendments moved by the Australian Democrats would limit the power of the government to seek specific and strategic short-term advice on matters of pressing importance to Australia's capability as an innovative nation. It should be remembered that the minister is already limited in what power may be used to direct the ARC regarding the recommendations of funding for a particular proposal. For those reasons, in short the government will oppose Democrat amendments Nos 6 to 11.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I thank the opposition for their limited support. I assume I will be moving those amendments either in two sets of three or individually. I am not sure how you want to put them.
—The chair will be putting them separately, in two groups.

—Thank you, Chair. I do want to record my disappointment with the government's position. I ask the minister if he could clarify, in relation to ministerial accountability, whether or not the amendments I have moved in relation to ministerial accountability—primarily the issue of the particulars of directions and requests for advice to be tabled in both houses of parliament within 15 sitting days—echo the provisions contained in the NHMRC provisions, given that that was a point raised by the minister earlier.

speech.para: I am disappointed that the opposition will not support the change in relation to general directions. I think we have all expressed our concern about limiting the direction, the influence or the power of the minister in relation to direction he or she can give to the board about the performance of the ARC's functions. I would have thought that that would have been one way of ensuring that general direction would be the role of the minister, as opposed to more specific or stringent advice that may actually impinge on the so-called autonomy of that organisation. But I am asking the minister specifically about the accountability matters that I have put forward in the form of an amendment that advice and requests for that advice be tabled in both houses of parliament within 15 sitting days. Does that not echo the NHMRC provisions to which he earlier referred?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I do not use the NHMRC as a precedent. What I said in the committee stage earlier was that, if you were to rely on it as a precedent, then that did not have the tabling of requests for advice or the provision for that. What we have here is Democrat amendments Nos 8, 10 and 11, which deal with provisions which go to a reporting, if you like, and the Democrats say that they enhance accountability. The government says that directions are still open to proper scrutiny through the annual report process. That is what the minister directs. It is still subject to that process, and this bill will protect the ARC's independence in recommending excellent research proposals for funding, as the minister is prevented from making directions concerning recommendations to fund or not to fund particular research proposals. It is for those reasons that the government sees these as not being necessary.
—The question is that Democrats amendments Nos 6, 7 and 9 be agreed to.
—The question is that Democrats amendments Nos 8, 10 and 11 be agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Democrats amendments Nos 12 and 13:

quote.para: (12) Clause 12, page 8 (after line 16), after paragraph (b), insert:
(ba) a person who represents research students; and
(13) Clause 12, page 8 (after line 21), at the end of the clause, add:
(2) The person mentioned in paragraph (1)(ba) must:
(a) be enrolled in a post-graduate degree course at an Australian university; or
(b) have obtained a post-graduate degree from an Australian university in the 12 months preceding his or her appointment.

speech.para: These amendments relate to the membership of the board and reflect our concerns that a student representative be included on the ARC board, either as an additional board member or as a non-voting associate member. This is something that we outlined in our response to the committee inquiry into the bill. It is something that came forward in at least one submission. The CAPA submission noted that research students perform approximately 60 per cent of the research in universities, and they produce approximately 35 per cent of the publications. Therefore it makes sense that they should have some role in this organisation. The Democrats have a long history of supporting increased student representation in the management of issues and affairs which affect them. These amendments reflect that.

I seek, through these amendments, to add to the membership of the board clause, in relation to what the board should consist of, by adding a person who represents research students. In amendment No. 13 I have specified what I mean by that. The amendment says:

quote.para: The person mentioned in paragraph (1)(ba) must:
(a) be enrolled in a post-graduate degree course at an Australian university; or
(b) have obtained a post-graduate degree from an Australian university in the 12 months preceding his or her appointment.

speech.para: The amendments firstly ensure student representation and secondly provide some specificity as to what constitutes a postgraduate student in the circumstances. I commend these amendments to the Senate. I think they are fairly sensible amendments and I hope they receive support.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports both these propositions. In government the Labor Party ensured that there was student representation on such bodies. I think it is appropriate that they be included at this stage, and we support both propositions.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I would remind the Senate of Mr Bradley Smith's evidence before the Senate inquiry. He is the president of CAPA, and his evidence was that a ministerial appointment would not be acceptable and that CAPA would prefer that there be no representation at all rather than a ministerial appointment. I take it that the Democrats are saying that CAPA would choose the person to go on the board. The government believes this is inappropriate. The government believes there is a sufficiently broad-ranging representation of people from the community, the research sector and academia to make this board very effective. In fact, in the white paper Knowledge and innovation, the government outlined its intention to broaden the membership of the ARC board so that it was more representative of the views of those contributing to the national innovation system. I think it is fairly clear already who is going to be on the board. Clause 14 states that in appointing the eight board members:

quote.para: (2) The Minister must, in making appointments under this section, try to ensure that the composition of the Board reflects the breadth of academic, industry and community interests in the outcomes of research.

speech.para: The government believes this is broad enough.
Amendments agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The amendments that I am about to move on behalf of the Democrats, which relate to the appointment of members, are a fairly standard set of amendments that the Democrats put forward whenever we debate a bill of this nature that involves appointments to a board. They have been moved a number of times—I am not quite sure whether it is 16, 17 or 18 times—by Senator Andrew Murray, our accountability spokesperson. I put these amendments on behalf of the party. They are standard amendments to guard against jobs for the boys, basically, and to make sure that people are appointed on merit, as a consequence of independent scrutiny of appointments, to ensure that probity and transparency are maintained. I have a set of notes that serve as an explanatory memorandum to these amendments but, rather than read out 2½ pages for the benefit of the Senate, I wonder if I may seek leave to incorporate these notes. I recognise that the opposition and the government have not seen these speaking notes. I am just getting them photocopied now. I am happy to read them out and take up the time of the Senate, or defer the matter or have them distributed as we speak and seek leave to incorporate them. I seek your advice, Mr Temporary Chairman.
(Senator Sherry)—The minister has indicated that we should hold consideration of these amendments until the notes have been circulated. So we will move on to your next amendment, No. 14.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrats amendment No. 14:

quote.para: (14) Clause 42, page 23 (line 5), omit "a year", substitute "every 3 years".

speech.para: This amendment relates to the strategic plan—that is, the notion that the board must prepare a strategic plan at least once a year and give it to the minister for approval under section 43. The amendment proposes that the clause will read `every 3 years'. Again, the basis for that recommendation is set out in our comments in the Senate committee report on these bills. We believe that the requirement that the ARC prepare annual strategic plans for ministerial approval may further subject the decision making and strategic planning role to short-term pressures as well as taking up resources better directed towards other strategic activities. This is a worthwhile amendment and a fairly straightforward one. I hope it receives the support of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not be supporting Democrats amendment No. 14, which seeks to change the requirement for the board to prepare a strategic plan annually to once every three years. I think it is appropriate that strategic plans be reviewed annually, given the importance of this particular board and given the job we have allocated it under this legislation.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The production of a rolling three-year strategic plan was the express wish of the ARC. This ensures that there can be a more rapid response to the changing needs and priorities of the research and innovation system. The government agrees with the opposition that this is not an amendment that should be supported, in view of the comments made by Senator Carr and the ones I have just made.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —On the matter of Democrats amendments listed as (1) and (2)—

(Senator Sherry)—I am just coming back to those, Senator Carr. Senator Stott Despoja has not moved them. She has circulated some notes, I understand, to senators in the chamber, and her request is that they be incorporated.
—by leave—I move:

quote.para: (1) Clause 14, page 9 (line 3), after "Minister", insert , in accordance with a code of practice determined under section 14A,".
(2) Page 9 (after line 12), after clause 14, insert:

para.inline: 14A Procedures for appointment of the 8 members referred to in paragraph 12(c)

quote.para: (1) The Minister must by writing determine a code of practice for appointments to the Board that:
(a) sets out general principles on which appointments are to be made, including, but not limited to:
(i) merit; and
(ii) independent scrutiny of appointments; and
(iii) probity; and
(iv) openness and transparency; and
(b) sets out how these principles are to be applied to the selection of members.
(2) The code of practice must include a requirement for any person appointed to make a declaration if he or she is a member of a political party.
(3) After determining a code of practice under subsection (1), the Minister must publish the code in the Gazette.
(4) Not later than every third anniversary after a code of practice has been determined, the Minister must review the code.
(5) In reviewing a code of practice, the Minister must invite the public to comment on the code.
(6) A code of practice determined under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

speech.para: I add that the only reason I wanted to incorporate these notes was to facilitate the debate in the chamber. I just do not want to hold up the debate on this issue.

talk.start.para: —I am sorry, Senator Stott Despoja, but this is the first time I have seen amendments Nos 1 and 2 to clause 14. I am not certain how long they have been circulated. Has the government seen them before?
—Yes, we have.
—I will need to seek further advice on these matters. There has been no discussion with us about these particular proposals, so we may need to defer those until later in the proceedings.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That Democrats amendment Nos 1 and 2 on sheet 2035 be postponed.

speech.para: Do we have an idea when these amendments will be dealt with? I want to put on the record that these amendments have been distributed. I apologise that Senator Carr has not had them specifically drawn to his attention. They are standard amendments drafted in the name of Senator Murray, our accountability spokesperson. They have been moved to a number of pieces of legislation. I apologise for not bringing these amendments to Senator Carr's attention specifically, but I did ensure that they were circulated at least as early as 30 November. I am happy to postpone these amendments to give Senator Carr time to review them. My understanding is that they are standard amendments. We have moved them 16 or 17 times, at last count, and I believe they have not received support from the opposition. They are just a standard set of amendments that automatically come up if we are debating a bill that involves the appointment of people to a board. These amendments seek to ensure that that is done in an accountable and transparent manner. I will postpone that matter. I am not sure whether this is an indefinite postponement—

talk.start.para: —No, the amendments would be postponed until we get to the final motion that the bill, as amended, be agreed to, which I do not think will be far away.
—That is right. I can indicate that, if we have opposed them on 14 other occasions, I will not be the first to break with precedent.
—Can I take it from those remarks, Senator Carr, that we can now go ahead?
—I am seeking advice. I appreciate the Democrats telling us our policy on these matters, but I would like to seek advice from more conventional channels.
—The question is that Democrat amendment Nos 1 and 2 be postponed.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I am scared that I may have given the ALP the wrong advice. Maybe I should have just said, `On the 17 times, you have always said yes. They are great amendments; let's pass them.' I look forward to hearing back from Senator Carr. You are right: if anyone could change history or break a rule it is probably Senator Carr. I seek leave to move Democrat amendment Nos 15, 16, 18 to 22, 24 and 25 on sheet 2038 together.
—Senator Stott Despoja, I understand that Democrat amendment No. 16 should not be included because it is in opposition to clause 50. So that will be put separately.
—by leave—I move Democrat amendment Nos 15, 18 to 22, 24 and 25:

quote.para: (15) Clause 47, page 26 (lines 24 to 27), omit the definition of funding split determination.
(18) Clause 53, page 30 (lines 7 to 10), omit paragraph (1)(b).
(19) Clause 53, page 30 (lines 20 to 30), omit subclause (2), substitute:

(2) If, after a recommendation is made in relation to a proposal and before the Minister decides whether to approve the proposal, there is a variation of the governing funding rules in relation to the recommendation, the Minister must, in making that decision, disregard that variation and have regard to the funding rules as in force when the recommendation was made.
(20) Clause 53, page 30 (line 34) to page 31 (line 1), omit paragraph (3)(a), substitute:
(a) any subsequent variation of the governing funding rules; or
(21) Clause 53, page 31 (lines 5 to 12), omit Example 1.
(22) Clause 54, page 31 (lines 25 to 29), omit paragraph (a), substitute:
(a) must be consistent with the funding cap for the year, or each of the years, to which the approval relates; and
(24) Clause 59, page 35 (lines 25 to 29), omit subclause (4), substitute:
(4) The rules must take account of and be consistent with, the funding cap for the year, or each of the years, to which the rules apply.
(25) Clause 61, page 36 (lines 23 to 25), omit paragraph (b).

speech.para: These amendments relate to the distribution of funding caps—a discussion that has taken place in the committee. The Democrats have always believed that the goal of establishing a more independent ARC and enhancing the strategic decision making capacity of the ARC require that its powers be increased and that the power to set caps between research programs is a power more appropriately the preserve of the ARC than wholly that of the minister. As you can see, our attempt to delete clause 50 relates to that issue of the dividing of funding caps between different categories of research programs by the minister. We seek to remove the notion that he or she must do that.

talk.start.para: —I indicate to the committee that the opposition will be opposing amendments 15 through to 25. Essentially these amendments are about the discretion of the minister. The traditional position that the Labor Party has taken in these matters is to suggest that there are occasions when it is appropriate that ministers do have discretion. The critical issue here is the effectiveness of parliamentary accountability. I would suggest that the combined weight of procedures in this chamber and through the Senate estimates provides us an opportunity to inquire as to why ministers have used their discretion on these particular matters, and we think that is appropriate.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government similarly opposes these amendments. It really is the role of government to ultimately determine the allocation of funding across its various programs. I believe those sentiments are shared by the opposition. We believe that the ultimate decision maker in relation to the apportion of funding is the minister concerned.
—The question is that clause 50 stand as printed.
—The question is that Democrat amendment Nos 15, 18 to 22, 24 and 25 be agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrat amendment No. 17:

quote.para: (17) Clause 51, page 28 (after line 8), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) The Minister must not approve a proposal under subsection (1) unless the ARC has recommended that the proposal should be approved.

speech.para: This amendment is in relation to the approval of proposals. The Democrats seek to insert the words:

quote.para: The Minister must not approve a proposal under subsection (1) unless the ARC has recommended that the proposal should be approved.

speech.para: This amendment is self-explanatory. Again, it relates back to that balance between ministerial power, discretion, influence and responsibility and that of the ARC. We believe that the ARC should be responsible for recommending that a proposal be approved before the minister approves a proposal. It should not be a case of the minister having the power to approve proposals that the ARC may not have approved or recommended. I think this again goes to the heart of fulfilling the government's rhetoric of ensuring that we have a strong, vibrant and independent ARC. This is one way of ensuring that that happens in relation to the provisions that deal with the approval of expenditure on research programs.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes this measure by the Democrats. We feel that the minister should retain final authority to approve proposals. However, this issue needs to be seen in the context of amendment No. 3 to be moved by the Labor Party in which we require full details to be tabled in parliament when there is a divergence by the minister from the ARC advice. We think that is an appropriate safeguard in this regard.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government is opposed to this amendment. It would restrict the power of the minister as the ultimate decision maker. The sentiment or thinking behind it is allied to the government's opposition to those provisions that dealt with the allocation of funds which we mentioned earlier.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (3) on sheet 2043:

quote.para: (3) Clause 52, page 29 (after line 31), at the end of the clause, add:

(5) If the Minister does not approve a recommendation under subsection (1), the Minister must, as soon as practicable, cause to be tabled in each House of the Parliament copies of a report including the following information:
(a) for each of the proposals recommended but not approved for funding:
(i) the name of the organisation seeking financial assistance for the proposal;
(ii) a description of the research program;
(iii) the name and title of the person leading the research program;
(iv) a statement of reasons why the proposal was not approved for funding;
(b) the names of all persons who, or organisations which, provided advice to the Minister in respect of each of the proposals recommended but not approved for funding.

(6) If the Minister approves for funding any proposal other than a proposal recommended for approval under subsection (1), the Minister must, as soon as practicable, cause to be tabled in each House of the Parliament copies of a report including the following information:
(a) for each of the proposals approved, but not recommended under subsection (1) for funding:
(i) the name of the organisation seeking financial assistance for the proposal;
(ii) a description of the research program;
(iii) the name and title of the person leading the research program;
(iv) a statement of reasons why the proposal was approved for funding; and
(b) the names of all persons who, or organisations which, provided advice to the Minister in respect of each of the proposals approved for funding.

speech.para: This amendment deals with the approval of funding proposals, other than those recommended by the ARC, to be detailed in parliament. The minister, in his second reading speech, said that this bill demonstrates the government's commitment to an ARC that will be supportive of our most outstanding researchers and responsive to changes in the global environment. Presumably, then, the minister would have no hesitation in accepting the advice from the ARC about which research proposals should be funded. That is why the opposition believes that parliament is entitled to the full details of instances where the minister fails to accept recommendations of the ARC. Likewise, on occasions where a minister chooses to fund proposals other those recommended by the ARC, details ought to be made public and the reasons for the minister's actions ought to be fully explained.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government certainly opposes this amendment. Whilst the approval of funding is ultimately the minister's decision, the process for approving proposals has significant input from the ARC—more than the process as currently set out under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. This will ensure that only the grants which receive funding approval will be those which have been assessed by the ARC. It should be pointed out that some grants are eventually funded, even though they were initially not recommended by the ARC. These grants have been successful in an internal appeals process. While they are the exception rather than the rule, the applicants for these grants will be included in any such tabling proposed by this amendment. This could allow those grant recipients to be unfairly accused of cronyism or other arguments or criticisms, and that would be notwithstanding that their entitlement to such funding was entirely legitimate. It is likely, however, that there will be few proposals for funding that will need to be tabled. For these reasons, the government will oppose the opposition amendment No. 3.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —For the record, the Democrats will be supporting the opposition amendment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Australian Democrats amendment No. 23:

quote.para: (23) Clause 54, page 31 (line 34), at the end of subclause (2), add:
; and (c) must be in accordance with a recommendation made by the ARC.

speech.para: This amendment again relates to the issues that I referred to earlier but this time in relation to approval of variations. It seeks to specify that it is in accordance with the recommendation of the ARC. I suspect that, if the earlier amendment did not have opposition or government support, this one will not either.

talk.start.para: —The opposition does not support this matter. Senator Stott Despoja is obviously quite correct about that.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Nor does the government.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move Democrats amendment No. 26:

quote.para: (26) Page 36 (after line 27), at the end of subdivision D, add:
Particulars of rules approved by the Minister under section 60 or varied by the Minister under section 61 must be:
(a) tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the rules are approved or varied, as the case may be; and
(b) included in the annual report for the ARC for the financial year in which the approval or variation occurs.

speech.para: I am starting to get a complex.

talk.start.para: —At least there is a voice and a party fighting for increased independence of the ARC, student representation, accountability, transparency, and all those things that I think were brought up before the Senate inquiry into this legislation. I am not holding out too much hope for our amendments to the next piece of legislation in relation to the ARC—just quietly. Again, this amendment, which relates to the accountability of funding rules, seeks to add at the end of subdivision D particulars of rules to be tabled. Particulars of rules approved by the minister under section 60 or varied by the minister under section 61 must be tabled in each house of parliament by the minister within 15 days of that house after the rules are approved or varied, as the case may be, and be included in the annual report of the ARC for the financial year in which the approval or variation occurs. Again, this relates to the Democrats' concern that there be increased accountability measures, especially in relation to the minister.

speech.para: The proposed legislation sets out a procedure for reporting of ministerial directions to, and requests for advice from, the ARC. We have tried to amend that to ensure ministerial discretion. Now I seek to do it in relation to the accountability of funding rules. I am saddened that this is not receiving government support. Again, the Democrats are trying to ensure that there is some transparency in the legislation before us, especially because this particular body is supposed to underpin or be a key part—if you listen to the government's rhetoric—in relation to promoting an innovative, knowledge based economy and society. I am just regretful that such controversial issues as those, which we have looked at through the committee report—and we will soon be looking at the issue of contestability of funding, et cetera—and which actually underpin the agenda the government has set out in its white paper have not been adopted.

It is not like we came up with these amendments out of thin air. They are based on comparable legislation. They are based on evidence to the Senate committee, and not just from student groups like the NTU, CAPA or indeed organisations like FASTS but organisations like the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. The government had broad sectoral advice on how these bills could be improved and they have not been. I will not hold up the chamber much longer on this amendment or on my other amendments. I hope that we get through them fairly swiftly. I just put that on the record. We tried to improve the legislation, which could be quite good, and a body that has a key role to play in our society. I hope that these will receive the support of the chamber. If they do not, I am not quite sure what is going to happen with the next set of amendments that we have before us.

talk.start.para: —I am a bit disappointed by Senator Stott Despoja's last set of comments, even though she has said such nice things about me today. Perhaps I should remind her that we have supported her amendments Nos 1, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13 and, of course, this one. So it is not an insignificant number of amendments that we have supported. It is true, however, that we do think there may be other issues that will require greater attention in the consideration of this bill. Perhaps it would be more productive if we spent more time on the substantive matters that are before the parliament rather than, might I suggest, lesser priority issues—not that they are unimportant, but it is a question of which particular issues you regard as important and why you regard them as important. In regard to the particular proposition before the chamber, rather than the general political comments that Senator Stott Despoja has made, we think this proposition is worthy of support. It is appropriate that eligibility criteria be established when applicants seek funds. The assessment processes and the accountability requirements ought to be laid out in a way that is apparent to all and this should be included in an annual report. Therefore, we think it is appropriate to support this measure.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment. The rules are available on the Internet and they are widely available throughout the sector. There is really no need to table them. The government opposes the amendment on that basis.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: (Senator Sherry)—We now return to Democrat amendments (1) and (2) on sheet 2035.
—I indicate that this is another case in which Senator Stott Despoja was quite right. We have opposed these measures 14 times before.
—Is it 14?
—I will take your word on the number. This is not going to be a precedent where we support you.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

Senator STOTT DESPOJA

quote.para: The Democrats are concerned to ensure that wherever appointments are made to the governing organ of public authorities, whether they be institutions set up by legislation, "independent" statutory authorities or quasi-govern-ment agencies, that the process by which these appointments are made is, and is seen to be, transparent, accountable, open and honest.

The adage of "jobs for the boys" should be an anachronism in 2000. Notwithstanding this, there is a widespread public perception that very little of substance has changed. Many appear to believe that Government appointments result in patronage to handsomely remunerated positions. This perception can damage the reputation of these bodies, as in the public eye they are then seen as being controlled by persons who lack the appropriate independence and who may not be as meritorious as they might be.

The Democrats are of the opinion that whilst this is often not so, and many outstanding appointments have been made by both the previous and present Governments, nevertheless this is a matter which has to be addressed.

In truth, there is little empirical evidence that can be brought to bear to rebut this perception. It is still the case that appointments to statutory authorities are left largely to the discretion of the Minister with the relevant portfolio responsibility. In the absence of "umbrella" legislation to correct this situation in a systematic fashion, the Democrats will have to argue for each piece of legislation dealing with these bodies to include standard provisions setting out an accountable regime governing such appointments made by Ministers.
The Nolan Committee, which reviewed the processes for making public appointments in the United Kingdom, set out the following principles to guide and inform the making of such appointments:
(i) A Minister should not be involved in an appointment where he or she has a financial or personal interest 1;
(ii) Ministers must act within the law, which includes its safeguards against discrimination on grounds of gender or race 2 ;
(iii) All public appointments should be governed by the overriding principle of appointment on merit 3,
(iv) Except in limited circumstances political. affiliation should not be a criterion for appointment 4;
(v) Selection on merit should take account of the need to appoint boards which include a balance of skills and backgrounds 5,
(vi) The basis on which members are appointed and how they are expected to fulfil their roles should be explicit 6 ;
(vii) The range of skills and backgrounds which are sought should be clearly specified 7.

These guidelines provide only a basic framework for ensuring that proper practices are followed in the making of appointments. They do not necessarily represent "best practice", rather they set out what should really be taken for granted in a modem system of accountable government. Indeed, the UK Government accepted fully the Nolan Committee's recommendations on public appointments. The office of Commissioner for Public Appointments was subsequently created (with a similar level of independence from the Government as the Auditor General) to provide an effective avenue of external scrutiny. The Commissioner subsequently developed a Code of Practice for Public Appointments which came into force on 1 July 1996. The Code regulates, interalia, appointments to non-departmental public bodies. It sets out seven principles upon which such appointments must be based: Ministerial Responsibility; Merit; Independent Scrutiny; Equal Opportunity; Probity; Openness and Transparency; and Proportionality. The Code provides mandatory guidelines for the application of these principles.

A comparison of these reforms with the current practice of government in the Federal sphere in Australia shows clearly that we lag well behind the UK in this respect. We lack not only the external scrutiny mechanism in the form of the Commissioner for Public Appointments, but more fundamentally we do not have even basic procedural safeguards. This should be redressed as a matter of public importance, with a far higher priority attached to it than has hitherto been the case.

The public must have trust and confidence that a Minister will not allow improper or irrelevant considerations or personal interests to influence public appointments. Indeed this relationship is in some respects analogous to those of a fiduciary nature, such as trustee and beneficiary, in that it is founded on a high degree of trust and confidence. Yet where a breach of duty occurs in a fiduciary relationship. the person to whom the duty is owed has access to a range of equitable remedies. This is not the case where a Minister acts for improper purposes in making an appointment.

There is no law to prohibit a Minister from doing this or, where the appointment has been made, to make the appointment voidable. This omission is addressed in the recommended amendments to the Bill which require that all appointments be made in accordance with a published code of practice.

The code of practice is intended not to act as a mere "guideline" to the Minister in making appointments, but to regulate by law the way in which the Minister exercises the power of appointment. The content of the code of practice is designed to accommodate those principles designated as fundamental by the Nolan Committee and the UK Commissioner for Public Appointments, as set out above.

A further provision requires that even where the code of practice has been adhered to in determining an appointment, the Minister will be further obliged to consider the impact of the appointee on the overall complexion of the Authority. This provision is aimed at ensuring "capture" of the Authority by any particular interest group cannot occur. It is essential that Boards are genuinely representative of the inevitably divergent views of those groups affected by their actions. Without this requirement the potential remains for appointments to be made to Boards of persons that are well qualified, but who all hold similar views on key areas of policy. This must be avoided not simply because it is good public policy practice to do so, but to maintain the credibility of the Authority in its area of operation.
1 First Report of the Committee on Standards in Public Life (the Nolan Committee), (1995) Cm 2850-I, para. 30.
2 Ibid, para. 32.
3 Ibid, para. 36.
4 Ibid, para. 41.
5 Ibid, para. 46
6 Ibid, para. 46.
7 Ibid, para. 46.

talk.start.para: —I thank the chamber. As provocative as it is when the minister says that it is a government of consistency, I am not going to touch it. I had these flashbacks of the 1996 education election policy that was put forward by this government. I wish he had been consistent on that education policy. It was quite good. Of course, most of the promises regarding those provisions and policy objectives were broken. I record my concern and disappointment on behalf of the Democrats, and I have no doubt by Senator Andrew Murray in particular, that these amendments will not be passed. I cannot say I am terribly surprised. I will check the figure for Senator Carr as to whether it was 14 or 19. I know that Senator Murray has these figures in his head and he will no doubt add this to the number of times that the Senate has rejected the opportunity for boards to be assessed and chosen on merit and in a transparent and accountable fashion—so that it is simply not ministerial discretion to appoint people whom they want but a good basis on which people are selected to sit on committees and boards that governments are responsible for in this nation. They are worthwhile and worthy amendments and I am sorry that they will not be supported.

talk.start.para: —The amend-ments go to opposing the printing of items 2 and 3, so I will be putting the question in the form that items 2 and 3 stand as printed.

—The opposition opposes Democrat amendments Nos 1 and 2. The main reason for that is that we believe that your amendments, Senator Stott Despoja, do not actually do what you were hoping they might do. Therefore, we think it would be a weakening of this bill in terms of the objectives you have outlined, Senator, to support your amendments.

talk.start.para: —Taking into account the funding which would be appropriated under the proposed Australian Research Council Act—which we have just dealt with—the impact of this amendment would be to increase the total amount appropriated for Commonwealth higher education research and research training by approximately $500 million over 2001 and 2002. What the government says is that these provisions will ensure that all Commonwealth block funding for university research and research training will be consolidated in section 23, special research assistance, of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. This will enable the consolidation of existing schemes into the institutional grants scheme and the research training scheme.

speech.para: The amendment also recognises that funding for the research programs to be administered by the Australian Research Council will be appropriated under the proposed Australian Research Council Act and will, therefore, not need to be appropriated through this act. The regime for allocating block funding for research and research training will be strengthened by the accountability requirements of listing on the Australian qualifications framework registers and the provision of approved research and research training management plans. But what I do say to the committee is that the effect of this amendment will be an additional appropriation and therefore it really should form the subject of a request. In any event, the government is opposed to the amendment.

—It depends on whether Senator Carr is supporting Nos 3 to 6.

So we would oppose Democrat amendment No. 6 as it currently stands and support, obviously, our own amendment No. 3, which we think does the job more effectively. We believe that No. 5 is covered by our amendment No. 2. So it is Nos 5 and 6 I think you will need to consider at this point, Senator.

speech.para: I gather from Senator Carr's contribution that he will not be supporting amendments Nos 5 and 6. I am not sure if he is supporting amendments Nos 3 and 4. Otherwise, I am happy to move mine en bloc, have them voted down and then deal with Senator Carr's amendments, which I assumed would be backup amendments or a next best position, anyway. In addressing these issues again I refer to some of the comments that have already been put on record in the form of the Senate committee investigation into the Australian Research Council (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2000. The Democrats have a number of concerns relating to the legislation. We have outlined them specifically in relation to the quantum of funding.

This bill provides for the transfer of $700 million of funds from operating grants under section 17 of the Higher Education Funding Act to a separate pool of funding under section 23 of that act, opening up eligibility to that funding to institutions and organisations not listed in the schedule to the act. I understand that we had one way of achieving that particular outcome. Senator Carr will have a backup to ensure, first of all, that when it relates to the contestability of funds we will be prescribing very clearly—and this is where I think our amendments are not only comparable but the same—for the record that for the purposes of paragraph 1B(b) an institutional body is an accredited higher education institutional body if, and only if, the institutional body is included as a higher education institution on both of the following registers, as in force when the relevant expenditure proposal has been considered by the minister. It goes on to talk about (a) the Australian qualifications framework register of authorities empowered by the government to accredit post-compulsory education and training courses, and (b) the Australian qualifications framework register of bodies with authority to issue qualifications. That is in relation to special research assistance.

I cannot emphasise enough the concerns that have been expressed, not only to me but to other senators and to the Senate committee, regarding the contestability of funding issue. We note the concerns presented by a range of institutions, including the University of Melbourne Postgraduate Association, regarding the degree to which opening public funding to competition may also undermine existing cooperative research schemes. I think this has implications in a number of ways—not only in taking money from the public pool and potentially making it available to private institutions but also for cooperative research schemes that are already in place.

We feel quite saddened that this legislation is again not fulfilling the government's aims for educational research and development and training and innovation in Australia. For that reason we have moved these amendments. I am sorry they will not get support but I do understand Senator Carr's solution. I think the one inserting a schedule into the act was mooted by the National Tertiary Education Union. That is a proposal that we support. We think that is a measure that may have a similar effect to that which we were originally going to move.

We will be opposing these propositions because the legislation provides for the requirements for such events to be disallowable instruments, and there will be an opportunity for parliamentary scrutiny through that process.
