speech.para: These amendments go to the issue of keeping the institutional grants scheme and the research training scheme funding restrictions to institutions listed in the Higher Education Funding Act. This is an important matter because it goes to the very heart of the integrity of the research effort in this country. This bill takes some $700 million annually out of the universities' operating grants and puts it into another part of the Higher Education Funding Act in order to fund the new institutional grants scheme and the research training scheme. During the debate on these matters in the House, the minister talked about Commonwealth funds for research already being available to institutions other than universities. However, that is grant money from the research projects, money now to be administered by the Australian Research Council. We are concerned about the money for research training through the research training scheme and the institutional grants scheme funding, which is intended, according to the white paper, to `support the general fabric of institutions' research and research training activities'.

These funds are currently available for use only by those institutions listed in table A of HEFA. Institutions' names appear in that table only after they have been subject to parliamentary scrutiny and approval. This approval by the federal parliament ought to apply over and above the listing of institutions on the AQF registers. In any case, the AQF process is still under development, and I have made numerous comments about that in the Senate estimates: my concerns about the delay that has taken place and, I might suggest to you also, the rigour of the AQF processes themselves. Further work will obviously need to be done in that area.

Despite the agreed protocols, there is still a great deal more work to be undertaken in those particular matters. The Universities Quality Agency is still operating with an interim board and I think it will be at least the second half of next year, if I am correct—and perhaps you would advise me, Minister—before it will be in a position to begin any audits of institutions. Only recently have appointments been made by the Commonwealth and I wonder whether or not the states have appointed their representatives to the AQF board. It is my understanding that has yet to occur. It seems that, given the importance of this body, it would be appropriate that the whole process actually be speeded up in that regard. I do not think there has been any agreement yet as to how these audits will actually be conducted.

A further area of concern is what will actually constitute a quality audit. I look forward to discussion on that matter. I am sure we will have many hours of entertainment when it comes to examining what that actually means in practice for some of the institutions around the country. I think there are quite widely divergent views—that is the best way I can put it—as to what is meant by `quality' in some of our higher education institutions. I think at the very best one would have to say the idea of getting a nationally consistent approach on this matter will not be an easy task. In any case, it is the Labor Party's view that the federal parliament needs to have a final say on the distribution of significant amounts of Commonwealth higher education funding. That is what these amendments address.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The government strenuously opposes these amendments put forward by the opposition. It believes that they will limit access to funding for research and research training by institutions which are not listed on the proposed schedule, that is, they will limit funding to private universities. The government believes it has a responsibility to ensure that postgraduate research training occurs in environments that provide access to high quality research and infrastructure support, no matter in which university this takes place. The amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 will require that all universities demonstrate that they are accredited and quality assured before they can receive funding from the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs to support their research and research training effort. It should be noted that Bond University already has limited access to funding for research and research training available under this provision, and no-one would doubt that that is an excellent educational institution serving the community.

speech.para: In relation to the AQF board, the representatives from the states and when the auditing might take place, I do not have that answer for Senator Carr. I can say that there is a consultation process that has to be gone through, but at this stage it is unwise to put a time on when this might take place.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —It is one thing to express concern about limited access to research funding or research dollars for private universities, but the minister has not really addressed the issue that most people are concerned about—that is, not simply the transfer of funds but the fact that the eligibility for these funds is open to institutions and organisations that are not listed in the schedule of the act. That is why the amendments being put forward by Senator Carr are supported by the Democrats—to try to give some specificity, to make clear the institutions or the bodies that are eligible for that special research assistance.

speech.para: I do not think the government has really provided sufficient justification in any form or in either house as to why we should be looking at this funding contestability. Perhaps Minister Kemp's outdated white paper figures might suggest that we are adequately funding research in Australia, but I do not think anyone would deny that the quantum of funding available for research and development has declined and that we have seen radical cuts to higher education institutions—in every sense, not simply to operating grants—and an increased expectation that they will rely on `user pays' to resource their institutions. Without a substantial increase in the quantum of funding to compensate for some of those past cuts—cuts which combine with the decline in funding relative to GDP; in our report, we talk about a seven per cent decline since 1995-96—the possible diversion of funds away from public institutions to private organisations will exacerbate these pressures. We are not simply talking about the Bonds of the world; we are talking about organisations like Microsoft and Telstra. That was what was provided in evidence to the Senate committee—that these rules would allow for private companies that may already have broad infrastructure, that would already have a research and development unit or resources, to access these research dollars at the expense of public institutions that are heavily reliant on these resources.

We are yet to hear a justification from the government as to why that is appropriate, although maybe this government would justify it in the context of having no problems in shifting to the private sector—whether it is private institutions or private schools—money from the public sector. Maybe that is an ideological issue that we will never meet on, but I cannot see how the government can continue to justify not only the time line on contestability but the actual issue itself. When you take into account the funding decline we have seen in relation to research, when you take into account the cuts that have been made to higher education institutions and when you take into account that these private organisations or private organisation institutions have a lot of money to spend on research, we should not be abrogating government responsibility by redirecting these funds elsewhere. I guess that gets to the heart of the earlier Democrat amendments and amendments yet to come which oppose the transfer of those funds. This process should not be rushed, and it should not be happening along these lines; there is certainly a lot of evidence to substantiate that argument, but there is limited evidence to substantiate the government's consequential provisions. Indeed, there is little rationale for what they are doing in the context of supporting public institutions. I cannot think of a time when our higher education public institutions have needed more support—yet what we are giving them is the opportunity to compete with Telstra, for goodness sake.
Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 3:

quote.para: (3) Schedule 1, item 4, page 4 (lines 8 to 13), omit subsection (1E) (but not the note), substitute:
(1E) The Minister may, by instrument in writing, determine requirements to be satisfied for a plan to be approved under paragraph (1C)(b).

speech.para: Amendment (3) goes to the issue of removing the minister's power to bypass the AQF process in approving funding. The Labor Party's approach on this issue of quality assurance has two strings to its bow. On the one hand, we are saying that there needs to be a schedule in the HEFA act which designates the particular institutions that are eligible, and that is a process by which the parliament can have some form of review. We are also suggesting that the AQF process is not without merit. Our concern is that, in its present format, it may need a good deal more work. But, in the longer term, we believe that it will be able to produce a strong quality assurance framework which will allow us to have a look at how the universities are comparing with one another.

During the Senate inquiry into the Australian Research Council Bill 2000 and the Australian Research Council (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2000, I pressed this issue quite strongly. I think it would be fair to say that every witness that appeared before the inquiry held a similar view—that is, that the government's proposals in this regard were quite contrary to the established wisdom within the industry, across all shades of opinion. It got to the point where it was put that the interpretation of subsections (1D), (1B), (1E) and (1E)(b), as given by the minister's powers to bypass the AQF process in handing out Commonwealth funding, were incorrect—a view even the department was obliged to support. I know it is difficult to get the department to agree more generally with the industry at large, but every now and then these strange mysteries unfold before us. We heard Mr Gallagher say to us:

quote.para: We have heard the evidence given to the committee that this has been interpreted as giving the minister much wider power. As a member of MCEETYA, the minister recently signed up to a set of national protocols that go to achieving some consistency across the country for the accreditation of higher education institutions and courses. He has no interest in circumventing those procedures. Without subsections (1D)(b) and (1E)(b), the bill would not be substantially altered. It is merely a contingency measure.

speech.para: In other advice, we have basically had the proposition put to us that this is a bit of a drafting error, that it is a bit of a mistake, and that it was not intended that the bill would be interpreted in the way it has universally been interpreted. In fact, I asked a question of Mr Gallagher as to whether or not the department would be recommending to the minister that he accept amendments in the chamber if the Senate chose to remove these subsections, given that they did not really matter. Mr Gallagher was very helpful and he advised that the department would be recommending that to the minister. One can only presume that Mr Gallagher is true to his word in these matters and that the department has recommended to the minister that he accept these amendments. One could not see any possible reason why the government could seriously oppose these propositions. I am looking forward to the minister's detailed argument which will justify what, to all intents and purposes, would be a bizarre situation: if the minister were to suddenly discover that there was something wrong with these propositions, given the evidence that we have from every quarter of the industry and from the department itself. We are assuming that the minister will now stand before us and tell us that it is a good idea and that the government had better support the Labor Party in these matters. Minister, I give you this opportunity to do so.

Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I could not resist that, Senator Carr. The government will not oppose this provision.
—The walls of Jericho have fallen!

talk.start.para: —The walls of Jericho have not really fallen, Senator Carr. For the record, it was the 17th time that the opposition and the government opposed the accountability amendments. subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Ellison:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has proven time and again that he is not concerned about wasting parliamentary time on lost causes. Every bill that he has put on the Notice Paper in this session is proof of that. With the Workplace Relations Amendment (Tallies and Picnic Days) Bill 2000, he goes one step further, putting forward a lost cause which is so petty, minor and pointless that we really must question whether he has lost the plot in the legislative sense. Before turning to the bill itself, I want to look briefly at its history to illustrate the point that this bill was in fact dead in the water well before today. The proposals contained in this bill were first brought before the parliament last year in the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment More Jobs Better Pay) Bill, or mojo bill. The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Committee considered the bill at great length. The conclusion of the Labor senators and the Democrat senator, Senator Murray, was that the bill was the most worthless piece of ideologically driven, antiunion and antiworker legislation. The Labor Party indicated its total opposition to the legislation and, with small exceptions, the Democrats did the same. The minister is not the type, though, to let complete and utter defeat put him off. Thus, we are here today.

speech.para: Since the blocking of that legislation, he has returned to the fray with four pieces of legislation—this being the first—which have been raised from the wreckage of his mojo bill. In a style he has made his own, the minister—whom I characterise as the `minister for misrepresentation'—not only has returned with four of the most worthless elements of his discredited mojo package but would have us believe that he is doing so after thoughtful consideration of the results of last year's fiasco. In his second reading speech on this bill—it is important to note that this comment is repeated in the second reading speeches of the three other surviving mojo bills—he asserts that the return of these four bills is a considered response to the Democrats' comments about these proposals. To quote the minister:

quote.para: Since opposing the `more jobs, better pay bill 1999' last November, the Democrats have publicly indicated that they prefer to deal with the contents of that bill on an issue by issue basis, not as an omnibus piece of legislation.
In a speech to the ACT Industrial Relations Society on 6 April 2000, Democrats spokesman Senator Murray said:

`In my view only technical bills should be general and broad ranging. Policy bills should be specific. It is far better for a reformist government to deal with one issue at a time on a specific and limited basis.'
And again, in the course of the inquiry by the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee into the bill, the senator said:
`It seems to me the act can be conveniently broken up into major sectors ... I find these kinds of omnibus bills result in a lot of negativity and it is very difficult to progress them.'

Taking these sentiments into account, the government has sought to accommodate the preferences of the Australian Democrats by proceeding, other than on technical issues, with an issue by issue consideration of policy matters arising from the more jobs better pay bill 1999.

speech.para: One has to admire Minister Reith for perhaps the magnitude and audacity of his misrepresentations. These make him that little bit special.

Senator Murray did, of course, say those things and there is no question that, in his supplementary report on the mojo bill, Senator Murray did express the view that some parts of the bill had merit. It was a 300-odd page bill with 16 schedules and you would be pretty unlucky not to include something worth while, even just by accident. But Senator Murray was also perfectly clear on his views and, by implication, the Australia Democrats' views on schedule 6, which this bill mirrors in part. Senator Murray said this:

quote.para: This is one of the least attractive schedules in the bill. It has the effect of watering down the award safety net and launching a further round of award changes when the current exercise of award simplification is only half complete.

speech.para: This general statement is hardly a ringing endorsement. If anyone but the current incumbent had the job, I would suggest it would be unlikely that they would be trying to salvage that proposal. I am absolutely certain that they would not be claiming that they were taking Democrat sentiments into account in putting these proposals up again.

This bill is never going anywhere. It was the subject of an appropriate level of consideration last year and was found wanting. Only a masochist would have returned to the scene of their greatest beating, as the minister has. Unfortunately for the parliament, Minister Reith's desire to be re-issued that beating is a monstrous waste of the time of this parliament.

Let us look at this specific bill, the first of the four, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Tallies and Picnic Days) Bill 2000. This bill serves as a potent illustration of two symptoms that have plagued this minister's tenure in the workplace relations portfolio. Firstly, it illustrates his obsession with matters ideological at the expense of sensible and practical solutions and, secondly, it shows once more the arrogance of the minister in usurping the role of the independent umpire in favour of his own biased, irrational and political solutions. On that point, let me be totally clear. The Australian Labor Party believe in the role of an independent umpire. We have protected the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, where we could, from attacks on it by this minister and we will continue to do so and to support it. The commission has been part of the structures governing industrial relations in this country for 100 years and has, for most of that time, been able to exercise discretion unfettered by a partisan government. In 1996, that minister changed all that. In limiting the matters allowed in an award, the minister placed himself in the role of the industrial arbitrator. Never before had a government asserted such a place for itself in the industrial framework. This bill is a continuation of that awful aberration.

This bill has two parts, as the title suggests: one dealing with the removal of tallies from allowable award matters and the other dealing with the removal of picnic days from allowable award matters. Perhaps the irony to highlight here is that, with the Prime Minister and the minister's recent statements about the importance of their industrial relations reform agenda, it appears likely that tallies and picnic days will be the matter that the government allows some degree of time for in the very important allocation of parliamentary business to conclude this session. This is despite the statements made by the Prime Minister at the ACCI annual dinner last week that it was up there, out front and the most important thing this government was dealing with. So here we are, one week later, and it looks like, of all the industrial matters that have been sitting on the Notice Paper for quite some time, we will deal with tallies and picnic days.

It is clear on the evidence received by the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business Committee from industrial participants—that is, unlike the minister, people who know what they are talking about in these areas—that the changes proposed in this bill are either unnecessary or unworkable. Let us deal with the first in the case of tallies. What is proposed in this bill is now completely superfluous. The issue here relates to just one award, if you believe the government's case. The award governs the meat industry. What we have here is the minister dancing to the tune played by the National Farmers Federation. When this provision was first proposed in the More Jobs Better Pay bill, the meat industry award had a tally system determining pay rates in that industry. The National Farmers Federation was seeking to have the tally system removed by applying to the commission and arguing that it was out of date. This was the normal and appropriate way to go about it. In fact, it is the way every other employer would and does go about it. But the National Farmers Federation wanted an insurance policy. If you have an antiworker, ideologically positioned minister, then you will get the hearing and you will get this sort of action. For, like the faithful servant of the employers that he is, the minister came to the party with this legislation.

As a result of the National Farmers Federation's application to the commission, in a decision by the full bench handed down on 1 September 2000 the commission removed the tally system from the meat industry award. Again, this action is superfluous. But let us go back to how the commission's decision highlights our case that these matters should be handled by the commission. In reaching its finding and in its decision, the commission indicated that it had to be mindful of the transition arrangements—the move from one system to another. And there are some concerns with perhaps the ongoing effect of this legislation. Whilst the commission has determined the issue in relation to the meat industry, there are perhaps two outstanding issues on which this legislation may have an unintended impact: on incentive payment systems in other awards that might be characterised as tallies, and in respect of whether appropriate transition arrangements are incorporated.

I see that Senator Murray has circulated the Democrats amendments in the chamber. They are seeking to look at a couple of those issues. As I understand it, a transition period of six months is regarded as insufficient by the Democrats. They are proposing a 12-month period and also a change to what would be the definitional arrangements in effect to protect or preserve incentive based payments from the reach of the provisions in this bill. We would argue that that is why these matters should not be removed as allowable matters and that the commission is the best judge for dealing with these issues as they pertain to any particular industry that may fall within the scope of the issues associated with tallies, their currency and whether they should be removed from awards.

I want to go back to the National Farmers Federation's main argument in relation to why we should legislate in relation to tallies. As a side issue from the fact that such legislation is now superfluous on the basis of the commission's action, the NFF's main argument was that justice delayed is justice denied. The National Farmers Federation have had their justice from the commission now. They got the decision that they essentially wanted. But we need to remind the community in general of the circumstances within which this decision was dealt with by the commission. We have had Justice Giudice recently coming out in the annual report of the industrial registry indicating that time delays are being imposed on the commission because of limitations in funding and the minister's approach to resourcing the Australian Industrial Relations Commission while at the same time enforcing on that commission significant changes in its workload. I note today that it has been announced that the minister has appointed four new senior deputy presidents to the commission. This was one of the most glaring needs in terms of resourcing for the commission, but there were many other areas highlighted by Justice Giudice when he said that these issues are causing the commission delay. Yet, on the other hand, we have the National Farmers Federation arguing that justice delayed is justice denied. Rather than this superfluous and unnecessary legislation which is wasting all of our time, it would perhaps be better if the minister looked at more adequately resourcing the independent umpire—that being the commission—so that he could deal with some of these things in a much more timely fashion.

As I said, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision in relation to tallies in the meat industry illustrates the merits of the Labor Party's position in our central dispute with this government over industrial relations. We say the commission is best placed to determine what is and what is not contained in awards. The minister thinks he is best placed to determine the industrial arrangements between parties. But the government does not hear all the evidence. The government does not know the intricacies of the industries involved and the government is certainly not impartial. What the minister is left with is a piece of worthless, pointless legislation insofar as it purports to deal with tallies, but he perseveres. I would like to address next the issue in the legislation of union picnic days.
Debate interrupted.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: —Order! The committee is considering the Gene Technology Bill 2000 as amended, and amendment Nos 1 to 8 on sheet 2062 moved by Senator Brown. Item 6 is to oppose clause 141, so the question will be that clause 141 stand as printed.

—In the earlier consideration of this matter, I asked the parliamentary secretary if he would explain the wording on the proposed schedule under the heading `Dealings exempt from licensing'. It says `any dealing involving a host vector system mentioned in part 2 of this schedule if the dealing does not involve an intentional release into the environment'. I want to know what is meant by that. Is the laboratory dealing with gene technology signing up to say they do not intend to release it into the environment? If so, what the heck are they putting all their money into this experiment for? On the other hand, if they do not intend to release it into the environment, what are the safeguards in this process to ensure that it will not be released into the environment, particularly as this dealing is going to be exempt from the Gene Technology Regulator's overview?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the area where Senator Brown raises his concerns is an area where there will be strict surveillance and licensing required by the regulator with regard to the release in any of these areas.

—Where is that strict overview and watchfulness by the Gene Technology Regulator laid down? I would have thought it would be in that regulation. If it is not there, is it in the bill? If it is not there, where is it going to be?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the exemption is only in respect of those contained areas of work; otherwise, the full regulatory system applies.

—It is the contained areas that are not subject to the regulatory system that we are looking at. We now have this term `contained area'. If there is an experiment going on in the contained area—which means a laboratory that is exempt from being licensed—what is the process for oversighting those premises to make sure that whatever is going on in there is contained in that area, and that there is not an escape into the environment? Moreover, in that regulation, what does the parliamentary secretary mean by, `You get exempted provided you do not intend to release something to the environment'? It is not very well thought out. Most experiments that are taking place under such conditions are for gene technology, which has at the end a patenting process and a profit motive. People who remember the calicivirus experiment, for example, will want to know that where such experimentation has taken place it is not just contained by the people involved in that experimentation—that there is some federal regulatory system and inspection system which make sure that what is going on in there is not a threat to the environment. By the way, I do not think the environment is separate from what is going on in the laboratory—there is a continuum; people coming and going all the time, and so on. We need to know that experiments that involve gene technology are safely contained. The government is aware that there is a need for this through the very way in which this regulation is written. On the face of it, it seems to be saying that, if you have an experiment going on in a laboratory which involves the manipulation of genes and it is a contained area, you will not need a licence; you are exempted. Having got the exemption, I want to know how that laboratory experimentation is policed. It is a pretty simple proposition that we should have that information.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the regulator will be doing full inspections of these particular areas and the facilities will be fully certified under the bill to ensure that the facility is appropriate to the dealing. Exempt dealings do not involve intentional release into the environment. If they want to release, the full regulatory system applies and they need to have a licence.
—Senator Hill. Correction: Senator Brown.
—I will think about that one, Chair.
—Don't! It's a bit early in the night for that.
—The night will never be long enough for that one.

—I am chuffed. First—and we can get this information while we are talking—I want to know how many people are employed by the Gene Technology Regulator at the moment in policing activities. They have some pretty onerous duties, we now find. Secondly, where does the intention not to release something into the environment alter to an intention to release it into the environment? I would say that it comes when an experiment has turned up something that the experimenters think they can turn into money and it is going to be useful in the marketplace. I do not think we should leave it to that being the arbiter of when an intention not to release something into the environment becomes an intention to release something into the environment.

speech.para: The point I am putting is: I cannot see why any of these places should be exempt from licensing. That is the whole point of the Greens amendments. We are saying: where there is gene manipulation taking place, that place should be licensed. The Gene Technology Regulator should be keeping an overview; it should be on the public record; there should be a one-stop shop so that any member of the public can know what is happening as far as gene manipulation in this country is concerned—particularly research and experimentation. We believe that you should know where it is occurring and that the whole process should be transparent. This suite of amendments says: `Let's not have exemptions; particularly, let's not have exemptions which apply to places which are engaged in experimentation which inherently, by the wording of the regulations, would worry the government if that was released into the environment.' The parliamentary secretary might explain why these places should be exempt. It is as simple as that.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —There were a number of questions raised by Senator Brown. Earlier in his comments he asked a question about staffing and numbers. I am advised that the current staffing of the Interim Office of Gene Technology Regulator is approximately 40. However, that is not a limited number. There will always be enough employed later if necessary to do the job, and of course there will be special contracting arrangements—whether that is with AQIS, the state agencies, environment agencies et cetera—to undertake inspections and monitoring on the regulator's behalf.

speech.para: With regard to the latter part of the question, most exempt dealings relate to the use of GMOs as tools in basic medical and biological research and would never be intended for release into the environment. I would also refer Senator Brown to the explanatory guide with regard to the regulations. At page 39 it says, `The exemptions apply to a very limited number of dealings with GMOs that have been assessed over time as presenting no significant biosafety risks to public health and safety, including occupational health and safety or the environment, and are undertaken within contained facilities; that is, they do not involve intentional release of a GMO into the environment.'

talk.start.para: —The parliamentary secretary says that it is okay, because these experiments do not involve any significant risk to the safety and health of Australia. I would of course move on to ask, `What is the meaning of this word "significant"?' There is a value judgment written in there. It is always a bad word. We should be legislating to take away that value judgment and make it clear. The parliamentary secretary has not answered the question: `What is the problem with having these places licensed and an eye kept on them?' I do not believe there is an argument for that. I believe that all such places involved in gene experimentation should be registered and what they are doing available to public view. That is why, amongst other things, we have been suggesting that this whole process of licensing gene technology in Australia be a one-stop shop and that the public have access to it through the Internet so they can see what is going on, where it is going on, and what it is for.

speech.para: The parliamentary secretary says, `These experiments are of such a nature that it is intended that they will never be released into the environment.' What on earth are they doing it for? Does it mean that they cannot be applied to human beings, that they are not going to be applied to crops, or that they are not going to be applied to anything outside laboratories? What on earth is going on? I do not believe that. In fact, it is not so. The aim of this experimentation is either highly altruistic—that is, to intervene for medical benefit—or, more likely, a profit motivation to create some new knowledge which can be patented and from which the people who are investing in the laboratory, wherever it might be, can get a good return. I cannot see why, given all of that, we should have these exemptions. I might ask: is the point of the exemptions to reduce the workload on the Gene Technology Regulator? I would have thought that would be the first thing the parliamentary secretary would come back with, but he hasn't.

Finally, what happened to the Gene Technology Regulator at Mount Gambier? There is something that was not exempt, where the containment process broke down, where genetically modified material was dumped right outside the place from which it had come—outside the so-called safety zone—and the Gene Technology Regulator did not know about it and was found to have been very short of the mark in policing that crop and that dumping of waste from the crop. If the Gene Technology Regulator is not policing that sort of thing, what faith are we to have that there is going to be adequate policing of laboratories which are exempt from the need for a licence?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —There is a very big distinction between those arrangements that have applied as an interim arrangement and the issues that applied to Mount Gambier and to what is now being proposed as the permanent arrangement. You cannot not have exempt dealings if the risks are low, the dealing is within a contained facility, the facility is monitored and inspected regularly and there is a history of use that demonstrates low risks where exemptions are appropriate. I should stress that the list in the regulations is a draft list. This seems to be the point that Senator Brown is missing. If Senator Brown has scientific data that would support removing GMOs from the exempt list, it is appropriate that this be brought forward. I think many of the issues that he has highlighted were addressed by Senator Crowley's committee, particularly those relating to Mount Gambier. Exempt dealings represent negligible risks, and exemptions relate only to very low risk activities occurring in laboratories only. This work has been exempt for the past 20 years and there have been no risks or problems identified. Even once the list is finalised, the exempt GMOs will continue to be reviewed by the regulator. So I would hope that Senator Brown would feel that what is being intended in the legislation certainly is comprehensive enough.
—So there we have it: it is going to come down to my responsibility to keep a watch on all these places—
—Then we are safe, Senator.

—Yes, I am going to be busy and put in a complaint if I do not think it is being adequately looked after. This is why we need a register. We need nothing to be exempt; we need it all to be on the register and we need it to be available to people with much better knowledge in this matter than I. If there are no worries about that, the government should be agreeable to it. I think this is an extremely important point. This is about transparency and raising public confidence; it is a matter of being open about what is going on. The government simply has not been able to explain to me why we should exempt these places from licensing and the direct requirements of the Gene Technology Regulator as far as licensing is concerned.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —First of all, I wish to put on record the increasing concern that the Democrats have about the increasing amount of delegated legislation with which this chamber deals. Anyone who has been in parliament or has been working around legislation for the past 10 years would be aware of the changes we have seen in the amount of matter that ends up in regulations as opposed to in the actual legislation. So I want to ask the government why this is appearing before us—it is not being dealt with specifically today. Why are the definition and the criteria regarding exempt dealings in the form of regulation, delegated legislation, instead of in the bill, in the act, for which I think there are very strong arguments? I commend the role of the department in making available the regulations—as they did with the draft legislation—for public comment and consultation. It may have been a while since some of us looked at the regulations in detail but, looking at them in detail, I have a question for the minister in relation to part 1, exempt dealings. This is regulation 9, item (4), which states:

quote.para: Any dealing involving a host/vector system, mentioned in Part 2 of this Schedule, if...

speech.para: And it goes on to list a series. I am interested in item (4)(a)(vi), which reads:

quote.para: does not comprise or represent more than two-thirds of the genome of a virus or viroid and the dealing is not an experiment in which the genetic material missing from the viral genome, and essential for producing infection, is available in the cell into which the incomplete genome is introduced, or would be made available by subsequent breeding processes;

speech.para: I would like the minister to outline for the benefit of the Senate his understanding of that particular section. Senator Brown is correct when he says that we do not want to have to be relying on people simply with our levels of knowledge in this debate. There is good reason for more information to be made available to the public and for experts to be responsible. When I say `experts' I include the public in my definition, because I think you have to balance scientific expertise with that of lay people and community and public general concern. I want to know how what I have just read out sits in relation to certain aspects of first-generational agricultural gene technology—that is, where you see the insertion of a virus genes into crop plants, obviously to protect them against disease. But we know what sort of mutations can take place as a consequence of that, intentional or otherwise. Does section 6 guard against that—for example, migrating viruses acquiring the inserted genes and producing novel viruses with new properties, something which was pointed out in a couple of submissions that the Democrats have provided to various government committees? So I want to know what `does not comprise or represent more than two-thirds of the genome of a virus or viroid and the dealing is not an experiment ...' means in terms of the insertion of virus genes into, say, crop plants.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I can appreciate that people who have a far more scientific involvement in this area than I can often be very confusing. I appreciate that the need to give good information at this particular stage of the debate is very important. I am advised that exempt dealings are in the regulations because they will be regularly reviewed and monitored by the regulator and updated regularly. I think this is the very point that Senator Brown was making earlier: that there is obviously a philosophic point there as to the differences in when regulation ought to apply and what should be in the legislation that may require subsequent changes and appropriate review from time to time—where it is much more appropriate to have those matters dealt with by regulation.

speech.para: Senator Stott Despoja said that the issue was confusing and required further clearer articulation. The issue was reconsidered by the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee and other experts, and this provision is being revised in the next draft of the regulations to be released this month. It gives people the opportunity to provide further comment. The reason the government has released the regulations early—as you say, Senator—is to ensure that they are fully tested by the community. We will continue to refine them over the coming months before bringing them before the parliament.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for his answer. I am assuming that you meant that part (vi), to which I referred, was going to be clarified.
—Yes.

—What I am curious about, though, is the intent of that. I am not meaning to be difficult or pedantic; I am genuinely interested to find out not only the intent of that particular part of the regulations—acknowledging that it may be updated or made better or whatever—but, if it is going to be improved or articulated in a better fashion, the purpose and the impact that that might have, for example, in relation to allowing the insertion of virus genes. I suppose we are trying to establish—though I cannot speak for Senator Brown—what kinds of safe mechanisms we are putting in place with not only these regulations but also even the allowance of exempt dealings. I think there is probably a spectrum here. You could argue, `Do we really need anything to be exempt?' I am sure there are arguments in favour of minimal exemptions. But I am not satisfied that these regulations necessarily provide for those exemptions, if any should be allowed. So I am curious to find out not only the intent of that part but also the implications of the amendment.

speech.para: I guess this returns to the issue that was discussed before question time. It seems a long time ago now, but it will probably seem even longer by the time we have got through this bill tonight, if indeed we do. In the question that Senator Brown raised he genuinely made a plea for specificity and an example. I know some examples were provided but I do not think they were in the form that satisfied the chamber—for example, what does this mean; what can we tell people in the street that this means; what kinds of things will be exempt? I understood from the parliamentary secretary's response before question time the kinds of things that would be exempt, but now I am really curious to get into the nitty-gritty and to find out what it means for viruses or what have you. Why do we qualify it by saying `does not comprise or represent two-thirds of the genome of a virus or variant'? I am genuinely interested. I am happy for the parliamentary secretary to take this on notice for a while as we proceed with this debate. I know he has expert advisers—they know their genetics back and forth—so I am quite happy to wait. The parliamentary secretary does not have to deal with this immediately, because I think this debate is probably going to go all night.

talk.start.para: —I want to make some very brief comments on the points that my colleagues have talked about. We are dealing here with some exemptions that are written in language that is so technical that I would imagine that even some scientists may not understand what this is about. It is very specific. I think people might be terribly interested to know what a gene-knockout mouse is. Fortunately, there is a brief explanation—that is, `a mouse whose genetic modification involves deletion or inactivation of a specific gene'. So that is someone that has been kayoed. So a piece of gene is kayoed; hence the term `gene knockout mice'.

speech.para: Item 4, which we are talking to, as Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Brown has said, says that any dealing involving a host/vector system as mentioned in part 2 of the schedule is exempt `if the donor DNA ...' and then there are six points which are all followed by the word `and'. I need to know if this donor DNA has to be all of those things or some of those things. The word `and' there instead of `and/or' makes it specific. As I understand it, to be an exempt dealing the donor DNA would have to be (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v) and (vi): that is, if it:

quote.para: is not derived from microorganisms capable of causing disease in human beings, other animals, plants or fungi, or is fully characterised—

speech.para: and someone might explain as a footnote what being `fully characterised means'—

quote.para: and will not increase the virulence of the host or vector; and is not an oncogene; and—

speech.para: which I think means will cause cancer—

quote.para: does not code for a toxin for vertebrates with an LD50 of less than 100 micrograms/kg; and—

speech.para: we are now going deep into specificity—

quote.para: is not uncharacterised DNA from a toxin-producing organism; and the dealing does not involve an intentional release into the environment; and—

speech.para: That is the point that Senator Stott Despoja read out. Are these all necessary definitions of the donor DNA that must all be fulfilled to allow that to be exempt?

A lot of people might be terribly pleased to meet a non-conjugative plasmid. It sounds like something in a sci-fi film. I do not wish to mock the language of science. I have been around it long enough to know that these things have very specific meanings, and it may be important to have those specific meanings written—possibly better than having them all hidden. But I would suggest that, first of all, we need it explained and then we have to deal with the fact that it is highly technical and we will possibly need some kind of commonsense or colloquial explanation—that is, that DNA is not going to make the organism into which it is put sicker, or get cancer or be poisoned and then subsequently be released into the atmosphere. I think we will probably need to spell out some of the high-tech science so as to make it clear to people what is being protected. But we have to also appreciate that this is going to be the cause of a lot of furrowed eyebrows in the public arena.

So we might need to look at a way in which it can possibly be explained to people in some kind of colloquial fashion. It may indeed have to be the challenge of the community education sector—I hope by an independent source—which might want talk to people about what GE, GM, or whatever it is, is doing. I ask a specific question: in (4), as each of those clauses is followed by `and', does it have to be all of those? It does. The advisers are nodding, so perhaps you could put that on the record, Senator Tambling.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am responding to questions in this section by both Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Crowley. Can I make clear to Senator Stott Despoja that the intent is not to allow infectious viruses to be produced. The intention of (vi)(a) is that, if there is any likelihood that the production of the GMO were likely to result in the production of an infectious virus from the GMO, the dealing would not be exempt. Again, as Senator Stott Despoja mentioned, if she would like anything further on this matter or additional information, I would be happy to take that on notice and provide her with written explanations of that particular area.

speech.para: On the issues that have been raised by Senator Crowley, it is always a difficult balancing act to draft regulations that are sufficiently certain and scientifically clear yet also able to be read by lay people. The regulations have been drafted based on existing GMAC guidelines that have been used for years and understood within the scientific community. However, we take the point raised by Senator Crowley about the drafting—and this was raised during the consultations—and we are certainly attempting to simplify that in the next draft. With regard to the specific question asked by Senator Crowley, which focused on `and'—all the points from 4(a)(i) to 4(a)(vi) must be fulfilled for the GMO to be exempt.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to Greens' amendment (6), I would like to look specifically at section 141, which this amendment opposes. Looking at the structure of section 141, the regulator may review exemptions. It states:

quote.para: The regulator may, at any time, in accordance with this Division, consider the following matters:
(a) whether a dealing that is an exempt dealing within the meaning of subsection 32(3) should not be an exempt dealing;
(b) whether a dealing should be an exempt dealing within the meaning of that subsection.

speech.para: I would like to take the committee to division 2 of the bill on page 23, subsection 32(3), which says:

quote.para: exempt dealing means a dealing specified by the regulations to be an exempt dealing.

speech.para: In subsection (4) it goes on to say:

quote.para: Regulations under subsection (3)—

speech.para: which is the subsection I have just read—

quote.para: may be expressed to exempt:
all dealings dealings with a GMO or with a specified class of GMOs;
or
a specified class of dealings with a GMO or with a specified class of GMOs;
or
(c) one or more specified dealings with a GMO or with a specified class of GMOs.

speech.para: In that the Greens' amendment is speaking to subsection 32(3), when you read what the exempt dealing covers, I do not believe it is restricted by what Senator Tambling has been telling us. There is nothing in subsection 32(3) on the description of an exempt dealing, nor in subsection (4), which refers to that definition, that restricts any GMO to be an exempt dealing. In other words, I am saying that my reading of the bill is that it is wide open—not restricted, as Senator Tambling has expressed to us. I look to Senator Tambling for an explanation on how subsection (4) restricts an exempt dealing.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the combined effect of the bill and the regulations allows the capacity Senator Harris is raising. We believe that there should be exempt dealings, as long as these are regularly reviewed and monitored. That is what clause 141 does and why we would, therefore, oppose the Greens' amendment.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —People are starting to look even more confused. I would like to return Senator Tambling to my original question. I am still curious about (vi). I do not feel that the intent of that section has been adequately outlined to the chamber. Again, in the context of whether or not this allows the insertion of virus genes—and, if I am completely wrong on this, can your advisers please advise?—my reading of this means that the donor DNA cannot have more than two-thirds of the genome of a virus or a viroid and, in fact, that precise genetic material required for the purposes of producing an infection cannot be in it. Is that right? It reads: `The genetic material missing from the virus and essential for producing infection.' The components of that which are necessary for producing infection are not allowed to be a part of that—right? I got a nod from an adviser. I do not want to misrepresent—
(Senator Crowley)—I think you are right, Senator. It is important to ask Senator Tambling to make it clear on the record.

—In response to me last time, Senator Tambling spoke about the importance of intention. I guess what I am getting at is the notion that you may not intend to cause an infection or a certain consequence, but that does not mean it cannot happen. I am just wondering what, under these regulations, prevents that happening. According to this, those very features that produce infection cannot be a part of that donor DNA. That is what I want clarified, and not just in relation to the intent of that section. Senator Tambling was talking about `your intention of causing infection'. I hope that makes sense. What I am trying to get at is: how much of a virus can you insert?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I give the assurance that I gave previously and reiterate the point that the intent is not to allow infectious viruses to be produced. Regarding the issues that Senator Stott Despoja raised, again I would like to make the offer that I made earlier in the evening: in the course of the debate, we would be happy to give a written statement that I think will clarify this in the way in which she is expecting and anticipating. If she would take that in good faith, I think it can be provided in the very near future.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I did not realise that Senator Tambling's earlier offer was within the context of this debate. That gives us about three days, I reckon.
—You've got tonight!
—You should be so sure, Parliamentary Secretary. I am not so sure myself. I will take on board that assurance and we will return to this issue later.

—I return to the situation that I put to Senator Tambling. There is nothing in his answer that gives me any confidence. Senator Tambling clearly said that the government will be relying on the review of regulations to specify what exempt dealings are. My point to Senator Tambling, through you, Madam Temporary Chairman, is that if subclause 32(4) stands, it is possible that all dealings with a GMO or with a specified class of GMOs could be an exempt dealing. I do not believe that this should be so. For the regulator, under section 141, to have the expressed ability to review exemptions both ways—whether they should or should not be—is inappropriate. At this point, this section does leave the ability at some future time for the regulator to say that all dealings with a GMO come under an exempt dealing. This is the concern that Senator Brown has also raised in relation to this section.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The bill and the regulations must be taken together to give the assurance that Senator Harris is seeking in this regard. It is when you put the two into context and in parallel that you achieve that. I refer Senator Harris to page 57 of the explanatory memorandum to the Gene Technology Bill where it states:

quote.para: GMOs may be defined by a range of matters. For example, an exempt class of dealings with a GMO may be limited by the type of GMO, who deals with the GMO, how the GMO is dealt with and whether the GMO is regulated under existing legislation.

speech.para: It is the regulations that provide that exemptions must not involve intentional release of a GMO into the environment. In addition—and I have mentioned this earlier this evening in debate—the next version of regulations will provide that the exempt dealings must occur within a secured working environment.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Tambling for his answer. I draw the attention of the committee to the paragraph preceding the one that Senator Tambling has just read out. I will not persist with this—I will just read the first line:

quote.para: Sub-clause 32(4) provides that regulations may exempt all dealings with a GMO ...

speech.para: That is a direct quote from the government's own explanatory memorandum. I do not think it can be put any clearer.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harris and I have probably exhausted the particular issue. I go back to the issue that was raised previously by Senator Stott Despoja when I said that I would seek further information. I am advised that the intent is that, if the dealing involves a viral sequence, the sequence must be missing at least one gene essential for viral manipulation and the DNA must not be able to complement or recombine to produce with infectious virus a viral vector used in the host vector system or with viral genes present in the host. This intent will be reflected more clearly in the next draft of the regulations. I hope that gives you the assurance you were seeking.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for the explanation of the intent of (vi). Perhaps he could table the notes from which he was reading. I understand how the reworded intent seeks to echo that in the original (vi), although it does read, obviously, quite differently in terms of the notion that there has to be missing one gene component that would be essential for the purposes of viral manipulation, et cetera. So thank you for that, but can it be put on the record, please?
—Certainly.
(Senator Crowley)—The question is that clause 141 stand as printed.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Would senators please resume their seats. The question now is that amendments (1) to (5) and (7) and (8) be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, the contrary no. I think the noes have it. Senator Brown, are you seeking the call?
—I find it impossible to know what is going on with the current state of the committee.
—I have just put the motion that amendments (1) to (5) and (7) and (8) be agreed to, and the noes have it.
—The ayes have it, in that case.
—Division required?
—Yes, in that case.
—Are there two voices requesting a division? As there are, ring the bells for one minute.

para.inline: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

talk.start.para: —Chair, I did not hear you putting anything to the chamber because there was confusion reigning supreme.
—I am sorry, Senator Harradine, I have put the question that (1) to (5) and (7) and (8) be agreed to. I called it for the noes. Do you have a point of order?
—Yes; you have no right to put that when honourable senators have not heard what you are putting.
—I am sorry but—
—We were not back in our seats. So under those circumstances you could have ruled us out of order for voting when we were not in our seats.
—I am not ruling you out of order, Senator Harradine. I have called—
—I am raising a point of order.
—I am sorry, Senator Harradine, if you did not hear me make the call.
—On a point of order, Madam Chair: as I understand it, the bells are ringing outside now. I want your direction as to what is actually happening.
—This is because the division was called.
—Is the division actually proceeding? If so, from what time?
—The time for the division is up because it was a one-minute division. But it would appear that many bodies have—

—Madam Chair, if I could point out to you the fact that the bells were ringing outside whilst the vote was proceeding here on the point of order from Senator Harradine; I just want your direction. I think the bells should ring for at least one minute more to give honourable senators the opportunity to convene.
—Madam Chair, could I speak to the point of order?
—Okay, but before anybody else speaks: will people standing around resume your appropriate seats in the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam Chair. I am flattered that they have all come down to hear this speech. Given that, as I understand it, you put the motion on the amendments at a time when people were returning to their seats and there was a fair amount of noise and a lot of people did not hear it, could I suggest that we put the motion again. Then we can proceed and get on with it. We have a long night ahead of us, and I think that would be a good idea.
—I will put the question again if that would be the wish of the committee.
—On the point of order, Madam Chair, I want to support what Senator Forshaw said. We should start again and have a four-minute bell and re-present the thing.
—No, I am actually going to go back. Is it the wish of the committee that I put it all again? It being so, the question is that amendments (1) to (5) and (7) and (8) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 5 to 8 on sheet 2026:

quote.para: (5) Clause 32, page 23 (line 22), before "2,000", insert "imprisonment for 5 years or".
(6) Clause 32, page 23 (line 23), before "500", insert "imprisonment for 2 years or".
(7) Clause 34, page 25 (line 12), before "2,000", insert "imprisonment for 5 years or".
(8) Clause 34, page 25 (line 13), before "500", insert "imprisonment for 2 years or".

speech.para: These amendments mostly deal with clause 32 of the bill. That clause covers penalties prescribed where persons deal with a GMO without a licence. The current proposal is shown in clause 32(2) of the bill:

quote.para: (2) An offence under subsection (1) is punishable on conviction by a fine of not more than whichever of the following amounts applies:
(a) in the case of an aggravated offence—2,000 penalty units;
(b) in any other case—500 penalty units.

speech.para: The proposal of the opposition is to amend clause 32 and clause 34 in their respective sections to insert a provision which would provide also for imprisonment. The proposal is that, where there is a prescribed penalty at the moment in the bill of 2,000 penalty units, there be also inserted a provision for an offence under that subsection to carry an imprisonment term of five years. Correspondingly, where the proposed penalty is for 500 penalty units, we propose an amendment to insert a provision which would encompass the option of two years imprisonment. Clearly, the more serious penalty reflects the more serious offence, referred to as an `aggravated offence'. We believe that these penalties will give the regulator real teeth when it comes to enforcing the requirements of the act and particularly in punishing any offences under the legislation, as referred to in clause 32. We submit—and we would hope that the Senate would agree—that some of the serious offences should, where appropriate, provide for a term of imprisonment rather than a fine. Giving the penalties regime this strength would, in our view, minimise the chances of the sorts of incidents that have been referred to earlier in the debate and are well known—such as that which occurred at Mount Gambier and that of the cottonseed release—from happening again.

For completeness, I will refer to a further amendment, amendment No. 9, which I will be moving next. That amendment will provide that, where a person or an organisation commits a breach, they can be fined for each day that the offence continues, for up to 100 per cent of the initial penalty. So not only do we strengthen the provisions in providing for terms of imprisonment but also, in the next amendment, we provide for the penalty to have a compounding effect where the offence continues each day. I seek the support of the Senate for our amendments in that area.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will support the amendments put forward by the opposition. The inadequacy of the penalties outlined in the act has been the subject of great debate, and certainly the penalty provisions have been subject to quite a deal of criticism. These are well documented in the Senate committee report of the inquiry into this bill. For the record, I note that the ACF stated that penalties for committing an offence under the bill are `grossly inadequate'. The Friends of the Earth Fitzroy argued that the maximum penalties for infringing the provisions of the bill should be increased tenfold. Similarly, the National Genetic Awareness Alliance also provided evidence along those lines. It was a conclusion and a committee recommendation that the penalties be increased not only in a monetary sense but also with the possibility of allowing for a term of imprisonment. The Democrats are glad to see that that is a recommendation that has been adopted by the opposition, and I hope it will receive the majority support of the chamber.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the government will accept these amendments, which will include imprisonment terms for breaches of the legislation.

—I also support the opposition's amendments. I seek some clarification from Senator Tambling in relation to section 32. The bill refers to a person not dealing with a GMO without a licence. I seek clarification as to a corporation that did deal with a GMO substance without a licence. Who does the government intend that that section of the bill would refer to? Would it be the chief executive officer, would it be the board or would it be an actual person who is an employee? Or—I stress this point—could this section of the bill refer to a person who is an agent of that person? I seek clarification as to who the actual individual would be should this section of the legislation be implemented.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I refer Senator Harris to division 4, clause 188 of the bill. This deals with conduct by directors, employees and agents. It is set out on pages 123 and 124 of the bill in considerable detail. I think it would address—as would the explanatory memorandum—the issues that are very specifically raised by Senator Harris. I think all his issues and concerns will again be covered in clause 188.

—I ask Senator Tambling whether the actual transportation of a product that is a result of a genetically modified organism would fall within a licence and, if this is so, where the bill covers that. Also, in part 2, division 2, section 10, on page 6 of the bill, under the definitions of `dealing with', would that section of the bill also cover the storage of a GMO? It may not be entirely appropriate for this to be discussed in the penalty section of the bill, but I would like to ensure that, when a person obtains a licence, that licence would also cover the transport of any product that is a result of that genetic modification. Can we also ensure that the actual storage of the product is covered? If, for example, I am using canola seed that has been produced in a trial process and that seed has been harvested, does the bill cover the storage of that product prior to its being either shipped overseas or used anywhere in Australia?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that I can give Senator Harris the assurance he seeks: the storage is certainly covered. The definitions, as he pointed out, relating to section 10 on page 6 of the bill which deal with `dealing with' cover the very issue he first raised with regard to transport and, certainly, storage, and it is intended to cover all those incidental issues that arise.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (9):

quote.para: (9) Clause 34, page 25 (after line 14), at the end of the clause, add:

(4) A person who is guilty of an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of a separate offence in respect of each day (including the day of a conviction for the offence or any later day) on which the person is guilty of the offence.

speech.para: I did comment on the reasons for this amendment when dealing with opposition amendments (5) to (8). It is related to the issue of penalties.

talk.start.para: —I indicate to the chamber that Pauline Hanson's One Nation amendment (23) is similar to the opposition's amendment, the only difference being that in One Nation's amendment under subsection (2) we had clarified that the maximum penalty for each day that that offence continues is 10 per cent of the maximum penalty that could be imposed in respect of the principal offence. The amendment which Senator Forshaw has just moved is identical to One Nation's amendment except for that section. I will not proceed with that amendment but speak in support of the Labor amendment because it raises the issue that the unintentional release or the intentional release of a GMO into the environment is a substantial offence.

speech.para: I believe the bill should have sufficient teeth in its punitive action, so that those who do intend to deal in GMOs know exactly what the dangers are. We have all spoken about the Mount Gambier incident. I believe that, once this legislation is passed, such an incident would not be acceptable—it is not acceptable even without the legislation, but it would not occur because the responsibility will be there very clearly, for those people who have a licence, to carry out that licence in accordance with the conditions. I support the opposition amendment.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government is pleased to accept this amendment which is a natural extension to the stringent offence provisions already contained in the bill.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move One Nation amendments (22), (25), (92), (111) and (112):

quote.para: (22) Page 26 (after line 25), after clause 37, insert:

para.inline: 37A Person must not damage licence holder's property

quote.para: (1) A person who intentionally destroys or damages any property relating to the premises of a GMO licence holder without lawful excuse is guilty of an offence.
(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), a person destroys or damages property intentionally if, but only if:
(a) his or her purpose, or one of his or her purposes, is to destroy or damage property; or
(b) he or she knows, or believes, that his or her conduct is more likely than not to result in the destruction of, or damage to, property.

(3) For the purposes of subsection (1), it is not a lawful excuse that a person believed that to destroy or damage the premises or property of a GMO licence holder, a person covered by a GMO licence, or premises or property otherwise associated with a GMO licence was:
(a) in the public interest; or
(b) necessary or desirable in order to protect neighbouring or nearby property or the environment from contamination by a GMO.
(4) An offence under subsection (1) is punishable upon conviction by a fine of not more than whichever of the following amounts applies:
(a) in the case of a first offence—50 penalty units;
(b) in the case of a second offence—100 penalty units;
(c) in the case of any subsequent offence—450 penalty units.

speech.para: Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.

quote.para: (25) Clause 40, page 29 (after line 13), after subclause (3), insert:

(3A) An application which specifies that dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence will involve the intentional release of a GMO into the environment must include details of the location and the size of the dealings.
(92) Clause 138, page 86 (after line 14), after paragraph (c), insert:
(ca) if the dealings authorised by the licence involve the intentional release of a GMO into the environment—the location and size of the dealings;
(111) Clause 184, page 120 (line 6), after "relates", insert ", other than the information specified in subsection (1A),".
(112) Clause 184, page 120 (after line 7), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) The information specified for the purposes of subsection (1) is as follows:
(a) the location of field trials involving GMOs;
(b) the size of field trials involving GMOs.

speech.para: The essence of these amendments is to clarify that a person must not damage a licence holder's property. During the period of the Senate inquiry in relation to this bill, there was considerable concern raised by those licensed people who are already carrying out trials in Australia. One of the reasons that they strongly oppose disclosure of the whereabouts of their trials was that those trials, in effect, could be maliciously damaged or interfered with to such a degree that it would render worthless any scientific value from those trials. The reason for moving amendment (22) is to put a section in the bill stating that a person should not destroy or damage any property relating to the premises of a GMO licence holder without lawful excuse.
During the inquiry, there were concerns raised as to the secrecy of these trial locations. In the committee report on page 58, in paragraph 3.131, it states:

quote.para: The District Council of Grant in South Australia expressed concern at the lack of information on trial sites made available to local councils. The Council submitted that `No notification is supplied to the Council or the public, regarding the location of the trial sites, duration, size and conditions pertaining to the trialing of genetically modified crops (for example Canola).

speech.para: In paragraph 3.132 the report goes on to say:

quote.para: It is worth noting that in Europe, where there is widespread opposition to gene technology, the location of GMO crops is not concealed as it is here—

speech.para: `here' referring to Australia. Further on in the report, in paragraph 3.137, it says:

quote.para: Avcare, an umbrella organisation of biotechnology companies, proposed an alternative approach to providing information on trial site locations:

[that] Avcare members ... make the locations of trials available to an independent third party who could be contacted by a concerned grower. The grower would then be told whether a trial was nearby and, if so, directed to the proponent of the trial for information.

speech.para: So that is one alternative that was put before the committee that lies halfway between disclosure of the sites and retaining, to some degree, the secrecy of where the sites would be. The report also, in paragraph 3.139 on page 59, goes on to say:

quote.para: The Committee considers that Avcare's proposal may undermine confidence in the GTR and confuse the public in relation to where information on trials and other issues concerning the regulation of gene technology should be sought. The Committee supports the views of the Organic Federation of Australia and considers that it is more appropriate for GM growers to make details of trial site locations available to those who may be affected.

speech.para: I also indicate that I will be moving an amendment at a later date that would specifically address those properties which either adjoin or are close in location to a site on which a genetically modified organism is actually being trialled or carried out as a crop. That is because, when we are looking at this legislation, we also have to look past the trial process in relation to genetically modified organisms. This legislation is going to have to cover, should it be granted a licence, broadacre production of genetically modified crops. The disclosure of the size of the sites is an issue that was raised substantially in the committee stage.

In supporting their disclosure, we also have a responsibility to ensure the integrity of those sites that are licensed sites. It is with that in mind that Pauline Hanson's One Nation have moved this group of amendments relating to the location of licensed dealings, to get a balance between letting the public know where these trials or broadacre crops are actually being planted and at the same time having some security for those people who have a licence and are carrying out a licensed activity. I commend the amendments.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the government will be opposing these amendments. These amendments require that all applications include information about the location and size of the dealings, including field trials. I can assure Senator Harris that this will in fact be the case.
