The gene technology regulations already require that every application must include details about the scale and location of proposed dealings. These amendments are therefore unnecessary, but I will welcome Senator Harris's comments on the draft regulations. The amendments also require that the information about location be included on the record of GMOs and GM products. Again, I can assure Senator Harris that the record must include details of licensing conditions.

speech.para: In relation to interference with dealings, I can flag at this point that the government is inclined to accept the ALP's proposed amendment, which is much later in the evening when we get to clause 192, which addresses the destruction of property. The licence conditions, for example for a field trial, would include where a field trial could be grown. This would therefore be included on the record.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the opposition will not be supporting these amendments moved by Senator Harris. As the parliamentary secretary for the government has just said, we indeed have an amendment, amendment No. 19 on our list of amendments, that deals with the issue of interference with dealings with GMOs, which we believe is more appropriate. In respect of the other issues regarding disclosure, they have been adequately covered by the parliamentary secretary.

—I wonder if the parliamentary secretary could tell us more explicitly what is wrong with these amendments. Are they too stringent? If the information is going on the record, what is the problem with these amendments? I ask the parliamentary secretary: is all the information about location and size of crops, and the experimentation or the modification involved in the crops, going to be available on the public record?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that this is an area in which there is a combination of issues. In the main the issues are covered by the regulations. As I indicated to Senator Harris, the gene technology regulations already require that every application must include details about the scale and location of the proposed dealings. I also indicated that there were other areas where we were inclined to look at the ALP's proposed amendment relating to clause 192, which addresses the destruction of property. With regard to interference, the key difference is that Senator Harris's amendment is cast very broadly and may catch general break-ins that are not specifically ecotourism.
—I think the secretary might have meant `ecoterrorism'.
—I did.

—Maybe we have a new industry afoot here. I come back again to ask the parliamentary secretary, Senator Tambling, if all this information will be on the public record as soon as the applications are put in.

—While Senator Tambling is getting some advice on that, with respect to my comments in response to Senator Harris's amendments I should have mentioned earlier that the opposition also has further amendments, on sheet No. 2067, which relate to the issue of disclosure and confidentiality of commercial information.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I am glad Senator Forshaw added that, because the one component that was missing in the government's response to Senator Harris's amendments was in relation to the confidential commercial provisions in clause 184—one of the three amendments that relate to that issue. It was probably appropriate that Senators Tambling and Brown made reference to ecoterrorism, because I believe that kind of activity is partly motivated by and comes about as a consequence of people's fear or anger towards, in this case, a new technology. The case in Brisbane—which I think is our first reported case of ecoterrorism in relation to GMOs—probably sent quite a strong message to government, as indeed incidents like that over the world should. Again it relates back to the idea that, if we are going to have public faith in the legislation before us and are not going to incite or provoke those kinds of incidences around Australia again, we have to make sure that people feel that their rights, safety and environment will be adequately protected. As we have pointed out a number of times in this debate so far, we have not sufficiently tightened or strengthened this bill in a way that certainly the crossbenchers would like to see in order to ensure that we can instil that public confidence and faith. I think references to ecoterrorism in the context of this debate are probably, unfortunately, quite relevant.

speech.para: I understand the intent of Senator Harris's amendments. I am wondering whether the key concern the government has with one of the amendments is that it is superfluous—that it is unnecessary, to use the govern-ment's language. What is the risk? Is it the mere risk of duplication? To echo Senator Brown's comments, I am just wondering whether there are any further reasons that the government is rejecting these amendments apart from the fact they are opposition amendments. I do state that I believe that the opposition amendments, which seek to achieve similar objectives, have some value.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —It is important that we concentrate on the issues that Senator Stott Despoja has so rightly pointed out are contained in clauses 184 and 185 of the bill, relating to confidential commercial information. However, I should point out that it is the general tenor of this legislation to make as much information as possible available in the public arena. In fact, I draw particular attention to clause 185(2):

quote.para: The Regulator may refuse to declare that the information is confidential commercial information if the Regulator is satisfied that the public interest in disclosure outweighs the prejudice the disclosure would cause to any person.

speech.para: So it is very heavily incumbent on the regulator to ensure these areas of concern. The other area is probably more about philosophy, which does come back to those issues that can be addressed more appropriately in regulations, where issues can be addressed in a much more fluid manner than specifically apply in the body of the legislation.

talk.start.para: —On that point, the bill defines confidential commercial information as information declared by the regulator to be confidential commercial information. That is one of those definitions that ducks giving any information at all. It might be an indicator of what we are going to get under this legislation with the regulator, which I fear—and I think legitimately—will mean a lot of information being covered up under the guise of commercial confidentiality. Seeing the secretary has brought up this matter, I would like a definition of what will be commercial-in-confidence, because I do not think we should leave that to the regulator. I am very well aware that in this day and age the corporate sector will bring the curtain down on what it is doing over anything at all that it can under the guise of commercial-in-confidence. I am also very aware that the rules on this are much more against the public interest in Australia than they are in the United States, where freedom of information insists that a whole range of commercial information which is prohibited under provisions like this in Australia has to be on the public record.

speech.para: The secretary said, `Oh well, the regulator will have to judge this matter on what is in the public interest.' Well, if he appoints me as regulator, everything that is to do with gene technology is in the public interest. What we are not getting here is any definition, any guide, any indicator to the regulator as to where the balance between the public interest and so-called commercial interest lies. If we do not define that in here, it will be the commercial interest that will have sway, because after this legislation leaves here the Gene Technology Regulator will be under quite a lot of pressure from the commercial interests, who will be arguing—in camera—why their interests are commercial-in-confidence. They are going to hide a lot of information from the public under that label. So I think we should make it very clear—and the government should be making very clear—what is commercial-in-confidence. Otherwise we have a very legitimate right, as Senator Harris has, to suspect that a lot of information is not going to be made available. For the parliamentary secretary to say, `It will have to be released' or `The regulator will, out of the goodness of her or his heart, release this information as they think it is in the public interest' just does not wash.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I would invite Senator Brown to perhaps contain his comments at this point in time, and we will deal with them again further on in the agenda. The Labor Party does have some amendments to section 185 which deal with this area of commercial-in-confidence. I can certainly give Senator Brown the assurance that the public interest can and certainly will override the factors that are currently listed. As I said, they may change a bit. Section 185 (1)(a), (b) and (c) bring out those areas that do define the areas which are commercial, confidential information. They are set out in that particular regard, and I think it would be more appropriate to have this debate when we get to the Labor Party's amendment on that section.

—In response to my earlier comments, Senator Tambling said that the information that I am requesting be made public is available on the public record. Could Senator Tambling let us know where that record will be kept, who will have access to it, and whether that information will be available prior to the regulator granting a licence or whether it will be placed on the public record only after the regulator has issued a licence?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the information that will be readily available will certainly be on the web site, it will be available to people as part of the process that will be considered by the regulator, and there will be an availability for disclosure.

—Senator Tambling has not addressed the issue of when that information will be available. Will the information be publicly available at the point when an application is made for a licence, or will it be available on the public register only after the licence has been granted?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the information will be available when the application has been made and prior to any decision being made.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Australian Greens amendments Nos 43, 44, 45 and 47:

quote.para: (43) Page 27 (after line 12), at the end of Division 2, add:
38A Offence of causing significant damage to health or safety of people or to the environment
(1) A person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person intentionally causes significant damage to the health and safety of people or to the environment through the development, use or release of a GMO or GM product; and

(b) the person knows that the development, use or release of a GMO or GM product is likely to cause significant damage to the health and safety of people or to the environment and is reckless as to the likely effect.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.
(2) An offence under this section is punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a term not exceeding 20 years.

Note: Subsection 4B(2) of the Crimes Act 1914 lets a court that convicts an individual of an offence impose a fine instead of, or as well as, imprisonment. The maximum fine (in penalty units) the court can impose is 5 times the maximum term of imprisonment (in months).
(44) Page 27 (after line 12), at the end of Division 2, add:
38B Significant damage to health or safety of people or to the environment—strict liability offence
(1) A person is guilty of an offence if the person causes significant damage to the health or safety of people or to the environment, through the development, use or release of a GMO or GM product.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.
(2) Strict liability applies to subsection (1).
(3) An offence against this section is punishable on conviction by a fine that, in the discretion of the court, is commensurate with the damage caused by the person.
(45) Page 27 (after line 12), at the end of Division 2, add:
38C Offence relating to negligence

(1) A person is guilty of an offence if the person negligently causes significant damage to the health and safety of people or to the environment through the development, use or release of a GMO or GM product.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.
(2) An offence under this section is punishable on conviction by a fine that, in the discretion of the court, is commensurate with the damage caused by the person.
(47) Page 27 (after line 12), at the end of Division 2, add:
38E Meaning of significant damage

For the purposes of this Part, significant damage in relation to the health and safety of people or to the environment includes, but is not limited to, any actual adverse effect on the health and safety of people or on the environment in relation to the GMO or GM product.

speech.para: These amendments deal with offences causing concern to the public in the public interest. The first amendment says—and I will shorthand this—that a person is guilty of an offence if they intentionally cause significant damage to the health and safety of people. That offence is punishable by imprisonment for a term not exceeding 20 years. The second amendment deals with offences where a person has caused damage to the health and safety of people but it was not intentional. Therefore, the severe penalty of imprisonment is not levied. The next amendment deals with offences where there is damage to the health of people through the use or release of a GMO or GM product due to negligence. On this occasion, the offence would be punishable by a fine that, in the discretion of the court, is commensurate with the damage caused to the person.

Committee members will note that Greens amendment No. 47 makes `significant damage' effectively any damage having any actual adverse effect on the health and safety of people or the environment. In other words, we are getting out of this `leave it to somebody else to decide' and making it very clear that damage, when it occurs to other people due to the use of a GMO or a GM product, is the responsibility of the person who released or used that GMO or GM product. It is a very simple and fair set of amendments which leave no doubt that, where these products are being used—and I have no doubt the government is indicating that that is going to be where it is in the public interest—the people who are using them should be liable for any suffering as a result of that overall public interest in which the GMO or GM product is being used abroad.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I would like to indicate that the government is opposed to these amendments. These amendments increase the penalties in relation to certain offences and establish new offences, including strict liability offences. The government believes that the offence provisions already in the bill are more than adequate. The penalties imposed are high in comparison with like legislation and there are a range of offences, including strict liability offences and aggravated offences. Therefore, the government opposes the amendments.

—I do not think that is the case, and that is why we have the very clear language of the amendments. I would add that one could depart from this and look at the threat to citizens who want to defend the environment. You will know, Mr Temporary Chairman Watson, that in Tasmania in recent months people who have quite peacefully stood in defence of the forest environment have been jailed for months. Others have been fined up to $7,000 for doing nothing but peacefully protesting their intent to defend the environment. Here, we are dealing with people who, in their use of GM products, could, for example, intentionally inflict damage on the health and safety of other people. We know what that means. In those situations there could be enormous penalties to the public abroad through the intentional misuse of genetically modified organisms. I think we have to recognise that we are at the start of an industry that is being pursued because it is going to bring enormous benefits to society—as did the use of asbestos for insulation and brake lining purposes, as have many other things that have been brought forward as being in the public interest. But, very often, there are some members of the public who suffer as a result of that. These measures by the Greens say that we have to make sure that we limit that suffering by the public who are hurt by the release of new scientific entities. We want to make particularly sure that those who are in the business are neither negligent nor intentionally malicious in their use of the quite powerful technologies that can be unleashed. So we do not believe that the government's legislation is strong enough in this matter, hence the Greens amendments.
—I rise to support the Greens amendments. When you look at the context of the amendments, you can see that they do not specify a fixed punishment. If you look at proposed section 38A(2) it says:

quote.para: An offence under this section is punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a term not exceeding 20 years.

speech.para: It does not say it has to be 20 years; that is at the discretion of the court. If we look at 38B(3) it says:

quote.para: An offence against this section is punishable on conviction by a fine that, in the discretion of the court, is commensurate with the damage caused by the person.

speech.para: So it is clearly not setting out a minimum punishment. It actually allows the court to determine what that fit and just punishment should be. The last amendment, No. 45, which deals with an offence relating to negligence, says under subsection (2):

quote.para: An offence under this section is punishable on conviction by a fine that, in the discretion of the court, is commensurate with the damage caused by the person.

speech.para: So rather than what Senator Tambling has indicated to the chamber—that the penalties are too harsh—the way the amendments are structured rightfully allows the court the ability to apportion whatever it determines is commensurate with the damage the person has carried out; that is, an involuntary or malicious release into the environment. The thing we have to take into consideration with this bill is that, unlike so many of the acts that can be perpetrated that are recoverable—for example, there may be an unintentional spillage of oil offshore—and for which there is an accepted process for maintaining, containing and carrying out a process to remove that intentional or unintentional release, once a genetically modified organism is released into the environment there is no known process for reversing the issue.

This goes to the essence of where the judiciary should be. They are the correct people in this case to be able to apportion a fine or a jail term commensurate with the damage that that release may cause either to human health or to the environment, particularly when you take into consideration that there is no known process that will retrieve that genetically modified organism once it is in the environment. This is a stepping off the edge of a cliff with a parachute process, and we are hoping that the parachute has the ability to allow a safe landing. I believe the Greens' amendments, structured as they are, are appropriate, rather than, as Senator Tambling has said, excessive. Given that it is the court that will decide and apportion whatever measures are appropriate in relation to that damage, I believe the amendments proposed by the Australian Greens are completely within what would be publicly acceptable.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats have a great deal of sympathy with these amendments and the issues of strict liability provisions and negligence and also that niggly issue of intent and ensuring that people are held liable for those actions or any adverse consequences. Given the information provided by the department to the Senate committee's inquiry, I am curious to ask the parliamentary secretary how we compare with other nations that have enacted legislation in this particular area. I have looked very briefly at Canada and the various penalties that they prescribe—obviously, this is in a note form provided to the committee—and the two types of action that they provide for liability for contamination, for example. I am just wondering if we compare favourably with other nations. Of course, that is no reason for us not to come up with our own world's best practice in relation to ensuring that people are compensated if they are adversely affected or, alternatively, that people are punished if they are responsible for bad deeds. For that reason, and unless the government can give a better explanation as to what is wrong with these amendments other than their initial response to Senator Brown's amendments, the Democrats will be supporting the amendments before us from the Australian Greens. But I would be curious as to the government's response to the international comparisons for a start.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —In responding to various questions that have been posed to me by Senator Brown, Senator Harris and Senator Stott Despoja, I firstly point out that probably the most important area is that the fines imposed are up to $1.2 million per offence per corporation and we have added jail terms. In addition, the regulator can take all remediation action necessary and can charge the offender for costs. Further, there is a common law action open to any third party. I am sure Senator Brown would be pleased to note that there are no offence provisions in this bill for peaceful protesters. They are important aspects to note in the consideration.

speech.para: Senator Stott Despoja raises the issue of how we compare. It is generally accepted that Australia compares very favourably with other nations. This was highlighted in the department's submission from the Interim Office of the Gene Technology Regulator to the Senate references committee inquiry. I would refer Senator Stott Despoja to that submission, particularly under the terms of reference. At page 146 and a number of pages that follow it is set out in very comprehensive detail. Under `How do other countries regulate contamination and what recourse is available in other countries should contamination occur?' the first paragraph reads:

quote.para: When developing the Gene Technology Bill 2000 and particularly the approach to contamination and liability, the Interim Office of Gene Technology Regulator examined in detail the regulatory schemes adopted by the United States of America, New Zealand, Canada, the European Community, the United Kingdom, Germany and Japan. To summarise, there are three main ways in which these countries' regulators differ in their coverage of intentional releases of GMOs into the environment, and in particular how liability in relation to such releases is established.

speech.para: The submission then goes on to set out in considerable detail those three main ways. There is also a very detailed summary of the approaches adopted in each of the countries. As I said, by comparison we compare very favourably.

talk.start.para: —Is the government going to support the compensation measure put forward by the crossbenchers, or is it going to support the insurance provisions that the crossbenchers are flagging in our amendments?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that this will be reached in another form of the debate later on when we get to the issues that have been raised by the ALP with regard to insurance. But I am advised that we are not supporting any issues relating to compensation.

—That answer underscores the need for these amendments. You are going to have the potential for damage to be caused to innocent people, innocent farmers and people who want to keep their organic or GE-free farms uncontaminated. The Greens and other crossbenchers have amendments coming further down the line which say that in that case there should be insurance that can make some monetary recompense for that contamination or damage. We have also said that the gene technology industry as a whole should have a compensation fund from which the damages can be paid if insurance does not cover them. The government says, `There won't be either of those things and, moreover, we are not going to support these amendments to be tough on people who do cause such damage.'

speech.para: What we are seeing unfold here is the gene technology industry being absolved from all the downside which concerns the public. If this industry is so sure that gene technology is universally such a good thing, then it should be quite willing to undertake an insurance provision. But the government, which is speaking on behalf of the big end of the gene technology industry here, is not going to have that on. This action by the government speaks volumes. This industry says it is here for the public interest and we are all going to benefit from it, but it is not prepared to back that up with the courage of saying, `And we will stand by it; we will underwrite that.' We, as legislators, have a responsibility to say, `You should.' We understand—and Senator Stott Despoja has been very clear about this from the outset of this debate; and I agree with her—that there are glittering opportunities for humanity, if not the environment, through the use of gene technology. But there are also glaring dangers, and that is what concerns the public. We are regulating here to allow the industry to bring forward the advantages, but we are very remiss if we do not also say that we have to be very clear indeed that we are going to protect the public, including the farming public. I guess that is why Senator Calvert has said that he wants to hear what I have to say to make sure we protect the interests like those of the Tasmanian farmers—which I know Senator Calvert wants to see protected—and that would lead me to conclude, although he said nothing in this debate this evening, that he is going to support these amendments. However, he can get up and speak for himself on that. These are very important matters.

talk.start.para: —That can go on the record.
(Senator Crowley)—I would continue, Senator.

—I will be assisted by your advice on that matter, and Senator Calvert's comment can speak for itself on the record. That being said, I am not going to have now the government say that we do not need such a strong line taken about people who use gene technology in a way which damages other people. A bit later they will say, `We should not compensate people damaged by the negative side of gene technology.' And a bit later they will say `We should not require people involved in the gene technology industry to insure'—and we end up with nothing.

—I am sorry, we end up with common law—the parliamentary secretary just said so. We are here inventing law to deal with a very powerful invention, which is the modification of genes in the natural order. We have to make sure that the law covers all eventualities—the bad side as well as the good—and that is why it is very important that these amendments are supported.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown has misunderstood me. We will be supporting the amendments from the ALP on insurance. I made that clear. I also point out that Senator Brown should know that the evidence presented to the Crowley committee on this important matter by the department in its submission which was considered at the first meeting of the committee in Canberra on 14 August and, I am sure, was referred to a number of times by every senator who participated in that—although I notice Senator Brown only participated in one of the five hearings, the one in Hobart on 23 August—is very explicit in this regard. At page 136 of the department's evidence that was submitted to the Senate inquiry it says:

quote.para: The legislation does not establish remedies for third parties that may be affected by contamination. Some stakeholders suggested that the licence holder should be strictly liable for any economic loss or damage suffered by third parties and that compensation funds or the like should be accessible by third parties. States, Territories and the Commonwealth considered this issue in detail and concluded that:
- there are common law actions available to third parties to deal with such situations;
- there may be actions available under other statutes including State and Territory environmental protection legislation;
- strict liability (and the establishment of remedies for third parties) is not consistent with precedents in relation to the regulation of similar products under Australian law; and

- strict liability (and the establishment of remedies for third parties under gene technology legislation specifically) is not consistent with international precedent. In summary, New Zealand, the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom and Japan do not impose strict liability.

speech.para: That was an important reference on this particular matter. I would just like to take this moment to comment on the time and the progress that we are making. I would draw senators' attention to the program. I think it is very important that, of a list of some eight or nine pages, we are still not quite at the halfway mark yet.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I cannot let that remark go without some attention. My understanding is that the government and the opposition—I am assuming this is the case; I do not know for sure in relation to the opposition—have agreed to negate the adjournment tonight so that we finish this bill. There is no reason numerically to either consult or have the support of the crossbenches in order to do that. But I know, and I certainly speak for my party, that we are more than happy to proceed with this bill, to examine the issues and to subject it to the appropriate scrutiny and analysis that it deserves, whether it is tonight or whether it is tomorrow. We are not going to deliberately rush through what we think is one of the most important pieces of legislation that this federal parliament has debated or will ever debate.

speech.para: Obviously when you urge us along, Senator Tambling—through you, Madam Temporary Chairman—it just provokes responses like this: we are going to go through this bill and we are going to go through it in fine detail. Maybe the government and the ALP should agree to a guillotine. I do not think the ALP are favourable towards guillotines—nor are we, under the circumstances. We will just keep ploughing through. I am sorry if that is difficult for the government, and certainly for Senator Tambling, who has had only one bill to deal with today. If we can cope with it, we will keep going. I do not think there is any reason to rush this more so than we have done already. It is pretty much on record, and it certainly stands in the running order, that senators have done their best to deal with as many amendments at one time. I cite Senator Harris's 77 amendments that he more or less dealt with in 15 minutes on Friday.

I think we can have enough of those utterances from the government trying to speed us along, given that we are expecting to be here all night. I do not expect there will be complaints when we are calling divisions or having further discussion on any of the amendments, because this is a decision by government to put this bill on tonight in an attempt to get rid of the peripheral amendments that have been moved by the Democrats, the Greens, One Nation and Senator Harradine. I do not mean `peripheral' as in I am suggesting so, but clearly the government knows it is going to get its bill through and says, `Why not just make them sit all night?' I think that is an appalling policy and I think most of the public thinks so too. We should be proposing the adjournment at 9.50 as planned and coming back to debate this when the Senate sits tomorrow afternoon. Having said all that, I say to the government: if you are going to go all night, wake up your troops.

talk.start.para: —I support that. I agree that this is very important legislation. I do not think the course of the debate of this legislation is going to be altered one iota by the opposition and the government saying, `We are going to suspend the normal sitting hours to make the crossbenches suffer.' That is not a dignified way to be treating this important debate. I would expect that there is going to be a quorum in attendance for the rest of the evening to make sure that this debate does get the attendance that is required. I expect that the government and opposition members, through their presence in the chamber, will be paying sufficient attention to the detail so that they can report to their electorates on this matter when the debate has run its proper course.

—I support the comments made by Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Brown. This is an extremely important piece of legislation. I think that it is acknowledged as such all around the chamber. It would be unfair of the government to keep us here and to go through the committee stage. The committee stage is necessary so as to ensure certainty. I spent a lot of time on Friday of last week trying to get from the parliamentary secretary a definition of `whole human being'. What is a whole human being? When it is talking about cloning, does it include an embryo? Does it include a foetus? It would be a very grave error on the part of the government not to answer that question. I know what is coming along the road and I also know that attempts have been made to whittle down the recommendations of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, which is the very committee that had been approved to send recommendations to the government. There has been a deliberate attempt to water down its recommendations. The definition is a key matter.

speech.para: Furthermore, on the last occasion I raised questions of identicality in respect of cloning. I will be expecting the parliamentary secretary to answer those questions, which he failed to do, despite being given innumerable opportunities last Monday. It is easy enough to say, `This is a very complex matter,' but a lot of people are affected by this legislation. In fact, the community as a whole is affected. It is important for this chamber to be given the respect that is due to it—not that respect is due to us on the basis of being senators, but on the basis that we are representatives of the people. I for one—and I know a number of colleagues around this neck of the woods are—am appalled that the government should try and keep us here after 10 minutes to 10. People like me have to consider other questions, including the proposal that the gambling matter be brought back. I was told about this on the grapevine—I did not hear it from anybody officially—and I have not had a chance to get my head around it. I was on the committee. I will be pretty hazy trying to get my head around it tomorrow if we sit past 10 to 10 tonight.

talk.start.para: —Chair, I agree with the sentiments that Senator Harradine is expressing there and, it being close enough to 9.50 p.m., I move:

motion.para: That progress be reported.

speech.para: Question put.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —The question is that Australian Greens amendments (43), (44), (45) and (47) on sheet 1970 be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I move amendment (46) on sheet 1970:

quote.para: (46) Page 27 (after line 12), at the end of Division 2, add:

A person who suffers loss or damage that results from a contravention of this Act may recover the amount of the loss or damage from a person convicted of the contravention or from any person involved in the contravention, including, if a body corporate contravened a provision of this Act, from a director of the body.

speech.para: This is a very important amendment. I want to read it out because it is very easily understood:

quote.para: A person who suffers loss or damage that results from a contravention of this Act may recover the amount of the loss or damage from a person convicted of the contravention or from any person involved in the contravention, including, if a body corporate contravened a provision of this Act, from a director of the body.

speech.para: That is very plain and simple. It says that, if somebody breaks the law, this act, and causes damage to somebody else, the person who is damaged can seek damages in a court of law. I cannot stress how important this is to giving the public confidence that there is a remedy. In a way this is simply codifying the common law provision that the government says is there for people to pursue if they want to. It is very compelling, very simple and very clear-cut. If the gene tech industry itself is responsible and wants to give the public confidence, then it will support this amendment.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government is opposed to this amendment. The amendment allows third parties to recover damages if they suffer as a result of the release of a GMO. The issue of remediation and compensation was considered in detail by the Commonwealth and the states and territories, and it was the subject of considerable discussion during public consultations. On balance, the government considers that it is inappropriate to deal with compensation in the Gene Technology Bill 2000 as there are already remedies available under common law and under state environmental protection legislation. States, territories and the Commonwealth recognise that the existing measures are adequate to deal with any loss or damage flowing from the use of GMOs, just as they are adequate when dealing with other products. This approach is also consistent with international precedent and recent reports of the EEC that have not supported the establishment of compensation funds and damages provisions in specific gene technology legislation. The government therefore opposes this amendment.

—Senator Tambling has just told us that there are adequate processes for a third party to seek restitution under this legislation. Would Senator Tambling very clearly indicate to us how a third party would access compensation?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —There are adequate processes through common law and trespass and nuisance laws.
—What are those?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Can I again refer the senators, and particularly Senator Brown, to the submission made by the Department of Health and Aged Care to the Community Affairs References Committee. This information was made very publicly available to the committee, of which he was a member, and I refer the senator to page 144 of that submission:

para.inline: There are common law actions available to third parties to deal with such situations.

quote.para: The remedies that may be available to a party at common law will depend on the particular facts of the case and how the risk is characterised.

In summary, a third party may have an action in negligence, trespass or nuisance, and may also seek to restrain the ongoing commission of a tort by injunction. In order for a plaintiff to be successful in an action for negligence, the plaintiff must establish four elements:

speech.para: · a legally recognised duty of care to another person, or class of persons;
· a breach of that duty by failing to meet the legally recognised level of conduct required in the circumstances;
· a causal link between the breach of duty and the harm alleged to have been suffered; and
· compensable damage or loss on the part of the plaintiff flowing from the breach.

talk.start.para: —So a third party may have recourse to action under common law. That is the first thing. That indicates quite clearly that they may not have access to action through the common law as well. Then the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care went on to talk about negligence. I am not talking about negligence; that is only one component of the trio of concerns here—that is, wilful misuse, negligence or the simple application of genetic technology which is licensed but is then found to create damage to another person. Apparently, the government is blind to those situations. Well, I am not. I believe that we should be supporting this very important amendment. It says, by the way, that a person can seek compensation where somebody has breached the act. The government must support that; the opposition must support that. Are you saying that, if somebody breaches the act and damage occurs to an innocent member of the public as a result, we should not be specifying that they have recourse to recompense for the loss or the damage suffered? Of course they should!

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The issue of common law is a very important one that should always be addressed, but we certainly cannot pre-empt the court ruling, so we come back to the issue you dwell on about the use of `may' in that area. I would again refer the senator to the details of the submission of the Department of Health and Aged Care that was made to the committee. I did not continue the quote, which obviously I now need to do by reading the further section of that submission:

para.inline: There may be actions available under other statutes, including State and Territory environmental protection legislation.

quote.para: Each State and Territory in Australia has legislation for protecting the environment.

speech.para: I am sure Senator Brown is well aware of that. But let me return to the quote:

quote.para: In most jurisdictions, the environment protection legislation, among other things, establishes a general duty not to undertake an activity that pollutes or might pollute the environment or causes, or is likely to cause, environmental harm. In some States, this is framed as a general duty, and in others it is framed as a prohibition subject to criminal penalties.

Further, the environment protection legislation explicitly provides that a person who has had their interest affected by pollution (or an environmentally damaging activity) may apply to the relevant court or tribunal seeking compensation or an order to prevent the damaging activity from continuing.

speech.para: I will end the quote at that point, and I point out to Senator Brown that there are considerable resources and information available to him from his committee membership.

talk.start.para: —As clever as that might be, we have to go again to the aim of this legislation as stated by the government, which is to bring in a nationally uniform law. Now, when it comes to the section which might harm the interests of the corporations wanting to use the technology, we revert to state law. I do not find that acceptable. The parliamentary secretary says that people may have recourse to action and, if they do not have that in common law, they may have it under some statute if they are lucky enough to be in a state which has a law which covers them. I can tell the secretary, because he does not appear to know this, that the laws in these matters vary greatly from state to state. We are supposed to be bringing in a uniform law here in the interests of the people who create gene technology but, when it comes to those who might suffer damage as a result of that, suddenly that philosophy gets abandoned. It should not be. If there is loss or damage occurring to somebody or some entity because there is a contravention of this act, we should specify that people have a right to seek recompense. From whom? From the people who created the damage. It is very simple stuff, this.

speech.para: If the government turns this down, it is simply loading the odds in favour of the corporations who are inventing the gene technology and against the citizen. We are going to find, further down the line, that citizens do not have standing in many cases in which they would want to have an interest. We have already found that they are not going to have a compensation fund. We are going to have to wait to see what the government and Labor have come to agree on as far as insurance is concerned. But the matter is important. This particular clause is extremely important. It is commonsense. Simply referring me to a committee report which uses the word `may' over and over again is not satisfactory. I point out again that this is a case of being consistent, of making sure that there is a uniform law accessible to everybody equally. That should apply to those who have to suffer—and there will be such people—as a result of people going outside the tenets of this legislation. I do not accept the government's argument.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate that Senator Brown does not accept my argument, but it is premised very much on the basis that this legislation has arisen as a result of the complementarity of all of the states and territories and the Commonwealth in seeking to pull these issues together into a national policy yet at the same time sit it within the situations that do apply to those states and territories. I am sure Senator Brown is aware from earlier debate that the issues of complementary legislation will be addressed by the states and territories in this regard.

speech.para: It is also important to point out that Senator Brown raised, as a separate issue, remediation. Remediation is comprehensively covered by the bill. The regulator can recover all costs associated with remedial action from the offender. This acts in concert with the strict liability provisions and common law actions to provide comprehensive cover, and this is in addition to the state environmental laws. It is for those reasons that I would argue against the amendment by the Australian Greens.

talk.start.para: —If the regulator can seek remediation, why can't the citizen?

—In response to some of Senator Brown's questions, Senator Tambling made the statement that states have legislation pertaining to damage to the environment. Is Senator Tambling indicating to the chamber that a third party under common law would be able to initiate an action relating to a legislative act within a state?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The issue raised by Senator Harris addresses a very fundamental point. The states do have legislation that addresses the issue of remedies.

—I realise that, but my point is that we are talking about the rights of a third party to be able to access compensation for damage that they have suffered as a result of an unintentional or malicious release of GMOs into the environment. My specific question to Senator Tambling was this: does an individual have standing at law to commence an action under a legislative act in a state?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the senator's question is yes.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Greens amendments Nos 48 to 52:

quote.para: (48) Clause 40, page 29 (lines 7 to 10), omit subclause (2), substitute:
(2) The application must be in writing and, subject to subsection (2A), must contain:
(a) details of the geographic area or areas where the proposed dealings are to be carried out; and
(b) any information held by or known to the applicant about the possible risks to the health and safety of people or to the environment that may be associated with the proposed dealings; and
(c) such other information as is prescribed by the regulations (if any); and
(d) such other information as is specified in writing by the Regulator;
(49) Clause 40, page 29 (after line 10), after subclause (2), insert:
(2A) The Regulator may permit an applicant to include in an application a summary of the information mentioned in paragraph (2)(b) where the Regulator believes it is appropriate to do so.
(50) Clause 40, page 29 (lines 14 to 21), omit subclause (4), substitute:
(4) A person may apply for a licence only in respect of a dealing, or a specified class of dealings, with a GMO at a specified geographic area or areas.
(51) Clause 40, page 29 (line 24), omit "; or", substitute ".".
(52) Clause 40, page 29 (line 25), omit paragraph (5)(c).

speech.para: These amendments are to do with the issue of licences. Amendment No. 48 from the Greens says that the application must be in writing and must contain details of the geographical area or areas where the proposed plants are to be put. It says here `dealings are to be carried out', but that is what it means: where the crops are going to go. It must also contain any information held by or known to the applicant about the possible risks to the health and safety of people or to the environment that may be associated with the proposed dealings, such as crop plantings, and any other matter that is required by the regulator. It also says that, where this is a long and complicated business, the regulator may accept a summary of the geographic areas where the crops are going to be planted or where the gene technology is going to be employed, and the risks that are attendant upon that. That is pretty basic and obvious stuff.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes the amendments proposed by the Greens. The amendments propose various details about what should be included in an application to deal with a GMO, including details of the location of a proposed dealing and any information about the possible risks to health and safety or the environment as associated with the dealing. As detailed in the gene technology regulations made under the bill, the applicant will be required to provide information to the Gene Technology Regulator about the proposed location and scale of dealings with the GMO. The regulations require the applicant to provide details of the number of GMOs to be released, details of the number of releases proposed, and details of the number of sites for release, including identification of the municipality or shire in which all releases will take place and the geographical location, grid references and GPS coordinates of the site. The regulations also explicitly provide that, in preparing an application, an applicant must take account of possible risks of the proposed dealings with the GMO in relation to the health and safety of people and the environment. The information given in the application must be as comprehensive as current knowledge permits and be supported by data and relevant references. It is unnecessary to include in the bill the level of detail proposed by Senator Brown. We would, however, be pleased to consult with Senator Brown about the precise wording in the regulations.

—It is a question of whether this should be in regulations or in the legislation. The Greens obviously think it is more important that the licence carry information about where crops are going to be and the risks they may carry than the government does. The government simply wants it demoted to a matter of regulations about which we can talk outside the chamber. It is important that this matter be discussed here, and I think it should be written into the bill.

—I support the Greens amendments. I seek clarification from Senator Tambling as to whether, under the regulations, the regulator is required to seek advice relating to the issuing of a licence. Is the regulator required to consult with the relevant local government authority or the consultative group?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the senator's question is yes.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Greens amendments (54) to (59):

quote.para: (54) Clause 47, page 32 (lines 24 to 31), omit subclause (4), substitute:
(4) The Regulator must seek advice on matters relevant to the preparation of the risk assessment and the risk management plan from:
(a) the relevant State Authority; and
(b) the relevant local government Authority; and
(c) the Gene Technology Technical Advisory Committee; and
(e) the Consultative Group; and
(d) the Ethics Committee.
(55) Clause 47, page 32 (after line 31), at the end of the clause, add:
(5) The Regulator may consult:
(a) relevant Commonwealth or State authorities or agencies; and
(b) any other person the Regulator considers appropriate;

speech.para: on any aspect of the application.

quote.para: (56) Clause 49, page 33 (line 10) to page 34 (line 19), omit the clause, substitute:

para.inline: 49 Consultation on applications for dealings involving the intentional release of a GMO into the environment

quote.para: (1) Where the Regulator receives an application to which this Division applies, the Regulator must publish a notice in respect of the application:
(a) in the Gazette; and
(b) in a newspaper circulating generally in each State; and
(c) in a newspaper circulating in the region or State in which the dealing is proposed to be carried out; and
(d) on the Regulator's Internet website.
(2) A notice published under subsection (1) must:
(a) state that the application has been made; and
(b) state that a person may request further information about the application under section 54; and
(c) invite written submissions on any environmental, human health or ethical issue associated with the proposed dealing; and
(d) specify the closing date for submissions, which must not be earlier than 30 days after the date on which the notice was published.
(57) Clause 50, page 34 (lines 25 to 27), omit subclause (2).
(58) Clause 50, page 34 (line 28) to page 35 (line 4), omit subclause (3), substitute:
(3) The Regulator must seek advice on matters relevant to the preparation of the risk assessment and the risk management plan from:
(a) the relevant State Authority; and
(b) the relevant local government Authority; and
(c) the Gene Technology Technical Advisory Committee; and
(d) the Consultative Group; and
(e) the Ethics Committee; and
(f) each Commonwealth authority or agency prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this paragraph; and
(g) the Environment Minister.
(59) Clause 51, page 35 (lines 12 and 13), omit "the matters mentioned in paragraphs 49(2)(a) to (f)", substitute:

speech.para: the following matters:

quote.para: (a) the properties of the organism to which the dealings relate before it became, or will become, a GMO;
(b) the effect, or expected effect, of the genetic modification that has occurred, or will occur, on the properties of the organism;
(c) provisions for limiting the dissemination or persistence of the GMO or its genetic material in the environment;
(d) the potential for spread or persistence of the GMO or its genetic material in the environment.
(e) the possible impacts of the spread or persistence of the GMO or its genetic material on the environment;
(f) any possible impacts of the proposed dealing on the health and safety of people;
(g) any other matter prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this paragraph.

speech.para: These amendments are also to get information of the sort that Senator Harris was just alluding to. For example, these amendments would mean that the regulator is obliged to consult with a wide range of relevant state, community and Commonwealth authorities and, moreover, that when the regulator receives an application, she or he must publish a notice in respect of that application not only in the Gazette but in newspapers which are going to be read by the people in the area to which the application applies. There should be a call for written submissions from the public, and the regulator ought to make sure that the following matters are involved: the properties of the organism to which the dealings relate before it became or will become a GMO, the effect or expected effect of the genetic modification that has occurred or will occur on the properties of that organism, the provisions for limiting the dissemination or persistence of the GMO or its genetic material in the environment—it would be interesting to see those—and the potential for spread or persistence of the GMO as genetic material in the environment.

Frankly, we have seen crops planted in this country already where the persons who are involved in the technology and the planting of those crops do not have the foggiest as to the potential for the spread or persistence of that genetic material. We have the notorious Mount Gambier example where they simply dumped the end product of a crop containing genetic material in a rubbish dump. Also, the possible impacts of the spread or persistence of the GMO as genetic material on the environment and the possible impacts of the proposed dealing on the health and safety of people should be considered. This is pure commonsense. It is baseline stuff. There is nothing pioneering about this. It ought to sensibly be required of the regulator. It is good law because it is saying to the regulator, `Here are some guidelines.' This should be in the act and it should be available to those who are concerned and want to have input when genetic material is introduced into their environment.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes these amendments which address matters of process surrounding consultation on applications. The bill already provides the capacity for the regulator to seek advice from or consult with any party the regulator considers necessary, including state and Commonwealth agencies. The bill provides explicit requirements that the regulator must consult relevant Commonwealth agencies and state agencies for all applications involving intentional release of a GMO into the environment. The regulator may also consult on all other applications, including contained work.

speech.para: The amendment proposed by Senator Brown would also require the regulator to seek advice on individual applications from a gene technology consultative committee. Again, this issue was considered in detail by the Commonwealth and all states and territories, which were strongly of the view that under no circumstances should this approach be adopted. The committee is a policy committee and, given the extensive consultation processes described in the bill, it is inappropriate to provide applications to the Gene Technology Community Consultative Committee. However, the GTR will be able to refer matters of community concern raised in applications to the committee for consideration. I note that the ALP will move an amendment to clause 107 to make this explicit, and the government is disposed to support that amendment. Finally, amendment No. 59 simply provides more detail in the bill about matters that the regulator must take into account in preparing a risk assessment and risk management plan. Again, all of these matters are dealt with in the regulations. This is appropriate, given the level of detail that must be included. We are happy to consult further with Senator Brown on the wording of the regulations if the senator so desires.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I take issue with the notion that it is appropriate to be putting these matters into regulations. I think people now just fall for the argument that regulations are more flexible and therefore it is better to do it this way. It is not better to do it this way. This is an increasing phenomenon that we see, certainly in the federal parliament. It is one that I have observed not only in the five years that I have been in the parliament but previously as an adviser. This is an increasing tendency by governments in order to serve their own notions of what is desirable and therefore flexible. Increasingly they are putting matters such as this, which may actually be pivotal, crucial and integral to the legislation before us, into delegated legislation. So I take issue with the parliamentary secretary's notion that this is more appropriate because it provides flexibility. What rot! That is something that we seem to fall for these days, but I think that is quite a spurious claim.

speech.para: In relation to the amendments before us, the Democrats recognise their aims in relation to public consultation and broad ranging consultation, and we commend that intent. Senator Tambling referred to a Labor amendment that is coming up. Don't forget the amendments being moved by the Democrats that are coming up—I can see you could not possibly—in relation to the role of the environment minister. I think this is one of the most commendable aspects of the amendments before us moved by Senator Brown on behalf of the Greens: the prescription of `must'—not just `may' but `must'—in relation to seeking advice on risk assessment and the risk management plan. Yes, I am aware of clause 51F, but that is not enough. To that end, the Democrats will be giving the government another opportunity to meet their end of the bargain and not renege on the deal that they struck with the Democrats when they negotiated the environment bill last year. That was to guarantee a role for the environment minister. I think most Australians would find it absolutely appropriate and sensible that the environment minister's advice be sought and indeed taken into account.

There is nothing unnecessarily prescriptive about these amendments. I note that Senator Tambling referred to these as procedural and said that they should go in the regulations. I do not think that any of us should fall for that argument. Anyone who has been watching legislation over the years recognises that this increasing tendency to put information and matters into delegated legislation only serves the purposes of government. It is not necessary. If it is important, it should go in the bill; it should go in the act. It worries me that we have what Terry O'Gorman refers to as `function creep'. That is what we are seeing here. Senator Harradine has terminology for that as well.

We find these amendments commendable in their intent and put on notice to the government that we will be revisiting, possibly at length, the environment minister issue. Let us make this clear: the government agreed with the Democrats. The government agreed on a deal with the Democrats to ensure a role for the environment minister. What we have now is not only reneging on a deal but a watered down version. I cannot imagine that Senator Robert Hill is feeling too happy about that. So here we have the Democrats rushing to the aid of the environment minister. We are willing to support him. We know that he had it right last year when he went on record saying that this was crucial and important. I do not want to see the environment minister undermined in this way. So we are going to give the government a chance to show how much it cares about not only the environment but also Senator Hill. This is an opportunity, and I foreshadow those amendments.

talk.start.para: —Senator Stott Despoja is rapidly talking me into supporting Senator Hill as well.
(Senator Crowley)—We are grateful, Senator Brown, for a soupcon of levity at this hour. Do continue.

—Chair, I am wanting to search out the parliamentary secretary a little on this to see how we are faring. As he will know, genetically modified canola crops have been planted all over the country: in the Darling Downs, in the western plains of New South Wales, through Victoria, in the Midlands of Tasmania and in Western Australia. We also know that local governments have been excluded by the Labor Party and the government from having a role in keeping such crops out of the region if the farmers of the area do want to be GE free.
—Rubbish!

—That is not rubbish; that is how Labor voted on this matter. We are now dealing with the potential impact of much more complicated matters than canola crops, which you see, yellow flowering, all around the planet. I want to ask the parliamentary secretary: what is the potential for the spread or persistence of genetically modified material in canola crops in the environment in Australia? What have been the findings of the industry and the Gene Technology Regulator as far as canola crops and the persistence of genetically modified organisms are concerned? Is a buffer zone of 15 kilometres required around genetically modified crops, given evidence we had before the committee that bees can fly for eight kilometres in a straight line and could transfer genetically modified material at least that far?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown is obviously getting into the area of licensed conditions of the regulator. He is wrong when he says that local government will not be fully consulted. That was made very clear in the debate last Friday, where we acknowledged that there were provisions specifically for GM-free zones. With regard to the issues that he is raising with regard to genetically modified material, I suggest that these are issues he should have raised—and may have—at your committee, Temporary Chairman Crowley, when this matter was under consideration in quite considerable detail. Certainly they are the sorts of issues that should be pursued now with the Interim Office of the Gene Technology Regulator once it is established under this legislation.
—I am taking one provision out of dozens in the Greens amendments, one which says that the regulator should be aware of the following matters. Greens amendment No. 59 says:

quote.para: (d) the potential for spread or persistence of the GMO or its genetic material in the environment.

speech.para: I want to know from the government the potential as far as canola is concerned. Here we have the most famous and widespread case in Australia—lots of experience—so what is the potential for spread or persistence of the genetic material in the environment in Australia of that crop? I just want to say that we did discuss the matter of local government, and the government and opposition did say that local government will be consulted. The point that the Greens, the Democrats and One Nation have taken is that that is not good enough. Local government should have a say; it should be empowered. It is very different from being consulted and then ignored. We know what this legislation means. We know that the big corporations do not want local government to have a say, because the closer you get to the relationship between people and their land, the more strongly they will be wanting to have input into what is happening. So the best way you can go against their interests is to not have them at local level—at grassroots level, at local government level—and to have a veto. That is what it comes down to. We have already dealt with the amendments which the government and Labor Party have knocked out as far as local government having a say is concerned, so don't give me the stuff about `consulted'. It washes right over. For `consulted', read `disempowered'. I would be interested to know what the government has to say on the matter of persistence of canola in the environment.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The initial question posed by Senator Brown raised scientific matters which should be raised with the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee. I can, however, assure Senator Brown that GM canola, like any other GM crop, will be dealt with under the appropriate conditions. The regulations require the issues he raises to be addressed as distinct from what he is seeking to put in his amendment, which the government opposes.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —Suggesting that something is a scientific matter or a matter for scientific debate and therefore should be taken up with GMAC is not responsible. It is not good enough in the context of this debate. We are discussing scientific matters and legislation that go to the heart of the issues that Senator Brown raised in relation to consultation and environmental and health protection.

speech.para: Senator Tambling has advisers. They have scientific expertise. They are involved in, if not part of, GMAC and they can advise us if Senator Brown asks questions through the chair to the parliamentary secretary. We are expected to know this stuff and to understand this stuff because we are crafting legislation to protect the interests of Australians in relation to the approval and the assessment of genetically modified organisms. So we cannot cop out. Of all of us who cannot afford to cop out, the parliamentary secretary is the one. This is his job.

If Senator Tambling wants us to raise these issues with GMAC, I will start by asking him whether buffer zones and refuge zones are currently specified under GMAC guidelines. No, they are not. I know the answer—they are dealt with on a case by case basis, which is irresponsible and insufficient. My question to Senator Tambling is: what is the government going to do to ensure that the worst aspect of GMAC's current guidelines are not emulated or perpetuated as a consequence of the legislation before us? If the parliamentary secretary wants us to refer to GMAC for the answers, that is not good enough. He is responsible for this debate, and we expect answers. Also, there are enough loopholes currently in the guidelines that are not necessarily rectified by this legislation that once again give the parliament good reason to reject a lot of the aspects of the bill before it. It is an insufficient, inadequate regulatory framework. It is not good enough. It does not guard against the things or protect the things that the objects of the act say it will—mind you, we have not completed discussion on the objects of the act; we have not started the debate on the objects of the act. Do not refer us to GMAC, because I find that insulting. In the context of this debate, if I want answers to questions—scientific matters or not—I expect them. I ask the minister to tell us what he is going to do regarding the current inadequacies in relation to GMAC guidelines that see buffer zones and refuge zones being dealt with on a case by case basis.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —It is a fact that the bill cannot set specific conditions for a specific GM canola crop, as it cannot set conditions for any crop. It can only set the parameters for the conditions. When Senator Brown refers to the 15-metre buffer zone with regard to GM canola, that is setting an indication of what he sees as a view. The bill sets appropriate conditions in line with the risks of each appropriate application, and that must be the way in which it would work.

—I did not say that the bill has got to lay down, crop by crop, what the conditions are. What these amendments say is that the regulator is required to take matters into account. One matter is the potential for spread or persistence of genetic material in the environment. What I get from the government is that it is not going to be a matter that the regulator is required to know about when licensing crops and genetically modified organisms going into the environment, under the act. It may be under the regulations, but it is not under the act; nor are the other matters listed here. The Labor Party apparently agrees with that. It is just diminishing the responsibilities of the regulator, which we should be very explicitly laying down here. If the committee were being listened to by the government and the opposition, they would be very pleased with amendments like this which make the law clearer. The job of us, in a committee and in the Senate, is to write the law clearly, explicitly, in simple language, so that all involved—from the regulator through to the citizen in the street—can understand it. These amendments do that. What the government is saying is, `No, leave it to regulations. That will do.' By doing that it makes it much more difficult for the public as a whole to have access to what their rights are and what the requirements on the regulator are.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The legislation requires the regulator to take into account a risk assessment. In the regulations—and I again refer Senator Brown to the draft regulation document that is available and has been around; it was certainly made available to him and to members of the committee—clause 14 of the gene technology regulations specifically refers to risk assessment and the matters to be taken into account. It sets out a number of conditions. If I can be specific to the ones that Senator Brown referred to, the condition under subclause (b)(v) is `the potential of the GMO concerned to spread or persist in the environment'. So the matters are addressed currently in the broad in the legislation and in the regulations. The amendment proposed by Senator Brown is unnecessary.

—In answer to Senator Brown, Senator Tambling made the statement that the regulator must consult if he considers it necessary. If we look at clause 47 of the bill, under the heading `What the regulator must do in relation to application', subclause (4) of that clause clearly says:

quote.para: (4) The Regulator may consult:
(a) the States; and
(b) the Gene Technology Technical Advisory Committee; and
(c) relevant Commonwealth authorities or agencies; and
(d) any local council that the Regulator considers appropriate...

speech.para: So there is nothing in the bill that requires that the regulator must consult. The bill says that the regulator may consult. I believe this goes to the heart of the amendments that Senator Brown is proposing, and that is that the regulator must seek advice on matters relevant from the state authority, the relevant local government authority and the committees. Rather than saying, as Senator Tambling would have us believe, that the regulator must consult if he considers it necessary, the bill requires only that the regulator may consult.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harris needs to go specifically to the bill. Section 47 applies only to contained work when the GTR may consult. In relation to intentional release into the environment, the GTR must consult. I refer him to sections 50 and 52 of the bill, specifically clause 50, which is headed `Regulator must prepare risk assessment and risk management plan'. Subclause (3) states, `The Regulator must seek advice on' and subclause (3)(e) states, `any local council that the Regulator considers appropriate'.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: (Senator Chapman)—The next question is that clause 45 stand as printed.

—The Greens oppose clause 45. Let me read the clause out, Mr Temporary Chairman Chapman, and I am sure you will agree with me. The heading is `Regulator must not use certain information in considering licence applications.' It says that if a person—let's call that Monsanto—applies for a GMO licence and Monsanto provides information to the regulator for consideration, and the information is (according to Monsanto) confidential commercial information, then the regulator must not take that information into account for the purposes of considering an application by another person for a GMO licence, unless Monsanto has given written consent for the information to be so taken into account. Please explain.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —We are looking at a bundle of amendments proposed by the Greens in this particular area. The government one, as you indicated, specifically relates to clause 45. We will be voting that it should stand as printed. With regard to Greens amendments Nos 60 and 124-127, the government will be opposing them. The amendments proposed by Senator Brown enable the regulators to refuse to declare that information is confidential commercial information if it relates to health or environmental risks or geographic locations or if the public interest outweighs the prejudice that the disclosure would cause. The government will not accept these amendments. The ALP has, however, moved amendments in relation to clauses 184 and 185, which are amendments Nos 1 and 2 on sheet 2067, which also relate to disclosure of information. They ensure that the regulator will always publish either (a) the location of a field trial or (b) a statement of reasons for nondisclosure. The government will support the ALP amendments.
