—What is the definition of confidential commercial information in the government's clause?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I refer Senator Brown to clause 185 of the bill for that matter. Also, I think this is an issue that we will be addressing in more detail later when we address the ALP amendments.
—Let us look at clause 185. It says:

para.inline: Regulator may declare that information is confidential commercial information.

quote.para: (1) Subject to subsection (2)—

speech.para: that is down below—

quote.para: if the person satisfies the Regulator that the information specified—

speech.para: Let me again substitute Monsanto for `person, organisation or undertaking', because it makes it much more appealing listening. We could now say:`(1) Subject to subsection (2), if Monsanto satisfies the Regulator that the information specified in the application is: (a) a trade secret; or (b) any other information that has a commercial or other value that would be, or could reasonably be expected to be, destroyed or diminished if the information were disclosed; or (c) other information that: (i) concerns the lawful commercial or financial affairs of Monsanto; and (ii) if it were disclosed, could unreasonably affect Monsanto; the Regulator must declare that the information is confidential ...'
That says `must declare'—there is no `may' anymore—that the information is confidential. I guess `trade secret' has some legal definition to it but I ask the government: what is meant by:

quote.para: (b) any other information that has a commercial or other value that would be, or could reasonably be expected to be, destroyed or diminished if the information were disclosed; or...

speech.para: We will start with that. Give an example.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —This matter was addressed earlier this evening, and I also invited debate later when we were looking at the Labor Party amendments. Senator Brown is very obviously seeking to pursue conspiracy theories about Monsanto, or whoever else. But what is more important is that subclause 185(2) gives and empowers the regulator to be satisfied that, whatever his considerations are in the public interest, the disclosure outweighs the prejudice that that disclosure would cause any person. So the public interest can override, and in certain instances probably would. So, in the consideration of this issue, Senator Brown is tending to focus on the particular rather than on the specific areas outlined in the legislation. Senator Brown wanted an example of what would be commercial-in-confidence but not a trade secret: I am advised that a gene sequence for a non-commercial product would be.
—Let us have an example of where the public interest would outweigh a matter that Monsanto wanted to keep commercially confident.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —While the parliamentary secretary is seeking advice, could we also `clarify gene sequence for a non-commercial product'? Perhaps we could even be a little more specific, but that is presuming a patent is taken out on that gene sequence.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that, if a patent is taken out, it would be a trade secret. That is the issue that needs to be clarified in that regard.

—So it is a trade secret and, therefore, the regulator must declare that the information is confidential. Then we get to subclause (2), which the parliamentary secretary referred us to, which says that the regulator `may refuse to declare that the information is confidential if the public interest outweighs it.' This is just not satisfactory. What we are dealing with here is the fact that the profitable motives of corporations are to be defended and the public is not to have access to that information unless they can effectively show that the public interest is outweighed. To that I would say that the corporate sector is always going to be able to say, `Our interest is infringed if this information is released.' It is not until it is released and the public is shown to be damaged that you can argue that there is a public damage and you can say what that damage is going to be. In other words, the public interest is not going to be defined. The corporate interest is going to be defined and the corporate interest will win out under those circumstances. What we ought to be having is a protection of the information that goes before the regulator. When it comes to matters that have a commercial value, does that include where a crop is going to be, what the productivity of a crop is going to be or what the benefits to the community from that crop are going to be? Where is the limit on the matters that a corporation can say are of commercial importance to them? I think it covers every aspect of the application of gene technology. Every aspect will have a monetary value as far as the corporate entity is concerned.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am sure Senator Brown intends to raise this not only now but also when we get to amendment No. 185. As I said earlier, with regard to patents and trade there are important considerations. But, if there is no patent, it must be appreciated that its value could be diminished. Nevertheless, the important point to make—and I think I tried to stress this from the legislation—is that the public interest could outweigh the loss incurred by the applicant. The legislation assumes that all information should be disclosed.

speech.para: Question put:

motion.para: That clause 45 stand as printed.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown, as your following amendments in that batch were consequential on that particular motion, I presume you will not be proceeding with the remainder.
—That is correct.
—by leave—I move One Nation amendments (27) and (30) on sheet 2030:

quote.para: (27) Clause 47, page 32 (after line 31), at the end of the clause, add:

(5) A risk assessment and a risk management plan prepared under this section must have particular regard to the impact of the dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence on Australia's unique flora and fauna and on the maintenance of Australia's biodiversity.
(30) Clause 50, page 35 (after line 4), at the end of the clause, add:

(4) A risk assessment and a risk management plan prepared under this section must have particular regard to the impact of the dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence on Australia's unique flora and fauna and on the maintenance of Australia's biodiversity.

speech.para: The purpose of amendments (27) and (30) is to amend part 4 of the bill. Amendment (27) to clause 47 of the bill is to require the regulator to take into account a risk assessment and a risk management plan. This amendment requires the regulator to have particular regard to the impact of the dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence on Australia's unique flora and fauna and on the maintenance of Australia's biodiversity. Amendment (30) to clause 50 on page 35 of the bill would also require the regulator, when accepting an application, to prepare the same risk assessment and risk management plan to take into account Australia's unique flora and fauna and the maintenance of Australia's biodiversity. The amendments are crucial in that, rather than not have what should be protected defined, they would make very clear what the regulator is required to protect. Australia has a unique flora and fauna and wealth of biodiversity in this continent that must be taken into account when the regulator assesses or accepts an application and, having accepted that application, prepares a risk assessment and a risk management plan.

I foreshadow that the next two amendments I will move subsequent to having moved these two amendments will actually require the regulator to have also prepared an EIA or an EIS, depending on the level of impact or the potential impact of the application. So the intention of Pauline Hanson's One Nation amendments (27) and (30) is to require the regulator, when accepting an application and preparing the risk assessment and the risk management plan, to take into account our unique flora, fauna and biodiversity. I commend the amendments to the chamber.

talk.start.para: (Senator Chapman)—Senator Harris, would you care to move amendments (28) and (31) together with those you have just moved?
—No, Chair.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the government is opposed to these amendments. The requirement in clause 47 for the GTR to look at all risks to the environment and the many ways and any ways to manage such risks ensures that the GTR must look at Australia's unique flora and fauna and the maintenance of biodiversity. It is, therefore, not necessary that this additional provision be included.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I think it is highly commendable that this amendment has been moved and, with all due respect—through you, Chair, to Senator Harris—it is interesting that it takes One Nation to move it. I have to say the defence of biodiversity and the environment that has come from your area of the chamber tonight is quite impressive and refreshing, and the Democrats will be supporting this amendment. I am sorry that the government does not see fit to. If the government's only argument is that it is unnecessary because it is covered in other sections of the bill, then, unless there is a real problem with some form of potential duplication, I cannot see why the government cannot include this provision. Certainly, the impact of GMs in relation to biodiversity and our environment is something that has been explored at length by the Democrats, not only generally in our report on the committee inquiry but in a submission that I put forward on behalf of the Australian Democrats to the House of Representatives standing committee in relation to primary producers. Certainly, our commitment to the environment is well known. I commend the amendments and, on behalf of my party, we will be supporting them.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move amendments (28) and (31) on sheet 2030:

quote.para: (28) Clause 47, page 32 (after line 31), at the end of the clause, add:
(6) A risk assessment and risk management plan prepared for the purposes of this section must be prepared in accordance with the guidelines made by the Minister.

(7) Guidelines made under subsection (6) must set out procedures to be followed in the preparation of a risk assessment and risk management plan that are no less rigorous than procedures for the preparation of an environmental impact statement under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.
(8) Guidelines made under subsection (6) are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.
(31) Clause 50, page 35 (after line 4), at the end of the clause, add:
(5) A risk assessment and risk management plan prepared for the purposes of this section must be prepared in accordance with the guidelines made by the Minister.

(6) Guidelines made under subsection (5) must set out procedures to be followed in the preparation of a risk assessment and risk management plan that are no less rigorous than procedures for the preparation of an environmental impact statement under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.
(7) Guidelines made under subsection (5) are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

speech.para: Amendment (28) seeks to amend clause 47 of the bill. I find myself in an unusual circumstance. Senator Stott Despoja has referred to One Nation raising issues regarding the protection of Australia's flora and fauna. In relation to the amendments that I have just moved, I normally find myself on the other end—

talk.start.para: —You have seen the light.

—Senator Stott Despoja asks whether I have seen the light. I believe that is correct. Referring to my mining background, initially we viewed EIAs and EISs with great concern, particularly in what we call the non-corporate sector of mining. What we have found over subsequent years, having become used to working with an environmental impact assessment or with a slightly lower level of that—the preparation of an environmental impact statement—is that it has become of benefit to the non-corporate sector of mining because it has raised the awareness of the mining industry, particularly in the non-corporate area, as to our duty to protect the environment. In many cases it has actually resulted in improvements in our practices and the processes under which we mine.

speech.para: I believe that in relation to this bill it is even more essential for an applicant to prepare, as part of their application, depending on the potential of impact into the environment, either an environmental impact assessment—if it is a licence to carry out the planting of broadacre crops in the environment, it is incumbent on the person who is applying for the licence to carry out a complete assessment of the potential impact of the growing of that crop on the environment—or an environmental impact statement. For a field trial where part of the conditions requires that process to be carried out within a confined environment, as we saw in Mount Gambier when covers were to be placed over the trials to exclude any possibility of crosspollination from the genetically modified canola across to any non-modified canola in the area, I believe it would be quite appropriate for an environmental impact statement to be completed in relation to that lesser degree of exposure to the environment.

Amendments (28) and (31) require anybody who applies for a licence to deal in a genetically modified organism to come under the same legislative framework as any other industry that intends to operate in the environment. Paragraph (7) of proposed amendment (28) states:

quote.para: Guidelines made under subsection (6) must set out procedures to be followed in the preparation of a risk assessment and risk management plan that are no less rigorous than procedures for the preparation of an environmental impact statement under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

speech.para: Why should other industries have to comply with the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act when those who are proposing to deal in genetically modified organisms do not have to comply with it? These two amendments will make it very clear that anybody who proposes to carry out a dealing that involves the planting of a genetically modified organism in the environment should take the steps necessary to ensure that our unique flora and fauna and biodiversity will not suffer as a result. I commend the amendments to the chamber.

talk.start.para: —Talking about unique fauna, at least, if an environmental impact assessment were done on the smell of the coffee and raisin toast coming into the chamber from an adjacent place, it might close down that function because of the negative impact it is having on those who are in here trying to work. But we wish them well out there.

speech.para: In a serious vein, I support these amendments. I do not believe that enough work has been done on the matter. What happens if genetic modification escapes from crops into native flora? It stays there. The minister and all his advisers put together cannot get it back out. It is in the system forever. You have lost the flora, the plant life, in Australia, insofar as that genetic modification goes to work. In the case of Tasmania, a lot of the plantations of eucalypts that are currently spreading like a plague across the northern parts of the state, and now in the Huon Valley, are Eucalyptus nitans, which comes from Victoria. The genetic material from them is getting into adjacent woodlands. We do not know much about it at the moment but what we can guarantee is that it will not come back out again.

I would ask the government on a case in point about genetically modified river red gums. Former Prime Minister Paul Keating launched the genetically modified red gum proposals, the whole deal which the CSIRO has afoot. Can the government say what the impact of the genetic modification in the environment has been, who is looking at that, who is monitoring it, where it is occurring and who the Gene Technology Regulator is depending on for the feedback from that particular experiment?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government does not agree with the amendments proposed by the Pauline Hanson One Nation party and will be opposing them. The amendments are not supported for two key reasons. Firstly, the amendments involve the Commonwealth health minister issuing guidelines on the preparation of risk assessment and risk management plans. As this is a national scheme, it is not appropriate that this responsibility rests with the Commonwealth minister. Secondly, the amendments require that the risk assessment guidelines are no less rigorous than for the preparation of an environmental impact statement under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. This is not appropriate because the types of applications to which clause 47 relates are applications for dealing with GMOs that do not involve intentional release of a GMO into the environment. Therefore, the processes described in relation to environmental impact statements under the EPBC Act that only relate to activities being conducted in the open environment are not appropriate. I will have to take on notice the question posed by Senator Brown with regard to specific areas. It is an area with which we are not familiar.

—But the government is familiar with the reality that, when genetic modifications move out of the crops or trees which contain those modifications into the natural environment, there is no way you can get them back.
—That is why you need a strong regulator.

—Yes, but that is why you also need these amendments, which specifically point to knowing what the impact is going to be on Australia's unique flora and fauna before it occurs. The regulator, the minister, Prime Minister Howard and all their advisers cannot get back a genetic modification once it has got into the natural environment. The regulator is too late on the scene once that has occurred. What this is about is understanding how that process could occur before the event and making sure it does not happen. The parliamentary secretary is giving no indication that this legislation is going to prevent the spill of genetic modification into the natural environment in Australia.

—Senator Tambling has raised the issue that division 3, which is `Initial consideration of licences for dealings not involving intentional releases of a GMO into the environment', is not applicable to the amendments that I have moved. I believe that the applications for licences for dealings that do not involve intentional releases of a GMO are equally as important as division 4, which is consideration of dealings involving intentional releases. I support that by raising these issues. On a number of occasions viral elements have escaped from laboratories. If we want to look at an area that has some unique flora and fauna, we do not have to go any further than St Lucia, in Brisbane. Even though it is an inner Brisbane suburb, it has some very special natural flora and fauna. It also has something else—called human beings.

speech.para: If Senator Tambling can give us an absolute, ironclad, 100 per cent guarantee that no GMOs will ever escape from the proposed biodiversity laboratories at St Lucia in Brisbane, then I will agree with him: we will not need amendments under division 3. However, I do not have the confidence that Senator Tambling has in the track record of not only the biodiversity functions, the research, but also all other manners of laboratory research. History shows that they do have unintentional releases from those facilities. So it is equally important, if not more important, depending on what experiments will be carried out—and we know that there will be genetically modified experiments carried out in that facility in that residential area—and it is totally appropriate that these sections apply to division 4, which is the initial consideration of licences for dealings not involving intentional releases. It is most certainly appropriate that they apply to division 4, which relates to the initial consideration of licences for dealing involving intentional releases into the environment. Through you, Chair, to Senator Tambling: I refute his statement that these amendments are not appropriate to division 3.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats believe these are commendable amendments. I do not mean to be facetious but—through you, Chair, to Senator Harris—out of the mouths of One Nation! I respect you for putting on record the influence that your background of mining experience has had on your appreciation of environmental assessments and impact statements. I think that goes to the very heart of the fact that laws do change lives, laws influence our culture and laws have a meaningful impact on people's attitudes. So I think that we should be leading the way with these amendments. I think it is totally justifiable to put them in this section in relation to risk assessment, and reference to the EPBC Act is totally appropriate in these circumstances, just as I believe reference to it in other areas of this bill would be quite appropriate. So the Democrats support the amendments before the chair.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move amendments (7) and (8) standing in my name on behalf of the Australian Democrats:

quote.para: (7) Page 33 (after line 9), after clause 48, insert:

para.inline: 48A Regulator must seek advice of Environment Minister

quote.para: After receiving an application to which this Division applies, the Regulator must seek advice from the Environment Minister on matters relevant to the decision whether to issue or refuse to issue the licence.
(8) Clause 56, page 39 (after line 19), before paragraph (2)(a), insert:
(aa) any advice provided by the Environment Minister in response to a request under section 48A;

speech.para: These amendments to clause 48 and clause 56 relate to the role of the environment minister in relation to this legislation. Quite clearly, my amendment (7) states:

quote.para: 48A Regulator must seek advice of Environment Minister...

speech.para: There is no may, no ifs, no buts. It is actually quite prescribed—`must seek advice'. The amendment reads:

quote.para: After receiving an application to which this Division applies, the Regulator must seek advice from the Environment Minister on matters relevant to the decision whether to issue or refuse to issue the licence.

speech.para: Amendment (8) emulates that in relation to inserting a provision:

quote.para: (aa) any advice provided by the Environment Minister in response to a request under section 48A;

speech.para: Again, this is prescribing a role for the environment minister—not merely consultation but you, as the regulator, must be seeking the advice of the minister as to whether or not you issue or refuse to issue the licence. This was not such a controversial matter a year ago and it was certainly something to which the government agreed in the context of the EPBC Act. In negotiations Senator Hill actually thought this was quite appropriate.

The Democrats have put on record a number of times in this place and certainly to the committee of inquiry into this legislation not only our concerns about the role of the environment minister but our anger towards the government reneging on its deal, its negotiated position, in relation to the EPBC Act. The government broke that deal as a consequence of a federal cabinet decision, I believe, on 13 June this year to minimise the role of the environment minister in relation to gene technology in Australia. In fact, Senator Hill, in the Senate during the original passage of what became the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, the EPBC Act, said on 22 June last year that `matters that affect the environment will be referred to the environment minister for assessment and advice by that independent regulator'. He said:

motion.para: That will ultimately be provided for through an amendment to this legislation,—

speech.para: the EPBC Act—

quote.para: when it passes, in conjunction with the law that is going to be put in place to set up the new GTR.

speech.para: This commitment has been provided before the Senate. There is no ambiguity in relation to the commitment that Senator Hill gave as environment minister to the Senate and to the parliament and thus to the Australian community. I have put on record previously our concerns, specifically in a matter of public interest debate of the Senate on 21 June this year, when we discovered that the decision by the government was to be reneged on. A key senator involved in the negotiation on that bill, Senator Andrew Bartlett, our environment spokesperson, will elaborate on the Democrats' position.

As I stated earlier in the debate when I foreshadowed this amendment, we have had no justification from the government as to why there should be a lessening or a weakening of the role of the environment minister, especially when the object of the act and the general discussion tonight have been in the context of ensuring that we have a strong regulatory framework in order to protect not only the health interests of Australians but their environmental concerns, as well as to protect biodiversity. The Democrats would like to see inserted into the objects of the act provisions promoting ecological sustain-ability. How you can do that when you have a lesser role for the environment minister, when you do not actually prescribe that the regulator must seek advice from the environment minister, I do not know. But, again, it goes to the heart of the comments from Senator Harris most recently in this debate—that is, the need to protect our environment but the fact that we do not have a regulatory framework or a regulator that is going to have that first and foremost in their mind. One way of ensuring that it is first and foremost in their mind is to have a strong role for the environment minister.

I will break there to give the government an opportunity to explain its most recent position, on the off-chance that Senator Tambling has decided to stand by his environment minister and to keep the government to the promise it gave to the Senate on 22 June last year. This is a great way to show support for Minister Hill, not only because he has given a commitment that the government has broken as a consequence of a cabinet decision but also to ensure that there is a realistic and strong role for the environment minister in relation to this legislation.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government will not be agreeing to the amendments proposed by the Democrats. There is a very strong role for the environment minister in this legislation. These amendments are not necessary because the Gene Technology Bill 2000 already requires the regulator to seek advice from the environment minister on every application involving the intentional release of a GMO into the environment. The regulator is required by the legislation to take the advice into account in preparing the risk assessment and the risk management plan, which is the draft decision. Further, the regulator must then seek the environment minister's advice again on the draft decision and must take into account the environment minister's advice. In effect, the bill already requires the regulator to do what the Democrat amendments propose.

—I rise also to speak to the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Stott Despoja because they are of great concern not just to the Democrats but to the Australian community. I realise Senator Tambling is in the situation where he has to outline the government's position on this, but I have to say that the explanation he has just given is fairly flimsy, especially if the government is going to break a commitment. It was not just a verbal commitment to the Democrats in a backroom somewhere; it was a specific commitment given by the minister, Senator Hill, on behalf of the government as a whole to the Senate and therefore to the people, to the Australian community as a whole. It was a commitment that the government would amend the EPBC Act at the same time that it brought in this bill to ensure that the environment minister would be involved whenever there was a dealing involving the intentional release of a GMO into the environment. It would require that and it would also require the regulator to have regard to any advice provided by the environment minister under this section. Currently, the regulator can seek the minister's advice if they so choose and they can ignore it, even once they have sought it. The provisions in this bill are not dissimilar to ones in existing acts, such as the Quarantine Act—provisions which in practice have been shown to be completely inadequate. The bill places completely in the hands of the regulator the power to decide whether to send something to the environment minister and, more particularly, the power of whether or not to pay any attention to what the minister or his or her department says.

speech.para: If the government are going to break a commitment that they gave to the Senate as a whole, then the least they can do is not backflip in cabinet without consulting, if not with the Senate as a whole, those members of the Senate that supported the passage of the bill partly on the commitment that the government gave. If the government think that they can backflip on things like that with such glibness, with such lack of consultation in the months since the backflip was made, with such inadequate reasons, and that the Democrats or any other people in the Australian community will just sigh and say, `That's a bit of a shame,' without expressing deep concern, then I think they should rethink their approach. They should also realise that breaking commitments like that clearly makes the Democrats and, I am sure, anyone in this place think twice before supporting anything else on the basis of a commitment. It is unavoidable in parliament, in politics—as in any other area of life—that sometimes you have to take people on trust; you cannot have everything locked down all at once. Legislation in life is an ongoing process, and sometimes you just have to get a commitment that another area will be addressed at the appropriate time down the track. When those commitments are broken without adequate reason, without consultation, for no reason other than what seems to be a departmental turf war, then it is not surprising that you get particularly cynical about whether or not you can place trust in the government's word in the future.

That is not meant to apply specifically to the environment minister. I would not want to state this categorically, but it would not surprise me if the environment minister were somewhat disappointed with the reversal of the commitment that he gave to the Senate on behalf of the government. If he is not, he should be—it obviously reflects on him in particular. But I took it as a commitment, and I do take it as a commitment, from the government as a whole, not just from the environment minister. That breach of faith is not just something that causes the Democrats to think twice in the future about dealings with the environment minister; it causes us to think twice about dealings with the government as a whole on any issue, because it is a serious breach of faith. As all senators would know, the environment is a key issue of concern to the Democrats, and to have a backflip on an area as crucial as that is something that we take very seriously. I would urge the government, through the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, to realise that it is not something that we take lightly, thinking, `We lost on that one but them's the breaks.' Rather, it is something that we take very seriously, and I can assure the government that it is something that we will take on board and factor in very strongly in terms of any future decisions we have to make.

I particularly want to make a plea to the opposition in relation to this issue. The opposition, sometimes fairly, sometimes unfairly, quite regularly make attacks on the Democrats for our decision to support heavily amended environment protection legislation, the most recent time being just last week when we were debating regulations in this place. They made great play of saying how naive the Democrats were for trusting the government, how we would get sold out and how we would have no ability to do anything about it after the fact. This is a situation where we do have an opportunity to do something about it. We have an opportunity to force the government to meet its commitment. It will not undermine the integrity of the whole legislation; it will strengthen the integrity of the whole legislation. It will strengthen the Australian community's faith in the operations of the regulator and it will also force the government to keep its word. So this is an occasion when the ALP have a clear chance to force the government to keep its word. If they are not going to do that, I never want to hear again any criticism of how naive the Democrats might be in taking the government at its word, because it would apply equally to the ALP. If they have got a chance here to force the government to keep its word and they cannot be bothered because of some other arrangements they have made, that is fine, but don't let me hear ever again that somehow or other we have been dudded. If the ALP does not support this amendment then we are being dudded by them equally. That does not surprise me, but it is nonetheless a fact that needs to be pointed out.

Let me make it clear that the section of the bill we are dealing with deals specifically with applications for licences for dealings involving intentional releases of a GMO into the environment, where the regulator has to be satisfied that at least one of the dealings will involve such a release into the environment. What we are doing by our amendment is adding a simple section which requires that under such circumstances the regulator must seek advice from the environment minister on matters relevant to the decision whether to issue or refuse to issue the licence. So it is a simple requirement that advice from the environment minister must be sought. Then, when the decision is being made by the regulator as to whether or not to issue the licence, before issuing the licence, under the bill as it now stands, the regulator must be satisfied that the release can be managed in a way that will protect the environment. In making that determination, the amendment the Democrats are making now will require the regulator to take into account, to have regard to, any advice provided back by the environment minister. If those things are not put in there, there is not a requirement for the regulator to have to refer something to the environment minister and there is not a requirement for the regulator to pay any attention to that advice even if it does come back; it is discretionary but not essential.

Let me say also that that is not an onerous component. The overall assessment requirements of the regulator are not parallel to those under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. To some extent that is fair enough, because they consider issues much broader than those covered under the environment act. But in relation to issues concerning the environment it is surely essential that they must at a minimum meet the same requirements as under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. Otherwise, the government is undermining the integrity of its own act. The regulator may assess things in a way that is up to that standard or better than that standard, and I hope the regulator does, but again there is no requirement; it is at all on faith. As I said before, given the government's backflip on this issue, it is a bit hard to have faith in anything. The health department, the department that has oversight of this, and the regulator have a lot of things to take into account. They have to bear in mind industry aspects, health aspects, consumer aspects, government aspects, economic opportunities and industry development issues. Environment is only one of those.

If you are talking about release of a GMO into the environment, as has been pointed out many times in this debate in lots of other contexts, I would think it is more crucial than for most other environmental issues that it be properly assessed under the standards of the environment legislation and that the environment minister's advice must be taken into account. That is a bare minimum that surely should be there. In an ideal world, the Democrats would like a stronger setup than that, but surely as a bare minimum, if you are releasing organisms into the environment, the environmental aspects should be considered by the department that oversees environmental issues. They still do not have the decision. They still do not have a veto, which is something that the Democrats would prefer, that the environment minister had veto power in such circumstances. It is not even as strong as that but still leaves the power with the regulator and the department. I would think that should be enough. But at a minimum they should be required to be consulted; their advice should be sought and taken into account. I just cannot for the life of me see why that presents a problem for the government, the department and the regulator. It is so simple, so basic and so fundamental.

As has been said, in releasing GMOs into the environment, if we get it wrong you cannot fix it up. I do not want to make a blanket statement here, but in a lot of other areas, if you get it wrong, there might be some damage but you can repair it. In this one, if you get it wrong, you could well have the case where you cannot repair it, you cannot put the genie back in the bottle, you cannot fix it up, and the consequences could be extremely significant. We have already seen circumstances where adequate controls have not been put in place and the consequences can be unknown. Biodiversity itself, one of the cornerstones of the government's EPBC Act, can be significantly at risk through inadequate controls over the release of organisms into the environment. It also goes to the heart of one of the major concerns of the Australian community. It has been raised time and time again in this debate, and the government themselves have said this is a crucial part of why this bill is being put in place: to increase Australia's confidence and the confidence of the Australian community in the safety of this type of technology. It does have potential positive benefits. It is something that certainly the Democrats, and I think probably all of us in this chamber, recognise does have great potential if it is properly controlled and properly overseen and if the Australian community has confidence in it. But one of the areas where the Australian community clearly has its highest levels of anxiety is in terms of the potential impact on the environment if organisms are released into the environment. That is an area that is of great concern to Australians, because they can see that you do not need to be an expert, you do not need to be a scientist, to realise that unintended consequences of inadequately controlled release of a GMO into the environment can be very significant.

Australians need to be assured that the environmental aspects of releasing a GMO into the environment have been fully considered as much as possible by those with the specific expertise and oversight who assess these things in a coherent, specific, environmentally focused way. From the Democrats' point of view, it increases our apprehension and our concern significantly that there is this resistance from the government to something as basic as requiring advice to be sought from the environment minister and for it to be taken into account. It baffles me why that is such a problem, and the fact that it is such a problem can do nothing other than raise the suspicions of many people in the Australian community.

It is an issue of great concern to the Democrats in terms of the need for this amendment, which is not a big one and is not as strong as we would like. It is a minimum standard. It is also of great concern to the Democrats that the government has broken its unequivocal commitment to the Senate and to the Australian people without consultation and without even the most flimsy of rationales, other than just trying to cut the environment minister out of it and some dubious concept of simplification. They are not adequate reasons to go back on such a significant commitment that was made as part of the passage of a significant piece of legislation. I say again: it makes it very much harder for the Democrats and, I would think, everyone in this place to take the government on its word—from any minister in any area. It was a cabinet decision that overturned it. It is not specifically the fault of the environment minister, but it is still a breach and one that we take very seriously.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to enter this important debate. I was interested in the comments that were made by Senator Bartlett to the committee alleging unfair attacks by the opposition on the Australian Democrats. I have heard no such attacks. The only attacks I have heard, I can assure you, Senator Bartlett, have been very fair attacks. It is a little rich to involve the opposition in this concern that you have in relation to broken deals and broken commitments.

speech.para: I always counsel the Democrats—particularly Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Bartlett, who are in the chamber at the moment—to remember the commitments over the goods and services tax, for example. That is a very good analogy for me to draw in this important committee stage debate when you talk about broken deals and commitments. These are not deals and commitments that involve the opposition. That is the point that I would make to our erstwhile Australian Democrats senators who are in the chamber: it is just like the situation we had in relation to the goods and services tax. They were deals and commitments that did not involve the opposition either. It is properly, of course, a matter, I would acknowledge, for you to raise with the government, but not a matter that it is fair to involve the opposition in. If you have allegations that whatever private arrangements you might have come to with the government have been breached, it is not a matter on which the opposition would want to comment in this committee stage debate.

The position that the opposition are taking on the amendments before the chair which stand in the name of the Australian Democrats is, as you would expect, a very strong and principled position. We are not going to support the amendments before the chair. Labor believe that the addition of the precautionary principle, through our amendments—as well as the licensing conditions set out in division 4 of the bill; division 4, clause 14 of the draft regulations; and the requirement under clause 50 that the regulator must consult and take into account the advice of the environment minister in relation to the preparation of risk assessment and risk management plan—provide protection to the environment. All these factors provide very significant protection to the environment that is as stringent as is that provided under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act.

We argue—objectively and cogently—that, as a result, the amendments standing in the name of the Australian Democrats in relation to an increased role for the environment minister are not required. This is a very clear position which I put to the committee on behalf of the opposition. I understand the frustration that the arrangements, deals, commitments, understandings or fixes which the Australian Democrats believe they might have with the government on these matters might be causing. I counsel Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Bartlett: you have to get used to it. This seems to be a pattern that has been developing. I have drawn to your attention one very clear example of it. I commend the approach the opposition are taking but, for the good and cogent reasons I have outlined, the opposition will not be supporting these two Democrat amendments.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of the Democrats amendments and note that, just approaching midnight on the second day that we have been debating this very important bill, we have the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate contributing for the first time on the bill. The Democrats amendments, as Senator Stott Despoja has so clearly put, require, in the intentional release of a GMO into the environment, the regulator to take into consideration the opinion of the environment minister. The actual placing of Democrats amendment (8) is worthy of note in that the amendment is proposed for section 56, which says that the regulator mustnot issue the licence unless satisfied as to risk management. It is in that section of the bill that the Democrats are proposing that the regulator must take into account any advice provided by the environment minister. The importance of the Democrats amendments can be encapsulated in two issues. The first one is the requirement of the regulator to take into account the environment minister's contribution. But, as I said, in section 56 the important part is that the regulator must not issue the licence unless he is satisfied as to the risk management and, in doing so, must take into account any advice provided by the environment minister. I support the amendments that have been put forward by the Democrats.

—The environment protection bill ought to have had the release of genes as a matter that was relevant to the minister for the environment. Senator Hill apparently made a commitment to the Democrats that that would be the—
—It was to the Senate as a whole.

—It was to the Democrats, though, first up, Senator, and then to the Senate as a whole. Unfortunately, the Senate by that time was not in a position to use any leverage on the matter and the Democrats had given away their leverage. I suppose that there is something to be learnt from that, but I think in particular it is an indication not just of Senator Hill's failure as minister for the environment, in yet another hugely important component of the environment and one that is increasingly of public notice and will be an election matter, but also of the way in which this government has set its face against the environment. I think I heard Senator Bartlett say that Senator Hill got rolled in cabinet on this matter.
—It's a badge of honour.
—Well, did he?
—I don't know.
—It seems to me that Senator Hill did not advocate his case very well in cabinet.
—As if you'd know.

—I can only go on the result. Senator Alston will agree with me that the result that we are seeing here tonight is a pretty poor one as far as the government is concerned. Here we have the Democrats amendment to say that the release of a GMO should be referred to the minister for the environment for advice, and the government is going to oppose that. That probably shows the assessment of the government of the relevance of Senator Hill as minister for the environment. There is no point giving him advice because it is not going to affect anything and the amendment here is going to fail. The problem was that it was not written into the EPBC Bill 16 months ago. There is no catch-up available now. The opportunity has flown. The government is now not going to show faith in this minister for the environment because it is not going to support this. So we are left with the minister for the environment being irrelevant to one of the most important and substantial measures affecting the environment that there is in the 21st century.

speech.para: There are huge concerns about this matter all over the world. Let me read from a recent sworn statement to the United States District Court for the district of Columbia by the renowned Dr Richard Lacey from the United Kingdom, who was one of those who very early on warned about the potential for mad cow disease. His warning came as early as 1990 on the matter. He says:

quote.para: It is my considered judgment that employing the process of recombinant DNA technology (genetic engineering) in producing new plant varieties entails a set of risks to the health of the consumer that are not ordinarily presented by traditional breeding techniques. It is also my considered judgment that food products derived from such genetically engineered organisms are not generally recognized as safe on the basis of scientific procedures within the community of experts qualified to assess their safety.

speech.para: He says further in his declaration that he will show why these new foods entail higher risks and explain why none of them is generally recognised as safe, and then he goes on to do that. He concludes by saying:

quote.para: As far as I can ascertain, the current policy of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration is primarily based on these two assumptions. Therefore, although it claims to be "science-based", this claim has no solid basis in fact. The only way to base the claims—

speech.para: that is, about genetically modified organisms—

quote.para: about the safety of genetically engineered food in science is to establish each one to be safe through standard scientific procedures, not through assumptions that reflect more wishful thinking than hard fact.

speech.para: He concludes by saying:

quote.para: As far as I can ascertain, the current policy of the US Food and Drug Administration is primarily based on those two assumptions and therefore, although it claims to be science based, the claim has no solid base in fact. The only way to base the claims—

speech.para: that is, about genetically modified organisms and the safety of genetically engineered food—

quote.para: in science is to establish each one to be safe through standard scientific procedures, not through assumptions that reflect more wishful thinking than hard fact.

speech.para: This is a scientist speaking about the failure, at the highest level, of science to be taken into true consideration when evaluating genetically modified organisms. The reason it is not is that that would take some time. But if these matters were referred to a minister for the environment who stood for the environment, he or she would recognise that scientifically it is reckless to release genetically modified organisms into the environment without your being able to establish through experimental procedures that that is safe. This whole legislation tonight is a failure to establish the safety of the release of genetically modified organisms. Worse than that, it is a failure to properly insure and recompense the community, if such a thing were possible, for the damage that can accrue from the release of genetically modified organisms. We have already debated how damage, for example, to the native flora and fauna of the country cannot be repaired once a genetically modified organism has infested part of the natural ecology.

These are very mild amendments. It simply says, `Get the opinion of the minister for the environment.' I know that that opinion is not worth much. But we have to look forward to a time when that opinion will count, when we do have a minister for the environment who advocates for the environment in cabinet and outside, and is prepared to tackle tough issues such as woodchipping, the coal industry's pollution of the atmosphere, and the release of genetically modified organisms. We cannot, of course, make a minister do anything except go through the motions, but we have to set legislation as if the minister were dinkum about the environment. That is why these amendments by the Democrats should be supported.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I thank Senators Brown and Harris for their support of the amendments and put on record my genuine surprise that the Labor Party is not supporting these amendments. I thought maybe it would. I thank Senator Faulkner for his brief contribution to this debate. He has gone now so—
—He's not far away.

—He never is far away. When Senator Ray came in, I thought, `Wow, we are in for a really full-on debate now.' But, first of all, I will respond to Senator Faulkner. As my colleague Senator Bartlett outlined, this was not a commitment given in a verbal manner to the Democrats or even in a written form in, say, a letter that might be exchanged between the government and a party that might be in the midst of negotiations with them—and we know that happens. This is a commitment that was given to the Australian parliament and thus to the Australian people. So by breaching or reneging on that agreement or promise, the minister has misled the Australian people. He has broken a promise in the most flagrant and blatant way possible and, for that, all Australians as well as this chamber are owed an explanation.

speech.para: It is one thing for Senator Faulkner perhaps to lecture me and my colleague Senator Bartlett—somewhat ironically, I might add—on the issue of the GST: `Don't accuse me of being naive enough to fall for those promises, because I did not believe them at the time.' But, all that aside, there are many promises that this government makes and breaks; so I can only record my disappointment. As a Democrat, we are aware all the time of broken promises made by the government. I am aware of ministers being overridden, whether it is in relation to science issues, nuclear issues or environmental issues. You only have to look at the influence of people such as Senator Minchin or Minister Tuckey in the cabinet to know that most of the good notions—if any are held by this government in relation to the environment or conservation—are usually overridden in cabinet.

I have seen blatant government commitments like, in 1996, a commitment by the Attorney-General to introduce privacy laws that would extend the Privacy Amendment Act 1988 to the private sector. Admittedly, that has happened finally, but not before that decision was overridden within a year by the Prime Minister of the day. So I am used to seeing promises or commitments made on record and broken by this government, or promises by one minister being overridden by the wishes of another or an influential cabinet. But yes, maybe I am a little surprised at the blatant manner in which this promise to the people through the parliament has been broken. Yes, I learn to live with disappointment under this government, and so there is no point in Senator Faulkner lecturing me or any of my colleagues on the issue of naivety.

To use Senator Faulkner's terminology, what is frustrating is the fact that we have the numbers in the chamber tonight, if we so choose, to reinstate this provision to hold the government to this particular promise and commitment, and to do so, to use Senator Faulkner's terminology, in a totally principled fashion. I do not understand why the opposition are not taking advantage of that opportunity—unless this is, and I stand to be corrected, part of the deal that they have negotiated with the government. Senator Faulkner says, `Well, it is not necessary, because the role of the minister for the environment is strong enough in the act,' and then cites their precautionary principle, the amendment that we have yet to debate, of course, because that is only relevant to the entire piece of legislation. I do not know what is going on there; I would have thought that debate would have been resolved between the two old parties by now. But when Senator Faulkner dares to state as evidence of a commitment to the environment the watered-down precautionary principle mooted by the Labor Party that does not even mention the word `health', what kind of precautionary principle is that? It is the most watered-down version, one that will probably be further watered down when they factor in cost effectiveness issues.

To cite as evidence of the ALP's concern for environmental issues under this legislation—and, therefore, the unnecessary nature of the amendments before the chamber—the precautionary principle as outlined in the Labor Party amendment is quite extraordinary. I read that amendment for the benefit of the chamber. It seeks to insert in the regulatory framework:

quote.para: (a) provides that where there are threats of serious—

speech.para: and note there is no `health' mentioned—

quote.para: or irreversible environmental damage, a lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing measures to prevent environmental degradation;

speech.para: So sure, there is reference to the environment—but what a watered-down precautionary principle! I think people on this side of the chamber have registered our concerns, but I again put on record: how can we debate this bill when we have not determined the objectives of the legislation, of the act, especially as it pertains to environmental protection and health safety and possibly—if you look at the amendments moved by the Democrats—ecological sustainability, or other matters? Certainly, most of the crossbench members have moved a precautionary principle of sorts. All of us have very similar amendments in relation to the precautionary principle—except the Labor Party, and I am assuming that they have had to settle for a lesser one.

So I am frustrated that we cannot fix a problem that has arisen as a result of government weakness and flagrant breaching of government promises. But in some respects I suspect that Senator Forshaw, Senator Faulkner and certainly others in the party probably know that they are handing this to the progressives in the chamber on a plate. Do you think that the Australian community is going to wear the fact that we had the opportunity to ensure that there was a fundamental and explicit role for the environment minister in relation to the GMOs approval and assessment processes and that the Labor Party stopped that environment minister having a role? Do you think that the Australian people are going to wear that? Do you think that your voters are going to like that, your supporters are going to like that, or that your members are going to like that? No. So in some respects, you are handing many of your supporters to us on a plate.

As much as I would like to see a huge boost in the Democrat ranks through totally legitimate means and a rise in our vote, I care more that the legislation is actually good, sound and progressive and that the objects of the act are ones that hold high the notion of environmental protection and safety and that there is a role—an equivalent role, at a minimum—for the environment minister. I care about all those consultations that the government undertook in good faith—and I acknowledge that—and all the good work of the department in relation to getting public feedback on the concerns in relation to this issue generally and the bill specifically. When people came and said, `Look we want equivalent dealing and balance given to the environmental and health considerations,' I want to see that reflected in the legislation. Senator Hill wanted to see that reflected in the legislation. That is why he gave a promise not simply to a political party, not simply to a bunch of people in the chamber who happened to be around at the time, not in writing to one or two individuals or a party organisation; he made a commitment to the Australian people and he put it on record in a blatant fashion. He was right to do so and we are right now to hold him to it.

I am very surprised that the ALP have taken this path for a whole range of reasons. I can conclude only that the parameters in which they are negotiating with the government do not allow for support of these amendments. But I really wish that they would reconsider, because we can fix this one and the Australian people expect the environment minister to have a strong role. Let's give it to him. Unfortunately, I read the numbers in the chamber and I think it is really disappointing. Do not worry; I hold this against the government, but I say to the ALP: be it on your head.
Question put:

motion.para: That the amendments (Senator Stott Despoja's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I move Greens amendment No. 61:

quote.para: (61) Clause 54, page 38 (lines 9 to 15), omit subclause (2) (but not the notes), substitute:
(2) If a person makes a request under subsection (1), the Regulator must provide to the person a copy of the documents, other than any confidential commercial information contained in the documents.

speech.para: This amendment says that, where a person requests copies of an application by a person or company to release genetically modified organisms into the environment, the information that is available on those applications, with the exception of confidential commercial information, should be released to that person. The clause as it stands would prevent a person from getting information, besides confidential commercial information, also relating to a corporation that had broken the law and committed a crime previously in such a matter. I think it is fair enough that that matter should not be hidden from the public and should not be hidden from somebody who wants to find out what such a corporation or corporate entity is doing or has done. Looking at clause 58, you will read that, when the matter of considering whether a person should get a licence is being decided under subsection (2), it states:

quote.para: (2) Without limiting the matters to which the Regulator may have regard in deciding whether a body corporate is a suitable person to hold a licence, the Regulator must have regard to the following:
any relevant conviction of the body corporate; and
if there is a relevant conviction of the body corporate:
whether the offence concerned was committed at a time when any person who is presently a director of the body corporate was a director; and

whether that offence was committed at a time when any officer or shareholder of the body corporate who is presently in a position to influence the management of the body corporate was such an officer or shareholder; and

any revocation or suspension of a licence or permit (however described) held by the body corporate under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a foreign country, being a law relating to the health and safety of people or the environment; and
the capacity of the body corporate to meet the conditions of the licence.

speech.para: In that section a `relevant conviction' means one which occurred within the last 10 years and which was punishable by a fine of $5,000 or more. So we are dealing with very important previous offences. I am particularly concerned that a corporation which has committed past offences and which applies for a licence to release genetically modified organisms into the Australian environment will have that information covered up if a member of the public, a neighbour or somebody else goes to see what the licence application is about. That should not be the case.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —This is an amendment that the government will oppose. The Attorney-General's Department's advice is that the Senate, through the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, has always been cautious in legislating to require the disclosure of prior convictions. This caution is well founded, being based on the right to privacy and rehabilitation considerations. Under clause 58, relevant convictions must be disclosed to the regulator who must take that information into account in deciding whether an applicant is a suitable person to hold a licence. This amendment would require disclosure of convictions to anybody who asks. There is no justification for this. Clause 54 already provides for members of the public to have wide rights of access to relevant documents. There is no need for details of past convictions of applicants to be placed in the public domain.

—Convictions are what we are talking about here. We are talking particularly about corporations. I am quite happy to limit it to that if the government has problems with individuals, but we are talking about major convictions for crimes committed by corporations against the public being required to be listed on an application for a licence by somebody who is going to use a genetically modified organism, and the need for that information to be available to somebody who wants to see what the record of this corporate entity is. We are not just dealing with the ordinary matter here of giving a defendant before a court the protection of not having their record before the court in the consideration of the crime that has been committed. We are talking here about the privilege—and indeed the huge responsibility—of releasing a genetically modified organism into the Australian environment. If we are dealing with a corporation which has committed a crime where the offence is punishable on conviction by a fine of $5,000 or more, or imprisonment of a year or more, then I think that should be a matter for public disclosure. Not everybody should be releasing genetically modified organisms. If somebody has a criminal conviction for a relevant matter, then that should not only be taken into account by the regulator but be on the public record as well.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move One Nation's amendments Nos 33 and 101:

quote.para: (33) Page 39 (after line 9), after clause 55, insert:

para.inline: 55A Rights of adjoining property owners etc.

quote.para: (1) The Regulator must not issue a licence for the intentional release of a GMO into the environment at a particular location unless the Regulator has notified the owner and occupier of each property adjoining the location (the adjoining property) in writing about the application.
(2) A notice for the purposes of subsection (1) must include the following:
(a) a copy of the application;
(b) details of the location and size of the proposed dealing;
(c) a copy of the risk assessment;
(d) a copy of the risk management plan.
(3) For the purposes of this section:
adjoining property, in relation to the location of a proposed GMO dealing, means a property that:
(a) has a common boundary with the property on which the dealing is proposed to be undertaken; or
(b) is separated from that property by a road, access way, easement or public area.
(101) Clause 179, page 117 (after table item 1), insert:

entry.para: To issue a licence for the intentional release of a GMO into the environment
the owner or occupier of a property adjoining the location of the release

speech.para: The amendments that I am proposing relate to the rights of an adjoining property owner. I will speak to amendment No. 33 first. This is important, considering that the amendments that have been proposed by a combination of the Greens, the Democrats and One Nation, have to a great degree been voted down by the government and the opposition, particularly those that relate to the identification and notification of a dealing with a GMO relating to the release of a genetically modified organism into the environment.

Too many times we have seen legislation and regulations produced that will give some notification to property owners immediately adjacent to a property, but there are very few that will actually take into consideration properties—and I am speaking now mainly about rural areas—that happen to be separated from that particular property by either a normal road or even, in some cases, a narrow lane. So you can have a situation—and we will use an illustration of a powerline as an example—where a 132,000 kVa powerline with a draw of in excess of 100 millivolt amps is being constructed on one property, and there is a 25-metre laneway and then another property adjoining on the opposite side. There is considerable scientific evidence that the effects of electromagnetic fields will carry far beyond that 25-metre laneway. So therefore you can have a property adjacent to a property on which, in this case, a powerline was going to be built and not only is there no necessity to notify those property owners of the construction of that powerline; they would also have no right of redress whatsoever.

The essence of this amendment is to ensure that, if a licence is granted for the release of a genetically modified product into the environment—and this could quite possibly be by way of broadacre planting of a crop—all property owners or occupiers who have boundaries adjoining that property would have to receive notification of the granting of that licence. This amendment would then go one step further to ensure that any property adjacent that is separated by a lane, an easement or a public area would also receive notification in writing. That is the essence of amendment No. 33.

Amendment No. 101 would cause an amendment to clause 179 of the bill on page 117. This part of the bill relates to review of a decision. In essence, it would insert a new section 1A into the clause relating to a reviewable decision and the eligible persons. The new section 1A would list the owner or occupier of a property adjoining the location of the release. So amendment No. 101 also has the effect of giving that person standing in relation to being able to review a decision of the Gene Technology Regulator.

As I have explained in the example that I have used of the powerline, where we have the intentional release of a genetically modified organism into the environment, it is very clear that because of pollen drift, as has been scientifically proven in America with the genetically modified corn contaminating other adjacent fields, a 15-metre exclusion zone around broadacre cropping would be totally inadequate. It is commonly accepted that bees can travel anywhere between five and eight kilometres in a direct line when accessing water. There is an ability for that genetically modified organism to cross the boundaries of properties, as I have described in this amendment. These amendments bring in a definition of `adjoining property' and the boundaries for owners or occupiers are well within what I believe should be set in the bill. To recap, the purpose of amendment No. 33 is to bring in a new definition of the rights of an adjoining property owner and the purpose of amendment No. 101 is to give the owner or occupier of that property adjoining the location of the release in relation to a review of a decision of the regulator. I commend the amendments to the chamber.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government is opposed to these amendments. The amendments proposed by Senator Harris require the regulator to notify each and every occupier of land adjoining the location of proposed GMO crops about applications received by the regulator. These amendments are not supported by the government. For every application that involves an intentional release of a GMO into the environment, the regulator will directly contact anyone who has asked to be supplied with this information. In addition, the regulator will notify receipt on the regulator's web site and in newspapers. I am advised that currently, when an application for general release is notified, it is done through about 40 newspapers, including local country newspapers and publications like The Land. It is simply not practical to do more than personally notify anyone who has indicated interest in receiving information, and to advertise in newspapers throughout Australia. It is not practical to contact individuals who have not supplied their name and address to the regulator and asked to receive the information. The government does not, therefore, support these amendments.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —For the very reasons that the government have outlined that they do not support the amendments, the Democrats do support the amendments. We think that people, especially those in adjoining areas, have the right to have as much information as possible. I know the government's counterargument to that is, `Well, they can write in and apply for it.' I do not think that Australians should have to rely on the extrasensory perception—the ESP—provisions of the bill and contact the government for more information. I think they should be informed in one fell swoop at the outset of the process.

speech.para: I am not sure of the Labor opposition position on these amendments, but I am sure that Australians will once again see this as another lost opportunity to actually ensure that there is adequate public awareness, information and education and, thus, increased public faith in not only the technology but also the regulatory process. I might add that I was not kidding before when I was talking about the swelling ranks of Democrat support, because I notice that it has just come through on the news that our support is higher than it has been in a year. That has just popped up. So clearly we are having an instantaneous effect on our polling, as a consequence of this debate. I say that facetiously, but I do anticipate that Australians will be somewhat dejected by the opposition to these amendments. The Democrats will be supporting the amendments being moved by Senator Harris. I put on record my disappointment at the way that the media, certainly on the wire, is reporting this debate as being that somehow the government and the opposition are being hijacked or ambushed into debating the legislation and how we are `dragging on' the debate, when basically this is an enormous bill that has a lot of amendments and is quite complex. I do not think that it should be dissed in that way.

talk.start.para: —I do not accept Senator Tambling's reasoning about notifying what could be approximately four, maybe six or even seven property owners who are adjoining a property about which the regulator—the government's own department—is making a decision to release a genetically modified organism into the environment. The government is telling us that it is an impost on that person for them to find out who the property owners are adjoining that property and to notify them. That is absolutely and totally unacceptable. I will refer to one piece of correspondence—one of many hundreds—that I have received in relation to the bill. The particular correspondent speaks about the appeal rights of people:

quote.para: The rights of appeal for decisions made under the GT bill are currently limited to the applicants for a licence for GMO dealings. Important public duties should be enforced on any member of the public, allowing courts and the AAT to scrutinise the substantial merits of each case.

speech.para: This correspondence asks that the public have the right of appeal. However, Pauline Hanson's One Nation amendment limits that to the adjoining property owners. The correspondence goes on to state:

quote.para: Furthermore, limitations on the rights to injunct relief in the draft bill are not in accordance with the Commonwealth's best practice legislation.

speech.para: These people are saying that the public in general should have the right of appeal. The government is saying that its position is such that not even the adjoining property owners should have the right to be notified.

As I indicated in amendment No. 101, that would give adjacent property owners or occupiers—because primarily these intentional releases will happen in rural areas and rural properties may not necessarily have the owner in occupation; a lessee could be leasing the property or renting accommodation on rural properties—the right not only to be notified of the intentional release of a GMO but also to have standing to seek a review of the decision of the regulator under section 179. I believe that that is not an impost on the government; it is a necessary requirement for the government to fulfil its duty of care to those people.
Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Greens' amendments Nos 63, 64 and 74:

quote.para: (63) Clause 56, page 39 (lines 12 to 17), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) The Regulator must not issue a licence unless the Regulator is satisfied that any risks posed by the dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence to:
(a) the health and safety of people; and
(b) the environment;

speech.para: are negligible.

quote.para: (64) Clause 56, page 39 (lines 20 to 23), omit paragraphs (2)(a) and (b), substitute:
(a) the precautionary principle;
(b) the risk assessment and risk management plan prepared under section 47 or 50, as the case may be;
(74) Clause 71, page 48 (lines 4 to 9), omit subclause (4), substitute:
(4) The Regulator must not vary the licence unless the Regulator is satisfied that any risks posed by the dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence as varied to:
(a) the health and safety of people; and
(b) the environment;

speech.para: are negligible.

These amendments will be supported by the government, the reason being that the first amendment says that the regulator must not issue a licence for the release of a genetically modified organism unless the regulator is satisfied that any risks posed by the dealings proposed to be authorised by that licence to the health and safety of people and to the environment are negligible.
