If the government does not support that, I would like to know the level of risk to the health and safety of Australians and their environment the government is prepared to allow through the release of GMOs. The second amendment says that you must take into account the precautionary principle and the risk assessment and risk management plan prepared under sections 47 or 50, as the case may be.

The final amendment, amendment No. 74, states that the regulator must not vary the licence unless satisfied that any risks posed by the dealings proposed to be authorised by the licence, as varied, to the health and safety of people and the environment are negligible. We have here a whole industry which says that the risks are negligible, so we should put that into the law and simply say, `Let's take them at their word and let's ensure that the regulator is satisfied that that is the risk level to the public, to the public health and to the environment. If you can't show that it's negligible, don't proceed.'

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government, to the surprise of Senator Brown, will be opposing these amendments! The amendments propose changes to the matters that the regulator must take into account as part of his or her decision making. The government does not support the amendments. The bill contains detailed information about the matters that the regulator must take into account, and this information is supported by further information in the draft regulations.

speech.para: Further, as a result of other amendments that will be considered shortly, clause 4 will again be referenced by this committee. We agreed to that on Thursday or Friday. There are amendments there with reference to the precautionary principle. So this is caught up in that debate, and I believe that the matters raised by Senator Brown will be addressed very satisfactorily in those amendments. We will be returning to them at a later hour. As such, it is not necessary that it also be included in this clause.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I will be brief. I am not sure that there is a later hour; it is getting pretty late. I am wondering if it is appropriate now to begin the debate about the objects of the act. The argument that this will be dealt with or is better dealt with in a regulations format is an argument that the Democrats do not subscribe to and is one we are a little sick of hearing, because I do not think that is a justification for half the failures of the government to actually endorse some of the amendments that have been before the government.

speech.para: These amendments are good amendments. They even endorse the objects of the bill in its current form—that is, without any amendment in the form to which Senator Tambling referred or even in the much stronger form of words in relation to the precautionary principle and the objects of the act that Senators Harris and Brown and I are moving so that the risks to the health and safety of people and to the environment are negligible. I cannot see how these are scary amendments for the government. I have the Macquarie Dictionary in front of me. It defines `negligible' as `that may be neglected or disregarded; very little'. So even within that meaning there is actually scope for risk.

I do not think these are overtly prescriptive amend-ments. Even if they were, what is wrong with that? I think anything that guards people's health and safety in this context is more than appropriate. The Democrats will be supporting these amendments. We are sorry that the government is not. I wonder what the opposition is doing on these, because I cannot see how they necessarily contravene the objects of the act as proposed by the opposition. They do mention health, which is, of course, different from the precautionary principle amendment moved by the opposition, but I do not see that these are particularly terrifying amendments, and I think in many respects they encapsulate the most important aspects of this debate. I do again ask Senator Tambling when we will begin discussion on the objects. I think we have really gone about the discussion of this bill the wrong way, and I would like us to have that debate sooner rather than later.

talk.start.para: —For the benefit of Senator Stott Despoja, we will not be supporting the amendments.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move amendment No. 35 circulated in the name of Pauline Hanson's One Nation:

quote.para: (35) Clause 60, page 41 (lines 28 to 31), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) A licence continues in force:
(a) for a period of 3 years from the date of issue; or
(b) until it is cancelled or surrendered;

speech.para: whichever is the sooner.

The purpose of the amendment is to change the bill in such a way that a licence does not continue ad nauseam once it is issued. It will ensure that the regulator will, from time to time, reassess the direction in which a licence that has been granted is actually progressing. Rather than licences carrying on in perpetuity once issued, this amendment will require the regulator to reissue and, in reissuing, to reassess the progress of that licence. Another effect of the amendment is that, if there are licences out there that are applied for and are not taken up and exercised, they will automatically drop off after a three-year period and cease to have effect. So we will not have the situation where a licence is applied for in the immediate future and then that licence is picked up and optioned many years down the track as a right.

As I have said, the purpose of the amendment is to require the regulator to regularly reassess the situation relating to an issued licence three years from the date of issue. That will be caused by the applicant having to reapply. If an application is received for a licence and those GMO dealings are not carried out in that period of time, the licence will not be sitting there able to be picked up and used at any time in the future purely because the company has gone through the process of applying for a licence five or 10 years prior to them commencing operations.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will support the amendment, whether it is One Nation's or the Greens'. I am not sure if Senator Harris made a Freudian slip when he said `ad nauseam'. That is what we are really hoping to avoid in this particular piece of legislation. The Democrats certainly can see that the arguments are valid, and we will support the amendment.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The government will oppose the amendment proposed by Pauline Hanson's One Nation. We do not think that this amendment achieves the results that Senator Harris desires. The amendment provides that a licence continue in force for three years unless it is cancelled or surrendered at an earlier time. This amendment is not supported as it sets a mandatory period for licensing of three years. It is intended that the Gene Technology Regulator may issue licences for periods considerably less than three years; it would be extremely undesirable if the legislation provided that all licences continued for three years. For example, in relation to many field trials, the GTR may issue a licence for only one planting season. The GTR needs the flexibility to apply whatever licence terms are appropriate given the individual circumstances.

speech.para: Senator Harris can be assured that, no matter what the term of the licence is, the GTR will review all licences on a regular basis. For example, as a minimum requirement, all licence holders will be required to report annually on the licensed dealings with the GMO. This, in addition to the ability of the GTR to undertake auditing and monitoring on a regular basis, ensures that there is ongoing review of licensed dealings to ensure appropriate compliance with any licence conditions and appropriate protection of human safety and the environment. If the GTR has any concerns at all, the GTR may vary, suspend or cancel a licence at any time.

talk.start.para: —Is it possible, under the government's proposal, for a licence to be issued and for a licence to continue in perpetuity?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the answer to the senator's question is no, they are reviewed continuously.

—Again, Senator Tambling is saying they are `reviewed'. Reviewing a licence does not terminate the legal effectiveness of that licence. My question to Senator Tambling is: once granted, and if reviewed and not revoked, can a licence continue in perpetuity?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the licence can be reviewed or revoked at any time, and that will provide the sufficient sanctions that Senator Harris is looking for.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I draw attention to the fact that we are now over three hours past the time at which this Senate should have adjourned. That is not fair on members of the Senate, but more particularly it is not fair on the staff who have to keep this place going. It is not fair on the advisers of the government, who are public servants; and I believe that it is unnecessary. The legislation is being dealt with, I would have thought, quite reasonably. In order to register the fact that it is not fair, I draw your attention to the state of the house. (Quorum formed) I seek leave to move amendments Nos 2 and 3 together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: (2) Clause 61, page 42 (line 5), after "sections", insert "62A,".
(3) Page 43 (after line 9), after clause 62, insert:
It is a condition of a licence that the licence holder does not engage in human embryo cloning.

speech.para: May I make it perfectly clear to everybody in the chamber that this bill and its regulations as they now stand do not prohibit the reproduction of embryonic human beings by cloning. Let that sink into the minds of everyone in this chamber. Do you think that this is a proper state of affairs? If you do not think that it is a proper state of affairs, you will vote for my amendments or similar amendments. My amendments actually seek to tighten up the regulations in the area of human cloning. The amendments would make it a statutory condition of licences issued under section 40 that licence holders not produce or attempt to produce an organism with the capacity for human development of a human zygote or embryo other than by the union of a genetically unmodified ovum by a genetically unmodified human sperm. The amendments also place similar restrictions on the certification of facilities under section 83 and for the accreditation of organisations under section 91. Without these amendments, the definition of a genetically modified organism, despite the exclusions in the bill and the regulations, would include an organism which is the product of a somatic cell nuclear transfer to a human ovum or to a human embryo and an organism formed by manipulating stem cells harvested from a human embryo.

Section 10 of the bill defines a genetically modified organism as `an organism that has been modified by gene technology'. This would include an embryo formed by the transfer of a somatic cell nucleus to an ovum or to an embryo. In that process the ovum is modified by genetic technology to form an entity capable of development as an embryo. In the case of Dolly the sheep, that embryo developed to adulthood. There is an exclusion at (d) of section 10 of the bill which excludes those human beings who have undergone somatic cell gene therapy. What happens in cloning does not fit this description because, at the time that the transfer takes place, what is in existence is an unfertilised ovum, and of course an unfertilised ovum is not a human being. Further, the embryo formed has yet to develop somatic cells. What occurs is actually germ cell gene therapy, not somatic cell gene therapy. What is produced, however, by the transfer of a somatic cell nucleus to the unfertilised ovum is an embryonic human being. There are some further exclusions to this section in the draft regulations that are No. 6 on page 3, but none of these would apply to a human embryo resulting from a somatic cell nuclear transfer.

I have been concerned all along that the amendments not interfere with what the Australian Health Ethics Committee, AHEC, of the National Health and Medical Research Council—which hereinafter I will call NHMRC—describes as `current cloning techniques that do not involve human embryos'. The amendments would permit cloning research involving human somatic cells—that is, ordinary cells—as distinct from human germ cells, sperm and other, and, of course, as distinct from embryos. These amendments would enable this bill to meet the standards of the Universal Declaration on the Human Genome and Human Rights which assert that reproductive cloning of human beings shall not be permitted. They are also in line with the recommendations of the NHMRC that the Commonwealth government affirm that ban and that the states and territories that have not legislated to do so should do so. Your support of these amendments would ensure that the monitoring and regulation of cloning human cells and tissues would remain under the authority of the Gene Technology Regulator, as is already provided by the bill, but the cloning of a human being would be effectively banned and the ban implemented by the Gene Technology Regulator through the licensing, certification and accreditation system. I think that is a much better path, to be quite frank, than the criminal sanctions route and all that is involved in that.

We have been advised by the senior medical research body in the land that there should be legislation to prohibit cloning involving human embryos, and these amendments will achieve that objective but will not hinder research involving gene therapy, the development of the use of stem cells obtained from somatic cells and existing practices in relation to cloning human DNA and ordinary human cells. This approach to human cloning is consistent with that adopted by the Council of Europe and the parliaments of Canada, Germany, Norway, Slovakia, Sweden, Switzerland, Spain and Denmark and the intention of at least some states in this nation, although there is some doubt about the meaning of the definitions and I will come to that later. Incidentally, Japan passed and enacted in the House of Councillors on 30 November a measure that would make human cloning a crime carrying a punishment of up to 10 years in prison. A Reuters business briefing of 4 December reads:

quote.para: Specifically the new law's prohibition concerns embryos created by implanting a somatic cell into an unfertilised egg deprived of a nucleus.

speech.para: That is precisely what I have been saying here. It also pertains to hybrid embryos generated by matching a human egg with animal sperm and chimera embryos created by mixing human and animal cells.

So, here we are: unless we do something like that, even Japan will be in front of us. I have not, to be quite frank, had a thorough look at the legislation that they have. This is a much more effective way of implementing a ban on cloning than the use of the criminal law which is the model employed by the states that now have legislation. I also see it as preferable that a matter of principle and of international law be decided directly by the parliament and the legislation itself rather than be handled in the regulations. I believe that this proposal deserves the support of the chamber. I am happy to respond and to answer any questions that may arise in the minds of honourable senators insofar as I can at this hour of the morning.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the government is opposed to Senator Harradine's amendments. The government does not support the amendments specifically to clause 61 and after clause 62 on the conditions of licences. I know that this is an important issue. That was very obvious in the debate last week. At that stage I did foreshadow an amendment which I am not going to proceed with, but I should indicate that today I have distributed other foreshadowed amendments to insert new clauses 192B, 192C and 192D. I invite senators to be mindful of those proposed amendments which I will move after we have dealt with this particular debate.

speech.para: Senator Harradine defines `human embryo cloning' as `any dealing that involves the production, or attempted production, of a human organism with the capacity to undergo development similar to a human zygote or a human embryo, other than by the union of a genetically unmodified human ovum with genetically unmodified human sperm'. The government's legal and scientific advice is that this goes well beyond what is commonly understood to be human cloning—that is, cloning for the replication of human individuals or creating a human being with the identical genetic make-up of another human being. Senator Harradine's definition could capture medical research such as stem cell research since this produces human tissue which technically could develop into a human zygote or embryo. This type of research, often referred to as therapeutic cloning, refers to the cloning of cells and tissues to replace tissues damaged or destroyed by injury or disease.

The intent of therapeutic cloning is not to produce viable embryos or whole humans but tissues and organs. Therapeutic cloning offers huge benefits for human health and society. However, these techniques do not enable anyone to produce another human being. Research of this nature may result in the development of cells and tissues which might alleviate the suffering of thousands of Australians who are waiting for donor organs and tissue to become available. On average, every week two people die waiting for an organ or tissue transplant. Fifty-five per cent of those awaiting organ or tissue transplantation will die before a suitable donor can be found. Therapeutic cloning offers, although many years away, the potential to replace dysfunctional organs with tissues prepared using the patient's own cells.

Currently, medical scientists are able to culture human skin cells to replace skin destroyed by major burns. This is greatly increasing the life expectancy and decreasing the recovery time for third-degree burn victims in this country. Scientists are investigating the use of stem cells for the treatment of diseases such as Parkinson's disease, which afflicts so many older and some younger Australians. Cloning technology can be used therapeutically to create differentiated tissue which can then be used to seed organ regeneration. For example, precursor kidney cells might be wrapped in an artificial membrane and nurtured to become a precursor kidney.

The purpose of stem cell research is not to create spare parts in a cupboard for future use. Under no circumstances should we allow the cloning of a whole human being to occur. However, the use of cloning technology to create differentiated tissue is an example of how recent developments in scientific knowledge can be harnessed to ease the suffering and enhance the lives of thousands of Australians. So I would urge the Senate not to accept the amendments currently proposed by Senator Harradine and to give consideration at a later time to the amendments that I have proposed and foreshadowed as a method of ensuring that in this legislation the issues that are raised are appropriately addressed.

talk.start.para: —I think I should respond to the parliamentary secretary because he has painted a scenario which is neither intended by my amendments nor would be their effect. Let me explain it to the committee. If that is the line that the government is taking, it is an extraordinarily shallow line. The bill affects those individuals, institutions and corporations that are conducting genetic modification by requiring them to be licensed—this is what the bill does. My amendments prevent licensees from creating a human organism that has the capacity of a human embryo or zygote for development. If the parliamentary secretary has got some problem with the definition, there are other definitions which might well be useful—that is to say, the development of a human organism which is oriented to adulthood. But we can come to that later.

speech.para: The amendments do not prevent the use of somatic stem cells as they are only pluripotent. They can be used to develop other cell types, but they are not capable of developing as a human embryo to form a foetus and go on to adulthood. Let us get that very clear. I ask the parliamentary secretary to get up after I have finished to say that it is capable and to deny what I am saying. Am I saying something that is correct or not? Let me repeat: the amendments do not prevent the use of somatic stem cells as they are pluripotent only: they can be used to develop other cell types but are not capable of developing as a human embryo to form a foetus and go on to adulthood.

For a somatic cell to gain the capacity for embryo genesis it must be fused with an enucleated ovum or embryo. In other words, the amendments have no effect on culturing somatic cells unless the latter involves somatic cell nuclear transfer. In respect of the matters that the parliamentary secretary was talking about—the potential for using the patient's own cells—I presume he means the patient's somatic cells. If that is the case, what he says falls to the ground. My amendments do not do anything of the kind. However, the amendments would prevent licensees from forming human embryos by modifying the nucleus of an ovum or an embryo: that is, they would prevent them forming embryos for the purpose of research or experimentation by cloning somatic cell nuclear transfer.

But this is a good effect which will in fact direct scientists away from the problematic areas of cloning embryonic human beings and focus their attention on an area which is the likely end point in this work in any case, because obtaining the embryonic stem cells for transplant would necessitate the special creation of embryos that are histocompatible to the patient recipient in each case. This is not a matter of using leftover or discarded embryos in IVF programs. The research that would be prevented is that research that would involve forming embryos by cloning and then destroying them to harvest the embryonic stem cells. Thus the amendments would not prevent the development of stem cell transplant treatment for Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's, diabetes, leukemia and so on. Those treatments are likely to be based on a patient's own somatic cells—as the parliamentary secretary said or inferred—rather than on stem cells from cloned embryos in any case.

It should also be added that the timing of the development of successful treatments using stem cell transplantation is likely to be a long way off, as the parliamentary secretary noted. There are safety problems to be investigated first to ensure that transplanted stem cells form the right kinds of cells and the cells form the appropriate tissue structure. As has been indicated, at the moment the state of the technology is a bit like seeking to repair rusted girders on the Eiffel Tower or Sydney Harbour Bridge by standing at a distance and hurling new girders at the bridge in the hope they will fall into the right place and form the right structure.

There is much to be done, too, in relation to gene therapies. At the moment we have mapped the human genome, but the generally accepted expectation is that it will be at least two years before we have mapped each gene and at least 10 years before we have mapped each gene function. Successful gene therapies will not be developed until some time after that. Possibly it will be several decades away before they are safely available—certainly long after those in this chamber, even the youngest ones, have departed the scene. I will leave it at that. I can elaborate on that matter after I hear other contributions.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I might make a brief contribution at this stage. Senator Harradine is right to draw our attention to some of the extraordinary developments in modern science and biotechnology in particular, and again to direct our attention to some of the implications as a consequence of these advances. I am very happy to be finally having a debate in the chamber on issues such as cloning, specifically human reproductive cloning. I have to acknowledge my disappointment that it is 1.25 in the morning. This is a piece of legislation that, while it deals with some of the issues, causes me to maintain on behalf of the Democrats a concern that I thought was shared certainly by the government that I am not sure if this is identifiably the right place in which to be having this debate. Nonetheless, I do acknowledge that there is a relation between gene technology developments in a general sense and some of these important and pressing ethical and social issues.

speech.para: In the brief debates we have had on this issue I have said that the Democrats' position—or certainly my personal position—mirrors that of the Australian Academy of Science, which made public its position on scientific, ethical and regulatory aspects of human cloning to the House of Representatives committee. It was the brief of the committee to investigate those very aspects. The first of the academy's four pronouncements state:

quote.para: The Academy considers that reproductive cloning to produce human foetuses is unethical and unsafe and should be prohibited. However, human cells, whether derived from cloning techniques, from embryonic stem cell lines, or from primordial germ cells should not be precluded from use in approved research activities in cellular and developmental biology.

speech.para: The second point states:

quote.para: The Academy strongly supports the recommendation of the Australian Health Ethics Committee that the Minister for Health and Aged Care should encourage and promote informed community discussion on the potential therapeutic benefits and possible risks of the development of cloning techniques.

speech.para: That is certainly an objective to which I strongly adhere. That is why I have always argued that there is a role for the parliament in conducting these debates, not only reflecting the views of the community but obviously providing some sense of vision. The argument that science and technology versus the law are—sorry, through you, Chair, I acknowledge that Senator Forshaw wants me to wrap up: is that correct?

talk.start.para: —No. Not at all.
—I am quite happy to wrap up on this in this debate because I can see that probably these amendments will get the scant attention that most of the other—
—I don't know how you assume that.
—Perhaps the Chair was focusing on the general debate, but I am sorry, I think we are all getting—
—I was focusing on who would get the call next.
(Senator Calvert)—That is exactly what was happening.
—Okay; I apologise to the chamber. He was focusing on who gets called next. The third point in the academy's position paper states:

quote.para: If Australia is to capitalise on its undoubted strength in medical research, it is important that research on human therapeutic cloning is not inhibited by withholding federal research funds or prevented by unduly restrictive legislation in some States.

speech.para: I acknowledge Senator Harradine's point that he believes that the intent of his amendments and the actual implications or effect of his amendments would not do that. I am looking for further assurances to that end, obviously from the government as well. I guess that is why my concern arises in the context of a debate on gene technology specifically in relation to GMOs, that in some respects we have not had the necessary time—and for the record I point out that Senator Harradine had his amendments available before anyone else in this debate. So we have certainly had time to analyse and scrutinise those amendments, but I would much prefer we were dealing with a piece of legislation that generally dealt with the issue of human reproductive cloning. The fourth point of the submission provided by the academy states:

quote.para: It is essential to maintain peer review and public scrutiny of all research involving human embryos and human embryonic stem cell lines undertaken in Australia. The Academy supports the view that a national regulatory two-tier approval process be adopted. Approval to undertake any research involving human embryos and human embryonic stem cell lines would need to be obtained from a duly-constituted institutional ethics committee (IEC) prior to assessment by a national panel of experts, established by the National Health and Medical Research Council, of the scientific merits, safety issues and ethical acceptability of the work.

speech.para: I suspect we could all debate until the cows come home, or at least until they are genetically modified, whether a two-tier approval process is the best way to go and what criteria should be satisfied. But, in line with that academy submission, I feel that that should be the position of the parliament, and certainly that is my personal view. I offered some concerns, suggestions or a critique of the amendments before us last week, and I acknowledge for the record that I quoted Professor Bob Williamson from the Murdoch Children's Research Institute in relation to this debate who insists, and quite rightly so, that he be recorded as someone who is opposed to reproductive cloning. In his comments he said:

quote.para: The appropriate act, in my view, should ban the implantation of any group of cells with the potential to undergo development as an embryo into the uterus of a woman or any equivalent use with the intention to allow development into a living foetus and live-born individual.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: I would have no problem with such an act. However, this proposal is hasty and the definition could cause difficulty two or three years hence without identifying the key step in human cloning which is associated with implantation and development rather than potential.

speech.para: I am sure Senator Harradine has a response to those criticisms, but I throw them in as highlighting one of the issues in this debate, that is, that the amendments relate very clearly to the capacity to undergo development.

There are problems that have arisen, primarily in Victoria—and indeed in other jurisdictions, and we talked about some of those jurisdictions last week: Western Australia and South Australia—because a hasty definition of an embryo was employed at the time. The definitions used in those acts were developed at a time of quite substantial scientific change. I think some scientists would argue—perhaps even some ethicists, and I am not suggesting that the two are mutually exclusive—that those definitions have proved problematic. Perhaps that is one of the reasons that Minister Wooldridge has referred this to the Australian Health Ethics Committee for review. I know at least one of Senator Harradine's criticisms is in relation to not so much the review process per se but is a criticism which I share that it is taking a long time. There have been a number of announcements and pronouncements that have emanated from government, yet we have not actually seen a legislative response. We have a legislative response coming before the parliament today from the government. Indeed, we had a response designed for this debate on Friday, which I understand has now been withdrawn, but again this is not how legislation in relation to the human reproductive cloning issue should be coming about. I think we should be debating an act that deals with some of these specific scientific and ethical issues. It should be coming about as a consequence of not only the government's review through the House of Representatives committee inquiry process but also public consultation, debate and discussion. That is one thing I can say about the bill before us today: that is, while I might disagree vehemently with some of the stances taken by the government and the opposition, this is a debate that has been out there. It has been out there in the form of draft regulations discussion, draft legislative discussion, updates, rewrites and, of course, a Senate committee process. I do not think we can afford to underestimate the importance of that. Even if we have got to a position today in the chamber where I feel that it has been left to the crossbenches to move many of the amendments that actually reflect the views of the community, I do not think the community has had the same opportunity for adequate consultation and discussion in relation to some of the issues with which we are grappling today.

I know that in the context of the debate on Friday various people, including me, talked about whether or not this is too hard or too complex. I am not trying to dodge this debate. As I said on Friday, I have been waiting for this debate for a long time. Indeed, this gives me some hope that maybe we will progress to some of the other ethical, social and environmental implications associated with this rapidly advancing science, including a bill that hopefully outlaws the patenting of genes and gene sequences and a bill that protects people's genetic privacy and ensures that that information cannot be used against them. But I do not raise those matters in a legislative or an amended form in the context of this debate. Through you, Chair, to Senator Harradine, I know that may seem like a cop-out to you, Senator. You are one person with whom I have been able to discuss many of these issues, because you have maintained a similar interest for sometimes similar and sometimes different reasons. I commend the fact that you keep on with this issue of genetics, but I do not feel that I am in a position today on behalf of my party to support the amendments before us.

I say that also in the context of the amendments put forward by the government. Last week my understanding was that the government had a concern about this debate and whether it was relevant to this bill, yet now the government is putting forward amendments. That may be specifically in response to the concerns outlined by Senator Harradine, but I do not think that it is necessarily an appropriate legislative response. What I want to see is a bill from this government that takes into account all those issues that people have referred to, all those issues that have been canvassed in the House of Representatives committee review and all those issues that should be canvassed more broadly with the community so that we avoid hasty definitions, such as those we have seen in previous legislation that may seek to outlaw human reproductive cloning, and so that we avoid finding ourselves dealing with conflicting pieces of legislation at the federal level when we finally get around to this issue. That is the position of the Democrats. That is not to say that there is not value in the amendments before us for the purposes of discussion, but I would like to see this debate returned to the Gene Technology Bill 2000, and I would like to see legislation put forward by the government in the immediate future to safeguard against human reproductive cloning, which I think everybody in this chamber is opposed to. I think you would be hard-pressed to find anyone who actually supports the notion of human reproductive cloning.

talk.start.para: —What is the government's schedule for addressing this matter through discrete legislation?
—We are just going to proceed.
—What I meant was: when is the government bringing forward legislation that will deal with the matters that Senator Stott Despoja has just been talking about?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —In answer to Senator Brown's specific question, I do have other comments but I think other senators want to participate in the debate. With regard to that very specific question, I indicated in the debate last Friday that this matter is before the NHMRC, the various ethics committees and the AHMC, the Australian Health Ministers Council. Therefore, it is caught up in a process. I am not in a position to prejudge when the AHMC would be able to give consideration to it, but I am informed that it is proposed that there would be some form of reporting by about March 2001.

—At the outset and for the benefit of Senator Stott Despoja, I should explain what was happening during her speech. The then chair, Senator Calvert, was asking through gestures whether I would be seeking the call next. I indicated to him with a hand motion that I would be happy if others wanted to speak next. Let me make a couple of comments. I put the position of the opposition on this matter last Friday. The comments I made then, though not as wide in terms of canvassing the issues that have been put by Senator Stott Despoja, essentially went to the same issues. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care reiterated those arguments for the government in his comments earlier.

speech.para: The object of the Gene Technology Bill 2000 is clearly focused on protecting the health of humans and the environment. The bill has not been drafted, nor was it intended, to deal with the complex ethical issues that have been raised in Senator Harradine's amendments. As we pointed out—and it has just been stated only a moment ago—those ethical issues, particularly in regard to the issue of human cloning, are currently within the canvass of the NHMRC. Further, as we understand it, the NHMRC is meeting with state health ministers on 15 December—and maybe the government can confirm that for us—to progress further the July announcement made by Commonwealth and state health ministers. That announcement, of course, was that they would work towards developing nationally consistent legislation to ban the cloning of whole human beings.

We have also been advised that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is currently considering these issues in its inquiry and that will include, of course, consideration of cloning, including human embryo cloning. Further, we understand that it will report in or about May next year. Each of those processes is, I would suggest, not dissimilar to the process that has gone on with respect to the development of this legislation. The Gene Technology Bill 2000 has been some time in the making. It follows a very detailed inquiry and a detailed report by the Senate community affairs committee. Also, it follows a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Primary Industries and Regional Services, which related specifically to primary producer access to gene technology.

I understand that there has been other work done by parliamentary committees in the past, in one way or another, looking at issues of gene technology. There has also been a very extensive process going on over quite some time involving the Commonwealth and each of the states to reach agreement on this nationally consistent scheme for regulating gene technology. That has been a very extensive process and, of course, as Senator Stott Despoja quite rightly pointed out, it has also been a matter that has been widely canvassed, debated and commented upon, and reported in the media and in other forums, both within Australia and internationally.

So the background and the lead-up to this legislation being debated here tonight have been a quite extensive investigation in a number of different forms leading finally to this bill. We also recognise that—as I think the debate has demonstrated—as there are quite a range of issues that are clearly within the compass of this bill and clearly contemplated as being regulated by this bill, or related to the bill, some senators feel that it should have been dealt with differently. Hence, we have this large number of amendments. But each of those issues that has been brought forward by the Greens, Senator Harris, the Democrats and, indeed, the opposition are issues that are clearly within the scope of the bill and the objects and intention of what the legislation is to cover.

Our position remains as it was when I addressed it on Friday. I might indicate that we have had the advantage of being provided with the government's amendment that has been circulated. We will express our view on that when the debate comes on in due course, but I can say at this stage that we are disposed to support that amendment. In conclusion, as Senator Stott Despoja said again—I listened intently to her remarks, and I think she made a very constructive contribution—no-one in this chamber would be in favour of supporting human cloning and the sorts of issues that Senator Harradine has raised. They are more appropriately dealt with in specific legislation, which we hope and we certainly believe will be forthcoming.

talk.start.para: —I would like to raise the issue of how realistic this debate is and how the committee envisages the progress of this bill. In speaking briefly, I support Senator Harradine's amendments, but I think it is time that we had a look at the running sheet that we are working from. Given that we have skipped over half of the front page, we are now exactly halfway on a nine-page running sheet. This debate started on Thursday evening, the bill was debated Friday and yesterday and we are now approximately four hours beyond the time when this chamber would normally rise. With such an important piece of legislation, I bring this to the committee's notice and ask: is it realistic to have this debate continue for the rest of the night and probably well into tomorrow morning in an attempt to address the rest of this bill?

speech.para: I do not believe personally that in another couple of hours I will be able to do justice to this legislation. I am asking for some comments from the remainder of the senators who are in the chamber, realising also that both government members and opposition members are making themselves available, although I comment that I believe it would be of more interest to the general public if those members were actually here in the chamber participating in this debate. In closing, I would like to place on record that I support Senator Harradine's amendments that will clarify the situation of human cloning, but I also bring to the chamber's attention the futility of what we are attempting to do—progressing this substantial legislation at 10 minutes to two in the morning—considering what we have in front of us.

talk.start.para: —I agree with that. I think Senator Harradine, whatever else, can take the credit for not only having legitimised this part of the debate but also getting the government to bring in some form of amendment addressing, however unsatisfactorily, the matters that he is concerned about. I have not been able to get any clear indication of when the government is going to bring in legislation that comprehensively deals with the matters of human cloning and experimentation. The secretary says that it is caught up in a process. I have heard the months of May and March next year as a reporting time, but that has not got anything in particular to do with us seeing legislation before the parliament and, with an election year next year, I predict that we are not going to see it then either.

speech.para: Under those circumstances, Senator Harradine, being opportunistic in bringing this matter up at this time with this piece of legislation, has acted entirely in a warranted fashion, as I see it. I find the subject very complex and very difficult. It is not just a matter of the scientific complexity; it is a matter of the ethical complexity that is involved. The question of the experimentation taking place in the creation of an embryo and how that differs from the experimentation which leads to the creation of a `whole human being', to use the government and opposition term, is one that has not been explored and one which is not going to be explored in this debate. I think that is one of the things that Senator Harradine would like to see explored because you then are left to fall back on the intention of the experimenter or the person who uses the outcome of the knowledge or the embryo arising from the experimentation. Senator Harradine said that his amendments are not going to prevent the therapeutic uses which I think generally have been agreed can come out of genetic experimentation which does not involve the creation of an embryo.

I am inclined to support Senator Harradine's amendments, however—whatever pitfalls there might be in them—as a means of then having a piece of legislation which we have to come back and revisit so as to correct those pitfalls where they stand. I think that the promise in Senator Harradine's amendments is that we are going to get some action, and I think the difficulty with not supporting them is that we are not going to get action. Senator Harradine was good enough to read out all the countries that have attempted to enact some form of regulation in this extraordinarily important matter, but Australia has not as yet. This is as close as we have come so far. I do note that Senator Stott Despoja has had legislation pending on the matter, but our problem is that as private members we do not get the opportunity to see that legislation debated or taken seriously. By grafting his amendments onto this bill, Senator Harradine has ensured that at least for a short while in the wee hours of this morning it is being taken seriously. I think the fact that the government has reacted has legitimised his action. A debate that says it really should be at some other time and in some other place falls apart on that sequence of events.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I am not sure whether Senator Brown's reference to grafting was an allusion to the genetic debate. Come on, folks: we need to get what laughs we can at this time of the night. That is the other thing I want to address. Could the government please respond to Senator Harris's comments regarding the late hours? It is five to two. This is not doing this bill justice. I only have to look at emails I am getting from members of the public who think it is outrageous as well. Could we have some idea from the government as to what the plan is? When Senator Harris said he does not feel he can do it justice, not necessarily at this hour but in the next couple of hours, I think that is exactly what is intended: that we do not do this bill justice. If that is the case, Senator Tambling, could you give some outline of what is happening, because we are only halfway through the bill. We are roughly halfway in terms of the running sheet and we still have not done a series of amendments at the beginning of the running sheet. Is it not more appropriate to defer this debate and, by doing so, hopefully give those members of the public some confidence in the legislative processes of this parliament? Little wonder we are held in such low esteem.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I draw your attention to the state of the committee, as the parliamentary secretary did not respond. (Quorum formed) The minister advanced reasons for opposing this legislation which have all fallen to the ground. All of them have fallen to the ground, unless he considers—and I would like to ask him this—that the embryonic stem cells, namely those stem cells that are taken from an embryo to the destruction of that embryo, are totipotent and have the capacity to undergo development similar to a human zygote or a human embryo.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Can I just comment that I was under the impression that Senator Harradine was seeking the call prior to the quorum that was just called, because there were several other occasions when other members had gone to stand and I had noticed Senator Harradine was about to jump. So I was deferring to him, and then, surprisingly, he called a quorum. That was the reason I had not jumped to my feet at that particular point in time. We are discussing Senator Harradine's amendments. It is appropriate that he should comment and respond to the comments made by other senators who want to debate the issues in that area. I was giving him that opportunity; Senator Harradine did not take it up, and he surprised me by calling for a quorum and therefore taking up time.

speech.para: Senators raised several issues in the preceding period that I should respond to. Senator Forshaw asked me some specific questions with regard to the issue of cloning. I indicated that last week in the debate I had quite comprehensively outlined the various actions being taken by appropriate bodies and various other agencies. I appreciate the seriousness of this particular debate. As Senator Stott Despoja has said, it is a debate whose time has certainly come in the community, but the debate is an arm's length away from the legislation that we are considering. Let me reiterate for Senator Forshaw a couple of the comments that I made in the debate last week, amongst many others. My understanding is that all Australian governments have agreed that the cloning of human beings is unacceptable and that it should be banned. Each state and territory has undertaken to achieve this within its own jurisdiction as this is a state and territory responsibility. It is intended that this issue will be covered by assisted reproductive technology legislation. The NHMRC has organised a roundtable meeting with representatives from each state to take place on 15 December. The objective of this meeting is to achieve agreement on legislative action that needs to be implemented in each jurisdiction and on a time frame for this action. While the undertakings by the Australian governments relate to the banning of cloning on human beings, broader issues relating to this topic have also been referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired by Mr Kevin Andrews. I made all of those points in the debate last Friday, and I think they contribute to it. There is, of course, a reporting process. Equally, the matter is under attention from the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council. We are certainly aware that this is an issue that has to be addressed.

Senator Stott Despoja asked my advice with regard to the timing of debate. The Senate has a very comprehensive and detailed program before it this week. It was originally intended that this legislation would, hopefully, have been concluded earlier this afternoon but, of course, that was not achievable. Certainly, as senators have indicated, there is considerably more work to do and, given the objective of all parties to rise in the Senate on Thursday evening, there is no alternative but for us to proceed this evening—or this morning, I should say—in order to progress this matter as far as we can, despite the obvious limitations on so many of us. The Senate could debate the technicalities of what is and what is not captured by Senator Harradine's amendments. On the basis of our scientific and legal advice, the government believes there is sufficient risk in Senator Harradine's proposed amendments for them to be opposed and that was the issue that I raised. The government has advice—contrary, obviously, to that of Senator Harradine—that Senator Harradine's amendments may prevent stem cell research. That advice is from Professor John Mattick of the University of Queensland.

The cloning of humans, which is very clearly not acceptable—and that has been very apparent both here and in other places—relates to activities leading to the creation of a viable human embryo with the same genetic identity as another human being. Therapeutic cloning relates to the use of stem cells to treat diseases and injuries. Stem cells exist in the adult but are usually tissue specific. For example, skin stem cells are used to grow new skin for burn patients. Scientists are searching for the pluripotent stem cells which are able to evolve into all tissue types. Fertilised human eggs are one source of what are known as pluripotent stem cells and these are the most useful cells and allow a wide range of research to be undertaken. Scientists have proposed using excess fertilised eggs for research into stem cells. There is much work to do in this area in relation to discovering how cell differentiation is switched on and off and methods for generation of whole organs in vitro. Senator Harradine's amendment would prevent this work continuing. These are important issues and, as other senators have said, this is a debate that we are seeking to attend to in so many other areas of government and in other jurisdictions. I believe that the amendment that I have foreshadowed will, with regard to this legislation, cover adequately the issues that have been raised and that are of concern at the current time. (Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —The parliamentary secretary has just committed this government to research which could only be undertaken when the embryo reaches the foetal stage. I think the whole chamber would be interested in what the minister said about the need for research to be undertaken to obtain whole organs. That is what he said: whole organs. The only way whole organs are able to be developed is by developing a human embryo to the foetal stage. Are you, Minister, committing the government to that? If you are, be honest. You have now changed your tune. When you were talking about stem cells before you actually stated—and I quote your words—`stem cells using the patient's own cells'. My amendments will not affect that at all. Now you are coming to a situation where you are suggesting that human embryos be cloned for the purpose of developing and culturing them to the stage where you have tissues and whole organs. My goodness! Is that consistent with the Australian Health Ethics Committee recommendations? I ask the parliamentary secretary: do not the Australian Health Ethics Committee recommendations oppose such research? I just ask you that question since it was you that raised the question about the Australian Health Ethics Committee and the National Health and Medical Research Council. I will leave it at that. I ask the minister to respond to my question: do the National Health and Medical Research Council's recommendations oppose that sort of research?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine has, I think, totally misquoted me. I would like him to restate the issues about which he is concerned. I have looked through my notes, and I cannot find the statements that he has attributed to me. Therefore I believe he has misquoted me totally, out of context, and is confusing the debate. In that sense, I would ask him to restate those issues of concern so I can check them against the notes that I used.

—Hansard will show the result of that. I understood that on advice you had stated that my amendment would prevent stem cell research. You used the words originally `stem cells using the patient's own cells'. Of course, I was able to say that my amendments will not prevent that at all, that my amendments are totally consistent with that of the NHMRC and the Australian Health Ethics Committee. I see one of your advisers shaking her head—
—She is talking to me.

—I see. Fine. What I heard the minister say came very clearly to me that it was the development of the scientific research which will produce and which will develop whole organs—as far as I know, those were the words that you used—for various diseases. As I mentioned, isn't it so that whole organs can only be able to be developed when the human embryo is developed to the foetal stage? I know, Parliamentary Secretary, you are in a difficult position—but, on advice from your advisers, you referred to research. Isn't that research opposed by the National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines and AHEC?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the guidelines of the NHMRC that Senator Harradine refers to control the in vitro fertilisation area and not the areas which we are currently addressing. In perusing my notes, the only issue that Senator Harradine might like me to repeat was my statement that the government has advice to the contrary, that Senator Harradine's amendment may prevent stem cell research, and that was from Professor John Mattick of the University of Queensland. I can see nothing else in my notes. The only issues I made with regard to organ and tissue transplant were in the argument where I was talking about the number of people who were waiting for organ or tissue transplant. That was certainly part of a more general argument. I cannot see the points that he has attributed to me whatsoever. We are debating Senator Harradine's amendment, and I think it is for him to prove if he wants to proceed any further on this issue.

—I have asked the parliamentary secretary a question about National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines, and I refer to the guidelines that have been recommended by the Australian Health Ethics Committee. Once the Australian Health Ethics Committee makes its decisions, are those decisions not binding on the National Health and Medical Research Council and on medical research involving Commonwealth funds? If I can go to those recommendations and pick them up, these are the Australian Health Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council scientific, ethical and regulatory considerations relevant to cloning of human beings. What does that say? Just as an example, recommendation No. 2 says:

quote.para: Noting that Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia have legislation regulating embryo research and prohibiting the cloning of human beings, the Minister for Health and Aged Care should urge the other States and Territories to introduce legislation to limit research on human embryos according to the principles set out in sections 6 and 11 of the NHMRC ethical guidelines on assisted reproductive technologies.

speech.para: This is a recommendation by the Australian Health Ethics Committee.

I will read out section 11 of the document referred to by the Australian Health Ethics Committee. I ask honourable senators to bear this in mind because it completely contradicts what the parliamentary secretary says. It reads:

quote.para: The following practices are ethically unacceptable and should be prohibited:
developing embryos for purposes other than for their use in an approved ART treatment program.

speech.para: The minister has just denied that. What he said is quite contrary to what the facts are. I know there is an attempt to overturn those things, but the parliamentary secretary and Senator Forshaw have talked about the matter being in the hands of the NHMRC, that the minister referred it. Yes, the minister has referred this matter to the Australian Health Ethics Committee, and the Australian Health Ethics Committee in December of 1998 came back with its recommendations, which included what I have just quoted. Might I say that the chairman of AHEC, Professor Don Chalmers, in his covering letter advised the minister as follows:

quote.para: In responding to your request, AHEC advises that a distinction must be drawn between the cloning of human beings, which is ethically unacceptable and legally prohibited in three states, and the cloning of such parts as DNA and cells. Cloning of DNA and cells is currently undertaken as part of routine laboratory research.

speech.para: I have mentioned that my amendments will not affect those whatsoever. Then he goes on to say this:

quote.para: This report recommends that you urge remaining States and Territories ... which have not legislated in this area to introduce legislation prohibiting the application of techniques to clone a new human individual. This legislation should not, however, interfere with those cloning techniques which do not involve human embryos. This legislation should be drafted in such a way as to be consistent with the National Health and Medical Research Council ethical guidelines on ART.

speech.para: This is quite contrary to what the parliamentary secretary has been telling us. And here we are at 20 past 2 and I see Senator Forshaw coming in and he seems to think the same thing. I hope Senator Forshaw heard what I just said, because it is quite a serious matter where you have got the parliamentary secretary saying something and you seem to be accepting it.

On the National Health and Medical Research Council you say, `Oh, it's in their hands.' Yes, and AHEC, its ethics committee, is very much opposed to destructive embryo experimentation. I think it is necessary, because it is very important, for me to draw the attention of the chamber to what I believe is an attempt to undermine the National Health and Medical Research Council and its Australian Health Ethics Committee and to do so by drawing those people together in order to achieve a national ban on the cloning of `whole human beings'. Those are crucial words. I ask the secretary again to advise the chamber as to what those words mean. Do they include cloning of human embryos? Do they? One of the real problems in respect of cloning of human embryos is that as distinct from those embryos in the IVF area—and I have some problems with that—who do have parents who, in some legislation, have certain responsibilities for them, cloned human embryos do not. The owner of them is the scientists and technologists. They can do what they like with them now. That is precisely why something has got to be done now.

I again ask the minister: does the government intend to legislate nationally? From what he has just been saying it does not appear so. It appears again to be a bit of a run round of the Australian health ministers conference to have a national ban on cloning of whole human beings. We do not know what `whole human beings' are. If it excludes human embryos then it is quite contrary to the Australian Health Ethics Committee's decision. It is a matter of very grave concern and I do feel that I should alert the chamber to the dangers. It is an extremely serious matter, concerning the briefing of heads of all state and territory departments of health in relation to a national ban on cloning of whole human beings. In a briefing note dated 1 November 2000, an officer of the National Health and Medical Research Council included background information to the decision by health ministers to ban the cloning of whole human beings. The background information includes a report of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, 1998, about its advice to the minister for health on human cloning. The officer of the NHMRC states:

quote.para: AHEC identified a distinction between cloning of whole human beings and therapeutic cloning.

speech.para: Therapeutic cloning is widely understood, since the publication of the Australian Academy of Science's position paper on human cloning, to include the cloning of human embryos for experimentation or therapy but not their development beyond eight weeks when they become foetuses. The reality is quite different. The reality is that the AHEC recommendations of 1998 did not identify in its report to the minister a distinction between reproductive and therapeutic cloning. I challenge the parliamentary secretary to deny that. Rather than endorse cloning human embryos for experimentation to develop therapies, AHEC recommended in recommendation 2 that there be legislation to regulate human embryo research according to sections 6 and 11 of the NHMRC guidelines for assisted reproductive technology and a ban on cloning of human beings. Section 11.1 of the guidelines declares that the following practice be prohibited:

quote.para: Developing embryos for purposes other than for their use in an approved ART treatment program.

speech.para: That is the program that attempts to circumvent infertility by achieving pregnancy. In effect, the NHMRC guidelines would limit embryo experimentation to spare embryos on IVF or embryo transfer programs. It should be noted that those guidelines were issued by AHEC. Under the NHMRC Act 1992, NHMRC is obliged to adopt guidelines for research issued by AHEC. By reporting AHEC support for producing human embryos for purposes other than ART in this way, the National Health and Medical Research Council not only is misrepresenting AHEC recommendations to the minister but also is in grave danger of being in breach of its own statute. It is a serious matter that the health ministers would appear to have been misled concerning the position of AHEC in relation to cloning. It also prompts questions about the origin of the phrase `whole human being' in government amendments to the Gene Technology Bill 2000 and the fact that the position that appears to have been adopted by the health ministers was based on misrepresentation of the position adopted by AHEC. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is very obvious that we have reached a section of the Gene Technology Bill 2000 that is of vital importance. It appears to be based around the differences between the government's position on what represents the cloning of a whole human being and Senator Harradine's definition that, if adopted as a definition for this bill, it should be very clearly set out that anything other than the union of genetically unmodified human ovum with genetically unmodified human sperm would be determined to be human embryo cloning. I do not believe that the answers we have received from Senator Tambling go any way to clarifying the difference between the government's position and that of Senator Harradine. It would appear, from listening to both sides of the debate, that Senator Harradine's definition would not eliminate the production of T-cells from a donor—in other words, for experimentation pertaining to that individual's own particular needs in relation to T-cells.

speech.para: It is very obvious that this debate is continually leading us to a situation where it is getting later and later and we still have not progressed from the position we were in more than half an hour ago when I raised the issue of being able to realistically complete this bill while the senators who are still in this chamber are able to stay on their feet. I still see that as a real problem. In the situation that we find ourselves in at this time in relation to this bill, it would appear that the difference is very clearly the difference in interpretation between the government and Senator Harradine on what is ultimately going to be defined in this bill as the human embryo cloning. (Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —It is clear that the parliamentary secretary on behalf of the government is not attempting at all to defend what apparently an officer of the NHMRC has been doing—in other words, misrepresenting the very body which, by its very statute, is required to observe the recommendations. That is a very serious matter. It is apposite to this debate because time and time again the minister has refused to tell this committee, either on Friday of last week or today, what is meant by the cloning of a `whole human being'. I again invite the parliamentary secretary to acknowledge that the NHMRC guidelines and the AHEC recommendations prohibit the type of experimentation that the parliamentary secretary was advised to bring up in this chamber in opposition to my amendments. I find that to be quite extraordinary.

speech.para: I will also refer to the comments made by Senator Stott Despoja, as I was invited to do so by the parliamentary secretary. She is not in the chamber at the moment, so I will wait to do that in her presence in a moment. Senator Stott Despoja has been here probably all night, except that she has just had to leave. I will refer to the comments of Senator Forshaw. Senator Forshaw, on behalf of the opposition, said something I really could not follow: that the matter is with the NHMRC and was reported to them by the minister. As I have said, that was a report. The minister referred the matter to the Australian Health Ethics Committee in 1998 and in December 1998 they reported to the minister. So let us get that clear. What I am doing is fully consistent with those recommendations by AHEC; that is what I am doing. It was also mentioned by Senator Forshaw that the House of Representatives committee will be possibly reporting on the matter of cloning by May next year. There is no guarantee. Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, as Senator Forshaw I think indicated, there is no guarantee that there will be any legislation. Maybe it was not you who said it.

talk.start.para: —It wasn't me.
—Sorry, I say it then. There is no guarantee, unless we get—
—You're starting to catch Senator Brown's disease.
—It may have been Senator Brown who said it; I do not know. Whoever said it or indeed thought it was—

—I see, did he? In any event, there is no guarantee that anything will happen there. For years now, the NHMRC and AHEC have been urging governments to adopt legislation to prevent the type of activity which my amendments would be preventing. But, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, if it is a problem for Senator Forshaw and his colleagues that perhaps we are pre-empting what they may do, why should we be leaving this matter year after year after year to be determined by the science technologists? Why should we?

speech.para: This is a hugely important matter. It poses grave problems for the whole of humankind, including the questions of genetic characteristics, future humans, the introduction of new organisms into the environment, genetic discrimination, the status of the disabled, et cetera. These are hugely important matters. Why should we leave them to the dictates of the science technologists? That is what we are doing. I do not accept that the Australian Academy of Science should have the last word on this. After all, they are scientists. A body has been established for the purpose of looking at these matters, and that is the Australian Health Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. As I have mentioned, that body has made its decision, and my amendments are thoroughly consistent with its recommendations.

The parliamentary secretary raised the question of stem cells and he talked about the use of somatic cells. My amendments do not touch that—not at all. So what is the objection to my amendments? Is it true that certain persons in the NHMRC want to, or one person in the NHMRC wants to—I am sure the government does not want to—redefine what AHEC has said? Can you tell us, Parliamentary Secretary, what is meant by the words that you used, `the cloning of a whole human being'? What is meant by a `whole human being'? The parliamentary secretary referred to cloning, meaning the creation of another individual with the same genetic make-up—in other words, identicality. I ask the parliamentary secretary again what he means by that. Can he name any authority which would suggest that cloning produces a genetically identical individual to the being that was cloned? Parliamentary Secretary, is that what you are saying? That is what I understood you to say in one of your comments in respect of this particular matter.

On the issue of the House of Representatives committee, I am prepared to accept an amendment to my proposal, that is, a sunset clause to the effect that my amendments on cloning would have no effect after the proclamation of Commonwealth legislation following the tabling of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That would, in effect, be a moratorium so that the matter could be revisited then. What research would be interfered with if that moratorium were invoked? These are important questions and we need to know the answers to them. What is wrong with having a moratorium—or doesn't anybody want to face the facts at the final stage? That would guarantee legislation; it is the only way it is going to guarantee legislation. There is no suggestion by the government, through the parliamentary secretary, that there will be legislation. I ask the parliamentary secretary: is there going to be Commonwealth legislation in respect of cloning of human beings? (Quorum formed)
Amendments not agreed to.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments (1), (2) and (3) on sheet ED233:

quote.para: (1) Page 127, before line 24, before clause 192, insert:

para.inline: Cloning of human beings is prohibited

quote.para: (1) A person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person engages in conduct; and
(b) the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the conduct will result in the cloning of a whole human being.
Maximum penalty: 2,000 penalty units or imprisonment for 10 years.

speech.para: Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.

quote.para: (2) In this section:

cloning of awhole human being means the use of technology for the purpose of producing, from one original, a duplicate or descendant that is, or duplicates or descendants that are, genetically identical to the original.
(2) Page 127, after clause 192B, insert:

para.inline: Certain experiments involving animal eggs prohibited

quote.para: A person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person engages in conduct; and

(b) the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the conduct involves carrying out experiments or research that involves putting human cells, or a combination of human cells and animal cells, into animal eggs.

speech.para: Maximum penalty: 2,000 penalty units or imprisonment for 10 years.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.

quote.para: (3) Page 127, after clause 192C, insert:

para.inline: Certain experiments involving putting human and animal cells into a human uterus prohibited

quote.para: A person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person engages in conduct; and

(b) the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the conduct involves carrying out experiments or research that involves putting a combination of human cells and animal cells into a human uterus.

speech.para: Maximum penalty: 2,000 penalty units or imprisonment for 10 years.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.

These amendments to sections 192B, 192C and 192D arise from a similar discussion we have been having on cloning. The government has proposed amendments to the bill in response to concerns raised in the parliament in order to prohibit the cloning of human beings and certain experiments involving human-animal hybrids. This bill is about public health and safety and the environment. As such, the Gene Technology Regulator's focus pertains to these issues. It is not the role of the regulator to consider other issues such as the ethics of research, which is a matter for the NHMRC through the Australian Health Ethics Committee. Currently, all research involving humans must be approved by a human research ethics committee constituted and acting in accordance with the NHMRC national statement on ethical conduct in research involving humans. The government amendments introduce three new clauses: first, a new section 192B, prohibiting the cloning of a whole human being; second, a new section 192C, prohibiting experiments involving fusion of human cells with animal eggs; and, third, a new section 192D, prohibiting putting human-animal hybrids into a human uterus.

talk.start.para: —The parliamentary secretary just said that it is not the role of the regulator to consider the ethics of research. I ask: what is the ethics committee there for? I ask: is the ethics of, for example, experimental GMO crops not a matter that the regulator has to consider?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The question was relating to the role of the ethics committee, if I understood it correctly. The role of the ethics committee is to make those decisions on whether or not the research should go ahead.

—I quote the parliamentary secretary again. He said that it is not the role of the regulator to consider the ethics of research. I thought that was embedded in this bill, that part of the regulator's role was to consider the advice coming from the ethics committee. In the example I asked about, is the regulator not taking into account the ethics of putting genetically modified controls into the environment?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —The issue raised by Senator Brown has been addressed in other debates previously with regard to the role of the ethics committee and the role of the regulator within the scope of this legislation. The other ethics committee I was referring to is the Australian Health Ethics Committee, which is quite separate and divorced in that particular regard.
—But do you stand by your statement, Parliamentary Secretary, that it is not the role of the regulator to consider the ethics of research?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —Let me repeat the statement I made. It is not the role of the regulator to consider other issues such as the ethics of research, which is a matter for the NHMRC through the Australian Health Ethics Committee. Currently, all research involving humans must first be approved by a human research ethics committee constituted and acting in accordance with the NHMRC national statement on ethical conduct in research involving humans. That was the context in which it was put, and I hope that is clear. This legislation of course relates to other matters.
