—The proposed government amendment No. 2 will insert a new section 192C referring to certain experiments involving animal egg prohibition. Paragraph (b) states:

quote.para: (b) the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the conduct involves carrying out experiments or research that involves putting human cells, or a combination of human cells and animal cells, into animal eggs.

speech.para: Senator Tambling, would it still be permissible under that section to have human DNA inserted into either an animal cell or an animal egg and in that way continue with transgenic genetic modification?

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the amendment as drafted and before you will not prohibit the issue you raise.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I would like the government to elaborate on what they mean by the terminology of `reckless'—the definition of `reckless' and whether there is a precedent in other legislation.

talker.name: Tambling, Sen Grant
Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that it is standard criminal law.

—In the final section of this suite of amendments, clause 192D says that certain experiments involving putting human and animal cells into a human uterus are prohibited. What is the government's argument for excluding certain experiments involving putting human and animal cells into an animal uterus?
—That matter is not addressed in the amendment.
—That is why I am asking. Why isn't it?
(Senator Watson)—The question is that government amendments Nos 1 to 3 be agreed to.

—I put a question to the minister, and it is no good somebody else from the party telling him not to answer it. Why is the final component of these amendments restricted to experiments involving putting human and animal cells into a human uterus and why does it not cover the putting of human and animal cells into an animal uterus?

—Through you, Mr Chairman, I put a question to Senator Tambling that relates also to the government's proposed amendment No. 3 in clause 192D. It again goes to subclause (b), referring to when a person knows or is reckless as to whether the conduct involves carrying out experiments or research that involve putting a combination of human cells and animal cells into a human uterus. Would that clause prohibit genetic manipulation by putting either a human cell or human DNA into the uterus of a chimpanzee? The DNA of chimpanzees has approximately 99 per cent similarity to the DNA of human beings. Would the government's proposed third amendment prohibit the placement of either human cells or a derivative from a human sperm or ovum into a chimpanzee?
—Are we going to get a response from the parliamentary secretary?
—He has been instructed not to respond.
—Senator Ian Campbell has closed him down.
(Senator Watson)—The question is that government amendments (1) to (3) be agreed to.
—I ask the minister: what is meant by the words `a whole human being'?
—The question is that government amendments (1) to (3) be agreed to. Senator Harradine.
—What is meant by `a whole human being'?
—I call Senator Harradine.
—What is meant by `a whole human being'?
—Senator Harradine.
—This is a very serious matter. It appears that the government is treating it very lightly. Government amendment (1) says:

quote.para: (1) A person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person engages in conduct; and
(b) the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the conduct will result in the cloning of a whole human being.

speech.para: Does that include the cloning of a human embryo?

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine.

—Do these words include the cloning of a human embryo? Won't anybody get up and try to find out? This is a very serious matter. This is part of the operation that is going on to water down the very clear recommendations of the Australian Health Ethics Committee and the National Health and Medical Research Council. Those recommendations make it perfectly clear that this sort of operation should be prohibited. The only problem is that their recommendations apply only to that research which is Commonwealth funded; they do not apply to privately funded research or research funded by state governments.

speech.para: I believe that I am entitled—and the whole of the chamber is entitled—to know the response of the parliamentary secretary to that question. What do the words `a whole human being' mean? Does that include the cloning of a human embryo? If it does, what you are doing is allowing a situation to exist where those cloned human embryos will have no connection with anybody except the science technologist who can do with them what they will. As I pointed out previously, at least in the IVF area, the human embryos developed from sperm and ova do have people who are responsible for those individual human embryos, but the ones that are cloned do not have anybody at all to be responsible for them. The question I am asking is reasonable and I would like to hear an answer from the parliamentary secretary. Again: what is meant by `cloning'? The parliamentary secretary is sitting in his seat.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine.

—Mr Chairman, I do hope that some members of the government and some members of the opposition who are outside the chamber are listening to this. The phrase `whole human being' is ambiguous. Is it inclusive of foetuses? Is it inclusive of embryos? The amendment may indeed allow the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator to approve cloning of human embryos provided that they are not transferred to a woman to develop to birth. Is that what you mean? The prohibition might thus allow embryos to be cloned but might then prohibit anyone from allowing them to have a mother and carry them to term. The amendment may even allow the cloning of a human embryo, transfer to a woman and then abortion of a mature foetus in order to obtain whole organs for transplant to a family member.

speech.para: I would suggest that there is clearly a need for an amendment to this particular proposition. The definition of cloning of a whole human being is not inclusive of human cloning by somatic cell nuclear transfer to an ovum, as the embryo formed would have some small genetic changes due to the inclusion of some DNA and RNA in the mitochondria of the ovum which are external to the nucleus. Thus, cloning by somatic cell nuclear transfer does not involve producing a genetically identical embryo. The sentence defining `cloning', which borrows from the 12-year-old definition in the Western Australian legislation, focuses on genetic identicality which allows cloning of a human being, provided that some minor genetic changes occur. Surely that is not what the government intended by this? In fact, it is now known that such minor changes happen even with so-called identical twins. In the latter case, an analysis of their genomes shows minor differences. In cloning there is the additional matter of the non-nuclear genetic material, the mitochondrial DNA and RNA. One of the ethical problems with cloning, as I have tried to indicate to the committee, arises from asexual reproduction. That is, reproduction without parents, without anyone to be concerned about the interests of the embryo.

Somatic cell nuclear transfer could happen using non-identified cells left over in a pathology lab or even obtained by trawling the sewers. Concerns such as this prompted the WHO to reject human cloning on the grounds of the lack of security of human genetic material if cloning were permitted. The amendments are not consistent with AHEC recommendations and the NHMRC guidelines on assisted reproductive technology. I again ask the parliamentary secretary to respond as to what constitutes a `whole human being'.

talk.start.para: —I think it is entirely reasonable that Senator Harradine gets an answer to his question and I think it would be productive for that to happen. If Senator Harradine will forgive me, I will just draw attention to what is happening here, because I think it is important that it be recorded. We have had Senator Ian Campbell come into the chamber and speak with the parliamentary secretary. The parliamentary secretary has been silent since then. There seems to be some extraordinary government strategy here, whereby it is believed that, if the government is silent in the committee, progress will be made. I think that is a mistake. The function of a committee is to get information from the government when the government is sponsoring a bill, and the function of a committee has to be to get information when the government is putting forward the amendment that the committee is dealing with. Otherwise you have the government shutting down. The government cannot shut down a committee and at the same time expect the committee to make progress to pass its legislation. As the government has vacated its function in the place and, for reasons best known to itself, is incapable of carrying on at 13 minutes past three in the morning, I move:

motion.para: That progress be reported.

speech.para: Question put.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —The question is that government amendments Nos 1 to 3 on sheet ED233 be agreed to.

—Again, to give the minister a chance to respond to the questions, I have a few quite reasonable questions. What is meant by a `whole human being'? What is meant by the cloning of a `whole human being'? Again, I ask very deliberately: do you include a human embryo as a whole human being? Do you include a foetus as a whole human being? What do you mean by `cloning' in these circumstances? In order for us to get clearly into our minds what is meant, we also need to know: what is meant by `cloning' in your definition?

—Through you, Chair, I would like to put a question to Senator Tambling, in relation to the proposed amendment No. 1 on ED233 and, in particular, to (2), which refers to the cloning of a whole human being. The essence, I believe, of the government's amendment is that the product from that is genetically identical to the original. My question to Senator Tambling is this: if, in the process of transferring DNA across, an antibiotic marker is used to be able to substantiate whether that DNA has transferred, would that not automatically make the transfer of that DNA different to the original and, therefore, allowable?
—The question is that government amendments Nos 1 to 3 on sheet ED233 be agreed to. I understood that there were some amendments to these, Senator Harradine. Do you wish to proceed with those?

—I would like to hear the response from Senator Tambling to the question that was just raised. It is a very important to know what is meant—I think this is what Senator Harris was getting at—by the definition of `cloning' in the amendment.
—Again I will ask the question that I asked of Senator Tambling, and this time I will read the entire government's proposed definition:

quote.para: cloning of awhole human being means the use of technology for the purpose of producing, from one original, a duplicate or descendant that is, or duplicates or descendants that are, genetically identical to the original.

speech.para: If in that process an antibiotic marker is used in transferring that DNA across, then the products are not original. Therefore, under the government's definition of `cloning of a whole human being', they can actually genetically modify a human being and, because it is not genetically identical to the original, my understanding is that the government's own amendment would allow that to be carried out. I think it is incumbent on the government to explain to us how it cannot be carried out, because I believe that definition clearly says that the descendants are `genetically identical to the original'. If they have an antibiotic marker—in other words, the DNA from that antibiotic marker is used—and if that DNA has come across, then they are not genetically identical to the original. The point I make is that the government's definition will then allow genetic modification of what would ultimately become a whole human being.

talk.start.para: —The question is that government amendments (1) to (3) on sheet ED233 be agreed to.
—I have to call attention to the state of the chamber. We do need some answers. It is not going to get us anywhere if the minister does not respond.
—There is a quorum present, Senator Harradine.

—I am very disappointed in the situation here. I certainly do not reflect on anyone's intentions or otherwise, but when we are dealing with legislation we do need to have absolute clarity. I do point to the definition:

quote.para: cloning of awhole human being means the use of technology for the purpose of producing, from one original, a duplicate or descendant that is, or duplicates or descendants that are, genetically identical to the original.

speech.para: My question to the parliamentary secretary is: give us an example of that? We ought to have an example of that. I would invite the parliamentary secretary to give us an example of such a cloned being. Or is it a fact that cloning does not really produce from one original a duplicate or descendant that is, or duplicates or descendants that are, genetically identical to the original? If I am right in that, then this amendment is of no value; scientists can drive a horse and cart through it. I hope some learned discussions about this—and no doubt there will be some—will show that the amendment which relates to cloning is one that has very little effect. In effect, this means that, if cloning does not produce a genetically identical individual as compared with the original, then, as I understand it, it has no effect. If that is the case, let us hear it from the parliamentary secretary. I have two amendments. I can certainly go ahead with the second amendment which, in order to protect the situation as is desired by the government, suggests that in the definition of cloning of a whole human being `substantially if not completely' be inserted after the word `are'. That will mean the definition will read:

quote.para: cloning of awhole human being means the use of technology for the purpose of producing, from one original, a duplicate or descendant that is, or duplicates or descendants that are, substantially if not completely, genetically identical to the original.

speech.para: Surely that is something that could be accepted to ensure some sort of clarity in respect of this matter. I really do need to have an understanding from the parliamentary secretary, or indeed from anybody representing the government, as to what `whole human being' means. I think it might be premature under those circumstances to proceed with amendment (1) on sheet 2073 until we get from the government what that means. That may have to be clarified elsewhere than in this chamber, if the parliamentary secretary will not clarify it. But I do not think I should put members of either the opposition or the government or the cross benches in a situation which could mean some difficult conscientious considerations to be given to the matter at hand. So, in those circumstances, I will be awaiting a response from the government—if it is not given here by the parliamentary secretary, then elsewhere. But I do proceed with amendment No. 2 on sheet 2073. I do ask the government to at least accept that. We are all trying to make a genuine attempt to ensure certainty before the law. I move amendment (2) on sheet 2073:

quote.para: (2) Amendment (1), subsection 192B(2), definition of cloning of a whole human being, after "are,", insert "substantially if not completely,".

speech.para: Motion (by Senator Tambling) proposed:

motion.para: That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: —It's your amendment, Senator Harradine.

—The interjection from the government member opposite was that it is Senator Harradine's amendment. My understanding was that the motion was for the question to be put. We were voting against the motion being put. I seek clarification from the chair.
—The question is that the motion be put.
—No-one is prepared to say they want a division, so the question now is that—
—Madam Chairman, I understand the issue now before the chair is the amendments moved by me and I move that the question be now put.
—No. Senator Harradine's amendment (2) has been moved, and we must now put the question. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Harradine be agreed to.
—The question now is that Senator Tambling's amendments (1) to (3) on sheet ED233 be agreed to.
